HEADLINE: Canada Moves to Spur Consumers Into Buying

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The Canadian Government, fighting a recession even more severe than in the United States, has just begun its own program to spur housing demand and revive the economy along with its political fortunes.
Like the measures President Bush proposed last week, the Canadian actions are meant to raise the entire economy on a wave of demand by new homeowners for appliances, furniture and other consumer items. These actions could well give the United States a look at the possible results of its own program. 
 The programs, despite their differences, underscore the parallels between these economies. The two Governments are fighting huge deficits, which limit room to maneuver. Ottawa's accumulated debt is proportionately about as large as Washington's. Yet unemployment here is more than 10 percent, against around 7 percent in the United States.
In its first concrete response to widespread demands for pump-priming, Ottawa has announced that effective immediately the minimum down payment for first-time home buyers under Government programs will be halved.
 
Called Long Overdue
 The Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation, which backs mortgages much as the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration do in Washington, will insure loans of as much as 95 percent of a home's value, instead of 90 percent.
Builders said the action was long overdue and should lead to at least a 15 percent increase in new housing this year. Canada's construction industry is desperate for work, having started only 156,000 units last year, the least since the 1981-83 recession.
"This is the vote of confidence consumers need from the Government to spur them on to make buying decisions," said Gary Reardon, president of the Canadian Home Builders Association.
Even at 5 percent, where the minimum down payment had been until an explosion in borrowing in 1982, the rate is higher than under United States Government programs, where home buyers may now put down as little as 3 percent. Until regulations were tightened last year, Americans had been able to put even less down.
Some economists still question whether more borrowing is truly what the Canadian economy now needs. At the end of the last recession, many homeowers walked away from mortgages that exceeded the depressed values of their homes, leaving the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation's insurance fund deep in the red.
Potentially as significant as the easier down payment terms was Finance Minister Donald Mazankowski's statement in the House of Commons that the Government would also permit withdrawals from Canada's equivalent of individual retirement accounts for first-time home purchases.
His idea is to allow as much as $7,500 to be taken out of Registered Retirement Savings Plans, which have been in place since 1957 and now hold more than $100 billion of Canadian savings. The money could be used for down payments without penalties or taxes.
Only a few weeks ago, Government officials had described such a withdrawal plan as unworkable and risky. The turnabout perhaps reflected the economy's further deterioration. Government forecasts for renewed growth have been reduced this year even as interest rates and inflation have dropped sharply.
"They're desperate and groping for anything that will improve the economic situation," said Robert Blohm, a Toronto investment banker.
The painless withdrawals from the retirement fund, economists said, could have the same sort of impact as the $5,000 tax credit for first-time home buyers proposed by President Bush in his State of the Union Message to Congress last week.
The difference is that while the President depends on Congressional approval, the Government in Ottawa, which controls a large majority of the seats in the House of Commons, can readily enact what it proposes.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Time Warner to Take Over Cable Operator

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
Time Warner Inc. and the American Television and Communications Corporation said yesterday that they had reached an agreement under which Time Warner would acquire the 18 percent of the cable television systems operator that it does not already own.
The arrangement, which has been approved by the boards of the companies, will make easier for Time Warner to put American Television into the $1 billion joint venture it plans to form with C. Itoh & Company and the Toshiba Corporation, both of Japan. 
 Time Warner has agreed to sell those companies a 12.5 percent stake in Time Warner Entertainment, an entity that will include its cable television systems, the Home Box Office premium cable channel and the Warner Brothers film and television studio.
 
Advantage for Time Warner
 American Television, based in Stamford, Conn., is one of the nation's largest operators of cable television systems.
For Time Warner, the advantage of the deal is that it does not require the company to pay out any cash for slightly more than three and a half years. And the deal will give Time Warner the right to use the cash flow from American Television.
American Television has 19.7 million shares outstanding, and Time Warner plans to convert each share into the right to receive $82.50 of Time Warner notes.
Either Time Warner or the holder of the note can convert it to $82.50 in some combination of cash and paper on Aug. 15, 1995, or to $82.50 plus accrued interest three years later. The notes are due in 2002.
In over-the-counter trading yesterday, American Television's shares gained $1.125, to $58. Time Warner's shares also rose, gaining $1.50, to $93.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Somewhat Sweetened Deal
 The deal with American Television has been somewhat sweetened from a previous proposal. Several months ago, Time Warner offered preferred stock that could be redeemed for $75 a share three years after it was issued. The initial deal had a total value of $1.47 billion. The revised offer is valued at $1.62 billion.
In the new deal, the notes can be redeemed either at the discretion of Time Warner or the holder. The notes pay cash interest semi-annually at market rates, with a cap of 11 percent a year.
The notes can be redeemed, as Time Warner chooses, in any combination of cash, Time Warner securities or other securities.
If Time Warner calls the notes, holders can get any combination of cash, debt issued by Time Warner or a subsidiary or the exchange debentures underlying its Series C and D preferred stock.
If interest rates are relatively low and Time Warner can refinance its debt, it may want to give holders debentures or cash, depending on what the company can borrow. But if the bond market is not favorable, the company might want the right to give holders whatever financial instruments suits its needs.
Mario Gabelli, whose company, Gamco Investors, holds 1.55 million shares of American Television stock, said the deal was very good for Time Warner because it gave the company more flexiblity with American Television's cash flow and borrowing.
He noted that the deal was somewhat better than the previous offer. But, he said, the company had eliminated a conversion feature that was part of the previous offer, which would have given American Television's shareholders the right to own Time Warner stock and benefit from any gain in the shares.
Along with Gamco Investors, American Television's large shareholders include the Alliance Capital Management Corporation, the Capital Research and Management Company and Fidelity Investments.

HEADLINE: Times Mirror Posts a Loss

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The Times Mirror Company said today that it lost $13 million in the fourth quarter and that profits plunged 55 percent for the year as the recession continued to hurt the news business.
The quarterly loss compared with income of $45.6 million, or 35 cents a share, in the previous year's quarter. Revenues for the quarter were $975.8 million, up from $956.5 million. 
 The company's shares rose $1.625, to $35.625, in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange.
Times Mirror, whose flagship is The Los Angeles Times, attributed much of the quarterly loss to a $65 million write-down linked to the $95 million sale of The Denver Post in 1987. Times Mirror, which bought The Post in 1980 for $95 million, has said that notes it received in the sale of The Post to a Media News Group affiliate cannot be repaid on time.
The Los Angeles-based media company also recorded charges related to a Los Angeles Times early-retirement program, a voluntary severance program at The Baltimore Sun and others.
In addition to The Times and The Sun, Times Mirror publishes Newsday and New York Newsday and several other East Coast newspapers, and has interests in cable and broadcast TV, as well as book, magazine and other publishing businesses.
For 1991, Times Mirror reported income of $82 million, or 64 cents a share, down from $180.5 million, or $1.40 a share, the year before. The year's revenues were $3.62 billion, down from $3.63 billion.

HEADLINE: Paul A. Freund, Authority On Constitution, Dies at 83

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Paul A. Freund, an authority on constitutional law and the Supreme Court who taught at Harvard Law School for 37 years, died yesterday at his home at Cambridge, Mass. He was 83 years old.
Professor Freund, who retired in 1976 as Carl M. Loeb University Professor, died of cancer of the sinus, said Michael Chmura, a spokesman for the law school. 
 A former dean of the law school, James Vorenberg, yesterday called Professor Freund "the dominant figure of his time in the field of constitutional law."
In his teaching and writings and as an official of the United States Solicitor General's office in the 1930's and 1940's, Professor Chmura was a leading exponent of a relatively flexible interpretation of the Constitution in economic and social matters. He favored giving Congress and the states power to deal with the economic crisis of the 1930's and to take measures to prevent a recurrence of the Great Depression and to forestall other crises.
 
Crucial Court Role Envisioned
 In Professor Freund's view, the judicial system, with the Supreme Court at its apex, had a crucial role to play. In his 1961 book "The Supreme Court of the United States" (World Publishing Company), he wrote that the role of the courts in maintaining a working federalism was one of "mediation between large principles and particular problems, of interposing intermediate principles" that are "more tentative, experimental and pragmatic."
"The courts," he added, "are the substations that transform the high-tension charge of the philosophers into the reduced voltage of a serviceable current."
Admirers of Professor Freund said yesterday that over the years his teachings and writings had made law students, at Harvard and elsewhere, take a more supple view of the Constitution. They said he had played an important role in the movement to read the Constitution more generously in economics, while giving deeper protection to individual liberties of speech and press and racial justice.
 
Turned Down Kennedy Offer
 In the 1930's Professor Freund became staunch in his advocacy of reading the Constitution in such a way as to give Congress more freedom to experiment in measures to end the Depression and to provide what later came to be called a safety net against economic and other problems. While he was in the Solicitor General's office, from 1935 to 1939 and again from 1942 to 1946, he argued, or otherwise assisted in, court cases that tested such matters.
Three decades later, Professor Freund figured as a potential appointee as Solicitor General under President John F. Kennedy.
But as Professor Freund later recalled to friends, when Kennedy offered the position to him he turned it down on the ground that he wanted to continue working on a history of the Supreme Court, of which he was the general editor. To that the President replied: "I'm sorry. I hoped you would prefer making history to writing it."
 
Considered for High Court
 Then, early in 1962, Kennedy considered naming Professor Freund to a vacant seat on the Supreme Court, but chose Deputy Attorney General Byron R. White for the seat. And when another Supreme Court vacancy arose later that year, the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. wrote in his 1965 book "A Thousand Days," Kennedy "inclined at first toward Freund," but eventually chose Arthur Goldberg.
Paul Abraham Freund was born Feb. 16, 1908, in St. Louis, the son of Charles Freund and the former Hulda Arenson. He earned a bachelor's degree from Washington University in St. Louis in 1928, a bachelor of laws degree from Harvard in 1931 -- serving as president of the editorial board of the Harvard Law Review -- and a doctorate in law, also from Harvard, in 1932.
In 1932 and 1933 he was a law clerk to Justice Louis Brandeis. He then was an official of the Treasury Department and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation from 1933 to 1935.
 
Three Endowed Chairs
 When he joined the Harvard Law School faculty in 1939 it was first as a lecturer specializing in conflict of laws as well as in constitutional law. He became a professor of law in 1940 and then held three endowed chairs in succession: he was Charles Stebbins Fairchild Professor, beginning in 1950; Royall Professor of Law, beginning in 1957, and Carl M. Loeb University Professor, beginning in 1958.
His other writings included the books "On Law and Justice" (Harvard University Press) and "On Understanding the Supreme Court" (Little, Brown).
He was the editor of "Experimentation with Human Subjects" (George Braziller) and co-editor of "Cases on Constitutional Law" (Little, Brown). He was for some years the editor-in-chief of the multivolume "History of the Supreme Court," of which, Mr. Chmura said, additional volumes are planned.
Professor Freund was a fellow and past president of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
There are no immediate family survivors.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Worldwide In Advance of Jobs Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined broadly in global trading yesterday as dealers took profits and stepped to the sidelines in advance of the unemployment report scheduled for tomorrow.
Gold prices also declined worldwide. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $355.60 an ounce, off 60 cents. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 25 cents an ounce, to a late bid of $355.45. 
 Currency trading opened on a quiet note with the pace accelerating as the session wore on. Analysts said the dollar was trading at the low end of its recent trading range.
 
'Not Doing Anything'
 "Trading was influenced by technical factors rather than any fundamental" news, said Kevin Lawrie, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Boston. He said traders were "not doing anything" before the Labor Department's release of the unemployment data for January.
"If it is worse than expected, the market would assume another rate cut, and that's negative for the dollar," he said. When the Federal Reserve trims interest rates to stimulate the economy, it reduces the value of dollar-denominated securities.
In addition, German monetary officials have indicated rates there would remain at current levels for some time, said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at the Mitsubishi Bank.
With foreign rates remaining relatively high and United States rates possibly poised to decline, money managers have more incentive to keep investments overseas to capture higher yields, another negative for the dollar.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.14 yen, to 126.11. Later in London, it was quoted at 125.80 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 125.56 yen, down from 126.15 on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8060, from $1.8010 late Tuesday. In New York, it cost $1.8150 to buy a pound, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.8015.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday rates, included: 1.5815 German marks, down from 1.5930; 1.4120 Swiss francs, down from 1.4220; 5.3890 French francs, down from 5.4270; 1,188.50 Italian lire, down from 1,197.00, and 1.1796 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1814.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $354.35 an ounce, from $356.35 late on Tuesday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $353.80 from $356.05. Markets were closed in Hong Kong for the Lunar New Year holiday and will reopen tomorrow.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields on Tax-Exempt Money Funds Jump

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
The seven-day yields of tax-exempt funds tended to rise quite sharply for the week ended Monday, while the taxable money funds showed declines for the seven days ended Tuesday, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report.
Referring to the tax-exempts, Walter Frank, an economist for the organization, said, "Once more after a lull, a bigger supply of municipal issues is coming into the market, and that has helped drive up the seven-day yields because demand by the funds has been steady." 
 The seven-day compound average yield for the tax-exempt funds rose to 2.95 percent, up from 2.75 percent the previous week, while the seven-day simple yield also rose by 20 basis points, to 2.91 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
During the period, the 30-day compound yield dropped sharply, to 2.92 percent from 3.21 percent, and the 30-day simple yield fell to 2.88, from the previous week's 3.16 percent. Thirty-day yields do not reflect reversals in direction as quickly as the seven-day yields do.
The top Connecticut fund was Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Money Market Portfolio, which reported a seven-day compound yield of 3.35 percent, compared with 3.22 percent reported by the previous week's leader.
In New Jersey, the top fund once again was Fidelity Spartan New Jersey Municipal Money Market Portfolio, with a yield of 3.46, up 20 basis points from the previous week.
In New York, the top fund again was Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market. It had a seven-day compound yield of 3.77, up from 3.60 percent last week.
Assets of the tax-exempt funds, which had risen to a record of $98.1 billion two weeks ago, continued to decline from that level, losing about $34 million to settle at $97.1 billion.
Donoghue's said the average number of days to maturity of securities held in the tax-free portfolios was unchanged at 51 days.
Of the funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's with assets larger than $100 million, the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, based in Milwaukee, continued to lead, with a seven-day compound yield of 3.84 percent, up from 3.74 percent a week ago.
Meanwhile, assets of the taxable funds dropped by $788 million, to $504.3 billion, while the average number of days to maturity of their holdings remained unchanged at 56 days.
As for the taxables, Mr. Frank said the yields continued to be sensitive to Federal Reserve policy. "Yields are still declining in response to the Federal Reserve action in December," he said, "and in addition there was a subsequent decline in money market rates earlier this year, which was partly seasonal. We are in the bottoming-out phase now."
The average seven-day compound taxable yield fell 7 basis points, to 4.00 percent, while the seven-day simple yield also fell 7 points, to 3.92 percent.
At the same time, the 30-day compound yield declined to 4.14 percent, from 4.27 percent, and the 30-day simple yield dropped 12 points, to 4.06 percent.
The taxable fund with the highest seven-day compound return for the week was again Fidelity Spartan Money Market fund, with a yield of 4.83 percent, compared with 4.95 percent a week ago.
By comparison, the average bank money market account, a prime competitor of money funds, was at 3.83 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: Lending for Peace in Israel

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is fashioning a fair and sensible response to Israel's request for $10 billion in U.S. loan guarantees. Israel has sought the guarantees for a valid purpose: to raise money for the absorption of Jewish immigrants from the former Soviet Union. The hitch has been Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's massive expansion of Israeli settlements on the West Bank and in Gaza. These settlements are designed to strengthen Israel's hold on the disputed territories, thereby undermining a Washington-promoted Middle East peace initiative.
Secretary of State Baker is rightly demanding that Israel halt building of new settlements as a condition for receiving American loan guarantees. At the same time he offers a face-saving concession. Israel would be able to complete the housing units already being built. No American funds would support this construction; the U.S. would deduct from each year's guarantees an amount matching expenditures on roads and housing in the disputed territories. 
 As Thomas Friedman of The Times reports, no final bargain is expected before the impending Israeli elections. For now, Mr. Baker has quietly outlined a position that Americans can support and that Mr. Shamir can oppose only at some political risk. Assuming that crucial details on what constitutes a "housing unit" can be resolved, the proposed compromise can improve chances for peace.
Pressed by his hard-line flank, Mr. Shamir has strenuously resisted any freeze on new settlements. Yet only this week, the Prime Minister conceded that Washington has a right to lay down conditions on how loan guarantee money is spent. And visiting leaders of American Jewish organizations recently warned Mr. Shamir that Israel will have to choose between loan guarantees and settlements.
Americans are broadly sympathetic with Israel's need to provide jobs and housing for as many as 400,000 immigrants from former Soviet lands. But this is primarily an Israeli interest. If Israel fails to absorb the immigrants effectively, it will have lost a historic opportunity to strengthen its economy and society and to perform its self-assigned role as a haven for Jewish refugees.
Secretary Baker still faces the tricky task of closing loopholes in any final loan-guarantee agreement that might allow Israeli authorities to multiply housing units on existing settlements. This has been Housing Minister Ariel Sharon's past strategy for hiding the extent of settlement activity.
But the argument is only narrowly about loan guarantees or West Bank settlements. What is more fundamentally at stake is Israel's willingness to make reciprocal concessions to the Palestinians at a rare moment when peace is no longer an impossible dream. By pressing for an achievable compromise on loan guarantees, Washington can help nudge this difficult peace process forward.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Essay;
Reading Boris's Mind

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

 BODY:
My trip to New York and Camp David was not a happy experience.
I told the bankers and businessmen we have done everything Gorbachev refused to do -- free markets, supply and demand, Polish shock therapy. And did they come forward with investment? Did the central banks come up with a way to help me stabilize the ruble? No. 
 I told Bush, who at last asks me to call him George, we would make arms reductions that would destroy all missiles in the republics outside Russia, as he wants. And did he welcome my appeal for a joint space defense against terrorist nuclear missiles, getting the Red Army marshals out of my anteroom? No.
I told the U.N. we have not one prisoner of conscience left in Russia, the greatest triumph of freedom in the world, and the big news is Bush's meeting with Li Peng, which forgives him for Tiananmen Square.
I am in Paris now, but I hear that back in Moscow, demonstrations have been banned in Red Square because they were tying up traffic and we couldn't afford the police.
I am beset from three sides:
The lunatics who call themselves national patriots have started their nashi movement behind Zhirinovsky, our mini-Hitler, whose first act as dictator would be to invade the Baltics. I can use him to scare the West, but the television star Nevzorov, the brains behind him, must be watched.
The nomenklatura, the bureaucrats out of jobs, neo-Communists, the Soyuz group and some of the disloyal generals are putting together a coalition behind Aleksandr Rutskoi, who may be sick, and the man I gave 20 bodyguards and a dacha -- Mikhail Sergeyevich himself -- along with Yakovlev and his other hangers-on.
And what of my ardent supporters, the liberal intelligentsia? They are panicking, saying now that a union treaty would have been better than the new commonwealth, wailing about the further disintegration of the Russian republic.
(Of course, when I listened to Rutskoi and sent our Russian troops into Chechen-Ingushetia to put down the separatists, the liberals howled and made me stop. The intelligentsia want the impossible: democracy and unity, free markets and cheap food.)
The only people left on my side are the people. I'm supported by 43 percent in the polls, better than anybody else and as good as George Bush. I have asked for one year to make all the changes, which is a problem because my economist Gaidar, 35 years old and knows everything, says publicly it will take two years.
That's why my own appointees call us a "kamikaze Government," suicide pilots saving our country at the cost of our own political lives.
I am not a kamikaze. And unlike the nervous liberals, I do not feel pain in the amputated right arm of Ukraine. Russia is better off without the empire's drain, but disunion has gone far enough. There will be no independence for the Tatars or any other people on Mother Russia's historic land.
That makes me ask myself -- what if, Boris Nikolayevich, prices keep going up, and the world looks the other way, and the bureaucrats laugh at my decrees and the people make a hero out of crazy Zhirinovsky?
That would mean the time is not yet ripe for full democracy in Russia. My Government -- my 25 young men and a handful of grayheads -- would not turn this nation over to a lunatic, nor return it to the crowd that brought us to this sorry state.
So I answer, that is why I installed Viktor Baronikov, over liberal objections, at the head of the Ministry of Security of the Russian Federation, which now includes the former K.G.B., still at its full strength.
And it is why I balanced that by assigning a reformist, Minister of Justice Nikolai Fyedorov, to watch Baronikov and to clean out the entire network of Kryuchkovite K.G.B. generals and colonels from the Ministry of Security by July 1.
Between now and then, we will see if the world's capitalists are willing to become our partners. We will see if old debt is forgiven, new credit extended, and help given to develop our resources -- before it's too late.
If not; if the people are not ready to sacrifice for their freedom; if the nashi or the Gorbachev nomenklatura try to take over --- then it's Dobrym parnyem bolshye nye budu. Or as my cold and tightly smiling friend in Camp David puts it, "No more Mr. Nice Guy."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaing Trail;
From Nixon, Predictions on the Presidential Race

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
In a political season of character issues and secret tapes, Richard M. Nixon offers some predictions.
The former President, passing through town to talk some politics, forecast the 1992 election this way: 
 If Bill Clinton wins New Hampshire, he will roll into the nomination, unless there are new revelations. But Mr. Nixon suggested that the Clinton campaign would have to be careful about how it uses Hillary Clinton, because in general, "If the wife comes through as being too strong and too intelligent, it makes the husband look like a wimp."
Mr. Nixon praised Barbara Bush as a model of a wife who has her own opinions without upstaging her husband, and suggested that many Americans are still put off by a male politician who does not seem to be as strong as his wife. The former President allowed that, unfortunately, some voters agree with Cardinal de Richelieu, who said, "Intellect in a woman is unbecoming."
If Governor Clinton comes in second to Paul E. Tsongas, there will be agitation for a new candidate because, as Mr. Nixon noted drily, "Tsongas is too responsible to be nominated by the Democrats."
Just as a write-in campaign in New Hampshire may have helped to save his Vice Presidency in 1956, when some Republicans were talking about dropping him from the Eisenhower ticket, Mr. Nixon mused about the write-in campaign for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, noting that his name is easily spelled.
He has privately told friends he would relish seeing a race between the President and the New York Governor, whom he describes as "a heavyweight."
He said his former speechwriter, Patrick J. Buchanan, would get 28 percent of the vote in New Hampshire.
Mr. Nixon suggested that the Democrats might win the Electoral College and still lose the popular vote, titillating political science professors. He said the President would win the general, although he could lose California, which would make him dependent on having a solid South, plus Ohio and Illinois, which he said would be the battlegrounds of the election.
He said that the Republicans would gain 25 seats in the House, and would stay even, or lose two seats, in the Senate.
For anyone who doubts the accuracy of Mr. Nixon's predictions, remember that in 1966, a crucial year in his political comeback, he predicted that the Republicans would gain 47 House seats. They did.
 
Cuomo Treasure
 For those still fascinated with the thinking of Governor Cuomo, here is a bit of buried treasure.
In 1987, The New York Times columnist William Safire sent Mr. Cuomo a copy of his "Political Dictionary," marking the segment on "Presidential Draft," which begins: "A demand by a party that a man not seeking the nomination accept it; upon rare occasion, applies to one who did not encourage his own candidacy."
The Governor sent back a note with the line, "Re 'draft,' see the last paragraph of your 'Brokered Convention.' "
That paragraph reads: "By 1972, the proliferation of primaries and erosion of the 'unit rule' made brokerage more difficult, though not impossible."
 
Editing Bush
 The most important member of President Bush's campaign team may not be pollster, speechwriter or spin doctor. It just may be the editor who cuts and snips the footage for his campaign commercials.
In his first commercial, President Bush is presented as caring and crisp.
"This state has gone through hell," he tells a group of insurance workers in Dover, N.H. "It's gone through an extraordinarily difficult time."
Mr. Bush's actual answer, cut off mid-sentence, was not quite so polished.
"This state has gone through hell," he said, according to the official transcript. "It's gone through an extraordinarily difficult time, coming off of a pinnacle, you might say, of low unemployment. Now, you're at about the national level. And yes, people are hurting. And I am determined to turn it around.
"I told some of them over there -- there's a big difference, you know. People say to me -- difference between domestic and foreign policy. How could you lead the world -- and they gave me some credit for that in Desert Storm, that the American people still feel very, very strongly about -- and -- how can you do that and then have such difficulties with this economy?"
 
Clinton Humor
 Mr. Clinton has been fighting off a cold and allergies for a week now. "I wonder if they'll vote for a dead man," he muttered today, as he wandered about New Hampshire tearing and wheezing.
But he has tried to keep a sense of humor throughout his trial by tabloid.
At Portland High School in Maine last weekend, Alyssa O'Brien asked the Arkansas Governor what he thought of a newspaper advertisement placed by a Maine Citizens' Group asserting that President Bush fails to pay state income taxes there. The President owns a home in Kennebunkport but claims a hotel suite in Houston as his principal residence.
"I guess when he said no new taxes, he meant himself," Ms. O'Brien said.
Mr. Clinton grinned and said that such behavior was "not right." Then, flashing a pointed glance at the assembled press corps, he added: "If I did that, they'd write it up in one of those tabloids."
 
Man in Demand
 John Doggett, the man who taught the Senate about ego and erotomania, has moved from defending Clarence Thomas to defending Bill Clinton.
"God, this is my year, right?" said Mr. Doggett, a business consultant from Austin who went to Yale Law School with Mr. Thomas and the Clintons. "I'm checking through my book to see what my other classmates might do."
As a witness on behalf of Mr. Thomas during the Senate hearings about Anita F. Hill's accusation of sexual harassment last fall, Mr. Doggett gave a performance so loquacious and boastful that Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. was moved to comment on his "enormous ego."
He said that Anita Hill had found him so attractive that she had developed a romantic fixation on him, a story meant to back up the Republican suggestion that Ms. Hill was an erotomaniac.
Now it's deja vu all over again, as Yogi Berra said, for Mr. Doggett. He said that, at the request of a Clinton aide, he showed up at a rally in Austin last week to act as a character witness for the Arkansas Governor, who had just been hit by tabloid mania.
"The irony is that Clarence and Bill were both at Yale Law School, and both of them had their chance at very important positions questioned by women who made accusations with sexual overtones and both of them came forward with very clear, straightforward, believable answers that were complete denials," said Mr. Doggett, who said he has been deluged with calls, letters and speaking offers because he had "the strength to tell those guys in the Senate where to get off."
Mr. Dogget said he was a Democrat until 1990 when he switched to the Republican Party. But he left a different impression with Mr. Clinton. Mr. Clinton said he was surprised when Mr. Doggett showed up at a rally in Austin last fall and said, "I'm a Democrat. My wife's a Democrat. We really want to be for you," and then appeared at last week's rally in Austin as well.
Mr. Doggett, however, tells it differently. "I absolutely support Bill as a Democrat. I feel very comfortable saying that. But if I had to vote today I would vote for President Bush because I registered as a Republican. I don't feel that's a contradiction even though my political friends say, 'You can't do that, John.' My bottom line is that I'm not a politician. I'm a human being and American citizen."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Cuomo, on the Sidelines, Is Watchful and Wistful

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The question that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was asked at a news conference on Tuesday was about poor Randall Wells, the New Hampshire man who has received hundreds of misdialed telephone calls because his business's 1-800 number is similar to that of a Cuomo write-in campaign committee.
But the answer the New York Governor gave had nothing to do with the travails of Mr. Wells. It had to do with all the mail he continues to get encouraging him to run for President. 
 "We're getting letters -- I just asked them," he said, glancing toward the staff members slumping against his conference room wall. "Did you hear about the letters we got? How many letters did we get? Anybody know? Ten thousand?"
"What do the letters say?" a reporter asked Mr. Cuomo.
"I don't read them," he said.
"You just count them?" came the reply.
"I just read some of them," conceded Mr. Cuomo, who then explained with a chuckle that one of his aides had recruited a small platoon of volunteers to respond to the letters. "I asked Al Gordon," he said. "He brought in eight people today to look at them. Am I hearing things or is that the story?"
 
A Hint of Disappointment
 By that time, Mr. Cuomo may have realized that what seemed to him an intriguing anecdote seemed to others an unusually candid bit of conceit. He dislodged himself by joking that the letters had urged him to pass a state budget on time.
That, of course, is the mission that Mr. Cuomo says commands all of his energy these days. But the incident at the news conference provided a view of the wistfulness the Governor is reportedly feeling as the Presidential campaign begins to pass him by.
There is no sign in Albany that Mr. Cuomo has any interest in making a late entry into race, even though Gov. Bill Clinton's troubles have created a boomlet of speculation that another new Democrat will take the plunge. And yet the Governor cannot quite restrain himself from occasionally parachuting onto the Presidential landscape.
His aides say it is an expression of Mr. Cuomo's disappointment.
"I think he's expressed himself pretty clearly that he wanted to run for President and if he had a budget he would have run," said Alfred Gordon, a Cuomo adviser whose duties, among others, include monitoring the Governor's mail.
 
Sizing Up the Candidates
 A few of Mr. Cuomo's political advisers admit to spending some of their spare time war-gaming a last-minute candidacy. Most agree with Mr. Cuomo that the Democratic nominee will almost certainly be one of the five announced candidates, although it would still be possible for a party-crasher to pull off a miracle.
Ginny Terzano, a spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee, said a new candidate could still win the nomination, even on a first-convention ballot, by winning the last few primaries, earning the support of elected officials and other so-called superdelegates, and picking off the support of delegates committed to candidates who drop out of the race.
Mr. Cuomo has said he does not believe in such scenarios. After watching last Friday's televised Democratic debate, he praised the candidates as "a very strong field." That opinion was something of an upgrade from last Wednesday, when Mr. Cuomo said on CNN's "Larry King Live" that "this field is adequate to produce the next President of the United States."
 
In the Balance
 Last month, Mr. Cuomo put an end to the favorite-son campaign being discussed by some of his supporters in his home state. But he has made no effort to kill the write-in campaigns being waged on his behalf in New Hampshire and Illinois.
"It's very difficult to discourage people who are saying nice things about you," he said last week. "You try not to be ungracious. But the record is in modern times with this primary process, it comes out of the primaries. That's the way it is and that's the way it will be."
When he announced on Dec. 20 that he would not run for President, he said he wanted to be "a constructive force" for the Democrats.
In inimitable fashion, he showed the way for the Democrats in his appearance on "Larry King Live," when he used a searing metaphor for the economic proposals unveiled by President Bush in his State of the Union address. "What he did," Mr. Cuomo said, "was throw a few bonbons to a badly undernourished country."
But on the same show, Mr. Cuomo continued his attack on Mr. Clinton, the man once considered the Democrat with the best chance of unseating Mr. Bush. Responding to Mr. Clinton's comment that Mr. Cuomo "acts like" a member of the Mafia, Mr. Cuomo said the comment raised questions about the Arkansas Governor's attitudes toward minority groups.
A caller to the show questioned Mr. Cuomo's intent: "I can't understand if you're a real true Democrat and you really want to get rid of the worst President we've had in years, why you're painting one of our leading candidates in a corner."

HEADLINE: Democrats To Support A Tax Cut

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
House Democrats agreed tonight to press for a middle-class tax cut paid for by higher taxes on upper-income taxpayers, despite opposition to any such increase by the Bush Administration.
House Speaker Thomas S. Foley told reporters there was a "strong consensus" for such an approach, although at least two Democrats had argued against the middle-class tax cut, saying it would be too small to do any good. 
 Representatives Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn and Robert T. Matsui of Hawaii made that argument at a party caucus this afternoon. Mr. Schumer said he told his colleagues that any proceeds from upper-bracket tax increases should be spent on stimulating growth because his constituents were "much more worried about losing their jobs than about six bucks a week in their pockets."
 
The 'Fairness' Issue
 But such arguments were apparently stilled, according to members' accounts of the closed meeting, by the argument that since the party had been making an issue of fairness for months, it had to stick to it. If it abandoned that stance now, said Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, "we'd be absolute damn fools."
Mr. Foley told reporters that the middle-class tax cut was not aimed at stimulating economic growth, but at "fairness, basically." He said other provisions of the bill the Ways and Means Committee would write next week would be aimed at growth.
He said the measure would probably come to the House floor in the last week of February or first week of March. He said he expected the President's proposal would also come to the House floor for a vote as an alternative. He acknowledged that whatever passed in the House would probably be changed after Senate action.
House Republicans were not heard from on the President's proposals today. But the Senate's Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, introduced the package there and said that while he might oppose a few of its provisions, Congress should "roll up its sleeves" and get to work on passing it by the March 20 deadline that Mr. Bush set in his State of the Union speech.
 
An Alternative Emphasis
 The House caucus came after several Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee, at a closed meeting this morning, had argued that the middle-class tax cut should be dropped in favor of efforts to promote growth. They included Representatives Thomas J. Downey of Suffolk and Mr. Matsui.
Mr. Downey and Mr. Matsui both said later that they would join in the push for the middle-class tax cuts. Mr. Matsui said, "Now that we know what the caucus and the leadership want, we're going to try to come up with a package."
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, scoffed at the argument that the tax reduction the committee is likely to approve would not be meaningful. "Only within the Beltway is $300 or $400 not a lot of money," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 7, 1992, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about an agreement among House Democrats to press for a middle-class tax cut misidentified the home state of Representative Robert T. Matsui. It is California.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
On How to Make Political Ends Meet

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The House Ways and Means Committee's hearings on tax and growth legislation may not have any effect on what kind of bill Congress may pass this spring. Canny closed-door politics, not earnest open arguments, will control that process.
But the hearings offer instructive examples of the cynicism and special pleading that go into tax writing. And once in a while, they even offer edifying discussions of interesting ideas that will be utterly disregarded in the eventual law-making. 
 For instance, Representative Charles E. Schumer dropped in to offer a suggestion he said would do more good than his party's favorite shibboleth, a tax cut for the middle class, or the Administration's grail, a cut in the capital gains tax rate.
The Brooklyn Democrat argued that what the economy needed most was more savings and investment. He said a middle-class tax cut would be puny in its impact, and said there was no historical evidence that capital gains tax cuts or easier terms for individual retirement accounts would do more than help the rich.
Instead, he proposed indexing all savings and investment for inflation. He contended that a major reason why net national savings was only 1.5 percent of the gross national product in 1990, the last year for which there are statistics, is that people preferred to spend money on consumer goods rather than see their savings eaten up by inflation and taxes.
Under his suggestion, if someone put $1,000 into a savings account at 4 percent, earning $40, and inlation was 3 percent for the year, only $10 would be subject to tax. Now, all $40 is taxed, and the taxpayer in the 15 percent bracket gets a net, after inflation and taxes, of just $4. The 31 percent taxpayer actually loses $2.40.
For about 15 minutes, a few members of the committee discussed the idea with Mr. Schumer and said it was worth exploring. Sometime.
The prize for the slickest way around a complex problem was claimed Tuesday by Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, as he advocated cutting capital gains taxes.
There are few things Congress and the Administration say more often and with more insistence than their mutual declarations that this bill must not increase the Federal budget deficit. But Congress's Joint Committee on Taxation says the capital gains measure would cost $15.4 billion over five years, while the Administration says it would earn $6.9 billion.
Mr. Darman said the way to get around that was for Congress to pass the measure with a provision declaring a budget emergency, so that it wouldn't have to raise other taxes to make up the $15.4 billion.
But then the President would not have to declare the emergency, because he would take his Administration's word for it that the change would actually reduce the deficit.
Much of the hearings was devoted to pleading about how one existing clause of the tax code, or some new proposal, was critical to the economy. The interests of elderly farmers, makers of small airplanes, and real estate agents all had their advocates.
But few told a sadder story than James A. Willingham, a Long Beach, Calif., car dealer who attacked the 1990 luxury tax on cars costing more than $30,000: "In my own dealership, I did not sell a single Rolls-Royce subject to the tax in 1991, down from 13 the year before."
Republicans do believe in capital gains tax cuts, and Democrats do feel that middle-income taxpayers pay too much and the rich too little. If there is a bill, it will be informed by some elements of those beliefs.
The most important purpose of these hearings is to enable the witnesses to report to their constituents or clients that they told Congress what to do. Even if there were rarely more than half a dozen committee members in the room.

HEADLINE: 3 Western Allies Seek End To a High-Tech Export Ban

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
In a policy shift reflecting the end of the cold war, three European countries have proposed to their Western allies that they drop virtually all restrictions on exporting civilian telecommunications gear, according to people familiar with the discussions.
The proposal, generated by the increasing frustration felt by European telecommunications manufacturers eager to modernize the former Soviet Union's telephone system, would effectively remove the United States' veto power over the sale of fiber-optic and related communications equipment. 
 Germany, the Netherlands and Italy introduced the proposal last week in Paris to a working group of the Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls, known as Cocom. The committee is the Western agency long responsible for coordinating trade restrictions against the Soviet Union and its allies. Eight other European nations have said they will support the proposal, while American representatives are expected to seek delays to study its impact.
Separately, a group of 10 American Government officials is preparing to leave Monday to inspect Carl Zeiss Jena, a manufacturing company in the former East Germany. Last year the company sold a high-speed fiber-optic telecommunications cable to the Soviet Union, challenging American and British attempts to limit modernization of the Soviet telephone system.
The sale was based on a loophole in Cocom restrictions that provides an exemption for Eastern European manufacturers that had done business with the Soviet Union in the past. If the cable was actually produced in the former East Germany, then Cocom rules would not apply. But the American officials want to see whether Carl Zeiss Jena has such manufacturing capabilities, or whether the company might have merely acted as a transfer agent for some Western producer.
Cocom is a child of the Cold War that has been struggling to find a career in the current era. The 17-nation agency liberalized many export restrictions on high-technology products last year, but many members now believe that these restrictions are increasingly irrelevant as new capitalist economies emerge in the former East bloc.
"The Cold War is over," said Eric L. Hirschhorn, a former deputy assistant commerce secretary for export control who is now a Washington lawyer representing American computer makers. "Why is it over everywhere but in Cocom?"
 
Bitterly Contested Issue
 American and British Government officials have pursued a restrictive policy on exports of advanced telecommunications gear because such equipment would make surveillance more difficult.
But telecommunications exports have been a bitterly contested issue since the Soviet bloc began to collapse several years ago, and American telecommunications manufacturers have been among those protesting their country's stance.
These manufacturers have made several attempts to sell advanced telecommunications gear to the former Soviet Union. In 1990 efforts by the regional Bell company U S West to complete a deal for laying high-speed fiber optic cable across Siberia were blocked by United States enforcement of Cocom restrictions on the export of high-speed, high-capacity communications technology.
 
Need for New Focus Is Seen
 Many trade experts believe that Cocom must be reorganized to focus on issues including North-South trade between wealthier and poorer nations, and the proliferation of nuclear weapons and related technology exports. But it is unclear whether the group is the right one to carry out such a strategy. Without wider participation from former socialist countries as well as Asian and Middle-Eastern nations, any controls are likely to be ineffective.
"If Cocom is going to take North-South responsibility, it won't be able to unless it involves the Soviet Union and resolves this very divisive telecommunications issue," said Chris Padilla, manager of government affairs for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
The plan now before a Cocom working group in Paris would require countries to give Cocom 30 days advance notice of proposed exports. Although Cocom could still block these exports, the new rules would make such actions unlikely. The proposal is to be discussed by diplomats at the Assistant Secretary level on March 5.

HEADLINE: Dow Loses 2 but Broader Market Holds Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed again yesterday in heavy and choppy trading as blue-chip issues retreated a bit but with more records set in the broader market. The Dow Jones industrial average ended at 3,255.59, down 2.01 points.
Some investors stayed out of the market ahead of today's unemployment report, while others shifted their money from large-capitalization stocks to secondary issues, traders said. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 242 million shares, down from 262.4 million on Wednesday. The Big Board index closed up 0.09 point, to 228.96, as gaining issues held a 912-to-772 lead over losers.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks ticked lower, to 413.82, down 0.02 point, while the American Stock Exchange composite set a record at 416.25, up 1.01 points.
Trading on the Nasdaq pushed the composite to yet another high, as it closed at 637.67, up 0.70 point, and the Russell 2,000 took a 0.92-point gain to a new high of 210.26.
John Brooks, a technical analyst for Davis, Mendel & Regenstein Inc., was impressed with yesterday's volume. "As a rule, many investors usually hold back on trading before the release of some economic data that the market deems important," he said.
"With the market up dramatically since the beginning of the year and what appears to be a consolidation," the market seems headed for a fall, Mr. Brooks said. "Only this market refuses to go down in the face of all that."
Many analysts have come to the conclusion that when the market does move, it will head down, but Mr. Brooks said he believed that when it resolved itself it would rise.
"You still have an enormous amount of C.D. money coming into the large-capitalization, high-price issues, low-price issues and mid-capitalization growth stocks," he said.
Yesterday's market took a cautious tone that for the most part kept prices from building much momentum. Many analysts say that the data on employment scheduled to be issued today will be crucial for the near-term outlook for the Federal Reserve.
"If unemployment is up," the analyst said, "people will buy the market because it will give the Fed reason to ease further, but if it's down, it might cause the market to lose a day, but it will not create a major slide."
In active trading, Owens-Corning, jumped up 7 5/8, to 36 1/2, as it took an $800 million charge on its fourth-quarter results. Traders said many analysts agreed that the charge for asbestos liabilities was a positive sign and reduced the uncertainty surrounding the company.
Constar International, a big manufactuer of plastic containers, reported strong fourth-quarter earnings and the results pushed the price of its stock up 2 1/4, to 40 1/2.
Traders said the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, and the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, were both downgraded by Nancy Spady, an analyst with Shearson Lehman, to "buy" from "strong buy." But they said the nature of the adjustment was technical and did not change the analyst's favorable long-term outlook. Fannie Mae was off 3/4, to 63 7/8 and Freddie Mac lost 1/4, to 123 1/2.
Dresser Industries, an energy and natural resources company, which said late Wednesday that it would spin off its industrial and mining equipment units, rose 1 1/4, to 20 5/8.

HEADLINE: 'Domestic' Label for Mazda Would Be First for Japanese

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The Mazda Motor Corporation offered solid evidence today that its cars are becoming more American, introducing its new 626 compact model, which Mazda said would be the first "foreign" brand car to be classified as domestic for purposes of Federal fuel-efficiency regulations.
Mazda introduced the car at the Chicago Auto Show. All of the 626's steel, glass, paint, electronics and major components -- except the engine and transmission -- are bought from United States suppliers. 
 Some of the suppliers are longtime American companies; others are owned by Japanese companies, and some are joint ventures of American and Japanese owners. The United Automobile Workers union and other critics of Japan contend that Japanese auto makers import many parts and relabel them as domestic after changing them only slightly.
 
 
75 Percent U.S. Content
 The four-door Mazda 626 and the two-door MX-6, which are built at Mazda's Flat Rock, Mich., assembly plant, will contain more than 75 percent domestic content. Thus, the auto maker expects the Environmental Protection Agency to classify the cars as "domestic" for purposes of complying with corporate average fuel economy regulations. Those rules require each auto maker's fleet to deliver, on average, at least 27.5 miles a gallon; import and domestic fleets are averaged separately.
Mazda's announcement came at a moment of sharp tension between the United States and its auto makers and Japan and its auto industry. Big Three executives have been urging Washington to restrain Japanese sales as a way to forestall plant closings and layoffs in the United States.
Mazda and other Japanese auto makers assert that they employ American workers and contribute substantially to American economic vitality. A key component of this argument has been stressing the domestic nature of some of the best-selling Japanese models. The Japanese auto makers have also promised to increase purchases of American-made automotive parts to help redress the trade imbalance.
 
 
Ads Won't Wave a Flag
 But if Mazda is pleased with the American content of the 626, it does not plan to share that pride with consumers. Clark Vitulli, senior vice president of Mazda's American sales subsidiary, said Mazda would emphasize the domestic character of its vehicles to the news media and to politicians, but would probably not do so in its advertising.
"Most of our customers intend to buy imports anyway," Mr. Vitulli said. "Where the cars come from isn't as important to our buyers as quality and reliability."
The Japanese auto makers are nervous about protectionist legislation developing in Congress, as well as what they see as nascent Japan-bashing. But so far, automotive sales figures suggest that any "buy American" sentiment has not translated into lost sales for foreign makes.
The Honda Motor Company has also been building cars in Ohio that it says contain 75 percent domestic content. But because Honda also imports Accords built in Japan, the model's average domestic content is not large enough to qualify the Accord as a domestic car. The Toyota Motor Corporation builds many, but not all, of its Camrys in Georgetown, Ky.
 
 
Fierce Competition
 The new Mazda 626, when it goes on sale in May, will enter one of the most competitive segments of the automotive market -- larger compact and midsize cars, a category that includes the Accord, Camry, Ford Taurus and General Motors's midsize sedans like the Chevrolet Lumina.
The new Camry is one of the few models in this class selling strongly without manufacturers' incentives or discounts. Indeed, Toyota was able to raise its price sharply this year and sell it at the higher level. The price has not been set for the redesigned 626, but the base retail price of the current model is $13,226.
Last year, Mazda sold 68,000 626's in the United States; it sold 64,000 in 1990 and 55,000 in 1989.

HEADLINE: Falling Tax Would Lift All Yachts

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The nation's luxury-boat builders, many clinging to their businesses after two years of plunging sales, finally got some good news last week.
President Bush, in his budget proposals, asked Congress to repeal the 10 percent luxury tax on yachts priced at more than $100,000 (and also on private planes that cost more than $250,000). The repeal, which Congress is likely to approve, would be retroactive to Feb. 1. 
 Since the tax took effect in January 1990, hundreds of builders of large and small boats have spoken of it as a stake driven into the heart of an industry already suffering from the recession, tighter bank rules on financing and fallout from the gulf war.
In the last two years, about 100 builders of luxury boats -- recreational craft costing more than $100,000 -- cut their operations severely and laid off thousands of workers. Some builders filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
Now, sales personnel and owners of marine companies are hoping they will be swamped by buyers who have held off in the expectation that the tax will be repealed.
The 10 percent tax applies to the amount of the cost above $100,000, so that a boat selling for $300,000 carries a $20,000 luxury tax. That tax is in addition to any state and local taxes.
Mr. Bush's proposals were endorsed by Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine and majority leader, whose state is active in boat building. That increases the chances that Congress will accept the argument that repealing the tax will create jobs and promote economic growth. Overall employment in the industry, including the makers of smaller, less-expensive boats, has dropped to 400,000, from 600,000 in 1988.
Adding to the industry's optimism are signs of a small revival in boat sales. Most companies said they sold more boats at the New York National Boat Show earlier last month than at last year's show, when sales were very weak. They said the boat show also had good attendance during its run at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan.
Also, boat prices have dropped as much as 40 to 50 percent, interest rates have fallen and some lenders have begun to offer financing, though on very strict terms.
In 1991, sales of luxury boats dropped 70 percent from 1990's level, while overall boat sales fell 18 percent.
 
Relies on Foreign Customers
 "The luxury tax really hurt us," said William J. Healey, the president of the Viking Yatch Company in New Gretna, N.J.
He gestured toward a few big luxury boats being built there. A 50-foot boat costing $800,000 is bound for Italy; a $1 million yacht may be sold in Japan. A 65-foot motor yatch costing $1.3 million is bound for Greece.
The business from overseas, developed in the last two years, is enabling Viking to limp along, its work force cut to 150 workers from 800. "Very fortunately, it has helped us weather the downturn," Mr. Healey said as he pointed to two production lines that have been inactive for several years.
Domestic demand fell so sharply that a year ago Viking shut an operation in Tampa, Fla., that employed 800 workers. The plant was built in the boom of the 1980's, when most boat makers could not keep up with demand.
Robert A. Hazard, the general manager of the Egg Harbor Yacht Company in Egg Harbor City, N.J., got some orders at the New York show that strengthened the company's attempt to emerge from Federal bankruptcy protection. In a few weeks, a bankruptcy judge is expected to approve a reorganization plan under which management is pledging most of its personal financial resources to help back the plan.
"Everyone of us came out of the show with orders," Mr. Hazard said. He said he could have sold more boats but buyers had decided to wait in the hope that the luxury tax would soon be repealed.
Guy Castranova, who owns a contracting business in the Caribbean, is in the market for a 36-foot Tiara motor yacht that costs about $300,000. "Now is the time to buy," he said. "Interest rates are down, prices are lower.
 
Tradition in South Jersey
 Egg Harbor Yacht is among the oldest boatyards in South Jersey, where there was a plentiful supply of cedar -- the main building material before fiberglass hulls took over. It prospered in the 1980's; in some years it built 120 boats. But in January 1991, the combination of recession, the war and the luxury tax forced Egg Harbor to shut and lay off its 250 workers. A skeleton crew kept the lights on, answered the phone and kept in touch with customers while the company came up with a reorganization plan.
Like most builders that are beginning to call back workers, Egg Harbor has modest goals. At first only about 8 to 10 people will be called back to finish the boats that lie like skeletons on the production line.
By March, Mr. Hazard estimated, about 45 people will working to build 40 to 50 boats for the coming year. All the boats will be sold before they are built.
Many of the workers, whose families have been in the business for generations, are eager to be called back, even those who took higher-paying jobs at the casinos in Atlantic City.
Not far from Egg Harbor is Ocean Yachts, which opened in 1977 in Weekstown. It is among the youngest companies in the area, but it grew rapidly -- an average of 30 percent a year -- as recreational boating grew with the economic boom of the 1980's. It built a plant in Egg Harbor City in 1988, and the company had sales of $60 million three years ago, building about 12 boats a month.
Now the plant is closed, and the work force of 325 has been cut to 55. Ralph N. Leeck, the vice president of marketing for Ocean, said that because the 1980's were so highly profitable, most of the expansion was paid out of cash flow, leaving the company with little debt.
"We have manageable costs and litte debt," he said."That's how we can keep the doors open and keep on losing money."
His company has also seen a small increase in orders, particularly from owners who have not bought a new boat in a long time and want to trade up.
Mr. Leeck does not, however, expect a return soon to the good times of the 1980's. The retrenchment, he said, "is still going to continue into the 1990's."

HEADLINE: Region's Quick-Cash Frauds Snare Desperate Consumers

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Feb. 5

 BODY:
After losing her job as a computer operator -- with no savings, no credit and few prospects -- a 25-year-old Morris County woman found a classified ad in a national magazine offering fast, guaranteed personal loans of as much as $25,000.
Early last year she sent the Florida-based company $500, borrowed from her mother, as a fee to secure a $5,000 loan. She has not had any response. 
 "I was so desperate I didn't stop to think," said the woman, who spoke on condition of anonymity because, she said, she is ashamed of having allowed someone to bilk her.
 
Feeding on Desperation
 What happened to her is happening to people across the region. Fueled by a lingering recession that has made credit tight and people desperate, loan frauds that dangle the prospect of quick cash for an upfront fee are the fastest-growing category of consumer complaints throughout the metropolitan area, consumer agency officials said.
The agencies said that beyond advance-fee loan frauds, they had been inundated with complaints about other schemes that target individuals stretched to their financial limit.
In the mildest cases, consumers answering ads offering job information receive lists culled from old newspaper want ads, the officials said, and are bilked of the cost of a telephone call to a 900 number. Unemployed workers have paid bogus job consultants advance fees to process applications, the officials said, and homeowners facing foreclosure have sent fake credit companies overdue mortgage payments.
But in the worst cases, they said, homeowners have been tricked into signing second mortgages when they thought they were signing low-interest debt consolidation loans; some now face losing their homes.
"There is a very direct correlation between the recessionary economy and the increase in the types of consumer fraud we're seeing," said Emma Byrne, the director of New Jersey's Divison of Consumer Affairs.
Robert Winter, director of New Jersey's Division of Criminal Justice, said today's cases are reminiscent of those that were prevalent during the recession in the mid-1970's but became less frequent when times got better.
"In the 80's, we had a lot of over-the-counter securities stock fraud," he said. "Now, the victims are much more sympathetic."
The victims range from the urban poor to suburban homeowners, consumer officials said. In Connecticut, many are white-collar workers who have lost their jobs or are working part time and are hard-pressed to meet their bills, said Attorney General Richard Blumenthal.
In New York, where the fastest-growing fraud category involves advance-fee mortgage loans, most of the victims are homeowners in Queens and on Long Island, said Ed Saslow, chief of the Attorney General's Criminal Prosecutions Bureau. And in New Jersey, the victims are most often "those who can afford it least," said Ms. Byrne. "They're seniors, non-English speaking and the urban poor."
 
Mortgage Tricks
 Last week, the New Jersey Attorney General, Robert J. Del Tufo, ordered a licensed Bergen County home-repair contractor and a finance company to answer charges that they defrauded 12 homeowners by luring them into signing second mortgages on their homes when the homeowners thought they were signing applications for low-interest debt consolidation loans. The companies, Maywood Builders and Sterling Resources, have been ordered to appear before an Essex County Superior Court judge on March 5.
For Anna Brocal of Paterson, the resolution of the case cannot come too soon. Ms. Brocal said her mother was tricked into signing a $22,700 second mortgage loan by men who came to their home offering to replace windows at low cost.
"They said they worked for the Government," Ms. Brocal said. "The way they were talking, they made it sound so real." Ms. Brocal said that after asking her mother, Maria Brocal, whether she had credit cards, the men offered to give her a loan at 15 percent interest that would consolidate all her credit-card debt and cover the cost of replacing the windows. "When she signed the papers, my mother didn't know it was for a second mortgage," Ms. Brocal said. She added that her father is on Social Security, that the family's only additional income is from a rental apartment in their two-family house and that they had no intention of acquiring a second mortgage.
"These are the kinds of frauds we're seeing," said Ms. Byrne. "They hit people absorbed with three major costs -- home, car or health."
 
Nationwide Fraud
 Far from being limited to the New York region, the rash of frauds is nationwide, according to the Council of Better Business Bureaus in Arlington, Va. Last year, the agency received more than 300,000 complaints from consumers and small-business owners who paid advance fees of $100 to $10,000 for "guaranteed" loans, said a spokeswoman, Dianne Ward.
In most cases, the culprits are not caught and the victims do not recoup their losses. Attorney General Blumenthal said Connecticut has put one fraudulent advance-fee concern out of business in the last year and is investigating others. But, Mr. Blumenthal said, while his office recommends five-year sentences in such cases, judges are reluctant to send first-time offenders to prison.
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, a Connecticut Democrat who heads the Governmental Affairs Committee's Subcommittee on Consumer and Environmental Affairs, has proposed that Congress outlaw advance fees for consumer and small-business loans offered by unregulated companies. But until such legislation is in place, consumer agencies say, fast-moving schemers will prove unwieldy to curb.
The New Jersey Attorney General's office has closed down two advance-fee loan operations and 11 companies that operate 900 numbers. Last month the office won a conviction against Timothy Burke, alias Robert Chapman, on charges that he had persuaded owners who were about to lose their homes because of missed mortgage payments to make the payments to his company, First Jersey Equities.
But Mr. Winter of the Divison of Criminal Justice said such cases are hard-won. "The general rule of thumb is white-collar criminals in the state system are continually given less time," he said. Ms. Brocal, whose parents face the possibility of foreclosure if they are forced to pay for a second-mortgage loan, says it is high time a law is passed.
"We paid $400 for one window, when it was worth about $75," Ms. Brocal said. "It sounded good at first, but we were scammed."

They held their grandchildren, Edwin, 2 years old and Cecilia, 4 months. (F.N. Kinney for The New York Times) (pg. B4)
