HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Continental Plan to End Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. filed a bankruptcy reorganization plan yesterday in which its major unsecured creditors agreed to reduce the carrier's debt and interest costs sharply. In return, the creditors would get stock, making them owners of the airline.
If the plan is approved by the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., analysts say, it will greatly help the company survive the current slump and fare cutting in the airline business and enable it to become profitable in a recovery. 
 "This gives them the best chance at wiping the slate clean and starting over," said Helane Becker, the airline analyst for Shearson Lehman Brothers.
 
Has Remained Competitive
 Continental filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in December 1990. But passengers and travel agents continued to support the airline after the filing, and the carrier also maintained a good cash position by selling assets.
The Continental plan is similar to one filed by Trans World Airlines last week. T.W.A.'s unsecured creditors agreed to reduce the carrier's debt by $1 billion in exchange for stock, and bondholders accepted much lower interest rates.
Under the Continental agreement, long-term debt would be reduced by about 70 percent, to $1.7 billion from $5.8 billion. This would help cut the airline's annual interest costs by $270 million.
It is expected that current stockholders will get nothing, which was what the airline had said for the last year. Continental stock closed at 43.75 cents the American Stock Exchange yesterday, off 56.25 cents.
In such situations. unsecured creditors often have little choice but to accept stock for debt because forcing an airline like Continental to liquidate can throw hundreds of planes and other assets on the market at a time when there is small demand for them.
One significant uncertainty remains. Continental has not reached an agreement with the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, which has about $700 million in claims involving insufficient financing of the pension plan for Continental's defunct Eastern Airlines. When Eastern liquidated in January 1990, Continental was forced to take over the obligations.
 
Its Second Bankruptcy
 This is the second time that Continental has sought to reorganize under Chapter 11. In 1986, Frank Lorenzo, then the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation -- the forerunner of Continental Airlines Holdings -- put the carrier under Chapter 11, repudiated union contracts and cut costs and salaries. The airline was able to become profitable again, but it ran into trouble when it absorbed the failing People Express and lost support from business travelers because of service problems.
Continental, the nation's fifth-largest airline, continues to have problems attracting business travelers, who make up only about 25 percent of its passengers compared with about 50 percent for other big carriers.
Robert R. Ferguson 3d, vice chairman and chief executive of Continental, said that he was encouraged by a recent increase in traffic and that the bookings for the next several months seemed encouraging as well.
Under the plan, the company will keep its 43,000 employees and its present level of flights.
There have been talks about a possible merger with T.W.A., but they are at an early stage. The plan is not dependent on a merger and is meant to make the carrier workable as an independent airline without outside investment.
Kevin Murphy, the airline analyst for Morgan Stanley, said that of the three airlines now under Chapter 11 -- America West, T.W.A. and Continental -- Continental had the best chance to reorganize. He said that the airline was large enough to compete and had strong hubs in Newark and Houston, where the parent company is based.
The major creditors of the airline are bondholders who would take the largest loss in exchanging their debt for stock. There are 56,000 prepetition proofs of claim, totaling $4.3 billion, that would be converted to equity.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Dip Ahead of Job Data

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped and interest rates moved modestly higher yesterday, as dealers and their clients turned cautious in advance of the January employment report, which is scheduled to be released today.
"We have had a few clients ask us to lighten up positions in front of the number," one government securities trader said, "because they are very uncertain about what the number will be and how the market will react to it." 
 Based on an exceptionally wide range of estimates, economists are equally uncertain about what the data will show.
 
Up 100,000 to Down 125,000
 The most pessimistic forecasts look for a decline of around 125,000 in non-farm payroll employment, and a rise in the unemployment rate to 7.2 percent, from 7.1 percent currently.
Others, however, are projecting that payroll employment rose by 100,000 last month, and that the unemployment rate declined.
Traders said a report yesterday showing that chain stores reported strong sales gains during January had no market impact. But analysts said they were somewhat encouraged by the report.
"The comparison is against an extremely weak period a year ago," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America, "but chain store sales look to be on a good upward trend. These are the glimmers of hope that people in the White House and the Fed are looking for."
Another whiff of recovery appeared later in the day, when the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply posted big increases during the week ended Jan. 27.
 
M-2 Up $9.6 Billion
 The Fed reported that M-2, the monetary aggregate it follows most closely, grew by $9.6 billion in the week. That increase pushed growth in the aggregate to 4.9 percent over its fourth-quarter base, above the midpoint of the Fed's target growth range of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent. Last year, M-2 expanded at an extremely sluggish 2.7 percent rate.
"Money is growing stronger than was generally expected," said Paul L. Kasriel, a vice president and monetary economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "That is a very good sign for economic activity ahead."
While fourth-quarter cuts in interest rates engineered by the Fed have played a significant role in the speed-up in money growth recently, a slowdown in the closing of failed savings and loans and commercial banks by the Resolution Trust Corporation and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation have also been important, Mr. Kasriel said.
"These activities have a negative effect on money growth," he said, "because when banks are closed, deposits disappear. At some point, they will get back in the game again. That's why we could very well have a rerun of 1991 this year, with a pickup in economic activity during the first half of the year and then some slowing later on, when the R.T.C. and the F.D.I.C. get back into action."
 
30-Year Bond at 102 22/32
 Prices of Treasury securities were down before the Fed released the money supply figures, and further declines were recorded after traders saw the numbers.
By late in the day the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 10222/32 , down 14/32 , to yield 7.76 percent, compared with 7.72 percent late Wednesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10131/32 , down 10/32 , to yield 7.21 percent. The 6 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 3/8, down 5/32 , to yield 6.39 percent. And the 4 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 9922/32 , down 1/32 , to yield 5.04 percent.
Traders said there was good demand at an auction of new one-year Treasury bills.
Bids at the auction produced an average discount rate of 4.01 percent, up from the average rate of 3.84 percent at the last auction of one-year bills on Jan. 9.
 
Rates in Secondary Market
 In the secondary market for Treasury bills, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.80 percent late yesterday, down a basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged, at a late offered rate of 3.86 percent.
New-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by a two-part $350 million offering of securities for the Commonwealth Edison Company.
One part consisted of $150 million worth of 7 percent five-year notes. These securities were priced at $100, or par, 60 basis points above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 1/4 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $200 million were sold as 8 5/8 percent 30-year bonds. The bonds, which are noncallable for 10 years, were priced at $99.05, to yield 8.714 percent, 95 basis points above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021.
Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
American Express Issue
 Lehman Brothers acted as lead manager on an offering of $200 million worth of seven-year securities for the American Express Credit Corporation.
The 7 3/8 percent notes were priced at $99.50, to yield 7.468 percent, 71 basis points above the Treasury's 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The issue is rated AA-3 by Moody's and AA-minus by Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate securities said that prices of most issues dipped by 1/8 point to 1/4 point in slow trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged on the day.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Big Owens-Corning Charge Sends Its Shares Surging

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation said yesterday that it took an $800 million charge against earnings in the last quarter to cover uninsured asbestos liabilities through the end of the decade.
Wall Street welcomed the move as a belated response to investors' desires for a clearer accounting of how the company expects to be affected by the tens of thousands of asbestos lawsuits it faces, and Owens-Corning's stock surged, closing up $7.75, or nearly 27 percent, and reaching $37 a share before ending at $36.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 The jump in the stock price came even though operating earnings for the quarter fell below analysts' expectations and, after charges, the company posted a loss for the quarter.
The huge asbestos write-off represented one of the first decisions of Glen H. Hiner, who took over last month as chief executive at company headquarters in Toledo, Ohio. In the past, Owens-Corning reported asbestos expenses as they were incurred.
Mr. Hiner said that a new approach to handling asbestos cases, bringing most of the legal work inside the company, is expected to cut litigation costs to $50 million a year, from $150 million.
In addition to its asbestos charge, Owens-Corning took a one-time charge of $227 million to comply with new accounting standards being imposed on all major corporations by 1993 to cover future retiree benefits, primarily medical expenses.
After all of the special charges, the company lost $529 million in the quarter, compared with a loss of $33 million in the fourth quarter a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $687 million, down 9.4 percent from $758 million a year ago.
Owens-Corning said that it had operating earnings of $3 million, or 7 cents a share, in the last quarter, compared with $18 million, or 42 cents a share, for the fourth quarter of 1990. About $14 million of the decline, or 33 cents a share, was attributable to an accounting change that increased estimated taxes payable on overseas earnings.
"I was encouraged that our operating margins went up in the fourth quarter," Mr. Hiner said. "I don't see any extraordinary charges going forward. Now we can be judged on operating income and my goal is to improve it each quarter in 1992 and 1993."
Most of the company's income comes from the automotive and construction sectors, both of which have been hard hit by the recession.
For the year, Owens-Corning lost $742 million, compared with a profit of $73 million, or $1.73 a share, in 1990. Revenues in 1991 declined 9.3 percent, to slightly more than $2.78 billion, from nearly $3.07 billion in 1990.

HEADLINE: Wall St. Tradition of Giving To the Neediest Is Continued

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
The bright and the eager who flock each year to Wall Street's equivalent of boot camp, the analysts program, inherit two traditions: 80-hour workweeks and an annual campaign to benefit The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The analysts understand the necessity of hard work during their two-year stints. It is the time-honored way of identifying the movers and the shakers amid the cum laudes and the Phi Beta Kappas. But they are less certain about the origins of their connection with the Neediest Cases. 
 "We know it started seven years ago," said Nicholas N. Golding, an analyst at Salomon Brothers. "We don't know who started it, or why they picked the Neediest Cases. But the tradition continues because each year that the new arrivals are asked to contribute, they ask about the fund, learn about the good work it does and decide to support it."
That support translated into impressive numbers. A total of 759 analysts from 14 firms made contributions. Their donations ranged from $5 to $5,000 and together they totaled $95,818.39, said Mr. Golding who coordinated the effort with two of his Salomon co-workers, Craig A. Larson and Suzette M. Fandino.
"We're very, very pleased, especially given the state of the economy," Ms. Fandino said. "Working so hard it's easy to get wrapped up in yourself, but it also makes people eager to reach out to others if they're shown how they can help."
Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then the publisher of The Times, the Neediest Cases Fund has enabled millions of people to find that best part of themselves and lend a helping hand to New York's sick, poor and disabled. So far, a record $4.6 million has been raised from more than 15,000 donations.
The newspaper covers all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected is passed on to seven charities. The money buys food for the hungry, homes for the homeless and clothing for those without. It also helps Holocaust survivors, mentally ill substance abusers and people with AIDS.
Mr. Golding, who is in the second year in the analysts program at Salomon Brothers, began organizing the campaign in early December by recruiting Ms. Fandino, who is also in her second year in the program, and Mr. Larson, who is in his first year and plans to run next year's campaign.
They developed contacts at the 13 other firms and regularly checked in with their liaisons to inspire and cajole them.
"It wasn't a hard sell because the fund is very worthwhile," Mr. Larson said. "They especially liked the fact that none of the money goes to overhead so they get more bang for their buck. They liked that."
The 14 firms that participated in this years drive were: Bear, Stearns & Company; the Blackstone Group; Dillon, Read & Company; the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation; the First Boston Corporation; Goldman Sachs & Company; Kidder, Peabody & Company; Lehman Brothers; Merrill Lynch Capital Markets; Morgan Stanley & Company; Oppenheimer & Company; Paine Webber; Prudential-Bache-Securities, and Salomon Brothers.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Off 3.8% in December

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The Government reported today that factory orders were sharply lower in December and jobless claims were steady in late January.
Orders for durable and nondurable goods plunged 3.8 percent in December, contributing to the steepest annual decline since the previous recession nine years ago, the Commerce Department said. 
 "The sharp decline reinforces the expectation that a broad-based improvement in the economy is not under way and not likely to begin until spring," said Larry Meyer, head of Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, a St. Louis-based economic forecasting service.
In a second report that analysts said provides more evidence of a stagnant economy, the Labor Department reported little improvement in the number of initial claims for jobless insurance in late January.
 
Indicates Little Spending
 "It suggests that we really have a very, very weak employment situation," said Gilbert Benz, an economist at the Swiss Bank Corporation of New York. "It suggests very little income growth and very little spending," both of which are needed to lift the economy.
The Commerce Department said factory orders were slashed by 2.6 percent last year, to $2.8 trillion. It was the largest decline since a 3.5 percent plunge in the recession year of 1982 and the first decrease since a three-tenths of 1 percent drop in 1986.
Orders for both durable goods, costly items expected to last three years or more, and for nondurable goods suffered annual declines. The manufacturing sector had shown signs of recovery at midyear but then faltered during the fall.
In December, orders totaled a seasonally adjusted $233.8 billion, down from $243.1 billion a month earlier. The 3.8 percent drop was the steepest since orders sank 6.2 percent in November 1990.
Even the six-tenths of 1 percent advance initially recorded for November 1991 was revised downward in the newest report to four-tenths of 1 percent.
Factory orders are a gauge of manufacturing industry plans. Continuing declines could mean lower production and loss of jobs in a sector representing nearly 25 percent of the nation's economic activity.
Analysts also noted that businesses cut their orders for nonmilitary capital goods, often a barometer of plans to expand and modernize. Excluding aircraft, these orders fell 1 percent in December.
The Labor Department report said 450,000 people filed new claims for jobless insurance in the week ending Jan. 25, down from a revised 460,000 a week earlier.
But because of weekly volatility, many analysts look more to a four-week moving average, which showed claims holding in a 432,000 to 439,000 range. Mr. Meyer said that would reflect an unemployment rate of 7 percent to 7.25 percent.
 
Jobless Rate Report Due
 The department will release January's jobless rate on Friday. It stood at 7.1 percent in December, the highest since June 1986.
Orders for durable goods tumbled 5.2 percent in December, even further than the initial 5 percent estimate reported last week. These orders had edged up six-tenths of 1 percent in November.
Some analysts suggested the weakness in the durable goods sector might have been made worse by businesses postponing purchases to take advantage of an expected investment tax credit request in President Bush's State of the Union Message on Jan. 28.
Mr. Bush proposed a 15 percent first-year credit for equipment purchased after Feb. 1 and before Jan. 1, 1993.
 
Big Drop in Transportation
 The largest decrease was in the transportation category, which posted a 14 percent drop. All areas participated in the decline except for shipbuilding and tanks. Excluding the transportation category, orders were off 2.2 percent.
The often-volatile orders for military goods jumped 86 percent after plummeting 38 percent a month earlier. Excluding this category, orders fell 5.8 percent.
Orders for nondurable goods, like clothing and chemicals, fell 2.4 percent after edging up two-tenths of 1 percent in November.
Shipments of factory orders, a gauge of current production, declined 3.4 percent, the first drop since last March. Still, shipments for the year were down 1.9 percent, the biggest decline since 1982.
Unfilled orders, a barometer of how busy industry will be in coming months, slipped five-tenths of 1 percent in December, the fourth straight decline. These orders were at their lowest level since October 1989. For the year, they fell 3.1 percent.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

New Light for Photography
Photography is gaining new respect in the New York museum world. This week, the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced the formation of a separate photography department headed by Dr. Maria Morris Hambourg, who has been an associate curator in the department of prints and photographs since 1985.This is the first department to be created at the museum since the opening of the Robert Lehman Collection of Old Masters in 1975.
Meanwhile, the Whitney Museum of American Art has said it will begin aquiring photographs for its permanent collection. 
 Photographs had always been part of the print department at the Metropolitan, but Philippe de Montebello, the museum's director, said, "This is such an important and growing field we felt it was better served with its own set of programs, publications and exhibitions."
The Metropolitan's photography collection is significantly smaller and less diverse than collections at such institutions as the Museum of Modern Art, the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., George Eastman House in Rochester and the Art Institute of Chicago. The Met's holdings number about 15,000 photographs and include two important collections.
The first comprises about 450 works by Alfred Stieglitz and his contemporaries, which Stieglitz donated to the museum in 1933. The second is a group of 500 photographs by 180 American and European artists active between the two World Wars, which was donated to the museum in 1987 as a joint gift by the New York collector John C. Waddell and the Ford Motor Company.
The museum is "currently working hard on filling in the collection with photographs from the 1950's to the present," said Dr. Hambourg.
"For example," she said, "we are trying to acquire works from the 1970's in the Conceptual field."
Dr. Hambourg is also planning two major Metropolitan exhibitions for 1993. In the spring, there will be a show of the Gilman Paper Company Collection, which includes about 275 images acquired over the last 15 years by Howard Gilman, chairman of the Georgia-based paper concern, and his curator, Pierre Apraxine.
"The collection has set the standard for connoisseurship and collecting," Dr. Hambourg said. "It will cover the first century of photography, 1839 to 1939."
The second show, for the fall of 1993, is an exhibition of works by the 19th-century French portraitist Felix Nadar that is being co-organized with the Musee d'Orsay in Paris.
Unlike the Met, the Whitney has no significant photography collection, nor does it plan to form a separate department for photography. Sondra Gilman Gonzalez-Falla, who has headed the Whitney's paintings and sculpture committee for the last 10 years, will now be responsible for the photography-acquisitions committee.
David A. Ross, the Whitney's director, said the decision to start the acquisitions program was a result of photography's growing popularity with the museum's membership. "It's also an area I felt strongly needed to be developed," he added.
 
Application Denied
 Franklin Furnace Archive, the avant-garde space in TriBeCa that helped launch such performing artists as Karen Finley and Eric Bogosian and was the first showcase for Jenny Holzer and other multi-media artists, has been denied a $25,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Arts for its planned visual-arts program. The grant was one of two that made the final round but were refused last week; the other was a $5,000 request from Highways, a Los Angeles gallery, which submitted homoerotic photographs as part of its grant application.
Martha Wilson, the director of Franklin Furnace, said the decision was prompted by the submission of a sexually explicit video as part of the grant application.
"It's a sign of a deep layer of conservatism at work," said Ms. Wilson in a recent interview. The institution has received support from the N.E.A. for 16 years. In the last five years, endowment grants have ranged from $20,000 to $50,000. For the 1991-92 season, for example, Franklin Furnace was given $40,000. "This recent denial of funds could be a major threat to its future," Ms. Wilson said.
The process of awarding grants is a long and arduous one. First, applications are reviewed by a peer panel, an ad hoc group of people in the art world invited by the endowment to read applications in their fields and make recommendations. The recommendations are reviewed by another panel made up of the endowment's staff. The final vote then goes to the National Advisory Council, a group of representatives from the art world selected by the N.E.A.
Renny Pritikin, director of New Langton Arts, an exhibition space in San Francisco, headed the peer panel that recommended the Franklin Furnace application for final approval. Mr. Pritikin wrote a letter protesting the council's 17-to-1 vote. "It's like defunding the Met because you don't like one painting in one show," he said in a telephone interview. "Franklin Furnace is one of the most established places, and the N.E.A. should have had respect for them as an institution and not made a decision based on viewing only part of one video."
What the members of the council saw was 15 minutes of a 70-minute tape of the performance artist Scarlet O. In the tape, titled "Appearances Can Be Deceiving," Scarlet O is first dressed like a man and talks about exploring her sexual personae. Later she is wearing a short, slinky nylon dress, spike heels and a spiky black wig. Then she disrobes.
Wendy Luers, the president of Charter 77 Foundation, New York, a public philanthropic organization, is one of the council members who voted against the grant. "I'm a champion of the avant-garde and respond to what's going on sexually today," she said, "but the tape had no artistic merit. Had it been someone's work like Mapplethorpe I would have been bleeding down the table to support it because it would have been artistically significant. If Martha chose to submit that video she did it for a reason. And I had no choice other than to vote against it."
Ms. Wilson said that the tape was not meant to shock. "I don't believe there's such a thing called obscene art," she said. "This happens to be about sexuality, and sex is the oldest subject in art there is. It's crucial to show experimental works by artists such as Scarlet O. This artist is good. Even if she's perceived as bad, that's O.K. The N.E.A. used to be supportive of experimental art."
Responding to allegations by Ms. Wilson and other people in the art world who said they felt the decision was unfair, John E. Frohnmayer, chairman of the endowment, said in a telephone interview the other day that the decision did not represent a more conservative attitude toward endowment grants.
"The main issue here was that the council took responsibility for making artistic judgments," Mr. Frohnmayer said. He added that competition for financing had gotten stiffer: not only have the number of qualified applicants increased, but so have the dollar amounts of the applications. Of the 18,000 applicants for arts grants the endowment received this year, only 4,000 were awarded grants, he said.
"Franklin Furnace's reputation is well known," Mr. Frohnmayer said. "But in this instance what they submitted simply didn't make the grade."
 
Art Newspaper or Journal?
 Subscribers to The Journal of Art have just received a surprise in the mail. Instead of getting the Rizzoli-owned publication, which folded after the December issue, they have gotten The Art Newspaper, a two-year-old British publication with about 5,000 paid subscribers. But in a red box at The Art Newspaper's top right corner is the old Journal of Art logo.
Umberto Allemandi, the publisher and owner of The Art Newspaper, has bought The Journal of Art's title and subscription list from Rizzoli for about $250,000. Subscribers, therefore, will automatically receive The Art Newspaper unless they exercise their option to ask for their money back.
Mr. Allemandi founded The Journal of Art four years ago with the art historian Barbara Rose. But after 10 issues, Ms. Rose bought out his share of the journal, which stopped publishing in June 1989.
In 1990, Rizzoli became the major shareholder of The Journal of Art and resurrected the monthly. Ms. Rose, a partial shareholder, was its editor in chief. Rizzoli published The Journal of Art until the day before Thanksgiving, when it abruptly dismissed the staff and announced it would cease publication. The reason: the poor economic conditions in publishing right now. Ms. Rose announced a short time later that she was suing Rizzoli for not honoring her contract. But Gianfranco Monacelli, the president and chief executive officer of Rizzoli International Publications, said: "There are no suits pending. Rizzoli has honored all its commitments, including those to Ms. Rose."
The sale of The Journal of Art's title and subscription list to Umberto Allemandi & Company Publishing means the Americanization of the terribly British Art Newspaper. "Starting with the March issue we will be printing the United States copies in America," said Anna Somers Cocks, the editor of The Art Newspaper and Mr. Allemandi's wife. "We are also in the process of setting up an office in the United States and will have a core staff here." Eventually, The Art Newspaper will include a special section devoted to art news in the United States.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Lufthansa Appoints Top American Official

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Lufthansa announced yesterday that Frederick Reid had been appointed senior vice president for the Americas, making the 41-year-old San Francisco native the highest-ranking American in the recent history of the German airline and perhaps in its entire 60-year history.
The appointment is effective June 1, but Mr. Reid is essentially functioning in that role now. 
 That role, as it happens, is one of the troubled airline industry's prime hot seats. Mr. Reid is responsible for all of Lufthansa's ground and passenger operations in North and South America at the very time that the airline is threatening to pull out of the United States market.
Almost no American competitors believe the carrier -- Germany's national airline, serving almost 100 foreign countries -- will follow through on its threat, but they also expect additional storm clouds before the disagreements between Bonn and Washington are ironed out.
Those disagreements revolve around the air traffic pact between the United States and Germany, which dates to 1955, when Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines were the only American carriers serving Germany. Today, seven American carriers fly to Germany from 25 cities, while Lufthansa is limited to 12 American cities, two of which -- Washington and Charlotte, N.C. -- are under short-term exemptions granted independently of the bilateral trade agreement.
From 1980 to 1990, Lufthansa's share of the trans-Atlantic market vis-a-vis that of United States carriers fell to 39.8 percent from 49.9 percent, according to Air Transport World, a trade magazine.
Jurgen Weber, chairman and chief executive of Deutsche Lufthansa A.G., has publicly decried the fact that American airlines can fly from any city in the United States to any city in Germany and beyond, while Lufthansa is prohibited from flying beyond the 12 cities. He also accused Delta Air Lines, which recently acquired Pan Am's hub at Frankfurt, and other American carriers of trying to destroy competition over the North Atlantic by pricing fares below cost. The American carriers deny that assertion.
Mr. Reid was reluctant to get into that argument, beyond saying that if the current negotiations did not produce changes, "we would find our position in the U.S. untenable." He quickly added, however, that he fully expected the dispute to be resolved.
"Ten years from now, the airline industry of Europe will be vastly changed," Mr. Reid said, "and Lufthansa, with its hub and spoke system in what is the economic and geopolitical center of Europe, expects to be around to provide a counterweight to American mega-carriers."
Mr. Reid joined Lufthansa in November as an executive in its worldwide sales and marketing department. Previously, he was managing director of European sales at American Airlines in London. From 1976 to 1987, he held a variety of executive positions at Pan Am. Mr. Reid and his wife live in Frankfurt with their three children.

HEADLINE: Cartoons With a Political Conscience

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
If times seem tough, remember that Betty Boop was once homeless and Porky Pig nearly saw his father's farm go bust.
These sad events occurred during the early 1930's, the golden age of the socially conscious cartoon. Fourteen of them, some quite rare, will be shown tonight and tomorrow under the title "Cartoon Soup Kitchen," part of the Film Society of Lincoln Center's current program of films on the Depression. 
 The cartoon program has been organized by Greg Ford, who oversaw the weekly "Cartoonal Knowledge" series at the Thalia theater in the late 1970's and early 80's, and more recently has directed such Warner Brothers cartoons as "The Ducksorcist" and "Night of the Living Duck," both starring Daffy.
"I'm emphasizing what people have forgotten about 30's cartoons," said Mr. Ford, "which is the remarkable explicitness about social issues that people took for granted in their cartoons back then. It's a shock to see your favorite cartoon characters in bread lines."
 
Grim Visions
 In "Confidence" (1932), Oswald the Rabbit's thriving farm falls under the shadow of a cloaked, spectral figure, labeled "Depression," that rises out of an ash heap.
Betty Boop falls on hard times in "Betty Boop's Ups and Downs." The value of her house plummets and the chimney, grabbing wildly, can no longer hold all the parts together.
As the camera pulls back, it becomes clear that all the houses in the neighborhood are in similar straits. "It's a great image of real estate devaluation," Mr. Ford noted approvingly.
Another shot shows the entire United States with a For Sale sign hung out. Eventually the planet Saturn, spotting a bargain, buys the Earth.
Flip the Frog, created by Ub Iwerks, the original animator of Mickey Mouse, is reduced to panhandling and has to pawn his musical instruments. Walt Disney generally steered clear of social commentary, but he did produce "The Three Little Pigs," a cartoon that provided one of the signature songs of the era, "Who's Afraid of the Big Bad Wolf?"
 
Upbeat Endings
 Despite the surprisingly gritty realism of the cartoons -- in "The Flophouse," regiments of lice attack the residents -- most cartoons ended on an optimistic note. Oswald the Rabbit finds his way to the White House, where F. D. R. gives him a booster shot marked Confidence. Porky Pig wins big at the race track and returns to the farm in a limousine.
"Any skepticism toward government seems to be directed at the quick-fix idea," Mr. Ford said, citing "Prosperity Blues," a Krazy Kat cartoon in which a lunatic wearing a Napoleon hat marked N.R.A., for National Recovery Administration, runs around slapping N.R.A. signs on everything in sight.
But American optimism tended to win out. "The cartoons usually end in a frenzied musical number where America revives, usually to the tune of 'Happy Days' and 'We're in the Money,' " said Mr. Ford, who regards the suffering of his animated friends with something more than equanimity.
"It's entertaining to think of all the cartoon characters you know going through the Depression," he said.
"Cartoon Soup Kitchen" can be seen tonight at 9:30 and tomorrow at 2, 6:15, and 10:15 P.M. at the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street. Admission is $7 ($5 for Film Society members). Information: (212) 875-5600.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mostly Lower; Prices for Gold Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly lower in quiet trading on world currency markets yesterday as traders assessed the outlook for interest rates.
Gold prices were mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York gold bullion for current delivery settled at $355.70 an ounce, up 10 cents. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 15 cents an ounce, to a late price of $355.30. 
 Among the factors that depressed the dollar were comments by Germany's Bundesbank president, Helmut Schlesinger, defending the relatively strong mark. He said his country's monetary policy would not be loosened.
 
White House Adviser Comments
 In addition, President Bush's chief economic adviser, Michael Boskin, told Congress that the Federal Reserve had room to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy without stirring inflation.
"Trading focused on interest-rate differentials," said Michael Malpede, an analyst with Refco Inc. in Chicago. As interest rates remain high overseas relative to United States rates, which many say are poised to go lower, there is less incentive for investors to shift money into dollar-denominated, fixed-income securities.
There was little reaction to a Government report showing that December factory orders fell 3.8 percent, the first decline in three months and the steepest in more than a year.
"The general opinion is that we have seen the worst in the numbers," Mr. Malpede said.
Instead, traders are eagerly awaiting today's release of unemployment data for January. The dollar's direction "will depend on what this report means for interest rates and whether the Fed is prepared to act if the numbers are weak," Mr. Malpede said.
Many market observers believe, however, that the Fed will wait till the end of the first quarter before trimming rates again. The central bank needs time to assess the impact of the substantial rate cuts it made in December.
In Tokyo the dollar fell to a closing 125.40 Japanese yen, from 126.11 yen at Wednesday's close. But in London it rose to 125.68 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 125.65 yen, up from 125.56 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8200, from $1.8060 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.8215 to buy 1, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.8150.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE THAW;
'Lead by Example'

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
"The new world order in the next two years will feature two developments that are now being played out in Europe - increased national sentiment among countr4ies in the East, and increased emphasis on political and economic integration among countries in the West.
 "In the international arena, nationalism can prove to be destructive in the long run. Given that, the United States should work to curb the excesses of nationalism by promoting forms that buttress the mutual cooperation of nations. I think you can become a powerful giant if you lead by example. We're having severe problems with population growth in the world. The United States could step up and say: 'We recognize this. Here's what we should do.'
 "I also have in mind the creation of some international economic policy whereby various countries would reach agreement on economic strategies that would maximize stability and growth in all nations. Our economies are so interdependent it's no longer possible for amodern nation to take steps to confront account economic policies in other countries.
 "There is also a need to reach agreement on international solutions to such issues as the massive and growing immigration of citizens frompoor to rich nations and the growing gap between rich and improverished nations. The United States could in m any ways try to strengthen the United Nations so it could adequately address these problems. It would be a serious mistake to return to isolationism cloaked in nationalist sentiment."

GRAPHIC: Photo: William Julius Wilson, Professor of sociology and public policy at the University of Chicago. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Where Entertainment Industry Is Leading Us

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Obscenity Laws Exist, but What Breaks Them?" (The Week in Review, Jan. 19), on the difficulty of obtaining obscenity convictions, is all too accurate. Either we give up on obscenity control, or we get a new ruling from a more conservative Supreme Court. 
 The outrageously irresponsible entertainment industry, shielded by the American Civil Liberties Union, is primarily to blame for the increasing degradation of our popular culture. Its shamelessness is one of the most depressing phenomena of our day with consequences apparent on all sides. The entertainment industry does more to shape the moral values of our youth and the future of our nation than most people ever dream.
But when this is discussed, cries of "censorship" and "Puritanism" are brandished like clubs to intimidate critics of industry excesses. If you don't like something, don't watch or listen. End of discussion.
Are all legal restraints forbidden by the First Amendment?
That amendment was intended to protect serious discourse dealing with political, economic, social and religious issues. That's what a democracy requires, not the anything goes spirit of the entertainment world. The Founding Fathers never intended this amendment to cover the kind of licentiousness that now claims constitutional protection. Furthermore, the Supreme Court has long excluded marginal aspects of free speech and press from First Amendment protection, such as incitement to violence or picketing in a context of violence, fraudulent advertising, contempt of court and perjury. Obscene entertainment belongs in the category of unprotected expression.
One can hope a more conservative Court will redefine obscenity in a way that makes sensible restraints more feasible. But Court rulings aren't as important as a citizenry aware of entertainment's impact and willing to exert pressures to curb its libertinism.
 
REO M. CHRISTENSON
Visiting Professor, Political Science
Miami University
Oxford, Ohio, Jan. 23, 1992

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
1932 and 1992

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Nineteen ninety-two could be as seminal a political year as 1932. Perhaps more than the Presidential hopefuls realize, Americans fear the future and are open to profound change -- far more than in pivotal election years like 1960 and 1980. The candidate who catches and defines today's shapeless and plastic anxieties could harness a force as strong as the one that carried Franklin Roosevelt to the White House 60 years ago.
"Something weird is going on out there -- fear, anger, ugliness," said Roger Ailes, a Republican strategist. 
 "It's an explosive year," warned Peter Hart, a Democratic consultant.
"This election is about defining the future of America," reflected Douglas Bailey, publisher of Hotline, a daily political report.
The mood runs against the essentially status quo policies of President Bush -- even if the recession ends statistically by the summer. Republican leaders privately admit as much and worry that the President is grossly out of touch.
The mood favors Democrats who show they understand the fears and exude confidence about curing them. Democratic gurus fret about their candidates, but sense the kill and the enormous plasticity of the moment.
Yes, 1992 is not 1932. Recession is not depression. But expectations were low 60 years ago; and they have been sky-high since 1945. It does not take nearly as much today to depress a middle class long pampered by success. And 1992 is not 1960 or 1980 when voters were merely interested in "change" or "new leadership."
The historian Arnold Toynbee wrote of the early 1930's that "Men and women all over the world were seriously contemplating and frankly discussing the possibility that the Western system of Society might break down and cease to work." Similar rumblings can be detected now.
As with 1932, 1992 marks the end of an era. The cold war, the central organizing principle of American politics, has disappeared. Nothing can fill that void. Gone also is the central article of post-war faith that children would surpass their parents. Key industries and jobs that powered growth have disappeared under the waves, forever. Germany and Japan rise again, posing complicated threats.
Now as 60 years ago, intellectual and political categories have broken down. It is hard to locate right and left on the spectrum. Hawks and doves are merely birds once again. Voters cannot get their bearings.
Today as then, there is a loss of political inhibition, a willingness to think the unthinkable, as Leon Wieseltier of The New Republic suggested to me. David Duke can become a serious candidate for Governor of Louisiana. Shades of Huey Long. In frustration over lawmakers, momentum gathers to set term limits for elected officials and legislate policy by referendums. Senator Pat Moynihan laments "the savage prospect" of states legislating no help for new children born to mothers on welfare. "Can you imagine that?" he asks. The previously unimaginable now can become law, for good and ill.
Public opinion soundings begin to echo that volatility. A CNN/USA Today survey in January showed an astonishing 55 percent of Americans saying that the economy needs a "complete overhaul." In a Times/CBS News poll from last August on health care, 50 percent said the system required "fundamental changes," and 40 percent said it had to be "completely rebuilt."
The Democratic challengers have not tapped deeply enough into these rumblings. They all call for "fundamental change" or "reinventing government" or some such, and even offer far-reaching specific proposals. But they have not quite found the right words and seem to shy away from galloping with the full logic of their own proposals for change.
Franklin Roosevelt, too, exercised caution throughout the 1932 campaign. But he left no doubt that he understood the horror of the Depression, no doubt about his revolutionary plans to inject the Federal Government into economic planning, no doubt of his commitment to bold and humane experimentation.
Now as then, Americans do not expect their Presidents to have all the answers. But Americans want to be sure their next President is talking about the right problems, appreciates their despair and is committed to doing something, everything, to make their lives better.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The California Story

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Somewhere in this state, somewhere between the Mexican and Canadian borders, there must be Californians so interested in how the New Hampshire primary will go that it will influence their own thinking or voting.
There must be. The press, TV and politicians keep hammering it into our heads that New Hampshire voting is hugely important and will affect the nation, so pay paralyzed attention. 
 The only thing is, in a week of poking around I have not found a single Californian who is waiting for a cue from New Hampshire -- or anybody who knows such a person.
I found only people who feel that the voters of the most powerful state are fully qualified to choose among Democrats and between Democrat Whoever and President Bush without guidance from one of the smallest states.
Long-time, very long-time, Republicans told me that whatever happens in New Hampshire or any place else, election day will be tight for Mr. Bush in California. They know things are worse in California than in 1988, when he managed to win the state with a 3 percent majority. And they have a strong hunch that given the quizzical way the country looks at Mr. Bush right now, he could not win without this state's electoral votes.
You do not have to be a psychiatrist, just a listener, to discover that some Republicans are not yet putting their full muscle into the campaign. They feel Mr. Bush has been neither ideologically loyal nor polite enough to Ronald Reagan, their hero now and forever.
So Mr. Bush obviously will have to hustle to win in California -- hustle not just for the votes of that middle class everybody loves, but for the money, energy and shove of some of the upper class Californians who may not be as huggable politically anymore, but helped put the President where he is.
As for Democrats, including some leaning to Gov. Bill Clinton, they look at the list of candidates and can't quite believe that's all there is and that is all there is going to be. At every dinner, Democrats make lists of possible added starters. There are no new ones -- just the familiar few Senators (Bentsen, Gore, Bradley) and the one Cuomo. Talk goes on through the evening -- will one of them jump in and deliver the election victory Democrats can almost smell cooking in the oven but are not yet sure Governor Clinton can put on the plate.
Anyway, I am glad I am not a foreign correspondent in the U.S., say from Japan. Imagine trying to explain to readers in Hokkaido what New Hampshire is all about. For instance, why are 125,000 people, the number of Democrats who will vote in the primary and who would fit into Universal Studios tour buses on a good weekend, so important that they have to be interviewed by the press one by one?
How do you explain to Japanese why it should matter in the Napa Valley exactly how many votes are won in New Hampshire by a right-wing columnist with a thing against Zulus?
Statistically it seems strange that anybody thinks that Californians, who after all are smart enough to live in California, would be stupid enough to accept this New Hampshire hype.
In the arithmetic of politics, the opinions of California are more than 13 times as important as those of New Hampshire. California has 54 out of the country's 538 votes in the Electoral College compared to New Hampshire's 4. On election day that is the one, the only bottom line.
Talk about voting power as it ought to be counted, and California is 30 times as important. It has that many times the number of New Hampshire's million-odd.
If troubles are how attention should be judged, California has a variety as full as any state -- unemployment, smog, water feuds, migrant labor, welfare, crime, drugs. And it has an American reality not to be found in 98-percent-white New Hampshire -- burgeoning minorities demanding center stage.
And with all due homage to New Hampshire, California not only has more problems, it has a lot more artists, writers, scientists, engineers and other creators. If California does not move ahead, the chances are the rest of us, including New Hampshire, won't either.
So California is not waiting for New Hampshire to show the way, nor is any other state. That's the lead of the story, in Japanese or in English.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Bush on Health: Smart, Gutless

 BODY:
The health care plan President Bush presented yesterday in Cleveland strides in the right direction. It outlines creative ways to insure all poor families in the nation, promote group coverage and strip away legal obstacles to an efficient system of managed care. The plan also sets forth a vision of how costs could be controlled.
Yet this plan won't work. At decisive junctures, Mr. Bush cowers. He would cover the poor, but nearly strand the near-poor. He calls for consumers to choose cost-conscious insurance policies, but backs away from the single step that would make that happen. And he would encourage small firms to form large insurance pools, but fails to force their participation. 
 These are serious, but remediable flaws. With a few bold strokes, Congress could preserve the vision and correct the errors. The end product might not be ideal, but it would insure that no American need fear bankruptcy just because of illness.
Key elements of the plan include:
Coverage of the poor. Any poor family needing care would be automatically enrolled in an insurance plan. Families below the poverty line would qualify for a voucher worth up to $3,750 a year. States would be required to make available comprehensive insurance for that amount.
Unfortunately, the credit would be phased out too steeply. Even though the plan would also provide a new deduction for medical costs, near-poor families would still be strapped to pay their bills.
Cost control: The Bush plan can't control costs unless employees are pressed to choose low-cost plans among options provided by employers. But the White House backed down from the one measure that would work: limiting tax deductions for insurance premiums so that workers would be compelled to shop wisely. This is the plan's fatal flaw. Mr. Bush could have used the tax savings to pay for his $100 billion plan; instead, he made no firm financing proposal. Unless he summons the courage -- presumably after elections -- to cap tax-deductible insurance premiums, his plan crumbles.
Small-business insurance pools: Small firms have a strong incentive to hire only healthy workers to avoid high insurance costs. Mr. Bush would wisely encourage small employers to band together to buy insurance, but his proposal lacks bite. Small firms that go it alone shouldn't be allowed to write off insurance premiums from taxes.
Protecting the chronically ill: The Bush plan would forbid insurers from shunning the sickest people. But enforcing such regulations is notoriously difficult. The plan would cleverly overcome resistance, by requiring insurers who enroll individuals likely to be healthy -- say, young non-smokers -- to pay a small tax that would be used to compensate insurers who enroll individuals likely to become chronically ill, like the elderly.
Encouraging managed care: Mr. Bush accepts the idea that managed-care plans, run by sophisticated buyers, are best able to control costs and monitor quality. He wisely proposes to pre-empt state laws that stymie managed care. He would also provide financial incentives for the elderly to join health maintenance organizations and for the states to set up cost-effective H.M.O.'s for their Medicaid population.
It's easy to pick out flaws. The plan doesn't cover long-term care or adequately adjust vouchers for inflation or regional differences in costs. But the overarching vision is right: protect the poor and encourage cost-effective managed care. What's needed now is the guts to enforce the vision.

HEADLINE: Connecticut's Inescapable Pain

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell Weicker's new budget for Connecticut spreads harsh reality with a sharp knife. He offers a plan for real reductions in almost every category of state spending, remarkably free of fictitious savings. Some of his proposals cut too abruptly -- school aid, for example. But given the circumstances, his overall focus on cutting back is the only reasonable option.
After last year's bruising battle over the adoption of the state's new income tax, Mr. Weicker couldn't even contemplate proposing more taxes. Indeed, the issue is still so fractious that he even ignored sensible suggestions to make the income tax more palatable to middle-income taxpayers by adopting a fairer rate structure. 
 As a political independent, with no troops in the Legislature, Mr. Weicker plays a middle game -- successfully, so far. Democrats, who hold the majority in both houses, helped him get the income tax. This year he's banking on Republican support.
He has budgeted $8.1 billion. That's $400 million more than this year's spending, but the increase only mirrors the rising costs of such things as Medicaid and state employees' fringe benefits.
Another $800 million would have been needed to maintain all state programs at current levels; instead, he would cut almost all of them. Among his major targets: school aid, nursing homes, welfare, state employee benefits and the state payroll.
Commendably, he also proposes sensible reforms. He wants to repeal some statutes that mandate local outlays, particularly relating to municipal employees' pay and other compensation. And in cutting welfare payments, he proposes requirements that single adults seek work and that parents keep their children in school.
But his school aid cuts are a mixed bag; while there's more aid for large urban systems, some of the smaller, albeit wealthier, towns lose virtually all state funding in one devastating swoop.
As Mr. Weicker points out, Connecticut let the good times roll too far in the 1980's. Now the state is suffering from the particular severity of the recession in the Northeast, and from a disproportionate concentration of defense contractors -- United Technologies, Electric Boat and others -- whose booming business has shrunk with the ending of the cold war.
For Mr. Weicker -- and the Legislature -- there is no painless way out.

HEADLINE: Pittsburgh Journal;
Horror Is a Thing Of Beauty In a Movie

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Few legitimate industries can find their roots in horror and psychopathic killings, but that is the story of the growing film industry here.
 George Romero, the Pittsburgh-based impresario of horror, put the city on the map for filmmakers in 1967 with the cult film "Night of the Living Dead." And since Jonathan Demme shot "The Silence of the Lambs" here two years ago, Pittsburgh has been the backdrop for 23 major films and television movies. 
The emergence of Pittsburgh as a popular location has pumped $65 million into the local economy and pleased many, including the Rev. W. David Schorr of the Most Holy Name of Jesus Roman Catholic Church in Troy Hill, an enclave of ethnic Germans and Austrians.
 "You can bet your boots it's good," Father Schorr said recently in his rectory as carpenters were in the church parking lot recreating Jimmy Hoffa's Teamster Union Hall, circa 1935 Detroit. Danny Devito is directing "Hoffa," an HBO film starring Jack Nicholson as the teamsters' union leader and Mr. Devito as his right-hand man.
 Another movie, John Landis's "Innocent Blood," a thriller about a beautiful vampire who feeds on Mafia killers, will be shot this month inside the church's 125-year-old chapel, St. Anthony's Shrine of The Holy Relics, which has 5,000 relics of saints displayed the walls.
 "You name it, we've got it," Father Schorr said. "We have the whole body of Saint Demitrius under the altar, and we have Saint Anthony's tooth, but I don't know which one it is, to tell you the truth."
 Father Schorr said the diocese is strict about what takes place in the church. Fortunately, he said, Anne Parillaud, the French actress who plays the vampire in "Innocent Blood," does not enter the chapel. "I don't think the diocese would want us to use the church for vampires, because of the satanic connection," he explained.
 The church and its struggling grammar school expect to earn from $10,000 to $15,000 from the two film companies shooting the movie, plus whatever profits come from selling Mr. Landis 90 cases of candles to illume the chapel and its relics.
 Filmmakers, ever in search of new looks and cheaper production costs, began flocking to Pittsburgh after "Silence of the Lambs," a $20 million production that made $250 million. Pittsburgh is now on a list of the top 10 film locations compiled by Baseline, an information service for the entertainment industry.
 Still Pittsburgh, which last year landed 10 feature and television movies, is a mere footnote compared to the nation's top location, Los Angeles, with 217 productions, and the second-most-popular location, New York, with 123. But strikes, like last year's by cinematographers and stage hands in New York, and production problems have driven some business to places like Pittsburgh, Atlanta, Chicago and Boston.
 "We went to Pittsburgh because it's got a great look, with a lot of diversity in landscape and architecture," said Chris Brigham, the production manager for "Silence of the Lambs," a film about a serial killer.
 Most filmmakers find or create ways to make Pittsburgh look like somewhere else, like New York, Detroit or Memphis. But Pittsburgh has surprised some location scouts. "We wanted the film to have the feeling of a generic East Coast city with cold weather, but after we saw it, we decided Pittsburgh should be Pittsburgh," said Leslie Belzberg, producer of "Innocent Blood."
 The city owes its recent good fortune to Mr. Romero, said Robert M. Curran, director of the 2-year-old Pittsburgh Film Office. "He broke the ground for filmmaking here, and many people in the film industry have worked with him as a zombie or something," said Mr. Curran, who scouts locations and finds crews for film companies.
 In 1990 Mr. Romero filmed "The Night of the Living Dead, the Remake," a $4 million, color version of his $60,000 classic that depicts otherwise nice people becoming flesh-eating monsters after they themselves have been chewed up a bit by their monsterized friends and family members. The film has not yet been released, but last year Pittsburgh Magazine jumped the gun and named Mr. Romero "Man of The Year."
 The article also referred incorrectly to the remake of the film "Night of the Living Dead." The film, written by George A. Romero and directed by Tom Savini, was released in 1990.

 The article also misattributed a quotation praising Pittsburgh as a film location. It was from Ron Bozman, a producer of "Silence of the Lambs," not from Chris Brigham. Mr. Brigham, a film production manager, had no connection with "Silence of the Lambs."

HEADLINE: Accuser Flirted With Tyson, Witnesses Say

BYLINE: By E. R. SHIPP, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 6 -- When Mike Tyson's accuser first met the former heavyweight champion at a beauty pageant last July, she was "star-struck," flirted with him and was soon talking about his money, four witnesses testified today in his rape trial.
 One of the witnesses, Madelyn D. Whittington, a college senior from Ohio, testified that minutes after the 23 contestants in the Miss Black America pageant were introduced to Tyson, the accuser told her of plans to go out with him. 
Yes, of course, I'm going,' " Whittington quoted the woman as saying. " 'This is Mike Tyson. He's got a lot of money. He's dumb. You see what Robin Givens got out of him.' " Givens, the actress, is Tyson's former wife. Like Tyson's accuser, Whittington and the three other defense witnesses were contestants in the pageant.
 Tyson has been accused of raping the 18-year-old woman in the early hours of July 19. The testimony of the four witnesses was meant to bolster one of the main defense contentions: that his accuser is a gold digger who from the beginning viewed him as a source of wealth. Tyson conceded that he had sex with the woman, but he has insisted that she consented.
 
A Joke About Tyson
 Two of the witnesses, Cecellia Alexander and Parquita Nassau, recalled with almost the same words, a conversation between Tyson's accuser and another contestant, Pasha Oliver. Oliver, they said, jokingly referred to Tyson as the woman's husband and joked about how inarticulate he was.
 The witnesses said the woman's reply was: "Mike doesn't have to know how to speak. He'll make all the money and I'll do all the talking."
 Their testimony came after a one-day delay in the trial caused by a fire early Wednesday morning that heavily damaged the hotel in which the jurors were being sequestered. Two firefighters and a businessman were killed in the blaze, but none of the jurors were injured. One juror was apparently too shaken by the fire to continue today. The juror, a 36-year-old unemployed man, was replaced by one of the alternates, a 44-year-old telephone company employee.
 
'Was Not Arson'
 Local officials said today that the fire had probably been triggered by defective wiring in a refrigeration unit on the third floor of the hotel. But because the jurors were in the same hotel -- though on the sixth floor -- arson investigators have been trying to determine if the fire was more than just a coincidence.
 "All the preliminary indications are that this was not arson," Jeffrey Modisett, the Marion County Prosecutor, told reporters today.
 In presenting Tyson's case, his lead lawyer, Vincent J. Fuller, has contended that the woman fabricated the rape charge after discovering that she would be nothing more than "a one-night stand." If Tyson is convicted of rape, Fuller has said, the woman will find it easier to win a civil lawsuit and become, in his words, "a very wealthy woman."
 The defense has also asserted that during Tyson's 36-hour visit to this city, as part of the Indiana Black Expo, a lot of people saw his rude, even lewd, behavior.
 
Described as Friendly
 His accuser, they have implied, must have been aware of this conduct and, in still agreeing to go out with him, must have been consenting to his sexual advances. She has denied seeing or hearing anything that put her on notice about his intentions.
 But Christine Harris, one of the contestants who testified for the defense today, said she saw nothing offensive in Tyson's actions, even describing him as "friendly, shy and somewhat reserved."
 The other three all testified to sexually suggestive comments. Nassau said that when pageant officials introduced Tyson to the contestants during the rehearsal, he said that he wanted to have sex with all of them. "I'm a celebrity and we do that sort of thing," she recalled Tyson saying.
 During the opening ceremony later in the afternoon, she said, she ignored Tyson's advances. "If you don't want to go out with me, I can move on, cause I can have any one of these" women, she said Tyson had told her.
 Then, she said, he grabbed her buttocks. She asked why he was disrespecting her and he apologized, she said.
 Taken together, the witnesses painted a different portrait of Tyson's accuser than that which emerged last week. But during cross-examination, the prosecutors did elicit testimony that seemed favorable to them.
 All of them except Nassau said that they could not be sure that Tyson's accuser had heard his remarks or had seen his behavior. And all except Nassau said that the hugging and joking between Tyson and the woman had appeared to be innocent.
 Nassau said Tyson's accuser was aware that Tyson had asked several of the contestants. "I saw them cuddling with each other," she said in response to questioning by one of the defense lawyers, F. Lane Heard. "They looked like they were involved with each other."
 
Characterized as Naive
 But Nassau also provided the prosecution with the strongest support for its characterization of the woman. Nassau described her as naive and "not streetwise."
 In addition to the former contestants, the jury heard from a gynecologist, Dr. Margaret Watanabe, who said it was impossible to tell if the two small vaginal abrasions the young woman had were caused by a rape or by consensual sex.
 Last week a prosecution witness, Dr. James Akin, said he had performed 20,0000 pelvic examinations and that the abrasions that another doctor found on the woman were "incredibly unlikely to happen in consensual sex."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Issues;
Democrats All Agree Bush's Plan Fails to Meet Health-Care Needs

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
In New Hampshire and in Congress, President Bush's Democratic opponents are offering much more ambitious plans for overhauling the nation's medical-care system than the one he unveiled on Thursday.
Although no consensus exists on a particular plan, the Democrats are united in advocating more Government involvement in providing universal insurance coverage and restraining health-care costs. 
 Mr. Bush, on the other hand, would retain the Government's basic hands-off approach toward doctors, employer-paid insurance policies and private insurance companies.
 
3 Offer Specific Plans
 All the candidates, Democratic and Republican, agree that the Government must act to make health care affordable and readily available to everyone. Three of the Democratic Presidential contenders -- Bob Kerrey, Paul E. Tsongas and Bill Clinton -- have taken specific and competing positions on the issue.
Mr. Kerrey, a Senator from Nebraska, favors a system similar to Canada's, with coverage for all citizens at Government expense.
Mr. Tsongas, a former Senator from Massachusetts, supports "managed competition," in which insurers, doctors and hospitals would compete for contracts with large groups of citizens.
Mr. Clinton, the Governor of Arkansas, favors the "pay or play" system in which employers would be required to provide medical insurance for their workers or pay a special tax to support a Government insurance program.
The main Democratic plans before Congress generally follow one of these three approaches, although some Democratic lawmakers favor a full-scale nationalized system like the one in Britain.
The other two principal Democratic contenders, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, have been less specific. But they say they support some form of national health insurance. Mr. Harkin promises to call labor, business and Government leaders together and "preside at the head of the table" until they develop a comprehensive plan.
Some Republicans in Congress are also backing more ambitious plans than Mr. Bush. One measure sponsored by more than 20 Republican senators would help more people with tax credits and deductions than the Bush proposal would. The Republican plan would also give the Federal Government more authority to pre-empt state laws and regulations.
Political leaders agree that no comprehensive plan will be enacted this year. The Democrats in Congress will block Republican proposals, and the President would veto any Democratic plan that cleared Congress.
The only measure that stands a chance of passing is an incremental one sponsored by Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the Democratic chairmen of the tax-writing committees. It would make medical insurance more available and affordable to small businesses and make it easier for workers to change jobs without fear of losing insurance coverage.
But even if nothing is resolved this year, the election-year debate seems likely to pave the way for fundamental changes in the health-care system in the next Administration, regardless of who is elected President.
 
Strong Public Dissatisfaction
 The reason for the politicians' interest is clear: polls show enormous public unhappiness with the current medical-care system, in which 35 million Americans have no insurance and costs are rising yearly at more than double the overall inflation rate.
For instance, The New York Times/ CBS News Poll published last week found that three-quarters of all adults would like to see the Government spend more to provide affordable health care for all Americans.
There are several reasons why so many people now do not have medical insurance. In some cases their employers do not provide it, and they cannot afford coverage on their own.
In addition, more than half the people in the country with incomes below the official poverty line are not covered by Medicaid, the Federal-state program for the poor. That is because in most cases only families on welfare are eligible. In many states, the welfare cutoff is well below the poverty line, $10,857 for a family of three last year, and as a general rule the basic welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, covers only families with children.
In capsule, here are the main plans that are under discussion:
 
BUSH
 Main elements: Vouchers for poor people and tax deductions for the middle class to help pay for medical insurance from private companies. The insurance companies would be required to provide coverage to anyone willing to pay for it, regardless of pre-existing medical conditions. Small businesses would be encouraged to band together to buy health insurance for their employees, lowering the cost by spreading the risk. Health maintenance organizations and other arrangements less costly than fee-for-service medicine would be encouraged. Medicare and Medicaid funds would be cut to raise money to finance the plan.
Advantages: Those who cannot now afford insurance would get basic coverage. This plan would be less disruptive to doctors, hospitals and insurers than other proposals. Government would not intrude in the marketplace. Taxes would not be raised.
Disadvantages: Mr. Bush did not specify how the added cost, about $35 billion a year, would be met. With little incentive for employers to shop for insurance plans, it might not be easy to keep costs down. Insufficient provisions are made for adjusting the vouchers and deductions to account for inflation or for dealing with regional health-cost differences.
 
KERREY
 Main elements: Similar to Canada's system, the Government would impose new taxes to raise money that would be passed on to the states. Medicare, Medicaid and employer-based insurance would be scrapped. People could choose a state insurance policy or a private policy meeting minimum Federal standards. The private companies would be paid a fixed amount by the states for each person enrolled. States would set medical-service fees.
Advantages: Everyone would get full coverage without paying premiums. Costs could be regulated because state systems would operate under fixed budgets. States and private insurers would compete over which could provide better benefits, perhaps leading to savings. Workers would not have to depend on employers for insurance.
Disadvantages: Higher taxes would be needed, though they would be offset somewhat by the better wages employers, freed of insurance costs, would be able to pay. A Federal bureaucracy would replace the free-market system. Services might have to be rationed if state budgets fell short. Without the incentive of earning more money, health providers might not invest in improved technology.
 
TSONGAS
 Main elements: Insurance would be bought for everyone by a group like a large company, several small companies banded together, a labor union or a public plan financed by payroll taxes on employers. The unemployed and workers without steady jobs would be placed in the public plan. Private insurance companies and health maintenance organizations would bid for contracts from these groups.
Advantages: The groups would wield considerable market power. Costs would be restrained because insurers would compete to provide attractive services and because favorable fees could be negotiated with doctors. Experts would monitor quality of care.
Disadvantages: To hold down costs, most companies would contract with health maintenance organizations rather than allow fee-for-service medicine. That would limit consumers' choice of doctors. People who are bad risks because of their medical conditions could probably be forced into the public plans, costing the Government money. The system might not adequately control the rapidly rising cost of medical care.
 
CLINTON
 Main elements: Employers would have to insure all employees or pay an additional tax into a public fund to cover the uninsured. One such plan approved last month by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee would put the tax at 7.5 percent of payroll. A Government board would set national medical-care cost goals and perhaps actual prices.
Advantages: This would be less disruptive of the current system than the Kerrey or Tsongas approaches, would require little additional Federal financing and would keep insurance companies happy, which could make it acceptable politically. A big tax increase on workers would be avoided.
Disadvantages: If the payroll tax is set too low and costly conditions are placed on insurance plans, employers would opt to dump workers into the public plan. If the tax is set high, it would be an invisible tax on wages. Price controls could discourage doctors and hospitals from improving quality.
