HEADLINE: Japan's Unlikely Bidder for U.S. Pastime

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KYOTO, Japan, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Perhaps the most striking fact about Hiroshi Yamauchi, the president of the Nintendo Company Ltd., is that he cannot bear to play video games. "I really don't understand them," he said. The second most striking fact about Mr. Yamauchi, the first Japanese to bid for a controlling interest in an American major league baseball team, is that he has lived for 64 years in a nation obsessed with baseball and has never once gone to a game.
"Let me put it this way," Mr. Yamauchi said the other day in a 90-minute conversation in his office here, "Baseball, well, baseball has never really interested me."
 
 
In an Unlikely Position
 Such studied detachment, friends say, is characteristic of a man who is Japan's most unlikely high-tech success story, as well as an unlikely figure to be at the center of an international dispute over baseball ownership. 
 Mr. Yamauchi professed not to understand why his offer to buy 60 percent of the Seattle Mariners for $75 million, which would allow it to remain in Seattle, is the subject of such hot debate. To him, it is an attempt to help a city where Nintendo's American subsidiary employs more than 1,400 people and that his daughter, son-in-law and grandchildren have adopted as their home.
Seattle is also where he says he hopes Nintendo will eventually establish its world headquarters -- further complicating the question of what would constitute "foreign" ownership of an American team. The only question, he said, "is whether the Japanese Government will let me" move the company.
Americans did not become aware of Nintendo until the mid-1980's, as characters like the irrepressible "Super Mario Brothers" began dancing across home television screens. But in Japan, Nintendo is a name as old as some of Kyoto's majestic wooden temples.
 
 
Sold Playing Cards
 Shortly after the Meiji restoration 130 years ago, the start of modern, industrialized Japan, Mr. Yamauchi's ancestors began selling "karuta cards," a playing-card game based on seasonal flowers that was once popular among the Japanese elite. (It is still popular, but mostly as a gambling game played by Japanese gangsters.)
Mr. Yamauchi took over the company four decades ago, soon after Japan's defeat in World War II, and imagined that life would be much as it had been for his parents: a steady, not very flashy life selling playing cards.
"The truth is, I wasn't really thinking about entering new businesses," he said. But sales of karuta cards began to plummet, and Mr. Yamauchi faced an uncomfortable choice: Find a new business for Nintendo, or go out of business entirely.
Largely out of what he terms "a lack of imagination," he steered Nintendo into other games: board games, guns that shoot beams of light, baseball pitching machines and eventually arcade games. It was the last of these that gave birth to its huge video-game business.
But it is baseball -- rather than the alien-zapping games he has sold to one out of three American homes -- that has made Mr. Yamauchi the latest focus of emotionally charged debate about Japanese influence in America. Until this year, when his 880-person parent company is expected to make more money than giant Hitachi Ltd., Mr. Yamauchi prided himself in keeping out of the limelight. That ended when he found himself the center of criticism not only in the United States but also in Japan, where his bid has prompted uncomfortable questions about the openness of the Japanese sports world.
Would an American investor be allowed to buy into a "stable" of sumo wrestlers, controlling part of a sport that resonates deeply in the national psyche, like baseball in America. Or would an American company operating here be able to buy a Japanese baseball team, something no Americans have attempted?
"I imagine there are lot of opinions on this matter in the United States, but that is not of concern to me," Mr. Yamauchi said. "I thought about whether I could do a service to Seattle, and what others think about it, that is their business. If the people of America decided I cannot respond that way, it cannot be helped and I have to accept it."
 
 
Prospects Have Improved
 But in the last few days, Mr. Yamauchi's prospects seemed to improve. The other day, Fay Vincent, the baseball commissioner, seemed to be wavering a bit because control of the team would rest with American investors including Mr. Yamauchi's son-in-law, Minoru Arakawa, who runs Nintendo's American subsidiary and is expected to inherit the entire business soon. That may ultimately satisfy the letter of the policy. But in the end, of course, the money is Mr. Yamauchi's.
"Of course it is my money, and I'm glad I could pay it," he said. "But this is not business. What do I know about running a baseball team?"
A few years ago, Mr. Yamauchi could have said the same about running a video-game company. But he succeeded by pursuing a strategy that seems unlike those of other consumer electronics giants in Japan.
 
 
A Masterful Strategy
 Nintendo manufactures nothing itself. It farms out production of its video-game machines and other equipment to smaller suppliers throughout Japan, leaving the company with a relatively tiny staff and low overhead.
With no worries about building plants and cutting costs, Mr. Yamauchi focused on strategy. Nintendo had already missed the first wave of the American video-game craze, the one that marked the rise and fall of the Atari division of Warner Communications. Sitting in Kyoto, Mr. Yamauchi diagnosed the problem: Atari and others had lost control of the video-game software market, allowing poor-quality games to flood the market, undercutting prices and the reputation of the game systems.
His solution was quintessentially Japanese. Nintendo designed a system that could "lock out" software that did not use a patented computer chip. The company approved only a handful of programs every year -- apart from those designed by Nintendo's small staff of game engineers -- and assured that prices and profit margins stayed high.
 
 
Angered Software Makers
 It is a strategy that has made Nintendo phenomenally profitable: its sales tripled between 1987 and 1991, to $3.34 billion, and its net income rose to half a billion dollars. Along the way, Nintendo became intensely disliked on the software side of the game business. "We are at their mercy," an official of a software subsidiary of Atari told a Congressional committee nearly two years ago. "They can make or break any of us overnight."
Now Nintendo faces new challenges, chiefly from Sega, a company offering a new generation of 16-bit video game machines, allowing richer, more detailed and three-dimensional games. Nintendo's own 16-bit machine was delayed and made available in America in time for the worst Christmas selling season in years. The company is hoping for better timing in its next major release, video games on CD-ROM's, compact disks that contain video and data instead of music.
 
 
Planned In-Home Stock Trading
 Mr. Yamauchi has been hoping, as his career at Nintendo winds down, to be known for Nintendo's new drives into home stock-market trading -- video games with higher stakes -- and for the research the company sponsors at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on using video games as teaching tools.
More likely, he will be known for the battle he did not seek over the Mariners. Mr. Yamauchi said that when he made the bid, he thought he was returning a favor to the United States, "who helped us become such an economic power."
And what about the next logical step -- a Nintendo team for Japan, where many companies own professional baseball teams. After all, fans flock to watch the Nippon Ham Fighters, owned by a giant pork packager, and to cheer the perennial champions, the Yomiuri Giants, which belong to Yomiuri Shimbun, one of Japan's biggest newspapers. Wouldn't the Kyoto Super Marios -- perhaps with off-season help from Seattle -- be a sure-fire success?
Mr. Yamauchi grimaced. "I never even thought about a baseball team in Japan," he said. "Remember, I don't really like baseball."

HEADLINE: Japan Studies U.S. Workers

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The Japan Labor Ministry said today that by some measures American workers outproduce their Japanese counterparts.
The ministry divided the 1989 gross domestic product of each country by the number of workers in each country and found that American workers produce 1.62 times more than the Japanese, when the value of their work is calculated according to purchasing power. 
 According to the Labor Ministry, Americans surpassed the Japanese in terms of productivity per hour, partly because of the longer hours Japanese workers put in -- 42.3 hours a week in 1990 compared with 38.2 hours for United States workers.
But when productivity is calculated without considering purchasing power, using only the currency exchange rate to compare national output, American workers only produced 1.09 times as much as their Japanese counterparts, it said.
Yasuo Kuwashima, a ministry official, said the study was done at the request of Labor Minister Tetsuo Kondo, who recommended that such figures be released following remarks by Japanese politicians about American work habits.

HEADLINE: Weicker Divides the Poor by Family Size

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The welfare law proposed this week by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. makes sharp distinctions between poor single parents with children, who would by and large be protected, and the growing numbers of impoverished single men and women, many of whom might simply be thrown out.
Local officials and social services experts said that against the backdrop of welfare legislation being considered across the country, Mr. Weicker's proposals are very much a hybrid -- one part social engineering, one part plain old penny-pinching. 
 Like the law recently signed by Gov. Jim Florio in New Jersey, for example, the Connecticut plan seeks to modify the behavior of welfare recipients by tightening requirements -- that children be inoculated and enrolled in school, for example. No savings would result from those changes, and Connecticut would continue to have some of the most generous benefits in the nation for families with dependent children, ranging up to $680 a month in lower Fairfield County -- second only to Alaska.
But the other half of the Governor's welfare proposal, by contrast -- the aid for single individuals, called general assistance -- goes to the heart of the budget stress that has rocked Connecticut over the last year. There, the state would exact $107 million in cuts -- almost 10 percent of the total $1.1 billion in spending reductions outlined in Mr. Weicker's proposed budget.
 
'Employability' Standard
 The general assistance restrictions, similar to laws enacted last year in Michigan, Illinois and Ohio, would reduce aid or eliminate it entirely for perhaps two-thirds of the 35,000 people now enrolled in the program, according to estimates by the State Department of Income Maintenance.
In addition, a person deemed "employable" could receive aid for only 6 months out of any 12-month period.
"They'll become street people, I guess," said Norma E. Albright, the director of welfare for the City of New London, where the general assistance rolls have doubled in the recession. "There are no jobs here for them."
Neither the employability standard nor the six-month restriction is in the current law. Current rates of aid also vary widely across the state, and those rates would be standardized. For thousands of people, that would mean a cut.
In New Haven, for example, the city's Director of Welfare, Raymond M. Lopes, said the 4,800 people on general assistance receive up to $439 a month in combined food, personal and shelter allowances. That would fall to $356 a month under the Governor's plan, he said. In addition, Mr. Lopes estimated that one-half to two-thirds of the recipients have been on the program for six months or longer already. He said he had no idea what would become of them if the state were to deem them "employable."
"The changes come at the worst possible time," Mr. Lopes said. "There are no jobs in the area."
 
'Jobs and Children'
 Mr. Weicker, a former Republican who was elected in 1990 as a third-party independent, has consistently identified the priorities of his administration as "jobs and children." And in his budget speech before the General Assembly on Wednesday, that is how he presented his welfare plans.
The changes in general assistance, he argued, would tie the program more directly to the world of private employment because every recipient would be keenly aware from the start that help would not extend forever.
The changes in the family aid program, on the other hand, he termed an investment in the future. By strengthening the requirements to keep children in school, the cycle of welfare dependence could be broken, he said.
Officials at the welfare agency said the type of sanctions included in the New Jersey law, which allows outright cuts in family aid if a parent does not proceed toward getting a job, were deliberately avoided because the Governor saw such penalties as hurting children.
For the general assistance program, welfare experts said that the state's main problem would be establishing the new standards and definitions: Who is employable and who is not?
In Michigan, where a finding of employability now permits cutting off state aid, news reports have regularly identified bureaucratic blunders in which even hospitalized stroke victims have been denied benefits because a chart somewhere in the system listed them as fit for work.
 
Closing the Window
 "They're hard decisions to make, especially when the message coming down from the top is, 'We don't want to spend money,' " said Henry A. Freedman, director of the Center on Social Welfare Policy and Law, a New York-based group.
Mr. Freedman said another tough moment could come for Connecticut when the first six-month window expires. In Ohio, for example, which imposed a six-months-and-out standard last year, the first cutoff date will come on April 1, when 130,000 people could see benefits terminated. In Illinois, Mr. Freedman said, the state adopted a nine-month window for this year, and six months beginning next year. About 85,000 people will be caught by that state's April 1 cutoff.
Officials in Connecticut estimate that 42 percent of the 35,000 people on general assistance are employable. Of the total roster, 59 percent are men, and 30 percent have substance-abuse problems. The average age is 35 and the average level of education is 10th grade. Some 44 percent are black, 31 percent are Hispanic and 24 percent are white.

HEADLINE: Trying to Turn Around the Clark Bar

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
Nine months ago, the Clark candy bar, a rich concoction of peanut butter, taffy and milk chocolate, seemed doomed. A favorite in the Midwest and parts of the East, the Clark bar never had a national presence and its owner wanted to close its factory here.
That's when Michael P. Carlow, a 40-year-old Pittsburgh businessman who has made money in steel, glass, cement and the turnaround of Iron City beer, bought the D. L. Clark Company from Leaf Inc., the Chicago candy conglomerate. Now, not only is the Clark bar still being produced and packaged in its eye-catching red-and-blue wrapper, there are some early signs that Mr. Carlow may succeed where a candy giant stumbled. 
 "All the Clark bar needs is special attention, and it will do fine, Mr. Carlow said in an interview here recently. "There is, after all, a certain magic about candy."
Mr. Carlow has already won rent concessions from the State of Pennsylvania, which owns Clark's modern candy factory here; he is trying to get the crucial support of D. L. Clark's candy brokers, who have the power to decide whether Clark bars appear in stores and vending machines, and he has begun exploring how the company's fixed costs can be trimmed to make it easier to turn a profit. One possibility: have Clark employees share more of the costs of their health benefits.
Although Mr. Carlow will not disclose the terms of his purchase, or the financial performance of his private company, he predicts that he can make money if he can sell 50 million Clark bars a year. Under a big company with big costs like Leaf, D. L. Clark needed to exceed that level to break into the black, which under Leaf it never managed to do regularly. In its last year with Leaf, Clark made 35 million bars, only a third of its production capacity.
But candy experts say Mr. Carlow's Clark bar rescue could fail. While a few smaller candy brands have prospered in recent years, like Goldenberg's Peanut Chews, which are made in Philadelphia, and the Annabelle Candy Company's Big Hunk and Look bars, which are made in Hayward, Calif., many small confectioners have vanished, victims of the hard economics of the candy business.
"It's not easy being the little guy in a world dominated by giants," said John M. McMillin, the candy industry analyst at Prudential Securities Inc. "To survive, Carlow will have to be twice as good as Mars and Nestle."
The chocolate candy bar business in America is a classic oligopoly. Three players -- Hershey, M&M/ Mars and Nestle -- control 90 percent of the industry's $5.2 billion in annual sales. Leaf, whose brands include Whoppers, Milk Duds and Jolly Rancher candies, probably has another 5 percent. And while there continue to be a healthy number of regional chocolates, the bar business belongs to the big national brands like Mars's Snickers and Milky Way; Nestle's Baby Ruth, and Hershey's milk chocolate bar and its Reese's peanut butter cups.
 
Gaining Shelf Space
 This huge concentration and huge volumes -- there are roughly 15 regular-sized Snicker bars sold for every Clark bar -- enable big candy makers to gobble up crucial shelf space at checkout stands in groceries, drugstores, convenience stores and the other places where most candy is sold. Big companies can also afford large sales forces that help move candy to retailers.
"The big guys are in the stores every week," noted Janette Kitt, a leading industry consultant based in Sparta, N.J. "They are constantly able to not only obtain distribution but to maintain it."
Big-selling national brands also can afford fat promotional budgets that often amount to tens of millions of dollars. They can offer discount coupons to consumers, and provide retailers with special promotions and services, like the "midget" sizes of candy for Halloween. They can also afford to give away candy to fatten retailers' profits.
That makes Clark a midget among giants, with distinct disadvantages. Clark cannot afford to spend millions of dollars on anything; its sales last year were estimated at $13 million. It has to rely on independent distributors and wholesalers to sell its candy to retailers who usually do not want to bother with a low-volume brand. Although per-capita candy consumption, at 20 pounds a year, is nearly at a record in the United States, the dollar volume of candy sold in this country has shrunk in recent years after adjusting for inflation.
"It's very simple," said Leonard G. Teitelbaum, the candy industry analyst at Merrill Lynch. "If you've got a leading market share and you can show the supermarket guy that your product sells, the buyer will put your product out there."
 
Some Positive Factors

 
 But Mr. Carlow does not face impossible odds. His first job, industry experts say, will be to convince the brokers who distribute the Clark bar that the bar has the potential to succeed over the long term. Partly, they say, this will be an exercise in persuasion, but Mr. Carlow could end up having to pay his brokers more than the standard 5 percent commission.
"Remember, these are the same brokers who didn't do much with the Clark bar under Leaf," said Stuart Scherr, the president of L&S Sales, a big candy broker based in San Francisco.
At one time, Leaf poured money into Clark by trying to make it a national brand. But "we just could not break into the menu of consumers outside the Midwest," said James Hanlon, president of Leaf.
Mr. Carlow has met wth most of Clark's wholesalers but he concedes that he still has to whip up excitement for the 106-year-old bar. Over the years, Clark bars reached a peak of 180 million bars annually, but the company was bought and sold so many times that it fell into neglect as sales waned. Now, Mr. Carlow says, "it is still being viewed as a stepchild."
One of Mr. Carlow's intentions is to heighten Clark's visibility. He plans to spend 5 percent of sales on marketing and advertising, up from 1.5 percent. One early effort will be in Pittsburgh, where Clark bars have been a hit in the past and Mr. Carlow hopes some promotional efforts will pay off quickly. Clark will sponsor sports events here like hockey games and tennis matches, and do promotional activities aimed at young people in nearby regions of Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia. Miniature Clark bars were recently given away to 15,000 hockey fans attending a Pittsburgh Penguins game.
Mr. Carlow plans a string of new products to help cover his fixed costs; Clark already makes Slow Poke and Black Cow, two caramel suckers sold regionally. The Clark bar has 9 grams of fat and 250 calories; Mr. Carlow said he was working on a Clark Light bar that would have half the fat and 165 calories. He also hopes to offer a Clark Classic, which would have a milk-based caramel core, as the original bar did, instead of the current bar's taffy center.
 
Rivals Are Moving Too
 Whether all this will make the Clark bar a financial success is far from certain. For one thing, the competition has also been developing new products. Mars, for instance, has recently come out with mint- and peanut-butter-flavored M&M's to complement its M&M plain and peanut brands. Nor is the competition likely to sit still if Mr. Carlow beefs up marketing of the Clark bar. Hershey has already stepped up advertising of its competing bar, the Fifth Avenue.
The risk is that Mr. Carlow might whip up so much fresh excitement for the Clark bar that an industry Goliath decides to trample him. Mr. Teitelbaum of Merrill Lynch said: "Hershey & Mars will not ignore him. The only question is whether the Clark bar remains something they can live with."

HEADLINE: All Aboard for Influence, Donations and Votes

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Somewhere just outside Baltimore, Priscilla Anderson, a freshman Assemblywoman, squeezed and pushed her way through a knot of people in a smoke-filled railroad car and opened the door to the next car.
"Is this the last car?" the nearly exhausted Ms. Anderson exhausted. To her delight, it was. 
 In a political rite that is unique to New Jersey, Ms. Anderson and about 1,400 other politicians, business people and lobbyists opened the state's political season Thursday by riding a train from Newark to Washington, then joining the state's Congressional delegation for dinner.
The New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce began the ritual 54 years ago to provide a means for business people to meet and lobby the Congressional delegation. Over the last 25 years, the four-hour train ride has come to signal the start of the campaign season in New Jersey; to politicians and business leaders who spend most of the trip on their feet, prowling the crowded aisles, shaking hands and trying to wangle favors, the "walk to Washington" has become indispensable.
 
'Seeing and Being Seen'
 "Anybody who is trying to establish a presence in a statewide political race in New Jersey rides this train," said William R. Healey, a lobbyist and spokesman for the State Chamber of Commerce. "It is a unique way of seeing and being seen."
The chamber began the train ride and Congressional dinner in 1937, and except for two years during World War II when trains were not available -- 1942 and 1943 -- and 1974, during the height of the energy crisis, it has been an annual event.
"It really goes back to 1936, when there was a reception held in Newark for the New Jersey Congressional delegation and it was poorly attended," Mr. Healey said. "So the chamber decided to take Mohammed to the mountain."
To the uninitiated, the journey seems to be a pub crawl on wheels; every fourth car is a bar car, and drinks are mixed and served from many seats that have become impromptu hospitality suites.
 
A Maiden Voyage
 "I don't know what to expect," said Thomas S. Smith as he stepped aboard the train in Trenton. It was the maiden chamber trip for Mr. Smith, the Mayor of Asbury Park who was elected to the Assembly as a Republican last Nov. 5, and he had no problem acknowledging his apprehension. "I think I'll just be an observer this time," he said.
At stations in Newark, Metro Park, New Brunswick and Trenton special-interest groups handed out fliers by the hundreds -- a labor union urging the travelers to support Gov. Jim Florio's economic recovery plan, a group advocating national health insurance and a coalition of political consultants taking a Presidential straw poll.
A radio station gave away key chains, college presidents passed out pencils and the Essex County Sheriff, Armando B. Fontoura, deputized the entire train, passing out cards emblazoned with gold shields that designate the bearers as honorary special deputies for 1992.
Despite the carnival atmosphere, the train ride has become an important part of New Jersey's political gamesmanship.
"What's important is who is seeking whom and why," said the Hudson County Executive, Robert C. Janiszewski, a Democrat and a veteran of 14 train rides. "The politicians with the real clout are usually in the middle cars, where everybody passes by and comes to them."
 
'A Captive Audience'
 Holding audiences in the eighth and ninth of the train's 14 cars were the leaders of the newly powerful Republican Party -- the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco; the Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, and Assemblyman Robert Franks, the chairman of the Republican State Committee. The Republicans took control of both houses of the Legislature on Jan. 14.
"You have a captive audience here, at least for four hours," Mr. DiFrancesco said. "It's important that the businessmen get to spend a few minutes with Haytaian, Franks and me."
Mr. Florio missed this year's train ride because he had to be in Washington early Thursday to testify before a Congressional committee. But like every other New Jersey politician, he has made many a "walk to Washington." "This train is full of people who are and people who want to be," said a senior Democratic staff member in the State Senate.
With no major statewide races scheduled, this year's train ride was a bit less hectic than most, Mr. Franks said.
Still, dozens of public relations representatives plowed through crowded cars with clients in tow, creating human traffic jams as they stopped to introduce legislative movers and shakers.
"Say, I have a friend . . ." said one businessman, breaking the ice with a politician.
"Who hasn't," came the clipped reply.
Working one end of the train was William Gormley, a Republican State Senator who is expected to seek his party's gubernatorial nomination next year.
Near the other end of the train, another potential Republican gubernatorial contender, Christine Todd Whitman, worked the crowd.
"You can't really get into anything serious while on the train," said Ms. Whitman, who came within a percentage point of upsetting Senator Bill Bradley in 1989. "But there is no question that this train ride is obligatory for any statewide political candidate because of the contacts you make."

HEADLINE: Gas Price War Lures Drivers to New Jersey

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 4

 BODY:
The customers line up early and late at Nick and George Kambitsis's Raceway gas station here, drivers in everything from Jaguars to old pickup trucks. They are waiting patiently to cash in on an early harbinger of spring, the old-fashioned gasoline price war, which has pushed regular unleaded down to 89 cents a gallon at some stations here and to less than a dollar at most others.
These are the state's lowest gas prices in five years, according to the New Jersey Petroleum Council, and up and down State Highway 18, sellers of such major brands as Exxon, Sunoco and Texaco have similarly, and angrily, pushed their prices down. The big names are chasing Raceway and other independent retailers who are taking advantage of a glut, caused by the recession and mild weather, that promises to last into the summer. 
 The customers are delighted, and drivers from neighboring New York and Pennsylvania say they often detour several miles to buy gas at prices 30 and 40 cents a gallon less than they pay at home.
"After being ripped off by the oil companies for years, I feel like I'm finally getting something back," said Clarke Evans, a printing materials sales and service representative from White Plains who regularly gets off the New Jersey Turnpike to gas up here for 89 cents a gallon. At home, he said, stations charge $1.19 for the same 87 octane unleaded regular.
 
Lower and Lower Prices
 "And that's for self-service," he said. "In Jersey, they pump it for you."
The owners and tenants of major-brand stations, who must buy gas at higher prices under their contracts with refiners, curse those who discount and complain that they will be driven out of business unless prices rise. Yet they have little choice but to post lower and lower numbers on the big signs the law requires them to display at the roadside.
"Some of these independents are selling for 10 or 15 cents under what I have to pay for it," said Pat Pontoriero, who with his brother, Joseph, owns J & P Auto Service Sunoco at Tices Lane, about a mile north of the Raceway station. "But they've got us in this price war, and if they can sell for their price, the rest of us have to keep up."
So Mr. Pontoriero is selling his economy unleaded at 99 cents a gallon. Raoul Pangalinan, who runs the Texaco station to the south, is doing the same for his regular grade. The Hess station at Cranbury Road is charging 93 cents a gallon, and the Merit station, across the highway and a little north of J & P Sunoco, advertises unleaded regular at 89 cents.
Even before the price war, New Jersey enjoyed comparatively cheap gasoline. It is a particular bargain when compared to New York City, where the state Energy Office reports prices average $1.33 for full service. In the Hudson Valley and on Long Island, the office says, the average is about $1.32. In southwestern Connecticut, the state has found an average price of $1.37 a gallon for full service. Self-service prices are generally 5 to 8 cents a gallon cheaper, although the margin can be greater depending on local labor costs and other factors.
 
Accounting for Prices
 In contrast, the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection and Energy found an average price of $1.11 for regular unleaded with full service. New Jersey prohibits self-service stations.
Part of the price difference is a result of lower state taxes, which amount to 14.5 cents a gallon in New Jersey, compared with 24.7 cents in New York State and 29.6 cents in Connecticut, according to the American Petroleum Institute. All states also charge a Federal motor fuel tax of 14.1 cents a gallon.
Another reason for low prices is New Jersey's role as a petroleum shipping and refining center, with three major regional refineries, Exxon's in Linden, where the Colonial petroleum pipeline from Texas and the Gulf states also terminates, Amerada-Hess in Woodbridge and Mobil and Coastal in Gloucester County, in southern New Jersey.
But all of this is mere detail to Lynda Garritson, a single mother of two children who drove from New Brunswick, six miles away, to fill up here at 89 cents a gallon, 15 cents less than the $1.04 posted price at home. The savings, she said, are worth the extra gas she burns on her trip.
"These gas prices are the one good thing I can see in the economy," said Ms. Garritson, who supports her children on child-support payments from her former husband and occasional temporary office work. "Nobody has any extra money to spend around here, so at least if gas prices are going down, we've got something to smile about."
Nick Kambitsis, who with his brother owns seven other Raceway stations in the area, sits in his cramped, windowless office behind the cash register and works with a fax machine and a phone to find the cheapest gas available.
"Price war? We're not starting a price war," he said, cheerfully indignant. "We just try to keep to a fixed profit margin, and when the spot price moves, we move with it."
Right now, the spot market stands at 52 cents a gallon. Add 28.6 cents a gallon in state and Federal taxes, and the Kambitsis brothers keep about nine pennies for each of the 20,000 gallons they pump 6 A.M. to midnight each day, here on Highway 18. From that they pay their overhead at the station and the wages of eight attendants who seem to be in constant motion in their bright red coveralls, leaping over hoses and darting between the idling cars, trying to keep the customers going out as fast as they come in.
While there is no evidence of price wars in other parts of the state or the region, station operators readily admit that they are doing all they can to keep the peace.
Bill Denson, who operates stations in Somerville and Martinsville, N.J., dropped his price for regular unleaded at the Somerville station from $1.04 to $1.01 when sales began to sag last week. He would like to avoid going under the psychological $1 threshold, he said, but the balance is a delicate one.
"I try to maintain a certain volume," he said, "but at the same time I don't want to cut too much or start to undercut the other guy. Then you get into a price war, and nobody benefits."
Nobody, he could have added, but the customer.

HEADLINE: Consumer Credit Off for First Year Since '58

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Wary consumers paid off more debt than they took on in 1991, causing installment credit to shrink for the first year since 1958, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
The 1 percent fall in oustanding credit was another sign that spending was unlikely to pick up soon in an economy that relies on consumer spending for two-thirds of its growth. 
 Credit owed by consumers fell to $728.4 billion on Dec. 31, dropping $1.72 billion after a $170 million decrease in November. In 1990, consumer credit rose by 2.3 percent from the previous year.
Every major credit category shrank in December, with the exception of borrowing for mobile homes. In particular, the total that consumers owed on automobile loans was paid down by $689 million after falling by $1.89 billion in November and by $207 million in October.
 
Fewer Auto Loans
 Auto loan balances decreased every month in 1991, a measure of Americans' reluctance to take out loans for new cars when job conditions are so uncertain.
The latest unemployment report, published by the Labor Department, is likely to aggravate consumer concerns. Some 91,000 more non-farm jobs were lost last month and the unemployment rate stayed at 7.1 percent.
The latest credit figures reinforce a trend among consumers, who are being offered the lowest interest rates in decades but are reducing their indebtedness.
In the past, policy makers counted on lower rates to promote spending that in turn led to increased production and renewed hiring.
 But with more people losing their jobs, workweeks shortening and hourly wages falling, consumer confidence has fallen to levels not seen in more than a decade.
 
 
Credit-Card Debt Off
 In December, credit-card debt dropped by $207 million, despite the Christmas shopping season. Credit-card debt had grown by $1.01 billion in November and by $1.59 billion in October.
Bank credit, aside from home mortgages, was reduced by $876 million in December after growing by $599 million in November.
The only category that expanded was for mobile homes, which grew by $50 million after increasing by $116 million in November and by $51 million in October.
In 1958, the last year when consumers reduced their debts, the economy was entering a recession.

HEADLINE: U.N. Group Offers Plan to Control Pollution Through a Quota System

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 7

 BODY:
A group of experts sponsored by the United Nations is proposing cheaper and more efficient ways to control global air pollution by creating a worldwide market in pollution permits.
The plan is the most ambitious yet in the effort to control harmful emissions through the forces of the free market. It would for the first time put a worldwide price on one or more of the pollutants blamed for global warming. 
 The plan, commissioned by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development and released in Geneva last week, would set national quotas on emissions. Those governments or private groups that found it too difficult or too costly to meet their limits could buy pollution allowances abroad. Countries that polluted less than their quota could sell their allowances to other nations.
Proponents of the plan hope the concept will be approved in June at the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development in Rio de Janeiro. Lawyers, economists and energy specialists have worked for more than a year to prepare the plan.
 
Global Plan for Global Problem
 The proposal is a break with the common practice of tackling environmental problems through national and local regulations and rules.
People who prepared the plan acknowledge that a global system for pollution licenses and quotas for rich and poor nations will be difficult to negotiate. But they say that as long as there are clear benefits and incentives, the rapidly growing concern about climatic change does make such a plan possible.
Supporters note that the world's governments are already moving toward a consensus: limits must be placed on gases that can warm the earth. But there is wide disagreement on the size of the necessary cuts.
"Everyone recognizes that climate change is a global problem, so this is a first practical mechanism that can work on a global scale," said Frank Joshua, coordinator of the group that produced the plan.
 
Smaller Steps Expected First
 Even if a universal system cannot be put into place in the near future, those who have worked on the plan say they are confident that limited bilateral or multilateral agreements among countries could start in a matter of months.
Pollution experts say they are encouraged because the concept of trading pollution allowances is already gaining ground among policy makers. The European Community is discussing a 12-country plan for trading sulfur-emissions permits, and the concept is actually working on a small scale in the United States, where the Clean Air Act gave companies the right to trade in sulfur-dioxide allowances to reduce acid rain.
And last week, regulators in Southern California tentatively approved a plan to let companies trade pollution rights, beginning with emissions of nitrogen oxides.
 
'An Enormous Change'>
 Some environmentalists have reservations about the United Nations plan because it would effectively grant companies and governments permission to continue polluting. They argue that it would also let sellers of pollution entitlements make money off the fact that people elsewhere kept using so-called dirty energy like coal and oil.
But proponents, among them several longtime environmentalists, argue that pollution happens anyway and has long been free. By creating permits and credits, the plan would put a price on carbon dioxide, the initial target. Emissions could be valued in units of 100 or 1,000 tons produced.
"This would be an enormous change," said Tom Tietenberg, an American economist and expert in tradable permits who has worked on the global plan. "This means using the market to pursue environmental objectives rather than just economic objectives. Until now, the market has been seen as a powerful adversary, and environmentalists have wanted to block it at every turn. It's an attempt to make this powerful force work for you rather than against you."
 
Quotas for Carbon Dioxide
 In its first stage, the United Nations proposal calls for a binding international treaty to set a global limit on carbon dioxide emissions, which makes up the bulk of the so-called greenhouse gases widely thought to be warming the earth's atmosphere.
Quotas would then be set for how much carbon dioxide each country would be allowed to produce. Countries that produced less than their quotas would earn pollution credits that could be traded or sold to countries wanting to exceed their quotas.
"The purpose is to reduce waste, to get as much control as possible for the same dollar spent," said Mr. Tietenberg, an economics professor at Colby College in Waterville, Me. "If the U.S. has to cut emissions and it can look only within its own borders, there will be limited opportunities to do this at low cost. In Eastern Europe and other developing countries there are many opportunities to reduce emissions more cheaply."
Planners recommend starting off with carbon dioxide because, Mr. Joshua said, "its properties are well known; it's the largest proportion of gases produced; it can be measured."
A nation's output of carbon dioxide can be relatively easily estimated through its energy consumption. Other factors would be considered, like the seasonal fires in some parts of the world to clear fields and forests. If a system works for carbon dioxide, planners envision expanding it to cover other polluting gases.
 
All Nations May Benefit
 The experts who worked on the plan, which was financed by Norway and the Netherlands, said one basic guideline was that a global pollution-control program would have the best chance for success if all the participants saw benefits. Thus, the authors stress that buying or leasing emission permits can suit rich industrial countries where rules and standards can be very expensive to put into force and may not work anyway.
For developing countries, on the other hand, the plan would respond to a persistent demand: that the wealthy, industrialized nations, which are the world's greatest polluters, must provide expertise and money if they want the poorer nations to change environmentally harmful practices. Developing countries, which pollute less, would get pollution rights above their current needs and thus build up a surplus.
This surplus would leave a margin for future use so as not to inhibit industrial growth. But in the meantime they could lease or sell their surplus credits to other nations.
Some private projects of this kind are already under way. A Dutch utility, which was paying heavy taxes for exceeding its quota of carbon and sulfur emissions, is now financing a $35 million plant in Poland. The utility found that by spending that amount on its already finely tuned Dutch power stations, it could remove only 6,000 tons of sulfur -- just a small percentage. But for the same amount of money in Poland, it can remove 45,000 tons of sulfur a year. To finance this effort, the utility got Government approval to increase its rates to consumers and to use part of its money that would otherwise go toward taxes.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Digital Sets Plan to Build Its Own PC's

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAYNARD, Mass., Feb. 7

 BODY:
In an effort to increase its profit margins in the highly competitive personal computer market, the Digital Equipment Corporation is going to start building its own personal computers, possibly at manufacturing plants in the United States. The move represents an abrupt turnabout from its strategy of selling only PC's manufactured by Tandy, Intel and Olivetti.
The move was a surprise to analysts because Digital had won praise for its resale strategy. In addition, The company had built various PC's that failed in the market over the last decade. The main difference now is that the machine it plans to build is a low-price I.B.M. clone similar to what it has been buying from others. 
 John F. Smith, Digital's senior vice president for operations, said the plan to build PC's had always been part of Digital's strategy "if we reached certain volumes." He added that Digital would start building a new generation of PC's in Taiwan and quite possibly in the company's Albuquerque, N.M., plant.
 
Trying to Keep Profits
 Mr. Smith said that until this new generation of products was ready for shipping, which would be "very soon," the company would continue to buy from the other manufacturers. But he added that "instead of putting the profits into the pockets of Tandy and Olivetti, we'd just as soon put it in our own pockets."
A spokesman for the Tandy Corporation would not comment other than to say that the company anticipated doing business with Digital in the future.
Digital is also planning to announce on Monday a significant marketing and development agreement with Novell Inc. of Provo, Utah. George Colony, president of Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., said the two companies would announce that Digital would support Novell's popular Netware software on its computers.
It is also expected that Digital will resell Netware to its customers and will cooperate on joint research and development with Novell for future offerings. Netware allows networks of personal computers to work together and share files, electronic mail and data bases.
 
Surprised at Recent Report
 On another subject, Mr. Smith expressed surprise at an article that appeared in The Wall Street Journal today that said Digital planned to cut $400 million out of its $1.6 billion research and development budget. He said the company was simply continuing its recent cost-cutting strategy and "engineering was never exempt from this."
He added that last week Digital announced to its executives a significant restructuring of the entire company that would involve consolidating many units including engineering. "I don't know if the figure will be $400 million," he said. "We are going to save some dollars and I won't know how much that will be until I get a final consolidation plan from engineering, and that won't be for another two months. I sure hope it's $400 million."
Mr. Smith said he could not be sure whether the company would need to take another restructuring charge to cover the continued cost-cutting. Digital has already taken $1.65 billion in restructuring charges in the last two years, and the company has nearly $800 million worth of those charges remaining on its books that it expects to use by the end of June.
 
'Playing Musical Chairs'
 Terry Shannon, an analyst in Ashland, Mass., called it "a pretty dramatic shake-up." He continued, "They are playing musical chairs in Maynard with the senior executives and they are taking away a lot of the chairs."
According to the internal memo obtained by The Journal, Digital's president, Kenneth H. Olsen, was upset about Digital's second-quarter earnings statement, which showed Digital's first quarterly loss in the company's 35-year history. The memo indicated that the current reorganization was a result of Mr. Olsen's annoyance at the bad quarter, but Mr. Smith insisted that the moves were simply part of the company's plan to streamline operations.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Digital's share price rose 50 cents today, to $53.375.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Sharp Losses In Reaction to Jobs Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined sharply on world currency markets yesterday after the release of disappointing employment data.
Gold prices also lost ground after rising in Europe. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $355 an ounce, off 70 cents from Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold slid 80 cents, to a late price of $354.50. 
 The Labor Department reported that the United States unemployment rate held at 7.1 percent in January. But traders focused instead on a separate survey of employers' payrolls that showed an unexpectedly large loss of 91,000 jobs. Dealers were expecting a gain of 20,000 to 30,000 jobs.
"The dollar came off clearly on the disappointment over the figures," said Richard Levine, a foreign exchange broker at Merrill Lynch Futures Inc.
The sentiment in the currency markets, he said, had been that in the first month of the year the economy was beginning to pick up. "It may still end up that way," he added, "but any sporadic indication that that might not be true is going to rattle the market."
The surge in job losses led to speculation that the Federal Reserve might lower interest rates. Lower rates make dollar-denominated securities less attractive to investors, thereby diminishing their need for dollars.
Higher rates overseas are competing for investors' money. Traders said that currently there was little to focus on other than the differences in interest rates.
Despite the dollar's decline, many expect the economy to pick up in the second quarter. "I view this as one of the few remaining dollar selloffs," Mr. Levine said.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose before the release of the unemployment report, to a closing 125.52 Japanese yen from 125.40 yen at Thursday's close. Later in London, it fell to 125.20 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 125.30 yen, down from 125.65 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8370, from $1.8200 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.8370 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.8215.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5595 German marks, down from 1.5765; 1.3910 Swiss francs, down from 1.4065; 5.3150 French francs, down from 5.3725; 1,174.25 Italian lire, down from 1,187.00, and 1.1781 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1809.

HEADLINE: Rose Hirschman, 87, A Real-Estate Lawyer

 BODY:
Rose Korn Hirschman, a real-estate lawyer and volunteer at the United Nations and other organizations, died Jan. 24 at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.
She died of liver failure, her family said. 
 Born in Manhattan, she grew up there and in Brooklyn. She earned her undergraduate and law degrees at New York University. She began practicing law in Manhattan with her brother, Ashton Korn, and after his death worked on her own.
For nine years she represented the International Federation of Women Lawyers at United Nations commissions dealing with discrimination, minorities, women, economics, crime, commodities trade, human rights and population growth.
She was a past president of the Sisterhood of the Community Synagogue, vice president of the Congregation Emanuel Sisterhood and chairwoman of its youth activities and board member of the Young Women's Hebrew Association. She headed the Mount Vernon branch of the American Red Cross and served on the board of its Westchester County chapter. She was also on the boards of the Mount Vernon Nursing School and Mount Vernon Hospital and founded the hospital's volunteer services.
Her husband, Dr. Sol Hirschman, is dead. She is survived by two daughters, Judge Aileen Hirschman Belford of Fall River, Mass., and E. Judith Hirschman Berger of Manhattan; a son, Dr. Richard James Hirschman of Manhattan, and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Music Notes;
Composers Orchestra Defies the Conventional

BYLINE: By Allan Kozinn

 BODY:
The American Composers Orchestra contradicted two points of conventional wisdom when it announced some ambitious plans for its 1992-93 season. Although the orchestra's specialty, 20th-century American music, is widely considered the province of the new-music fringe, Jesse Rosen, the orchestra's executive director, said that the ensemble's ticket sales had tripled since 1985. And although many organizations have concluded that the prudent thing to do in a recession is cut back on performances, the American Composer's Orchestra is expanding its schedule to five concerts, up from four this season.
The orchestra has also just appointed its first music director, Dennis Russell Davies. Mr. Davies, who is 47 years old, was not a surprise choice. He was one of the orchestra's founders (with the composers Francis Thorne and Nicolas Roussakis and the conductor Paul Lustig Dunkel, all of whom are still involved with the group), and he has been principal conductor since 1977. His new contract begins this season and runs for three years. 
 "The American Composer's Orchestra is the organization I've had the longest association with in my career," said Mr. Davies, who is also the music director of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and of the city of Bonn, Germany. "And because I have conducted the orchestra in one or two concerts a year, many people assumed that I was music director. But we didn't work that way. Becoming the director is a way for me to reaffirm my commitment to the orchestra, and to take a hand in determining its future."
The orchestra has also just signed a three-year, three-disk contract with Argo Records that obliges the organization to contribute toward recording costs. Mr. Rosen said the orchestra's recording activities, together with the 25 percent increase in its concert schedule, might push the organization's 1992 budget as much as 40 percent higher than the current $900,000. Some of the money will come from a recent $175,000 grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation. Mr. Rosen said he was about to begin raising the rest.
Mr. Davies's plans for the immediate future include conducting three of next season's five concerts. The others are to be conducted by Mr. Dunkel and by James DePreist. The schedule includes world premieres of works by John Cage, Richard Wernick, Chou Wen-Chung, Ge Gan-Ru, Sheila Silver and Robert Beaser, who is the orchestra's composer in residence. There will also be New York premieres of works by Andrew Imbrie, Cindy McTee, Roger Rynolds, Leon Kirchner, Curtis O. B. Curtis-Smith, Leo Ornstein, Bruce MacCombie, John Duffy and David Dzubay.
As part of its new Argo deal, the orchestra is to record works by Mr. Beaser, Chinary Ung, Colin McPhee and Henry Cowell. It has already recorded a collection of William Bolcom works, which is to be released next week. Over the years, the ensemble has recorded about a dozen disks, mostly for the new-music specialty labels CRI and New World Records.
Speaking about his long-term plans, Mr. Davies said he hoped to explore the fullest implications of the orchestra's name by expanding its mandate to all of the Western hemisphere. For 1994, he is planning a series of programs that will include works by Latin American composers.
 
Souvenirs of Vienna
 When Carnegie Hall opened its new Rose Museum last season, the hall's archivist, Gino Francesconi, promised to supplement permanent exhibitions of Carnegie-related memorabilia with rotating presentations, some built around materials borrowed from other institutions. The first was "Tchaikovsky at Carnegie Hall: Centennial of an American Journey," an illuminating exhibit that commemorated the composer's visit to New York for the opening of the hall in 1891 and that drew on Tchaikovsky items from the Klin and Glinka Museums in Russia.
A new exhibition, "The Vienna Philharmonic at 150," opened on Tuesday at the Rose Museum and includes some tantalizing items from the Austrian orchestra's archives. The items will be on display until March 6. The orchestra itself will be visiting Carnegie on Feb. 27 and 28.
In addition to material relating directly to the orchestra -- a program from its debut concert on March 28, 1842, for example, and letters to the ensemble from Brahms, Mahler and Bernstein -- the collection includes items of broader historical interest.
A few are fetishistic curiosities: a ring owned by Beethoven, a pair of Brahms's spectacles, Bruckner's matchbox bearing a portrait of Wagner, and one of Mahler's hats. For the more musicologically inclined, there is a Beethoven sketchbook page, an autographed photo of Brahms on which the composer wrote an unidentified canon, and a Richard Strauss notebook with sketches of "Danube," an unfinished tone poem he was writing for the orchestra's centennial. There are also scores signed by Strauss and Bruckner.
The museum, at 154 West 57th Street (accessible through the Weill Recital Hall entrance), is open to the public every day from 11 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Admission is free.
 
Hemidemisemiquavers
 The Lark String Quartet, an American all-female ensemble, won first prize at the Shostakovich International String Quartet Competition in St. Petersburg. . . . Columbia University has awarded its $50,000 William Schuman Award for composition to Milton Babbitt, who is to receive the prize on April 1. . . .The Fromm Music Foundation at Harvard University has given the Tanglewood Music Center a $100,000 grant, to be used over the next five years to foster the composition and performance of new music. The money will underwrite an annual Fromm Concert, which will be part of Tanglewood's annual Festival of Contemporary Music, and will support a Paul Fromm Award for composers. Recipients of the award will write a chamber work to be performed at the festival. . . . William M. Hoffmann, the playwright who provided the libretto for John Corigliano's "Ghosts of Versailles," is toiling in the fields of opera again. He is writing the supertitles for the Brooklyn Academy of Music production of "Atys," part of the academy's French Baroque Project. The opera was a smash hit when William Christie and Les Arts Florissants first brought it to the academy in 1989. Virtually the same forces are returning for the revival, which opens on March 18.

HEADLINE: Uncle Sam Says 'Uncle' on Haiti

 BODY:
The criminal gang that now runs Haiti is all but dancing in the streets this weekend, celebrating two big signals that Washington is no longer pressing for a quick return to democratic rule.
By forcing Haitian refugees to return home, and then unilaterally relaxing a regional economic embargo, the Bush Administration has given Haiti's new rulers the impression that Washington concedes their hold on power. 
 Having outlasted the pressure, the Haitian military is no longer in any mood to bargain, even over cosmetic details.
In the case of Haiti, "criminal gang" is not mere bombast. The present crew seized power in a bloody coup against the democratically elected President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide. It has encouraged soldiers to intimidate poor neighborhoods still loyal to him. It has freed the Tontons Macoute enforcers of the old Duvalier dictatorship and let them terrorize civilians as before. And it has cooperated with smugglers, including those suspected of trafficking drugs to the U.S.
Haiti's regime may not be as dangerous to the outside world as Saddam Hussein's. But it is as deserving of Washington's unremitting hostility as, say, neighboring Cuba, or the former Noriega regime in Panama. At stake is international decency, the future of Latin American democracy, America's reputation and, most urgently, Haitian lives.
A quick change in policy is needed. Instead of easing the embargo, Washington, working with the Organization of American States, could stiffen it, imposing a naval blockade of all goods except humanitarian deliveries of food and other civilian essentials. These deliveries could be coordinated through international relief agencies.
Instead of forcibly repatriating refugees, the Bush Administration could grant them temporary protected status, for the duration of the crisis. That would not only safeguard innocent lives, it would show the present regime that Washington expects a speedy political solution. The Administration can put further pressure on Haitian leaders by freezing their assets in the U.S.
Such a muscular policy would not be likely to offend Latin American allies. Although Latins don't like unilateral U.S. bullying of established regimes, they have warmed to the idea of collective action against military usurpers. Venezuela and Argentina, for example, have consistently supported O.A.S. activism against the Haitian coup.
How about Uncle Sam?

HEADLINE: Miyazawa's Words

 BODY:
Following is the Japanese Foreign Ministry's translation of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa's full remarks in Parliament on Feb. 3 concerning the U.S. work ethic; they were made in response to a member's comments. Portions of the Prime Minister's remarks, as reported, have been widely seen as America-bashing. 
 I have heard your comment, which is easy to understand. [Your point would be] there is something that is lacking in America. Looking at what things have come to over the past 10 years: we might say that the interpretation of producing things or creating value has become very loose; it's that no one doubts that value can be created in the money market. Creating things by the sweat of our brows, a kind of work ethic, is related to various things. There is probably even a connection with computers. People graduating from universities are going to Wall Street for high salaries. As a result, the number of engineers, who actually make things, is shrinking, something Representative [Kabun] Muto and I both see.
While we were debating whether this situation was all right or not, the money market advanced and junk bonds appeared -- junk bonds, just as their name implies, are very dangerous. We have these leveraged buyouts where those without their own money can buy up things, and then, unable to pay the interest on their debts, [the companies] fall into bankruptcy. It should be obvious to anyone that such a situation could not continue long.
Yet, over the past 10 years, this very situation has continued. I have long felt that this might involve something like a lack of a work ethic. I think what you are worrying about is related to this situation. In one sense, there are many of these same elements present in what has been called Japan's bubble economy. After this bubble [burst], both [countries] now have a lot to clean up in the aftermath, and all of our people learned a lot from this. It is very important to build things of value with the sweat of our brows. This may sound like a sermon, but what I have said is what I feel. When President Bush talks about education, I believe he is trying to reiterate the above kind of message.

HEADLINE: Affirmative Action Looks Like Favoritism

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Great White Myth" by Anna Quindlen (column, Jan. 15) misses the target on affirmative action in the workplace. Clearly, she lacks the firsthand experience of those who have lived with goals and timetables, supported their intent and witnessed the consequences. I have been involved with affirmative action as an executive and a consultant. 
 Affirmative action was born of 200 years of discrimination against blacks and their inadequate participation in American economic life. Conceptually flawed, inconsistently administered and overburdened by the inclusion of white women among its beneficiaries, affirmative action has nonetheless created an important beachhead from which blacks can move forward.
However, the white males who bear the exclusionary burden are not the historic perpetrators of discrimination. They are not the executives who bought into the concept, but are often the very people who have been victimized by nepotism and the other forms of favoritsim to which Ms. Quindlen refers.
It is true that business leaders have forever favored their own at the expense of fairness. It is also true that many executives are obscenely compensated as a result of a pervasive relationship between officers and directors. Furthermore, companies have not done everything they should to make their reward (appraisal) systems the cornerstones of merit they were intended to be. Affirmative action's goals and timetables simply add to the list of flaws and contrivances in our places of employment. Good riddance to them all!
The emergence of black intellectuals who question the price paid by affirmative action's beneficiaries in a diminished sense of achievement is significant. Many blacks are distressed by perceptions of altered performance standards and the implication that they don't really have what it takes. Once again, the lunch is never free.
Ms. Quindlen points out that laws -- affirmative action among them -- don't change attitudes. What does? The clear, forceful assertion of fundamental values, supported by a uniform application of performance standards.
 
THOMAS W. MULLEN
Rye, N.Y., Jan. 23, 1992

HEADLINE: Keep Pan Am Sign as Memorial to Air Pioneer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Within a few months, Pan Am signs could possibly be removed from the Pan American Airways Building in New York City. 
 More than any other airline, Pan American pioneered international and intercontinental air travel. It initiated the flying boat routes across the Pacific Ocean and into South America, and grew globally until at the line's peak in the 1960's, the name Pan Am was synonymous with the United States.
It has been painful to watch Pan Am's slow disintegration over the years, even more painful to see it cease operations altogether. It is my feeling, and I'm sure the feeling of many others inside and outside the airline industry, that to leave the Pan Am sign up would be an appropriate way to honor one of this country's great exploring endeavors.
To many the building will always be the Pan Am Building. The sometimes expressed feeling that to leave the sign up would draw attention to bankruptcy at a time of recession is far outweighed by the richness of Pan Am's history. We celebrate and remember Rear Adm. Richard E. Byrd, Charles A. Lindbergh and those who opened the West. Let's leave this memorial to those who opened the world.
A vice president of Met Life, which now owns the building, has told me that the insurance company is considering plans to remove the sign and will arrive at a decision in the next few months. He said some within Met Life would like to see the sign remain, but others prefer to replace it with a Met Life sign or nothing at all. He said that, because the building is not the corporate headquarters, a Met Life sign would constitute an unacceptable form of advertising and that having no sign would make a dull and uninteresting building even duller.
The Pan Am sign brings the building to life, particularly at night, and gives it color and character. It has also, like it or not, become a Manhattan landmark, known and recognized internationally. To change it would change the face of Manhattan, would be very costly and a great shame as well.
 
CHRISTOPHER MCLAUGHLIN
Nantucket, Mass., Jan. 18, 1992
 
The writer is a first officer with British Airways.
