HEADLINE: Perspectives: Manhattan Rentals;
Building for the 'Young Professional' Class

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
EVERYONE to his own niche. The Brodsky Organization has found its niche on the West Side of Manhattan, where it has been building new residential buildings, often with office and retail space, for 10 years.
Beyond that, the Brodsky niche is in the apartment itself, a product priced to meet the lower end of the luxury housing market. The locations are not suitable for superluxury housing, where prices are not only higher per square foot but apartments are also larger, with special features and fixtures, and service staffs are larger. The price difference for a 1,000-square-foot apartment might be $700 a month or more. 
 Nathan Brodsky, the 74-year-old founder of the business, has no taste for the land prices that oblige builder-buyers to seek superluxury rents. "We never paid more than $55 a square foot," he said, which means $55 for every square foot of buildable space. At that figure $55,000 in cost is embedded in the purchase or rental price of the 1,000-square-foot two-bedroom apartment.
Some developers paid $100 or more per buildable square foot in the 80's. "We are conscientious about keeping our product as low-priced as possible," Mr. Brodsky said.
The Brodsky approach gives a special interest to the inventory of housing that he and his 47-year-old son, Daniel, have created in Manhattan over the last 10 years. It is eminently suitable for the young-professionals market, people with incomes in the $40,000-to-$90,000 range, often in households with two wage earners. The tenants are often new arrivals to New York City.
Now the question is when the Brodskys will be able to build for this market again.
The business was started by Mr. Brodsky in Greenwich Village after World War II. He bought and improved small residential buildings in the Village and Chelsea. He still owns about 1,500 apartments. Later, the turned to larger buildings. Failing residential hotels were purchased to be rehabilitated as rental apartments.
Currently the Brodsky Organization is finishing the rental program at the Concerto, a 248-unit 35-story project at 200 West 60th Street, just west of Ninth Avenue. The rental experience there is demonstrating the continuing market for this level of new rental housing in Manhattan.
But the Brodskys want to start on an encore to the Concerto, a 1,000-unit development called Manhattan West, which won approval from the Board of Estimate, now defunct, two years ago after a public review process. The four-acre site lies west of West End Avenue between 61st and 64th Streets. The Trump Organization is trying to win city approval for an even larger development on land to the west.
Manhattan West would be a $180 million development, the largest the Brodskys have undertaken. The problem is that rent projections for the mid-90's are such that the project is no longer economically feasible, even with tax-exempt bond financing and the Section 421a tax abatements to which it would be entitled as-of-right as a publicly financed development. A longer period of abated taxes would be needed.
Manhattan West is planned as "80-20" housing, with 80 percent of the apartments rented at market prices and 20 percent at prices affordable to households with incomes up to about $20,000 -- 50 percent of the median income for a family of four in the metropolitan area.
THE project would also provide at developer expense a new 1.25-acre park from 63d to 64th Streets, extending from West End Avenue to a new street 240 feet to the west called East Tower Drive.
The housing would line West End Avenue and the south side of a newly extended 63d Street, ranging in height from 17 to 38 stores. There would be garage parking for 350 cars, a public health club of 12,500 square feet, 5,000 square feet of community facilities and 38,000 square feet of stores.
In Manhattan, nearly all new multifamily construction has gotten the 421a benefit. However, builders of conventionally financed luxury housing must pay for it "up front" by subsidizing the construction of new low-income units, either on their sites or elsewhere. The cost to them has been about $18,000 an apartment. This is less than the savings from abatements and therefore makes more money available for financing.
But in the current market, projected rent increases no longer comfortably cover operating-cost increases that include a 10-year phase-in of property taxes. Under Section 421a in Manhattan, the tax phase-in is paid for by a rent increase of 2.2 percent a year.
The developers of 80-20 projects get the 421a benefit without having to pay for it. But still, if apartment rents are not rising fast enough, revenues won't cover the phased-in taxes for a development with the normal 75 percent loan-to-value ratio of financing.
"It worked fine when you had the inflation rates of the early 80's," Mr. Brodsy said. "It doesn't work in a noninflationary environment."
One way to restore the abatement's effectiveness in stimulating construction is to extend its phase-in period to 20 years from the present 10 years. Then rents would not have to rise so rapidly to meet the tax bill.
There is little evidence so far that the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins is prepared to sweeten the 421a program in Manhattan, perhaps because there is no current sense of housing shortage. "The project is six years old and it's still not in construction," Daniel Brodsky said ruefully.
At the Concerto, he said, tenants have been found for 91 percent of the apartments -- 225 of 246 -- since leasing began last May. A sample consisting of the most recent 103 leases showed that 44 percent of the tenants are new arrivals from outside the metropolitan area.
MOST of the renting households have incomes of $80,000 to $150,000. But individual incomes are mainly $50,000 to $60,000 a year. There are 59 single-person households and more than twice that many two-person -- usually two-income -- households.
To get to the current occupancy level in 10 months the Brodsky Organization has had to make some rent concessions, usually one or two months' free rent for less desirable units. Rents have averaged about $28.50 a square foot per year -- about $1,600 a month for a typical 675-square-foot one-bedroom on a middle floor, Daniel Brodsky said.
Since the Concerto was financed on the expectation that it would rent out at an average of about $30 a square foot per year, it has fallen short of expectations. On the other hand, interest rates declined during construction to about 6 to 7 percent compared with a rate over 12 percent projected. Thus the construction cost was less than expected.
The Concerto is a $75 million project that included 130 units of hospital staff housing in an attacheed structure on Ninth Avenue for Roosevelt-St. Luke's Medical Center and a 250-car garage. Before it the Brodskys built the 500-unit 51-story rental called South Park Tower, at 120 West 60th Street, an $80 million project with about 100,000 square feet of office space on the first 10 floors.
They also built two other West Side condominiums, the 160-unit Beaumont at 30 West 61st Street with 45,000 square feet of office space, and the 175-unit 45 West 67th Street, with 60,000 square feet of office space.
Major projects all, but rooted in a cautious approach that relies on choosing underutilized properties and sites that may be underestimated. It also relies on using space optimally. Lobbies are of modest scale even when they are elegant, as at the Concerto. "I don't like big lobbies," Daniel Brodsky said. "Or gaudy Miami Beach lobbies."
UNTIL the 80's, the Brodskys shied away from new construction. They had been concentrating on buying old and ailing residential hotels in promising locations and upgrading them as rental housing. These projects included the Alamac at 160 West 71st Street; the Beaux Arts, twin buildings across the street from each other between First and Second Avenues at 310 and 307 East 44th Street, and the Croydon at 12 East 86th Street.
Then came an opportunity to do a gut rehabilitation of the 70-room Walton Hotel at 104 West 70th Street. The idea was to sell the apartments as condominiums.
"Brewster Ives came around and said, 'You'll never sell those apartments, it's a wreck,' " Daniel Brodsky said. The late Mr. Ives, the senior figure at Douglas Elliman-Gibbons & Ives, the management and sales firm, was too pessimistic. The Walton sold out in four months.
In the early 80's, Mr. Brodsky said, banks had an attitude of confidence in lending to residential projects that were in the hands of experienced builders. "What has changed is that banks no longer want to lend to real estate," he said. "Bond financing and government programs to preserve and create housing are going to become more important."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1274 words

HEADLINE: Focus: The Northeast;
Debt and Mild Winters Afflict Ski Areas

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

DATELINE: WEST WINDSOR, VT.

 BODY:
THE empty chair lifts were swaying silently against a wintry sky -- skeletal reminders of headier days vibrant with the sounds of skiers riding up the mountain. Along the edges the neat rows of vacant condominiums stood like wooden sentries over the abandoned slopes.
Like several others, the 750-acre Mount Ascutney ski resort here, closed since last April, was brought down by excessive debts from speculative slopeside condominium development coupled with unseasonably warm winters. The shutdown has been particularly hard on the buyers of individual units, many of whom cannot even use their units pending a resolution with creditors. 
 There are now 69 ski areas in New England, against 107 just 20 years ago. About 70 percent of the loss has been in the last decade, reports Phillip Camp, executive director of the New England Ski Areas Council.
Some larger areas have consolidated with their weaker, smaller neighbors while others have simply gone out of business. Still others that floundered a few years ago are now back in business.
Tenney Mountain, for example, in Plymouth, N.H., has already come out of bankruptcy and is operating once again -- albeit on more limited basis -- under new ownership and a new structure that separated its financially troubled condominium projects from its ski operation.
Haystack in West Dover, Vt., which filed under Chapter 11 last August, is leasing its lifts and slopes to a more prosperous neighbor, in this case, Mount Snow. Its 107 condominiums, now mostly sold out, are operating independently.
Waterville Valley Ski Resort in Waterville Valley, N.H., headed off financial freefall after condominium sales slowed precipitately by raising the $2 million due its lenders through the sale of convertible preferred stock, said Tom Corcoran, Waterville's president.
The problem is not confined to the Northeast. Some Colorado ski resorts similarly attracted by the lure of condominium profits took an equally bumpy downhill run in the late 80's and are only now beginning to get back on their feet, said John Lay, president of Colorado Ski Country USA, a regional association of ski area operators in Colorado.
"There's been a shakeout," he said, adding that most are returning to life through some sort of restructuring that has separated the condominiums from the ski slopes.
BUT clearly, the region most severely affected has been New England, say officials at the United Ski Industries Association, the national trade group. Not only did the real estate market nosedive, but the mild weather also required operators to continually replenish the slopes with artificial snow just as cash flow was being squeezed by the debt service on unsold or partially completed condominium units.
Ski Magazine has estimated that it costs on average about $2,700 to cover one acre with a foot of snow, or about $800,000 to cover a typical 300 acres of ski trails.
A further blow was a decline in the number of people going skiing over the last few years after a three-decade blizzard of snowbirds. This, of course, meant that far fewer condominium units sold than originally projected.
To fully comprehend how ski area operators were lured into speculative real estate development it is necessary to understand what was happening to the ski industry when it all started, said Richard Owen, director of marketing for the United Ski Industries Association.
In the early 80's, slope owners needed vast infusions of capital to upgrade obsolete equipment and facilities and subsidize the rising costs of insurance, water supplies and energy.
Rather than raise lift ticket prices, they decided to develop their excess acreage to create a "bed base" -- facilities that would guarantee regular customers.
But instead of selling the land for someone else to develop, many were lured by a vision of dazzling profits and decided to do it themselves. In the beginning, they seemed to be walking a yellow-brick road. Buyers were attracted by the promise of cost-free ownership from rental income when they weren't using the unit. "It made it all look pretty painless," said Mr. Owen.
But thousands of units sprouted so fast that supply soon exceeded demand. In addition, resorts like Mount Ascutney, which had targeted the luxury rather than the economy market, found that only a limited number of customers had $200,000 to spend on a second or third home.
Further, said Mr. Lay, people became more interested in staying four or five days, rather than 14 days, as in the past.
The 1986 Tax Reform Act, which limited interest deductions to only one vacation home, and the stock market crash of October 1987 dealt the final blows, catching operators in a triple bind of unsold inventory, slipping values and heavy debt service resulting from construction costs.
Mount Ascutney filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code in April 1990, showing debts of $55 million, said John Canney, the court-appointed trustee. Of 172 units, 25 are still unsold.
It nevertheless remained open until last April, when the filing was converted to Chapter 7. Mr. Canney said that by then the lenders were no longer willing to pump money into a losing operation and the principals could not even meet a rescheduled level of payments.
Ever since, a complicated land-lease deal has shackled 100 of the 147 condominium buyers to a situation that precludes their using their units pending a resolution with creditors.
But real estate hasn't proved a disaster for all. Resorts well located in areas offering year-round recreation have bounced back or continue to do well, said Mr. Lay. Another ticket to success was maintaining healthy fiscal balance between the needs of the slopes and the real estate affiliate.
In the Northeast, Loon Mountain Ski Resort in Lincoln, N.H., stayed strong by selling land for cash rather than become involved in any development deal. Sunday River Ski Resort in Bethel, Me., which has 688 condominium units, prospered by concentrating on budget-priced units. It also adopted a policy of building units only after they had been pre-sold.
EVEN resorts that have fallen by the wayside have opened up opportunities for others. Last June, Tenney Mountain Skiing of New Hampshire, a consortium of three partners, picked up 380 mountain acres and the updated skiing facilities at Tenney for only $500,000 from Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia, a major lender caught in the former Tenney bankruptcy.
Seth Lichtman, Tenney's current director of customer services, said the 40 unsold condominiums had been separately acquired by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation following the collapse of another of Tenney's lenders, Maine Savings Bank, last February. Further, the remaining 80 units, all sold, had already become an independent entity.
Values at Tenney have tumbled nevertheless, said Mr. Lichtman. A one-bedoom unit orignally selling for $80,000 was recently fetching only $45,000. Two-bedrooms, intended to generate rental income of $650 a month, are lucky to find a renter for $450, he said.
All of which has left owners feeling helpless and cheated. "We were promised so much," said Diana Fay of Boston, who with her husband, Richard, bought a two-bedroom town house unit at Tenney for $113,000 in 1986. They have two teen-age children.
"We were supposed to get a health center, but nothing went up except a sign," she said. "We were told we would get a private beach at a lake nearby. That never happened either. All those grand plans for a wonderful four-season resort never materialized. Even Mother Nature has not cooperated by washing away the snow."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Empty chair lifts rise over condos at Mount Ascutney in Vermont. (Paul O. Boisvert for The New York Times)

GEOGRAPHIC: ;NORTHEASTERN STATES (US) UNITED STATES (94%); NORTHEAST USA (94%); VERMONT, USA (92%); NEW HAMPSHIRE, USA (79%); 

SUBJECT: SKIING; FINANCES; CREDIT; CONDOMINIUMS; HOUSING SKIING FACILITIES (91%); REAL ESTATE (90%); RESIDENTIAL CO-OWNERSHIP (90%); RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY (90%); RESIDENTIAL CONDOMINIUMS (90%); SKIING (90%); MOUNTAINS (90%); RESORTS (90%); CONDOMINIUMS (90%); HOUSING MARKET (78%); BUSINESS CLOSINGS (76%); INSOLVENCY & BANKRUPTCY (76%); CORPORATE DEBT (76%); BUSINESS INSOLVENCY & BANKRUPTCY (75%); SALES FIGURES (74%); BUSINESS FINANCIAL TROUBLE (73%); US CHAPTER 11 BANKRUPTCY (70%); WEATHER (69%); EXECUTIVES (68%); BUSINESS & PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS (68%); REAL ESTATE MARKET (64%); CONVERTIBLE SECURITIES (50%); PREFERRED STOCK (50%); 

PERSON: BROOKS, ANDREE RICHARD OWEN (57%);

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Debt and Mild Winters Afflict Ski Areas

"We were supposed to get a health center, but nothing went up except a sign," she said. "We were told we would get a private beach at a lake nearby. That never happened either. All those grand plans for a wonderful four-season resort never materialized. Even Mother Nature has not cooperated by washing away the snow."

HEADLINE: Small Pins Offer Bowlers a Big Challenge

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
SCORES of children screamed and squealed as bowling balls crashed into pins on a recent Sunday afternoon at Barnum Recreation Lanes in Stratford. Children outnumber grown-ups by a 3-to-1 margin on weekend afternoons at the bowling center on Barnum Avenue, and that would seem to bode well for the future of the game it features, duckpins.
But the general manager of the Barnum Lanes, Clarence Lavers, conceded that youngsters who come for family outings or birthday parties will not necessarily come back as they grow up. 
 "Once a lot of the kids get old enough to handle the bigger ball, they switch over to tenpins," Mr. Laver said, referring to the form of the game that most people know simply as bowling. "They watch professionals bowling tenpins on television, and they say, 'Hey, I can make $40,000 a year doing that when I grow up.' "
 
'A Much Better Game'
 For three decades now, the far more popular game of tenpins has been the bane of duckpin bowling, which uses much smaller balls and pins.
Duckpins have "dropped in popularity, particularly in Fairfield County," said Mr. Lavers. "And that's a shame, because it's a much better game -- far more challenging than tenpins. I'd like to think that duckpins is going to make a big comeback, but that will only happen if we get more television exposure. And I don't see that happening."
In Connecticut 21 bowling establishments still offer duckpins. But most of the alleys are upstate. The game has vanished in lower Fairfield County, where duckpins thrived from the 1930's through the 50's. Eight tenpin alleys remain in Greenwich and Bridgeport, but even that number is down considerably from the 70's and early 80's.
"We haven't had duckpins around here for about 30 years," said the secretary of the Lower Fairfield County Bowlers Association, Nick Romaniello. "But maybe a duckpin house could succeed." The number of duckpin bowlers in the state appears to be growing, and the number of establishments is holding steady. Some of them, like the Barnum Lanes and Sena's Center in Waterbury, have been in operation for more than a half century.
"I started out as a pin boy when my father opened the alleys in 1938," said Norman Sena, the owner of Sena's Center, which has 20 duckpin lanes. "Business is down a little this year, because of the recession. But overall duckpins is holding its own in the Waterbury area."
The game is strongest in the Hartford area and the northeastern part of the state, with lanes in Hartford, Manchester, Windsor Locks, Newington, Bristol, Mansfield, Rockville, Winsted and Waterford. Other communities with duckpins are Cheshire, Danbury, Hamden and West Haven.
Most duckpin bowlers say they are drawn to the game because they find it far more challenging than big pins.
"There's no comparison," said Mr. Lavers, who has been the nation's top-ranked bowler four times since 1982 and was named the best bowler on the duckpin professional circuit three times. "A top duckpin bowler could give a leading big-pin bowler a good go in tenpins, but a big-pin guy couldn't compete with a good duckpin bowler."
 
Hurt by Property Values
 Why did did duckpins lose ground in Connecticut, particularly Fairfield County?
"First of all, tenpin operators began putting up these beautiful bowling establishments that were family oriented," said Mr. Lavers. "At the same time, a lot of the duckpin alleys had been allowed to deteriorate. Then property values began to soar, especially in Fairfield County, and many duckpin owners sold out to developers. Network television of the pro tour also gave the game tremendous exposure. And people liked the higher scores. Meanwhile, duckpin operators did nothing to market or promote our game."
A duckpin ball is only about 5 inches in diameter, and its maximum weight is 3 pounds, 12 ounces, compared with a tenpin ball, which is approximately 9 inches in diameter and weighs up to 16 pounds. "It's almost impossible for a little kid to bowl a tenpin ball with three or four fingers in the holes of the ball," said Mr. Lavers, noting that duckpin balls have no holes.
Besides the size of the equipment, the major difference between the two games is that a duckpin bowler rolls 3 balls in each of the 10 frames, compared with the 2 balls in tenpins.
"Bigpins is a game of strikes, while duckpins is a game of spares," Mr. Lavers said.
In order to survive, Barnum Lanes and other old bowling establishments in the state have had to refurbish their interiors and expunge their unsavory image as dimly-lighted, smoke-filled places.
Prices for duckpins range from $1.75 to $2.50 a game. Some lanes are rented by the hour, usually for $10 to $12. Prices are generally lower for the elderly and children younger than 12. Rates are often cheaper during the daytime on weekdays.
"Leagues are the backbone of the bowling business, but nowadays we're also getting a lot more seniors on weekdays," said Jim Gesuelle, who with his wife, Nancy, has owned Farmington Avenue Duckpin in Hartford, near the West Hartford border, since 1989. The 16-lane establishment, which Mr. Gesuelle said was 52 years old, was previously known as the Mark Twain Lanes.
"The place was really rundown," he said, "and after we bought it, we shut it down for three months to completely refurbish the place."
 
Played in 12 States
 In the heyday of duckpin bowling in the state, many large companies had their own bowling alleys. Duckpin lanes were also often found in the basements of fraternal and sports clubs, generally with billiard tables nearby. Such alleys, though, are now as much a part of the past as pin boys, who were replaced by automatic pinsetters in the 1950's.
Still, Connecticut remains a stronghold, relatively speaking, of duckpin bowling. Only 12 states still have duckpin lanes, and four of them -- Pennsylvania, Florida, Indiana and Wisconsin -- have only one duckpin establishment each.
Duckpins remain most popular in Maryland, its birthplace. By most accountsthe game was invented in Baltimore in 1903 by John McGraw and Wilbert Robinson, who were then playing baseball for the Orioles and owned the Diamond Alleys there.
Five duckpin bowlers from Connecticut are currently ranked in the top 20 by the National Duckpin Bowling Congress. Besides Mr. Laver, who is ranked second, they are Mike Trepanier of North Haven, Brian Kulas of Windsor Locks, George Kaeser of Newington and Bruce Sylvester of Hamden, whose wife, Judy, is also an outstanding bowler.
Mr. Laver and the Sylvesters play twice weekly in a highly competitive league at Barnum Lanes. Others in the league include Frank Iaizzi of Stamford, who once held the world record for an eight-game set, and Tom Lynch of West Haven, who was ranked fourth in the nation in 1982. Mr. Trepanier, Mr. Kulas and Mr. Kaeser bowl regularly in another strong league at T-Bowl Lanes In Newington, the largest duckpin complex in New England, with 48 lanes.
All of them compete on the eight-event professional duckpin tour, which runs from March through November. "Nobody gets rich on the pro tour," said Mr. Lavers. "At the most, the leading bowler on the tour will make about $10,000 a year." Top bowlers on the tenpin tour earn as much as $400,000 a year.
More than 150 bowlers participate in the children's leagues at T-Bowl Lanes. One of the best is 12-year-old Amy Bisson, whose mother, Kim, is the establishment's general manager for operations and wife of one of the owners. Amy, whose average score is 128, holds four world records in her age group.
At the T-Bowl Lanes on Dec. 3, 1984, Ben McDonald of New Britain set a single-game world record when he bowled 267, a mark that has since been broken. Nick Tronsky of Kensington, who is regarded by many bowling experts as the greatest duckpin bowler of all time, bowled at T-Bowl for many years.
But the game has changed since Mr. Tronsky was first voted Duckpin Bowler of the Year in 1931, an honor he also achieved 30 years later. Wooden pins have given way to much livelier plastic ones, gutters are shallower, and sideboards are now made of rubber rather than fiber. These changes have combined to produce higher scores.
"In 1969 I averaged 134, which was the second-best average in the country," Mr. Lavers said. "Today I average 151, which is still the second best in the country. But I'm not any better than I was in '69."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Duckpin bowlers, top, at Barnum Recreation Lanes in Stratford. Above, the machinery that resets the pins. Lovers of the game can choose from 21 establishments in the state; Judy Sylvester bowling at Barnum Lanes. (Photographs by David LaBianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Pristine Open Space: A Clash of Interests

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

DATELINE: RINGWOOD

 BODY:
A PLAN by the United States Forest Service plan to limit development on more than a million acres of rolling landscape in northern New Jersey and southern New York State has drawn praise from conservationists and criticism from developers and farmers who own much of the land.
The draft plan, which was released last November and will be the subject of a public hearing on Tuesday, identifies more than 50 conservation strategies. These include the acquisition of prime parcels of land, the purchase of development rights in others, the issuance of credits to landowners in lieu of development rights and the establishment of a two-state regional planning authority to oversee future development in the area. 
 Environmental groups and many residents say the plan embodies the type of action that must be taken to protect the forest, watershed and wildlife refuge from unchecked development and suburban sprawl.
Developers, however, say the Forest Service's recommendation for a regional planning authority is excessive and unnecessary because existing laws adequately control future development in the area. Landowners and farmers add that constraints on development are an illegal taking of their property without just compensation, in violation of the Fifth Amendment.
The far-reaching plan touches on several critical issues facing New Jersey and the region. Those issues include increased concern over water quality, the preservation of the last remaining stretches of pristine open spaces and efforts by local officials to stem the urban flight that has left some large cities mere shadows of their former selves.
"This is the last refuge of open space in the tristate area," said Robert Pirani, director of environmental projects for the Regional Plan Association, a public policy organization based in Manhattan. "It's the backyard of millions of people."
Mr. Pirani said unchecked development in the 1.1-million-acre area, commonly referred to as the Highlands, could have a negative impact on residents, wildlife and the environment itself. "The Highlands provides the region with fresh drinking water, and it's one of the last intact ecosystems that can support large populations of wildlife," he said. "The fact that it has remained open and forested until now has provided shape and form to the entire region."
Mr. Pirani said his organization supported the two main concepts contained in the Forest Service's draft report: the acquisition of several of the area's larger pieces of land -- the "jewels of the Highlands" -- and the creation of a regional planning authority to control development in the privately owned lands that remain.
Without such action, Mr. Pirani said, development will fragment the otherwise continuous stretch of Appalachian forest that runs from Pennsylvania through much of northern New Jersey and into southern New York State. "We don't want suburbia to stretch from the Hudson River to the Delaware River," he said.
The Forest Service draft report, or preliminary plan, was the result of a yearlong study authorized by Congress in January of 1990. The bill provided the Forest Service with $250,000 to study the area and assess its resources, land ownership patterns and the impact that future development would have on the integrity of the ecosystem. In addition, the Forest Service was instructed to make recommendations for conservation strategies after completing the study and considering public opinion.
"We've just completed a round of public sessions which were attended by over 600 people," said Leslie A. DiCola, a member of the Forest Service's study team. "In addition to that, we've received over 500 written responses to our draft report," she said, referring to the 75-page document the study team released last November.
A key recommendation of the report called for the acquisition of some of the most ecologically sensitive tracts in the area and the purchase of development rights in some others. One tract that should be purchased, the report says, is the 17,500-acre Sterling Forest.
Though the forest is in New York State, it is an integral part of the 60,000-acre Monksville-Wanaque Reservoir Watershed Area, which provides drinking water to nearly 25 percent of New Jersey's population.
The forest's owner, the Sterling Forest Corporation, has recently submitted development plans to officials in New York State. The plans call for more than 14,000 homes, 8 million square feet of commercial space, employment for 20,000 people and an ultimate population of about 35,000 residents. About 75 percent of the forest would remain as permanent open space.
Robert Thomson, chairman of the corporation, said that any runoff from the development into reservoirs in the area would meet New York and New Jersey water quality standards.
Should the Forest Service acquisition plan be put into effect, however, a major stumbling block would be coming up with the money to make the purchase. Estimates of the value of the Sterling Forest tract run as high as $150 million.
 
'Money Is a Big Question'
 Ms. DiCola said "we don't know" where would the money come from. "The money is a big question," she said.
The Forest Service report also calls for the purchase of development rights in the 55,000-acre Pequannock Watershed in Sussex and Passaic Counties. About 35,000 acres of the watershed is owned by the City of Newark and provides a major portion of that city's drinking water supply.
"The foremost goal of the study team is the protection of watershed lands and water supply," Ms. DiCola said.
The report also recommends the creation of a New York-New Jersey regional planning authority to monitor future development in the area. In addition, it urges the examination of a planning concept known as "transfer of development rights" to protect landowners whose property value would otherwise be lowered by restrictions on development.
Transfer of development rights, Ms. DiCola said, involves giving affected landowners "development credits," which could be used or sold to developers. Those credits have value because they allow a developer who is building in another area to exceed that area's existing density requirements and build more houses.
 
Plan Draws Wide Support
 Ms. DiCola said that during the last nine months the Forest Service held nine public meetings in the area, including at the Forest Service study team office in Ringwood. The vast majority of residents and officials who testified at the meetings and who commented on the draft proposal voiced support for the report's recommendations, she said.
Organizations that support the draft plan include the New Jersey Audubon Society, the Sierra Club, the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference, the New Jersey Environmental Lobby and the League of Women Voters. In addition, officials of the State Planning Commission in New Jersey's Office of State Planning say the Forest Service's conclusions and recommendations correspond to similar recommendations the commission made last year in its Skylands Study Commission report.
"These are areas of critical concern," said James G. Gilbert, chairman of the State Planning Commission. "That means that the state should be taking steps to protect them or at least plan their growth."
Not everyone, however, is happy with the Forest Service's recommendations.
 
Others 'Very Distressed'
 "We were very distressed at the way the study team was assisted by the work groups and technical committees that were created," said Joanne M. Harkins, director of land use and planning for the New Jersey Builders Association, a Plainsboro-based trade organization. "Those groups were just not representative of the people who live and work in the area."
The study team and work groups, she said, "concentrated almost exclusively on forest and agriculture and public lands, and they didn't put any of this in the context of the economic activity of the region."
As a result, Ms. Harkins said, the report gives the impression of the Highlands' being "some remote area that can be preserved without considering all sorts of economic activity that's occurring there." That activity, Ms. Harkins said, which includes the presence of sprawling corporate headquarters for several international corporations, accounted for a large percentage of the state's job growth in the 1980's.
"You can't tell from this report, but I certainly don't think that forestry and tourism are the major economic activities in that area," Ms. Harkins said.
 
More Bureaucracy Called Unneeded
 Moreover, she said, the recommendation for a planning authority to monitor development in the area is unnecessary. "Our view is that the area is already protected and regulated through wetlands regulations, wellhead preservation programs and the various buffers that are already required," Ms. Harkins said. "What we do not need now is another layer of bureaucratic controls."
Landowners and farmers in the Highlands also object to much of the Forest Service's plan. "If all this land is worthy of protecting, then they should buy it," said Stephen J. George, president of the 5,400-member New Jersey Farm Bureau based in Trenton. "That's what the Fifth Amendment says."
Instead, Mr. George said, the Forest Service's plan will ultimately result in rezoning much of the land that farmers have owned and worked for years. "So many farmers have their retirements built into their land," he said. "We've put blood, sweat and tears into this land, and we need the equity that we've built up in it. But with the stroke of a pen they can reduce the value from $20,000 an acre to $1,500 an acre."
 
Farmers 'Saved the Land'
 "Because somebody in the Sierra Club wants to hike on this land doesn't mean you can get it for nothing," he said. "The farmers were the first environmentalists. We've saved the land, and now, because we're getting down to where there's less of it, they want to come in and regulate it away."
Mr. George said the "transfer of development rights" system being considered by the Forest Service "just doesn't work." The reason, he said, is that the development credits given to landowners in exchange for taking away their rights to develop their own property are nearly worthless. Referring to a similar system now in place in the Pinelands in southern New Jersey, he said farmers there are having difficulty selling their development credits.
"Why should a landowner say, 'All right, I'll take the credit' when they know very well that that credit may never be used?" Mr. George said.
Some conservationists, however, say the Forest Service plan could be fine-tuned in such a way that would not only protect the farmers and the land itself, but also inspire growth in some of the state's inner cities.
"We're putting out a proposal that links social needs to saving specific parcels of land," said William R. Neil, assistant director of conservation for the New Jersey Audubon Society in Bernardsville. "No one contemplates tough zoning or land use regulations over the entire million acres. It's just the good forested watershed lands that are still in private hands that need to be protected."
 
Audubon Society Proposal
 Mr. Neil said the Audubon Society had developed a plan that would use the system of transferring development rights to "save the best natural lands and, at the same time, build needed housing."
Under the Audubon Society proposal, landowners who own environmentally sensitive property in the Highlands would be given development credits in exchange for restrictions on development of their land. Those credits could be sold to developers who wanted to build in less sensitive areas, called "receiving areas."
The receiving areas, however, would be in cities, like Newark and Paterson, that have established, underused infrastructures and are in need of new housing.
The credits would allow the developer to build more houses than would otherwise be permitted, thereby insuring a greater profit for the developer and a market for the credits.
 
Plan for a 'Credit Bank'
 In addition, Mr. Neil said, the Audubon Society proposes the creation of a "credit bank" that would act as a clearinghouse and purchaser of last resort for the credits, thereby insuring their continued value.
"My proposal for making this work better is to have extra incentives so that the housing that gets built in these more dense zones is targeted to those parts of the population that need it most," Mr. Neil said. The incentives, he said, might include state and Federal moderate- and low-income housing aid.
At least one big-city mayor has embraced that philosophy."I am here to tell you that Newark has available urban land, and Newark wants redevelopment," said Sharpe James, Mayor of the state's largest city, in a written statement provided to the study commission in January.
"Newark has space and infrastructure," Mr. James said. "Newark can meet the developer's demands that otherwise will destroy forested land, will construct unnecessary roads and bridges and will carve up the remaining open space in the Highlands."

DiCola, member of Forest Service's team that studied plan to limit development in Highlands area. (pg. 14) (Chet Gordon for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 16; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: 1936 Prototype House Gets a New Life

BYLINE: States News Service

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE small concrete house in Hastings-on-Hudson had fascinated Peter Muckenhaupt for years, even though most of his neighbors thought it looked like a large, white appliance sitting on a hill.
As a 10-year-old boy, Mr. Muckenhaupt rode his bicycle to the newly paved intersection of Farragut Parkway and High Street to watch workers meticulously weld together the steel framework and carefully bolt together 10-foot-tall prefabricated concrete panels. 
 The four-room house looked peculiar among the larger Tudor- and Colonial-style homes on the street. Making it even more odd was the secrecy surrounding its construction and the fact that it was being built by Hamlin Andrus, the son of John Emery Andrus, a multimillionaire Congressman from Yonkers.
That was 1936. Despite the community's distaste for it, the house was completed, sold and eventually forgotten. But Mr. Muckenhaupt remained captivated. Now, at age 65, he not only owns the house but also has convinced the National Park Service to include it on its list of historic treasures.
In December, the Hastings Prototype House became the 110th Westchester County listing added to the National Register of Historic Places. The house is one of the first on the East Coast to be built in the sparse Modernist style, an avant-garde European design that stressed efficiency and economy over good looks.
It is also one of the first to be built with prefabricated concrete panels -- making it a precursor to modern-day skyscrapers, Mr. Muckenhaupt said.
"I was totally intrigued with it from Day 1 because it was just so different," said Mr. Muckenhaupt, who has spent many years studying the house. "It was in a very conspicuous location, right off a parkway. People in the community just didn't understand. They thought it was an abomination."
The stark-white house has few frills. Its most striking features are the curved front wall and the two-story portico over the front door.
 
Panels Stood the Test of Time
 Yet the plain white concrete walls are the main reason that the house was placed on the historic register. To make the 2-by-10-foot panels, workers in Yonkers poured cement and cinder into a mold of steel bars, which looked like a waffle iron, Mr. Muckenhaupt said.
The panels, which are patented, were light enough for two men to lift but sturdy enough not to crumble even after more than 50 years. Workers ran intricate tests of the panels before and after the house was constructed and delayed putting up the interior walls in order to conduct stress tests, Mr. Muckenhaupt said.
"They kept it as a skeleton," he said. "It looked like a barn inside."
Inside, the 800 square feet of living space was designed for efficiency, not spaciousness. There is a living room, a kitchen and two bedrooms, with a bathroom built into one of the rooms.
The house had one of the earliest types of gas-fired heating systems, which included a cooling system similar to modern air-conditioning. Fluorescent lighting was installed in the kitchen, a rare thing in 1930's homes.
 
Little Has Been Written
 Innovations in the prototype house were so unusual that they were included in the "Homes of Tomorrow" exhibition at the 1939 World's Fair in New York, Mr. Muckenhaupt discovered. But little else has been written about the house.
"Here was this amazing place, and there were no articles written on this thing," he said. "I searched endless microfilm to find references to the house."
He said he believed that "Andrus's people did not want anyone to know anything" in order to protect the patent on the concrete panels.
How the prototype was built and who built it is as unusual as its construction.
Hamlin Andrus was the driving force behind the prototype house. He hired a local architect, Charles Horn, and an industrial builder, Louis Gelbman, to design and build it. The three had planned to build similar houses in Florida, where the Andrus family owned land.
Hamlin's father, who had gained a reputation as a penny pincher, commuted every day by trolley and subway from his Yonkers mansion to the Arlington Chemical Company, his pharmaceutical concern in Manhattan.
Congressman Andrus was thought to be worth anywhere from $100 million to $800 million before the 1929 stock market crash, and even after that he was considered one of the 20 richest men in the world, according to an Andrus biographer, George P. Morrill.
 
Incentives to Save Allowances
 John Emery Andrus encouraged Hamlin and his other seven children to be thrifty -- prompting them to save their allowances by matching what each had saved at the end of the year, Mr. Morrill wrote.
After the elder Andrus died in 1934, his philanthropy lived on through the Surdna Foundation, which he started in 1917 to provide care for orphaned and troubled children. His money also built a library, a planetarium and a home for the elderly.
Hamlin Andrus, a Yale graduate, was not known for his business prowess, said Neil Larson, a researcher. While the prototype house was apparently Hamlin's idea, its design and construction dragged on for years, and he apparently lost interest in his scheme, the researcher said.
"Presumably, Andrus went on to find something else to do with his money," Mr. Muckenhaupt and Mr. Larson wrote in a report to the National Park Service.
"Today, people remember little about Hamlin Andrus except for his charming, boyish personality and his oddball investment schemes, few of which amounted to anything," the application for historic status said.
After years of research, Mr. Muckenhaupt wanted Mr. Andrus's house to have a small place in history, he said.
He bought the house -- rundown and threatened with demolition -- in 1978 and restored it to its original condition.
The house "was tragic, terrible," he said. "We wound up having to replace everything. It had to be treated like a brand-new house."
That meant stripping the inside down to its original walls and replacing 168 broken window panes, the heating and plumbing systems and the electrical wiring.
Mr. Muckenhaupt, a writer for Look magazine in the 1950's and later a public relations executive for the American Cyanamid Company in Manhattan, rented the house out for many years because it was too small for his family at the time. But now he plans to move into it, later this year, fulfilling a lifelong desire, he said.
Adding it to the National Register increases its value, but not by much, Mr. Muckenhaupt said.
"It could have more value now," he said. "It's awfully small for a house, though. I didn't do it for money. I did it to fulfill a consuming hobby."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Peter Muckenhaupt at back of Hastings Prototype House, with its stark lines. In contrast, dramatic portico, top, marks entry. (Photographs by Alan Zale for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Attention America! Snap Out of It!

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Just when Americans should be celebrating their victory in the cold war, they have grown alarmed that they are losing the next big war: the competitiveness war.
After years of watching Japan increase its manufacturing might, Americans have awakened to the dangers of losing the industrial base that long made their nation the envy of the world. At long last, Americans of all stripes, Democrat and Republican, white collar and blue, are groping for ways to close the competitiveness gap that has allowed Japan to muscle into the lead in such key industries as cars and computer chips. 
 Some of the proposed solutions are common sense. Some are controversial: for instance, some experts say the Federal Reserve should pump $25 billion into the nation's hobbled banks by purchasing their shares, which would enable them to lend some $250 billion to American companies for modernization.
Worried that American workers are ill prepared for the workplace of tomorrow, other experts say the country should adopt the German job-training system in which many high school students spend time in factories learning to master modern technologies and solve problems in teams. [One solution, page 13.]
Some say Washington should allow banks to own shares in industrial companies, as they do in Germany and Japan, because such a system of large, stable shareholders would enable American companies to think more long-term.
 
A New Cottage Industry
 These are just a few of the ideas being churned out by a new cottage industry in which hundreds of economists, think tanks, professors, politicians, columnists and management consultants ruminate full time on how to improve America's competitiveness.
To a surprising degree, these deep thinkers -- whether left-of-center or right-of-center, partisan or nonpartisan -- have reached a consensus on many prescriptions for America's economic ills. They generally agree that the nation needs to take the following steps.
* Increase savings to provide business with more money to invest in buildings and machines that increase productivity and living standards.
* Step up efforts to train American workers so they can adapt to the technologies and more flexible factories of tomorrow.
* Get companies to think long-term so they will make the strategic investments in equipment, training and research needed to compete with the Japanese and Germans.
* Rein in health-care spending, which puts a heavy burden on American industry and now accounts for 13 percent of the nation's gross domestic product, about double Japan's level.
* Spend more on research and development so that industry not only maintains its lead in innovation but also improves its ability to turn ideas into hot-selling products.
* Invest more in public structures like highways, bridges, railways and airports, which will raise productivity by reducing transportation delays and costs.
"Our greatest problem has been this nation's inability or unwillingness to adequately invest in our future productivity," said Robert B. Reich, a professor at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, whose book "The Work of Nations" examines competitiveness. "If we have an adequately educated and trained work force and a state-of-the-art infrastructure linking them together and with the rest of the world, then global capital will come here to create good jobs. If we don't, the only way global capital will be invested here is if we promise low wages."
As the economic slump extends from months to years, Americans worry increasingly that the nation requires not short-term fixes, but long-term prescriptions. Bruised by recession and foreign competition, G.M., I.B.M. and other stalwarts of Corporate America are laying off thousands of workers, helping to create a palpable eagerness to cure the competitiveness malady before more high-paying jobs vanish.
Evidence of the illness is everywhere. The weekly wages of the average American factory worker have fallen 9 percent since 1973. In recent years, productivity -- the key to improved living standards -- has grown at one-third the 1960's rate and one-quarter the Japanese rate, although America still leads the world in output per worker. Japan has certainly taken note of America's woes, with its leaders calling American workers lazy and illiterate. As the Presidential campaign gathers steam, protectionist pressures are mushrooming, a tacit admission that many industries have fallen behind.
At the same time, bridges and roads are crumbling, partly because the nation spends a far smaller fraction of gross domestic product on infrastructure than do Japan and Germany. Although Japan has half the population of the United States, its corporations invest more in absolute terms on the plants and equipment that lift a nation's productivity and living standards.
In the Annual Economic Report of the President issued last Wednesday, the President's economic advisers sounded the alarm: "Quite simply, without adequate productivity growth, America's standard of living will neither keep pace with the expectations of our citizens, nor remain the highest in the world."
 
Ideas From the Gurus
 The competitiveness gurus have made dozens of other suggestions. A few want a forthright industrial policy to build the industries of tomorrow, like superconductors. Some call for lowering the dollar further to lift exports, while others want to steer more students away from paper-pushing professions like law and toward careers more closely connected to competitiveness, like engineering.
As for what business should do, most experts say industry should put more emphasis on quality and reliability and speed up the process of getting products to market. They also say industry should be ready to customize products far more and have flexible manufacturing techniques to accomplish this. Many experts say companies should stop treating workers like discardable raw materials and involve them more in the company.
On the education front, experts stress improving primary and secondary education, especially in math and science. Others say far more has to be done to train high-school dropouts so that they can make a bigger contribution to the economy.
"The workers who drop out of school, who hardly get into the labor force, they're a tremendous drain on the future," said Robert Eisner, an economist at Northwestern University. "Productivity can be greatly improved if we train them properly."
Probably the biggest frustration for competitiveness experts is that so many recommendations go nowhere in Washington. Many complain that politicians within the Beltway are just as short-term oriented as Corporate America, caring far more about the state of the union this November than 10 Novembers hence. They also grouse that the recent generation of Dr. Feelgood politicians has refused to call for sacrifices like higher taxes.
"Politicians really underestimate the American public," said Felix Rohatyn, an investment banker with Lazard Freres, who has written numerous articles on revitalizing the economy. "Everyone knows what's required. . . . Too many politicians have given up on talking substance to people, especially when it involves some limited sacrifice."
Many economists were heartened that in his State of the Union address, President Bush talked at length about strengthening the nation's long-term prospects. Many praised his plan to increase outlays for non-military research and development 7 percent over last year, but most said his competitiveness proposals were just baby steps.
Economists often say one factor is at the heart of all the problems: Americans prefer to consume today rather than save money to be invested for tomorrow.
America seems trapped in a vicious circle because sluggish income growth over the last two decades has made families save less and borrow more in a desperate effort to maintain living standards. The catch is that a low savings rate makes it harder to increase living standards.
Japan's net household savings in 1990 were 14.3 percent of disposable income, and Germany's were 13.9 percent; both dwarfed America's 4.7. This largely explains why in recent years Japan's and Germany's investment as percentage of G.D.P. and productivity growth have far exceeded America's.
Most economists say one crucial way to lift savings and investment would be to slash the Federal budget deficit. But in an election year, President Bush and Congress seem intent on sweeping this gigantic problem under the rug. Many economists expect the deficit to soar to a record $400 billion this year and next year, up from $269 billion in 1991.
Last week, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, sternly warned the President and Congress that the deficit was an "insidious" and "corrosive" force that eroded savings and competitiveness. "I don't think you could overemphasize the importance of savings in this country as a crucial element involved in restoring the degree of long-term growth that we would all be comfortable with," he said.
According to most economists, the budget deficits and the low savings rate of the 1980's pushed up interest rates, helping to make the cost of capital higher than in Japan. That means American companies need a faster return on their investments, which makes them more short-term oriented.
"I don't believe Americans are genetically more short-term oriented than anyone else, but we have created things to force us to be short-sighted," said Clyde Prestowitz, a Reagan Administration trade official who is president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington-based think tank. "Requiring quarterly profit reports, when neither the Germans nor Japanese do, helps make us focus more on the short-term."
Mr. Prestowitz noted that the chairman of Toshiba, the Japanese electronics giant, once said he was prepared to lose money for 10 years to develop flat-screen displays, which will be crucial to many major products of tomorrow, like high-definition television. "No American executive can say that," he said.
To make American business more long-term oriented, Mr. Prestowitz proposed giving shares owned by long-term shareholders more voting power. To increase the time horizons of investors and executives, Professor Reich suggested a much lower capital gains rate for investors holding assets for more than six years. President Bush took a step in that direction by proposing that assets held three years be taxed at a lower rate than those held one year.
In his new book, "Short-Term America," Michael T. Jacobs, a former Treasury official in the Bush Administration, argues that Corporate America would become less short-term oriented if banks were allowed to become major shareholders in industry. This system would make shareholders more knowledgeable and involved, he said, adding that more knowledge means less risk. Less risk, he said, means investors would provide capital at lower costs, which would lengthen the corporation's time horizon. He added that making shareholders more knowledgeable about management's strategy would also make them more patient about results.
"If you have no clue as to what's going on in strategy and feel there is nothing you can do if management messes up, then you have to look for outward measures to know if your money is being invested properly," he said. "That is one reason American investors rely so much on quarterly reports."
While competitiveness experts agree on many measures, there are sizzling disputes over others. President Bush's proposal to cut capital-gains taxes has sparked the hottest debate. He insists it will create an investment boom, but many Democrats in Congress say these cuts will be a windfall for the rich and will barely spur investment.
 
Who Will Pay?
 Another huge debate is on how to finance increased spending on education and infrastructure. Many conservatives back a spending cap on discretionary Federal programs. "If they prevented Federal spending from rising by 4 to 5 percent a year, that would free up $50 billion a year," said Martin Anderson, an economist at the Hoover Institution.
But some economists say that once the current downturn ends, the Government should raise taxes to finance needs like improved schools. Advocates of higher taxes often note that in the United States, taxes represent a lower share of G.D.P. than in any other major industrial nation. "Higher taxes and more homework -- that's my platform," said Charles Schultze, a Brookings Institution economist. "That might not get me elected, but that's what America needs."
Mr. Rohatyn, the investment banker, said cuts in military spending resulting from the end of the cold war should provide plenty of money for programs to increase competitiveness. He also suggests a 50-cent-a-gallon increase in the gasoline tax, still be far below the taxes in many European countries. The increase would not only raise $50 billion a year, but would promote conservation, reduce oil imports and cut the trade deficit.
Mr. Rohatyn also proposes that the Government pump $25 billion into the banking system by buying non-voting stock. This would help end the credit crunch that is prolonging the recession and provide money for long-term modernization. President Franklin D. Roosevelt did the same thing to shore up the banking system, and after the banks regained their health, the Government sold its shares at a profit.
It is of course possible that all these proposals, timid or bold, will fall flat in Washington. For the last 12 years, the Reagan and Bush Administrations have for the most part taken a laissez-faire approach, believing corporations do best with a minimum of interference. But the five Democrats running for President say the time is ripe for Washington to become involved.
Who wins in November will in large part determine how aggressively the Government attacks these problems.
 
 
POTATO CHIPS OR MICROCHIPS?
 To some experts, an essential part of closing the competitiveness gap is to adopt an explicit industrial policy, where Washington openly aids industries considered vital for the future through research grants and other support.
These experts say America is competing with one hand tied behind its back, asserting that Japan and other countries have potent industrial policies. "Domestically we don't have a policy regarding the structure of our economy," said Clyde Prestowitz, a Reagan Administration trade official who now heads the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington think tank. "The attitude is, 'Computer chips, potato chips, they're no different.' "
Mr. Prestowitz much prefers computer chips, saying Washington should strengthen industries that add a lot of value, bring in export revenues and pay high salaries.
Advocates say America has an implicit industrial policy. Heavy funding for military research has made American arms makers the world's best. Tax breaks have favored commercial real estate. Subsidies help keep farmers in business. "We have an agricultural extension service," said Mr. Prestowitz. "Why can't we have a technological extension service."
Free-market economists worry that an industrial policy would have a heavy-handed Washington deciding which companies live or die. And if it does to electronics what it has done to commercial real estate, they say, it won't be doing anyone any favors.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Altered Outlook on Interest

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Last week three events, one in Germany and two in Washington, altered the near-term outlook for interest rates and stocks. As a result, rates will not be cut soon in Europe and rates may decline further in the United States.
Some analysts were not surprised by the latest developments. But, obviously, many investors were expecting something else. This was clear in the recent strong performance of the dollar, the rise of interest rates here and the rally of some stock markets in Europe. 
 In Germany and Europe, hopes were dashed for an early easing of interest rates by the German central bank, the Bundesbank. Recent rallies of the dollar and some stock markets were attributed in part to the expectation of a cut in short-term rates soon, maybe even by May or June.
In the United States, the result was the opposite. There is now a new chance for a further easing of short-term interest rates here, an expectation that many in the market had abandoned in the last month because of comments by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan.
For investors this means that European stock markets should be in for some corrections. For Americans, the dollar should be weaker against European currencies, which means that if they are selling European stocks in the near future, their gains from abroad could be enhanced.
"In the short term we have to be cautious" about corrections in European stock markets, said Nigel Rendell, an international economist for James Capel Inc. in London.
By Friday, the dollar was down 3.4 percent last week against the German mark. In London, the Financial Times Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares fell 2.1 percent during the week. The French CAC index of 40 shares was down seven-tenths of 1 percent, and the German DAX index of 30 shares was up just a fraction.
The event in Germany that changed investment prospects was the settlement without a strike of the wage negotiations between the steel industry and its union. The wage agreement of 6.4 percent for the year was higher than some had hoped. If this increase were matched in other negotiations now in progress, wages would rise this year much more than the Bundesbank wants. Helmut Schlesinger, the Bundesbank president, made this clear in a news conference on Friday. "It would be very critical if the steelworkers' wage agreement should be the benchmark for the 1992 pay round," he warned.
This wage development, the Bundesbank's concern about inflation and the continued rapid growth of the money supply all point to no quick easing in interest rates. Some analysts are even talking of another increase.
In the United States, the pivotal events were new comments from Mr. Greenspan followed on Friday by the announcement of an unexpected decline in nonfarm payroll jobs. In his testimony to Congress early in the week, Mr. Greenspan went out of his way to emphasize that the Federal Reserve would, if it deemed necessary, push short-term interest rates lower to assure an economic recovery in the United States.
This new emphasis changed the conventional wisdom, which had held since testimony by Mr. Greenspan on Jan. 10 that the Fed had reached the end of this round of easing.
Last month's rallies in stocks and the dollar suggest that investors were pinning too much hope on the steel negotiations in Germany and focusing too much on comments by Mr. Greenspan that he thought the Fed had already cut interest rates enough to spark a recovery.
"We had thought that the market had become misguided as to what the standards and criteria were for the Bundesbank by assuming that the wage settlement was the be-all and the end-all," said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers. "The markets had become too optimistic."
Mr. Lipsky said the Bundesbank was worried about much more than the wage settlements. And the signals it was giving in these other areas, including the growth of the money supply and credit, already provided indications that a near-term easing of interest rates was not likely.
In addition, Mr. Lipsky said that Mr. Greenspan had indicated a willingness to ease further in other recent testimony.
"In recent appearances the media and the markets have only seen the first part of his statement and have interpreted what he was saying as no more Fed easing and ignoring the second part of the formula," Mr. Lipsky said. "In Tuesday's testimony it seemed that Mr. Greenspan wanted to see that both statements were heard and heeded."
While last week's events alter the near-term outlook, Mr. Lipsky said he still expected interest rates in Europe to be falling by the end of the year, which would give a lift to the dollar and stock markets.
Mr. Lipsky said that even if German wage settlements average 6 percent, which would be below last year's average of 6.7 percent, this should not choke off a decline in interest rates but just slow it down. He said such wage settlements should allow inflation, which is now 4 percent, to fall as low as 3 percent by the end of the year.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Canada's Mr. Fix-It

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
"Run it past Maz," they say when anyone wants to get anything done in Ottawa. Maz is Donald Mazankowski, the Finance Minister, Deputy Prime Minister and chief operating officer of the Tory Government -- the man now charged with energizing a palsied Canadian economy.
Although his hands are tied by weak tax revenues and rising bills for welfare and the unemployed, the 56-year-old Minister of Everything -- as he is also sometimes known -- showed a little of his stuff last week when he and his like-minded boss, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, approved a sharp cut in minimum down payments for first-time home buyers. 
 That action, which costs the Government no money, could raise housing starts by at least 15 percent, builders said, not only providing work for the depressed construction industry but spurring demand for washer-dryers, bedroom sets, rugs, curtains and other goods that fill new homes.
A small-town boy from northern Alberta who got his start in small business and used to work in a hardware store, Mr. Mazankowski now stands behind the biggest -- and emptiest -- cash register in the country as he prepares a budget for the new fiscal year that he insists must avoid any further rise in the deficit. "He's looking for novel ways of stimulating without departing from the framework of fiscal austerity," said his press secretary, Tom Van Dusen.
One of the other ideas, which has echoes in the United States, is to permit withdrawals from Canada's equivalent of individual retirement accounts for first-time home purchases.
Also being run favorably past Maz is a plan that has been around for some years to build an eight-mile causeway and bridge across Northumberland Strait, establishing for the first time a fixed link between Canada's smallest province, Prince Edward Island, and the mainland. Mr. Mazankowski, who many say could be a future Prime Minister, figures that over the long term the Government would save by building the bridge because it would be relieved of subsidizing ferry service.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
'Thrilled Beyond Belief'

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
The Beach Boys sang, Henry Kravis danced disco and waiters in surfing garb offered White Castle burgers and peanut-butter-and-jelly sandwiches. Thus -- with food from the 50's, music from the 60's, dance steps from the 70's and celebrities from the 80's -- did the FMR Corporation introduce Worth, its magazine for the 90's, last Wednesday at Roseland in New York City.
FMR, the parent of Fidelity Investments, the giant mutual fund company, has put $20 million of its own money into the venture, and its chairman, Edwin C. Johnson 3d, was at the party, boasting and beaming over what he called his "new baby." 
 But the man of the hour, resplendent in a royal-and-orange Hawaiian print blazer with coordinating ascot and baseball cap, was W. Randall Jones, the 36-year-old former publisher of Esquire and now the chief executive of Worth.
In a day-after interview, Mr. Jones pronounced it a wonderful party, one in which Mr. Kravis and Robert Trump, Donald's brother, could "have fun in the same room" with unknown media planners. "And I have been thrilled beyond belief at the response to the magazine," he added. "Everyone at the least admires our courage for launching a magazine in this economy -- and, at the best, is mesmerized by the first issue."
According to its birth certificate -- the party press kit -- Worth is a personal finance magazine aimed at "leading-edge baby boomers who want to take control of their financial destinies."
The maiden issue featured a look at stock index funds, concluding that a low-fee Vanguard fund was a better deal than a Fidelity rival. But a piece on the boom in baseball card collecting did not mention that Fidelity funds have been big investors in Score Board, which sells baseball cards and collector kits.
