HEADLINE: Britain's Low-Profile Publishing Giant

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Ask securities analysts what they think of Reed International P.L.C. and many quickly say they like what the British company is not: a publishing giant dominated by one person.
That is understandable, given the collapse of Robert Maxwell's empire and the dire financial straits from which Rupert Murdoch's conglomerate is now emerging. Reed has spent more than $4 billion in the last six years on more than 100 acquisitions of consumer magazine, book, giveaway newspaper and information companies to become one of the world's largest publishers. While it often paid what seemed like high prices, it has not suffered from indigestion, let alone choked on the meal, despite recessions in its main markets, Britain and the United States. 
 Reed has even picked off pieces from the stricken Maxwell and Murdoch empires. In October, it paid the Maxwell Communication Corporation $145 million for directories, including Who's Who in America and a variety of business and professional listings. In 1989, Reed paid $825 million for Mr. Murdoch's Travel Information Group, which supplies hotel booking information to travel agents and corporate customers and also owns travel industry trade journals.
And Peter J. Davis, Reed's chairman and chief executive, is tentatively interested in yet another course: the bankrupt Maxwell Communication's Official Airline Guides, the dominant supplier of airline-schedule information to travel agents and computerized reservations systems in the United States.
"We would possibly be interested at the right price," he said. "That's quite a qualified possibly." Caution, in fact, is his watchword. Mr. Davis is proud that Reed allowed itself to be outbid by about $300 million for Official Airline Guides in 1988, when Mr. Maxwell paid what in hindsight was an astronomical $750 million.
Most Americans and Britons have probably never heard of Reed even though it is a major force in their countries. But Mr. Davis, pointing to all the entrepreneurs and financiers who built business empires in the go-go 1980's only to collapse in the 1990's, says he has no apologies about the low-profile "professional managers" who run Reed.
Reed delegates a lot of authority to operating companies but maintains tight central financial and strategic controls, he said, often installing its own financial executives in new acquisitions.
"It's not an ego-driven company," said Peter Bart, editorial director of Variety and Daily Variety, the two American entertainment trade publications Reed purchased in 1987. "The annual budget sessions at Reed are vastly more complex, detailed and strategically oriented than the other companies where I've worked," said Mr. Bart, who has been at three major film studios.
Unlike the Maxwell and Murdoch empires, Reed has been wary of taking on too much debt. Before making its acquisitions, it raised cash by divesting a slew of mostly nonpublishing businesses. As of Sept. 30, net debt -- that is, gross debt minus cash -- totaled 489 million ($855 million) or about 37 percent of equity. "The balance sheet is not under any pressure at all," said Terry Connor, an analyst at Smith New Court Securities Ltd.
At Reed, executives talk as much about the importance of maintaining a high credit rating and interest coverage -- how many times earnings cover interest payments -- as about the importance of products.
Mr. Davis, who is 50, says it is no coincidence that Reed almost never makes a public, let alone hostile, takeover bid. What Reed likes to do is take its own quiet time to assure itself that it knows just what it's buying. It may be no coincidence that an acquisition for which analysts still think Reed paid too much was a rare exception to the rule: the $840 million 1987 purchase of Britain's Octopus Publishing Group.
Some analysts, however, accuse Reed of being an unfocused conglomerate. For example, in the United States, Reed's Cahners Publishing Company is the leader in specialty trade and technical journals, with 69 publications as diverse as Variety and Modern Materials Handling. Cahners also has a growing stable of consumer magazines: the 13 include American Baby and Sail. Other American businesses include Martindale-Hubbell, whose Law Directory provides biographical information and ratings on more than 800,000 lawyers, and R.R. Bowker, publisher of Books in Print.
In Britain, Reed is the biggest publisher of consumer magazines as well as giveaway newspapers. It also owns a slew of directories, career guides and trade magazines, several of which are published in other European countries. Its ABC International is the biggest publisher of airline-schedule information outside the United States.
The usually congenial Mr. Davis bristles at the charges that Reed is unfocused, especially considering its past. Founded in the 1890's as a paper maker, Reed had by the late 1970's expanded into packaging, publishing, paint and wallpaper, bathroom fixtures and even wine. But it was foundering. So its leaders first decided to focus on paper, packaging and publishing, and then, in the mid-1980's, on publishing and information.
A sales and marketing expert who had worked at J. Sainsbury P.L.C., the British supermarket and home-improvement retailer, and the General Foods Corporation, Mr. Davis has overseen the second phase. Recruited to balance Reed's financially oriented executive ranks, he joined Reed in March 1986 as deputy chief executive and became chief executive the following November.
Besides not being too dependent on one market, he sees Reed continuing to expand in niche publications, whether they be regional newspapers, specialty business magazines or consumer magazines. "What advertisers are increasingly looking for are carefully targeted specific distribution media," he said. Advertising accounts for about 40 percent of Reed's revenues.
Already the world's largest organizer of trade exhibitions, Reed has also used customer lists from its businesses and others to develop data bases that can offer direct-mail advertisers clearly defined audiences.
The company's pre-tax profits have soared, by 120 percent over four years, to 302 million ($498.3 million) for the year ended March 31, 1990. In the same period, operating profit margin (profits before taxes, interest and exceptional items as a percent of sales) grew to 17.6 percent from 8.6 percent. (The economic downturns in the United States and Britain did cause pre-tax profits to dip in the last fiscal year, to $388.4 million on revenues of $2.77 billion. Analysts expect earnings to be flat or down slightly this fiscal year.)
Given these results, some analysts are reluctant to proclaim the transformation of Reed a smash success just yet. The stock, having touched a high of 6.20 a share in London in the heady mid-80's on speculation that Mr. Murdoch might try to buy the company, then plunged, has been trending up since late 1990 to a current level of about 5.25 ($9.55).
"It's a well-run company," said Mr. Connor of Smith New Court. "But like every other international publishing company, over the longer term they have to demonstrate that growth can come from more than acquisitions or growth in the economies they're in. They have yet to demonstrate the operating synergies between their various businesses."
Analysts also note that Reed's leaders have made some expensive detours, like subscription television in Britain, in their pursuit of a focused strategy. Reed had owned 20.9 percent of British Satellite Broadcasting and now has a 3.7 percent stake in British Sky Broadcasting, the product of the 1990 merger of B.S.B. and Mr. Murdoch's Sky Television. Last year, Reed took a charge to cover its $94.6 million investment in the venture.
Louise Barton of London-based Henderson Crosthwaite Institutional Brokers Ltd. echoes other analysts in praising the quality of Reed's management. But she worries that it is being spread too thin by its acquisitions. She also questions the strategic fit of consumer publishing, especially consumer books, Octopus's main business, and regional newspapers. "There's no synergy with the rest of the group. And they are mature, highly competitive businesses," she said.
But Mr. Davis says he has no intentions of selling these businesses. He also insists that Reed has already demonstrated its ability to improve the performance of acquisitions by reducing their costs, expanding their product lines, taking them international and offering their information electronically.
Such steps have enabled the Travel Information Group's operating profits to increase by about 60 percent since Reed acquired it in mid-1989, while Martindale-Hubbell's have doubled since it was purchased two years ago, Ms. Barton estimates.
At the Travel Information Group, Reed has come out with an international edition of its mainstay hotel directory, the Hotel & Travel Index, which before had only been sold in the United States, and further expanded the group's electronic distribution system.
When Reed bought Martindale-Hubbell, none of its information was available electronically. Now, the Law Directory is available on Mead Corporation's Lexis electronic network and on compact disks.
Britain accounts for about half of Reed's profits and revenues, a share Mr. Davis sees falling to 35 to 40 percent in five years or so as contributions from the United States, continental Europe and the Asia-Pacific region rise.
Reed could manage another big acquisition without lowering its interest coverage too much, he says. But in Europe at least, it has been rebuffed by several publishing companies, including Britain's Pearson P.L.C. and Elsevier of the Netherlands. "We haven't found either the right major acquisition or the right alliance although we would still like to," Mr. Davis said.
 
 
 
IMAGE-BEARING TRAVEL ADS
 The number of companies that distribute information via computer may be soaring, but advertisers eager to have potential customers see pictures of their products have all but ignored electronic publishers. That may now be changing due to technology like laser disks, digital compact disks and high-resolution computer screens.
In the worldwide travel industry, only two of the main computerized reservation systems used by agents to book hotels, flights, cruises and rental cars now enable advertisers to display pictures and maps on agents' screens. They are American Airlines' Sabre and Worldspan, whose main owners are Delta Air Lines, Northwest and Trans World Airlines. Apollo, the system owned by United, USAir, Air Canada and four European airlines, plans to begin offering maps, but not pictures, in June.
Less than $10 million a year is spent to advertise on reservation systems, but image-bearing ads already count for about half of that, estimates Samuel C. Wolgemuth, an executive at Reed International P.L.C., which sells the ads to Sabre. "As image ads catch on over the next five years, the total will jump 10-fold," he predicted.
The enhanced Sabre line -- Sabrevision -- was introduced in October 1990, more than a year after Worldspan's Iris, or integrated reservations and imaging system. But Sabrevision is in more than 1,600 travel agencies in the United States, Canada and the Carribean. Iris is in 315. One Sabrevision advantage is that its compact-disk player can be linked to up to 15 personal computers. The Iris laser-disk system, unlike Sabrevision, offers motion pictures and sound but needs a dedicated terminal.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Endangered: Retiree Health Benefits

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
IT would be perfectly understandable if Harold S. Share expressed some bitterness about nearly being done out of his retirement health benefits by the bankruptcy of the Federated-Allied department stores. "There is no shortage of villains," said Mr. Share, a former vice president at an Allied Stern's store in Paramus, N.J., but he said his place of employment was not among them.
"It was the excess of the 80's manifesting itself. It was Campeau and the people who provided him money," Mr. Share said, a bit of heat creeping into his voice when he referred to Robert Campeau, the quintessential financial buccaneer of the 1980's who at one point owned Federated and Allied. "It was not the management of the stores." 
 The saga of Federated Department Stores and the Allied Stores Corporation -- at $8.2 billion, it was and remains one of the most expensive nonbanking bankruptcies ever -- has wound its way to an apparently happy denouement. Mr. Campeau is long since out of the picture and last Wednesday, the stores, which include Bloomingdale's, Bon Marche and Jordan Marsh, emerged with a reorganization plan.
A small piece of that plan pertains to Mr. Share, who as the unpaid head of the Official Retirees Committee represented some 6,400 nonunionized employees, from clerks to senior executives, who retired before Federated-Allied entered Chapter 11 in January 1990. After 13 months of negotiating, Mr. Share and his committee reached a compromise with the department stores that preserved a semblance of the retirees' health benefits.
The Federated-Allied dispute emerged from one of the iron laws of business: companies, especially companies in mortal peril, will trim costs where they can. As times and hardball tactics grow harder, benefits of all types for all employees, past and present, have become fair game. A General Accounting Office study last year of 40 troubled companies found that nearly half ended benefits for some 91,000 employees. Nine million retirees are enrolled in health plans that could be terminated.
In the Federated-Allied bankruptcy, the company insisted it had the right to modify or end the health benefits offered to retirees -- as it did with current employees and post-bankruptcy retirees. "The pre-bankruptcy retirees argued they should be insulated from the changing costs of health care," said Glen D. Nager, a partner at Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue in Washington, which represented Federated-Allied.
The retirees argued that modifications could turn into de facto terminations because of rising costs or reduced benefits.
The two parties stayed at the bargaining table, through thickening and thinning patience, as mandated by Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Cincinnati, where Federated is based. According to both sides in the negotiations, the retirees' settlement represented persistence and ingenuity, in court and at the table.
In October, Judge Aug ruled against the retirees' argument that their benefits were vested for life, a decision that may clarify a provision of the bankruptcy code designed to protect retiree benefits.
But pivotal action took place around the table where, the sides agree, there were two crucial moments. One occurred when the retirees suggested that rather than continue haggling over restricting changes in the dozens of plans offered, the company make a "defined contribution" to a trust fund that would be administered independently.
The second came after a period of wrangling over how the fund would be administered, when the company accepted a proposal to establish a VEBA, or voluntary employee benefits association, a trust that provides tax benefits and a degree of insulation for the retirees from the potential vagaries of Federated-Allied's future.
In the settlement approved by Judge Aug 10 days ago, Federated agreed to make quarterly payments totaling $80 million over 50 years into the VEBA. The pact takes inflation and rising health care costs into account.
Mr. Nager of Jones, Day thinks the retirees did very well for themselves, at his client's expense. Their desire to protect themselves was reasonable, he says, but so was Federated-Allied's attempt to be responsible to creditors. "Sometimes solutions have to come from other sources than the company in Chapter 11," he said.
Mr. Share says the retirees will get about 42 percent less in benefits than they did before the bankruptcy -- but about 50 percent more than the the post-petition retirees get now. The best part, he says, is that "we are in control of our own destiny."
 
 
 
A SOMETIMES CHILLING END TO BENEFITS
 During its epic bankruptcy in 1986, the LTV Corporation created a pension and benefit milestone by declining to put retirees before other creditors. Since then, despite protective legislation -- passed and in progress -- retiree benefits are not the sure thing they once were. David Certner, a pension specialist at the American Association of Retired Persons, says retirees in general are being asked to assume more of the cost of health care. "A bankruptcy speeds up the process of pushing costs back on the retirees," he said.
The scope and suddeness of a turn in retiree fortunes can be breathtaking. When Pan American World Airways went bankrupt in December after a deal with Delta Air Lines collapsed, more than 20,000 retirees and their dependents were suddenly left without health benefits.
"The retirees' committee is scrambling to find the money for those who aren't insurable," said Kevin Burke, a lawyer at Cahill Gordon & Reindel who is working on the Pan Am and Federated bankruptcies. "We're not even sure how many there are yet."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Mr. Yacktman's 10-Year Horizon

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Donald A. Yacktman, who manages the $700 million Selected American Shares fund, based in Chicago, has consistently beaten his peers by 4 percentage points a year. For the three years that ended on Dec. 31, for instance, Selected American Shares rose an annual average of 19.1 percent, compared with 15 percent for all growth-and-income funds. The fund gained an annual average of 15.6 percent in the last five years and 18.8 percent in the last decade.
In 1991, the fund's gains were particularly strong -- it rose 46.3 percent compared with 29.3 percent for all growth-and-income funds. But even more impressive is how Mr. Yacktman did it. "He buys bigger blue-chip value-oriented companies but managed to turn in a terrific showing in a year that favored small, go-go growth stocks," said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc., a mutual fund research group. Mr. Phillips calls Selected American Shares "a solid, all-weather fund." 
 How does Mr. Yacktman manage to shine in good markets and bad? "I don't worry about predicting where inflation, the stock market, the economy or interest rates are going because you can't control them," he said. "But you can put a value on a business and then buy it at a discount."
Mr. Yacktman looks for companies in "good businesses" with "shareholder-friendly management." A good business, in his estimation, is one with a high return on tangible assets, few fixed assets and high turnover of products and services.
As for shareholder-friendly management, he looks at what a company does with its cash. The best use of cash, he says, is re investing in the core business or making acquisitions that fit well with the existing operation. He also likes managements that buy back shares because "they generally buy their own business at a discount to its true market value." [The contrary view, in Wall Street, page 15.]
As for dividends, he said, "the smaller, the better." As he explained it, a good chief executive should be able to do a better job of recycling cash than an individual investor. Worse than paying high dividends in many cases, he thinks, is paying down debt, which reduces the return on assets. But the least desirable course is to sit on the cash.
After finding good management, Mr. Yacktman turns his attention to price. He looks for low price-earnings ratios and buys shares "when the market is unhappy with the stock," usually for one of three reasons: an overall market decline, worries about a company's product or future, or a short-term problem that the market views as long term. In 10 years, he expects a stock to be worth 5 or 10 times what he pays for it. Three examples of cases in the last decade are General Mills, RJR Nabisco and Philip Morris.
Mr. Yacktman, who is 50 years old, grew up in Salt Lake City and began investing when he was still a student at the University of Utah, where he studied economics and engineering. After attending Harvard Business School, he worked for the investment firm of Stein Roe for 14 years, then left to join a small brokerage firm in Chicago. In late 1982, he took over the venerable Selected American Shares, which was set up in 1933.
Mr. Yacktman's investment style is slow and steady. He works with a decade-long horizon, so it is not surprising that in 1991 the fund's turnover ratio -- the amount of stocks replaced in the fund -- was only 21 percent. That compares with a turnover ratio of more than 90 percent for the average stock fund.
The fund can be fully invested or can hold as much as one-quarter of its assets in cash, and the average cash position is about 5 percent. Because Mr. Yacktman often buys shares when the market is down -- at the same time disenchanted mutual fund investors often sell -- he insisted on an unusual provision in the fund's rules: instead of selling fund holdings to meet investor redemptions, he can borrow money to do so. But he lets cash build if he cannot find acceptable stocks to buy. "I'm better off earning 4 percent on the money than losing it," he said.
Over all, Mr. Yacktman said, the fund earns its returns "on some very big long-term gainers while the worst stocks tend to be break-evens."
As of the end of 1991, the fund's biggest sectors were financial services (16.4 percent), health care (12.5 percent), food (10 percent) and tobacco (9.5 percent). The largest holding is Freddie Mac, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, which Mr. Yacktman bought in late 1989, about a year after the Goverment-owned corporation went public.
The fund's second-largest holding is RJR Nabisco, which Mr. Yacktman has owned in one form or another for more than 10 years. He said that while he does not endorse the use of tobacco, "it's a license to print money," creating a very profitable business, and the company is also strong in its food business.
Next comes Capital Cities/ABC, whose stock bobbed up and down last year because of analysts' concerns about the strength of the network television business. Mr. Yacktman, however, says the company "makes most of its money at the station level."
That is followed by Time Warner, which he says is suffering a "media hangover problem" even though its cable television, music and movie businesses are profitable.

HEADLINE: All About/Conference Centers;
Shorter Meetings on Short Notice Are the Rule

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Talk may be cheap, but not if you consider the $54.6 billion generated by the 350,867 meetings, conferences and conventions held last year, according to the International Association of Convention and Visitor Bureaus.
While conventions are the most glamorous part of the meetings market, sometimes involving a trade show and thousands of people, corporate conferences account for about 80 percent of the business. They rarely exceed 100 people and most are devoted to one topic. 
 While the number of conferences probably did not decline much if at all last year, despite the sagging economy and the Persian Gulf war, most were held closer to home and bargaining for lower rates was more common. "What we also saw," said Edwin L. Griffin Jr., chief executive of Meeting Planners, whose 10,500 members include about 4,000 corporate meeting planners, "was not so much fewer meetings but shorter and more intense meetings -- down from about four days to two and three."
Another trend, according to Tom Bolman, executive director of the 165-member International Association of Conference Centers, in Fenton, Mo., is that conferences are being arranged on much shorter notice than in the past with lead times of three months, rather than six months or more.
 
Not Just Motels
Meeting on Ships And at the Airport
 With so much money riding on conferences, it should not be surprising that everyone is getting into the act. Cruise ships are being built with conference rooms and existing ships are being reconfigured to include them. And not only are most airports surrounded by hotels that cater as much to conferences as to weary travelers, but airlines themselves are starting to provide conference sites.
American Airlines, for example, has eight conference rooms at La Guardia Airport in New York and 19 at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago. The rooms, which rent for $35 to $50 an hour, have the usual audio-visual equipment as well as such standard features as controlled lighting, flipcharts and moveable walls.
But 70 percent of all conferences are held in hotels and motels. "Conferences and conventions are the lifeblood of much of the hotel business," said Vivian A. Deuschl, a spokeswoman for the Ritz Carlton Hotel Company. "They affect your occupancy rates, your catering service and your restaurant business."
For that reason Holiday Inns is now aggressively pursuing the conference business, especially at its 53 larger Crowne Plazas. Such business currently accounts for only about 20 percent of the chain's business.
By contrast, hotels in the middle-price range, like Marriotts and Hyatts, bank on at least 30 percent of their business from meetings and often do much better. Last year corporate meetings accounted for 49 percent of the total business at the 23 Ritz Carlton hotels in the United States. At the ITT Sheraton Corporation's 290 hotel operations in North America, meetings accounted for 35 to 40 percent of last year's total business.
"The company tries to hold that percentage to no more than 40," said Pamela Hanlon, an ITT Sheraton vice president, "to avoid becoming overly dependent on a business that is often the first to be eliminated in an economic downturn."
At resort hotels, meetings accounted for $6 billion in 1990, or 43 percent of their total revenue, according to Coopers & Lybrand, an accounting firm. But the recession and the Persian Gulf war cut into that business sharply last year, causing many cancellations and lost bookings. Industry executives do not expect significant improvement before fall.
 
Letting the Public in
A Source of Business For the Weekends
 Most conference centers expect 1992 to be better than last year, when business was O.K. but not robust. Most of the approximately 300 centers survived the general economic downturn as well as they did because they were designed to accommodate small group meetings and thus were well positioned for the smaller, regional meetings that are now popular.
Conference centers, which generate some $3.5 billion in annual revenues, according to the accounting firm of Pannell Kerr Forster, range in size from 32 guest rooms (the Beaver Hollow Lodge and Conference Center in Java Center, N.Y.) to 400 guest rooms and four suites (the DFW Hilton Executive Conference Center in Grapevine, Tex.).
Many centers are open to the public on weekends. The Doral Arrowwood, a 274-room resort conference center set amid 114 acres of hills and fairways in New York's Westchester County does a strong outside business. The Radisson Corporation is also looking to do a brisk business with the public at the Scanticon-Minneapolis in Plymouth, Minn., whose management it took over six months ago (and renamed the Radisson Hotel and Conference Center -- Minneapolis).
Many corporate conference centers are closed to the general public, including those owned by Whirlpool, Motorola, American Express, Merck & Company and S.C. Johnson & Son. The GTE Management Development Center in Norwalk, Conn., is also closed to the public, but portions of the center are rented to Xerox and Champion.
The Chase Development Center in Wall Street -- owned and operated by the Chase Manhattan Bank Corporation -- also rents to other corporations, including Metropolitan Life, J. P. Morgan and many investment bankers. Some 75,000 people use the center each year, according to Virginia Stott, its managing director, and outside renters account for as much as 35 percent of the total during the peak meeting months of May and June and September through November. "Renting the center helps defray the operating costs," said Ms. Stott.
Without overnight accommodations, the Chase center charges $118 a day per person, including meals, conference rooms and amenities. The average meeting at the center lasts three days, Ms. Stott said, and is devoted to professional development. The industry-wide price range at conference centers is $150 to $350 a day.
 
A Campus Setting
Universities Cater To Nonprofit Groups
 The nation's first conference center, Arden House, opened in 1950 on the Harriman, N.Y., campus of Columbia University. Still regarded as one of the very best, with average occupancy of 65 to 70 percent a year, it now has plenty of competition.
In recent years modern conference centers have been built at many campuses, including Duke University, Babson College and the Universities of Alabama, Minnesota, Pennsylvania, Virginia and Wisconsin.
Among the trends reported at not-for-profit conference centers are the growing attendance of foreign executives and the growing number of weekend meetings.
Ten countries were represented among the 20 participants at the Conference Center Management Course at Cornell University last summer. And managers of other conference houses say that foreign executives often make up 25 percent of the participants.
As for weekend meetings, Richard F. Kopacz, general manager of the Arden Conference Center, said that such conferences are increasingly popular for scientific meetings or for conferences sponsored by various departments of Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons. Among other things, Arden has the advantage of being close to Columbia's campus.
 
 
THE FLOATING CONVENTIONS
 The 75,000-ton Monarch of the Seas was christened last November, and already the $300 million ship has been the site of many meetings in its conference center, a wood-paneled room that can accommodate 80 people. When the Monarch's sister ship, Majesty of the Seas, comes on line in April, it will have an identical center.
"If we had made cabins instead of conference rooms, we would have realized in excess of $1 million more on each ship over the first year or two," said LLoyd Axelrod, director of public relations for the Royal Caribbean Cruise Line, which owns the ships.
Mr. Axelrod is quick to point out that the company fully expects to earn more than that $1 million, because the conference business on cruise lines is big and getting bigger. "Over the last three years our conferences and meetings have risen from 6 percent to 10 percent of our overall business," said Lisa Lutoff-Perlo, director of incentive sales for Royal Crown. The typical cruise is three to five days with a group of 50 to 200 people.
All nine ships in the Royal Caribbean fleet have conference centers or conference rooms, and the company has made a major commitment to that market. Just six years ago, only three Royal Caribbean employees sold conventions; today 21 do.
Royal Caribbean is not alone in appreciating the conference market. The $125 million Radisson Diamond, a twin-hulled luxury vessel that debuts in May, already has so many conferences and charters scheduled that to accommodate them it revised several sailing dates that were to be reserved for individual travelers.
The Diamond will feature two conference rooms, a full-sized auditorium with stage, shipboard TV studio for long-distance video conferencing, closed-circuit television, direct-dial phones and a satellite communications system.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Cornell;
Athletes Opposing Decision to Cancel At Least 4 Sports

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y.

 BODY:
Student athletes and coaches at Cornell University say they are angry and frustrated over $600,000 in budget cuts announced by the athletics department last week. Department officials said the cuts would eliminate four intercollegiate sports, force four additional programs to rely entirely on their own fund-raising and require the department to reduce administrative expenses.
"Right now there's a feeling of hopelessness that no matter what you do, it won't work," said Michele Carey, a sophomore on the women's gymnastic team from Marblehead, Mass., who is majoring in English. 
 While the men's and women's gymnastics and fencing teams will cease to exist at the end of the 1992-93 school year, four other programs -- nationally ranked men's and women's equestrian polo; men's lightweight football and men's squash -- will lose their financing this summer, said Laing E. Kennedy, the university's athletics director. Thirty-one men's and women's intercollegiate varsity sports will remain.
More than 50 students will lose their teams and 4 coaches will lose their jobs by 1993 if they cannot be reassigned, the athletics department said.
Athletes and coaches on the teams said they would do whatever they could to keep their programs alive.
 
Fencing's 'Long Tradition'
 Philip T. Rach, the men's gymnastics coach, said he would urge the athletics department to give his team a small part of the gym or allow it to practice at an off-campus site, and to let the team raise its expense money rather than abolish the sport altogether.
Peggy Walbridge, a 1974 Cornell graduate who was the first woman inducted to the university's Athletic Hall of Fame for her success as captain of the women's fencing team, said, "Cornell has a long tradition in men's, and was one of the founders in women's, fencing." Ms. Walbridge, who is the associate director of admissions at Cornell's College of Arts and Sciences, added, "We are trying to contact the wider fencing community to bring pressure on the athletics department."
The reductions that directly affect the teams, which the administration said would save more than $260,000 annually, would be coupled with a $320,000 reduction in administrative costs and physical-education expenses. Cornell also announced plans to increase revenues by $200,000, partly through ticket sales and fees paid, for example, by those who use the campus golf course and ice rink.
The cuts come in the first phase of the athletic department's long-term planning, called Vision 2000, which Mr. Kennedy said had spent more than $50,000 on focus groups, interviews with members of the athletic groups and questionnaires distributed to 6,000 students and alumni.
 
Least Potential for Success
 "Our objective in expense reduction was to affect the fewest possible students, because they represent our highest priority," Mr. Kennedy said. He said that the Cornell Department of Athletics had sought to cut programs that had the fewest participants or the 'least potential' for success against competitors. 'Wins and losses are not everything, but we're not cutting any powerhouses,' he said.
Although the athletics department has spent more than a year collecting data and meeting with the Vision 2000 task force to plan the reductions, those directly affected by the cuts said they had no warning that their athletic careers at Cornell were coming to a close.
"We kind of feel like we're banging our heads against a wall," said Alan Simon, the captain of the men's fencing team and a senior majoring in economics from Rochester.
But the university defended its action and the way it had determined how to trim the $9.4 million budget of the athletics department, which is $450,000 in debt.
Cornell's president, Frank H. T. Rhodes, said the university would gain "a slightly smaller but better athletic department."
"I feel sorry to cut anything on campus," Dr. Rhodes said in an interview last week, "but the athletic department has to make the same kinds of economies that face every part of the campus here." Over the last two years, Cornell's private colleges have cut $10 million from their budgets.

HEADLINE: GARDENING;
Greens to Melons, Potatoes to Tomatoes

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST

 BODY:
VEGETABLE garden planning is at its height. Those who have grown their own for years know what does well. Most important, they know what the family likes or what should be grown in quantity for preserving.
Some gardeners have huge plots and grow just about everything. Others have just enough room for a few vegetables. They delight in homegrown tomatoes or tossing a salad with greens just picked. 
Neophytes may think they have to grow practically every vegetable in the seed catalogue. After all, the illustrated planting plans include space for just about everything that can be grown from seed. Often the commitment is excessive.
Many vegetables can be purchased at local markets, and quite often the quality far exceeds the successes or failures at home. But in these days of economic frugality, some sort of realistic planning must be done. Some vegetables are tricky to grow and best left to the farmers; others are easy crops and fun to grow.
Much depends on the soil conditions and preparation of the vegetable plot. The challenge is a major one, which many thrill to take on. In any case, vegetables require sun, at least four to six hours daily, plus good fertile soil that is well endowed with organic matter and some sort of water supply if there is a drought.
One vegetable that is truly tricky to grow is cauliflower. It requires a cool climate and excellent soil, and it must be blanched to keep the curd white. Another tricky one is celery, which needs the same conditions to maintain its usual crispness. And because it is mostly water, celery needs truly moist soil.
Some vegetables, like pumpkins and watermelons, utilize a lot of space. These are often grown in fields where the vines can ramble. In a home vegetable plot, where space is confined, these crops are often bypassed. Besides, pumpkin shopping is one of the delights for children who like to pick out the best. Similar conditions are true of watermelons, which are a must for those summer picnics.
Potatoes are not as aggressive surface-space users, but the plants do occupy the rows all summer long. Row hilling is vital to keep the potatoes from turning green from the sun.
All these crops could be grown at home, but they are best left to the experts or those who truly enjoy the challenge of growing them. Besides, all these crops are readily available at produce markets in quantity and quality.
At the other end of the spectrum are the easy-to-grow vegetables, the ones that taste best fresh picked for the table. Possibly the favorite grow-at-home vegetable is the tomato. If there is space for only a few plants, then the tomato wins. As long as there are tomato plants in the garden, then plan to grow a few others: salad crops, especially the leaf lettuces, escarole, arugula, mache and even Chinese cabbage. These vegetables are superb for summertime salads, and the ingredients are best when they are fresh from the garden.
Those who want garden-fresh vegetables should save some space for peas. Like sweet corn, this is one vegetable that deteriorates rapidly as soon as it is picked. Now that edible-pod peas have become so popular, the vines are almost a must to include. But remember that peas and spinach are cool-weather crops and should be planted early. March is not too soon, if the ground is open and can be worked.
As long as there is space for a vine or two, plan to have a few cucumber plants. For an early crop, the seed can be started indoors in March and the pots set out in mild weather at two-foot spacing. A few rows of scallions and maybe a row or two of radish could be tucked in at the base of these vines. These are fast-growing and appealing to children, because they can see results quickly.
The tomatoes cannot be planted outdoors until the soil is truly warm, so make space for beans, which will also need warm soil. Beans are very easy to grow, and if seed is planted every two weeks, the crop will continue through most of the summer.
In between are a host of other crops. One of the great summer delights is sweet corn, but the plants are huge and heavy feeders. They take a good supply of nutrients from the soil. Excellent sweet corn is readily available at farm stands.
Other crops that may or may not be part of the home plot are squash, another plant that takes up space, and cantaloupe. Members of the onion family have also been left in between crops like garlic, leeks and onions. And if the soil is heavy, rocky and difficult to work, then leave the root crops -- carrots, turnips and parsnips -- to those who can grow them best.

HEADLINE: Ms. Schattinger, Student, to Wed

 BODY:
Mr. and Mrs. James H. Schattinger of Shaker Heights, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Myers Schattinger, to Alistair Buchan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew S. Buchan of Edinburgh. A September wedding is planned.
Ms. Schattinger, 26 years old, graduated cum laude from Wellesley College and is pursuing an M.B.A. at Dartmouth College. Her father is president of the Pioneer Manufacturing Company, a manufacturer of products for industrial maintenance, in Cleveland. Her mother, Joan Schattinger, is a freelance writer and has written books on the the history of Cleveland. 
 Mr. Buchan, 28, is a senior associate for Barclays Bank PLC in New York. He graduated from the University of Edinburgh, form which he also received a master's degree in economics. His father, who is retired, was the general manager of the Royal Bank of Scotland in Edinburgh.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
A New Old Spider From Alfa Romeo

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
ONE of the nice things about driving lots of cars is that you can get into any vehicle and pretty much know where everything is. Sort of like being a garage attendant.
It doesn't always happen though, and when it doesn't, it is usually because the car is Italian. I was thinking that as I tried to find my way through New York's potholes, wondering also how I was going to drive the 45 miles home without dash lights. 
 The car was a new '92 Alfa Romeo Spider Veloce, a sleek little roadster, bright red, with tan leather bucket seats and a black instrument panel. At that point, of course, the colors didn't matter. It was dead of night and the interior was black from roof to floor.
I felt around, pushed this, twisted that. Finally, I pulled to the curb and searched with a cigarette lighter. Nothing. So I drove home, unable to see the speedometer, following other cars that looked as if they might be traveling somewhere near the speed limit.
It was another instance of what I learned a long time ago, a basic truth about Italian cars. You hate them until you get used to them, and then you say, "Gee, this isn't so bad." In that respect, they are much like jogging or learning to drink scotch, and some things just don't change.
In the Alfa's case, there is not much reason to think they would. The company, owned by Fiat and operating here in a joint venture with Chrysler, has been making the Spider without major renovation since 1966. And while the 26-year lifespan is not a record, it certainly makes the car a contender.
The first Spider carried a carbureted engine, and that lasted for three years, when the big change was fuel injection. Then, in 1971, the long, smooth tail was bobbed, creating a slightly different look.
In 1975, big bumpers were added, and the car went along for 10 years more without change. In '85, Alfa decided enough was enough and, voila, there were more new bumpers, along with a black spoiler. Which brings us to the current Spider, which was "new" for '91.
With this facelift, the roadster now has wider taillamps, a slight flare at the trailing edge of the trunk, a new nose, body-colored bumpers, 15-inch molded wheels, a new interior, and an air bag for the driver. It also has four-wheel power-disk brakes, power steering and a theft-proof radio that won't work without the proper code if it is removed from the car.
But this is still a very old automobile, and it feels that way, both in its controls and in the way it handles. Alfa fudges slightly, but it acknowledges the Spider's length of tooth by describing it as "the last of the great, traditional, open sports cars." And, indeed, it is that, with all the good and bad that the phrase implies.
There are two models, plain Spider and Spider Veloce, and prices range from $21,264 to $24,309, plus options. The tester was of the more expensive persuasion, with full leather seats and suede on the doors. And the doors, as much as anything else, reminded one of how old this car is.
First, the car has no lock-knobs. Instead, you push forward on the door handles as of yore. And then, wonder of wonders, there are real working vent windows! Some of the old stuff isn't so bad.
The glove box is small, but it houses a unique map light on a spring cord. Further oddities include four buttons for the two power windows (two for up and two for down), and manually operated vents, seven of them sprinkled hither and yon, for the air conditioning.
A three-speed automatic transmission is available, but a five-speed stick is standard, and the lever protrudes straight out from the center of the dash. Under it, in the console between the buckets, are various controls and a tiny analog clock, about an inch and a quarter in diameter, with all 60 seconds marked on it. Needless to say, you can't read it.
The four-spoked wheel is leather wrapped but unpadded. It has the typical Italian rake and can't be adjusted, but it is one of those things that you get used to -- and then find endearing. Another less-pleasant weirdness is the shallow trunk, which has no rear lock or latch. It opens with a remote release in the driver's doorjamb, and when you've discovered that, you also discover that 10.3 cubic feet really isn't much space at all.
At the other end, the hood hinges at the front and opens from the cowl below the windshield. Under it is a 2-liter aluminum four that puts out 120 horsepower and 121 foot-pounds of torque. There are twin overhead cams, and the compression ratio is 9-to-1, which means the Spider favors premium fuel.
Still, a fill-up doesn't cost that much, since the tank holds only a tad over 12 gallons, and fuel economy can be considered good, with a rating of 22 miles per gallon, city, and 30, highway.
One reason for that is the light weight of the car's unit-body. The whole package weighs only 2,660 pounds, and that translates into quick acceleration (albeit handicapped by the odd horizontal shifter) and into a cruising speed of 70-plus m.p.h.
Unfortunately, it also translates into a flexible body that bounces, jiggles and lurches on uneven surfaces. Initially, that makes the car less than fun to drive, and it is perhaps the single biggest factor that gives away the Spider's age. But, once again, you do get used to it.
In fact, this is a car that has had relatively steady sales, and Craig Morningstar, an Alfa spokesman, said the annual number generally hovers around 2,000, most of them in the Florida, California and other sunny climes.
As for a replacement, Morningstar said a totally new Spider will be along in late 1993. "If you saw it today," he said, "you'd think it was a concept car. It's very slick."
Considering his position, the hyperbole is understandable, but the car, like those past and present, will be a Pininfarina design, which speaks well for the future. What's certain is that it will be Italian and . . . well, different.
Meanwhile, and in case anybody asks, a Spider's dash lights are controlled by a thumb wheel underneath the instrument panel.

HEADLINE: Men's Movement: Win or Lose?

 BODY:
This most recent discussion of the "emerging men's movement" (Jan. 19) did a fine job of capturing the features of the movement that give me concern.
Why must this activity always be characterized as a win-lose situation for men and women? Most of the recent coverage describes the women's movement as gaining power at the expense of men. Perhaps it is a power that resides within individuals regardless of sex. 
 The type of energy and feeling of well-being experienced by being more in touch with yourself, your kids and the people you work with can increase total energy; it does not necessarily have to subtract from someone else's power and energy. In fact, in my experience, it is when you let go of power and control over others that the sense of well-being begins and increased personal influence with others rises. I believe this phenomenon to be human, not male or female.
I must quickly add some reality to my discussion: make no mistake, there is a women's movement and an emerging men's reaction to it, but the movements are grounded in politics and economics, not the essences of masculinity or femininity. Women are fighting for control of their bodies, an ability to work productively in an environment free of sexual harassment and a political-social system that responds to their needs. But this is no different from any other interest group like unions, the aged and farmers.
What is different is the reaction of men. Face it, we have been dominators, and what we are reacting to is a threat to that domination. I submit that this reaction, however frightening, is also human and should be addressed as a human issue, not a male vs. female issue.
We should be human enough to face these issues head on for what they are, issues of political, economic and individual equality. If we cannot face them and establish a legitimate dialogue with the women's movement, I predict a male siege mentality will be generated, leading to increased frustration in our interpersonal relationships with those we care for and work with.
We men would be better served to really listen, exchange feedback and modify behavior with the ones we love than to be pounding our chests and crawling around on all fours for a weekend in a spurious attempt to get in touch with our primeval roots.
 
STEPHEN C. REXFORD
Westport

HEADLINE: Continued U.S. Embargo Harms Cuba and Ourselves as Well

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Jan. 25 meeting on Cuba at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York City (news article, Jan. 26) focuses a light on one of the blind spots of American foreign policy -- the economic embargo of Cuba. Not only are all items of trade still prohibited, but so is travel to Cuba by United States tourists and even sending medical supplies and other humanitarian aid (with a few exceptions). 
 During the cold war this policy did not make sense. Today, after the cold war's end and the dissolution of the Soviet Union, it is an anachronism. What threat does Cuba offer the United States? On the contrary, our present policy of noncommunication is a threat to the Cuban people, particularly to the Cuban children, toward whom we have no hostility.
Now that Soviet support has been withdrawn, the Cuban people are in a desperate situation. Whether our Government likes President Fidel Castro or not, our policy harms not only Cuba, but also the United States. Resumption of trade with Cuba would no doubt be of commercial benefit to us, not to speak of the desire of United States tourists to visit Cuba and enjoy its weather and facilities.
If there are complaints by some about Cuba's human rights policies, resumption of relations would go a long way to correct that situation by direct diplomatic approaches.
Robert S. McNamara, former Secretary of Defense, has called for a normalization of relations between our countries. His comments followed the final meeting, in Havana, of an American-Russian-Cuban conference series on the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, when he was President Kennedy's defense chief. "If I had been a Cuban or Soviet official, I believe I would have shared the judgment," he told reporters in Washington on returning, "that a U.S. invasion was probable" (news article, Jan. 15).
On United States-Cuban relations today, he is quoted by the Cuba Policy Project of the Nitze School at Johns Hopkins University as saying, "we must get beyond the fear and hostility that has shaped our relations for the past 30 years."
 
ROBERT L. BOEHM
New York, Jan. 27, 1992

HEADLINE: On Viewing Labor as an Asset, Not an Expense

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was disturbed to hear today of yet another major American company announcing large layoffs, presumably, like so many others, to improve productivity and competitiveness in the new, global economy. The new, lean management style for the 1990's is beginning to sound more and more like good old American management methods -- from the 1890's. 
 As so often in the past, American business leaders seem to be learning the wrong lessons. We hear that job security is an outmoded value, which doesn't have a place in the modern world. Is that the lesson we learned from the Japanese? We are asked to accept reductions in benefits as necessary to improve productivity. Do the Germans have inferior employee benefits? Productivity is the key to our future economic well-being, but are we learning to be productive?
No manager would throw cash out in the street; he or she would evaluate the options and use that cash for maximum return. Cash, after all, is an asset. The same managers are blind to the asset value of skilled labor. We need to use our labor force productively, not squander it.
In our rush to improve labor productivity, we forget that the productivity equation has a numerator, output, as well as the denominator of labor cost. Productivity improvements can (and should) come through increasing output. The lesson of our "efficient" foreign competitors is that the best way to do so is by putting the proper tools in the hands of a well-trained work force, whose members are secure in knowing their jobs will not be arbitrarily eliminated, their families' health will be protected through medical benefits and they will share in the productivity gains they produce.
Perhaps if more American managers saw their labor force as an asset, rather than an expense, we would begin to see more investment and innovation being applied to its use. Alternatively, we could speed up the production line and cut out the lunch break.
 
JEFFREY E. MATCHEN
New York, Jan. 23, 1992

HEADLINE: A Trap for Candidates;
When 'the War' Means Vietnam, Politics Gets Muddy

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H.

 BODY:
For political longevity, it is hard to beat the generation that fought in World War II. For the last 40 years, the nation's chief executives have been products of this era, and seven of the last eight Presidents served in the armed forces during what was, in the title of the Studs Terkel book, "The Good War."
Eventually, though, even the most enduring generation must yield to its successor, and as voters prepare to cast the first ballots in the 1992 Presidential election, it is clear that this transition is haltingly getting under way. On the Republican side, President Bush of course has the classic military resume of a Navy pilot who was shot down over the Pacific. But none of the five leading candidates for the Democratic nomination served in World War II. And one of them, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, is the first major Presidential candidate who was a hero of the not-so-good war in Vietnam. 
 Tomorrow, the Presidential election season formally begins when voters in Iowa hold their caucuses, and Iowa Senator Tom Harkin is expected to win handily. The real contest will begin in New Hampshire on Feb. 18 with the nation's first primary. It is still too early to tell how the generational shift will play out in the coming election, but recent events suggest that the process could be painful.
For the Republicans, this is probably all for the best. In addition to possessing a traditional political profile, Mr. Bush enjoys all the advantages of incumbency, including a fully-researched biography. Having survived eight years of scrutiny as Vice President and three as President, Mr. Bush seems unlikely to be waylaid by any newly discovered unpleasantries from his past.
But for the Democrats, the uneasiness of the transition is emerging as a major obstacle. In recent weeks, the primary campaign has been dominated not by the nation's overriding concern -- the economy -- but by something far more marginal, the private life of Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton. Last week, after getting sideswiped by charges of marital infidelity, Mr. Clinton seemed to have gotten his campaign back on track, only to find himself slammed by allegations that he tried to avoid the draft during the Vietnam War.
With the debate over Governor Clinton's draft status, the Presidential campaign seems to have run headlong into a booby trap that was set 25 years ago. As the generation that came of age in the 1960's began to run for high political office, it was probably inevitable that someone would stumble into the snare; indeed, Vice President Dan Quayle almost did so four years ago, when charges surfaced that he had avoided being sent to Vietnam by using family connections to join the National Guard. The question that remains is: just how dangerous is this trap?
Just as some of the issues raised by Vietnam remain unresolved, the nation also seems divided about what constitutes an acceptable biography for a politician who reached draft age while the war was escalating and also growing more unpopular each year. With Governor Clinton, the question is whether he misled his local draft board to avoid conscription before 1969, the year the lottery system was implemented and he drew a high enough number to stay out of uniform. An official of his local draft board has said that he did mislead them; Mr. Clinton insists that he did not.
Michael Delli Carpini, a Barnard political science professor who has studied the generation that grew up in the 60's, says he is suprised how sensitive the issue remains.
"I would have expected that one of the changes you would have seen over the years is that by now we would have a different set of standards for what constitutes a legitimate experience for a politician," he said. "And one of the standards you would think would no longer be applied would be service to the military. But it seems the same basic standards are still being used, which really strikes me as ironic, given the way the Vietnam War is remembered."
What the debate suggests, Professor Delli Carpini said, "is that we as a country have not really come to grips with how we feel about people who did not support the war. The price we pay as a nation is that when something brings it up, we don't really have a set of rules or even a language to evaluate it."
In Mr. Clinton's case, questions about how he avoided military service are complicated by questions of how he represented himself. Thus, the full depth of the nation's discomfort is probably reflected better in the experience of Senator Kerrey.
At the start of the campaign season, many Democrats hoped that Mr. Kerrey would lead the party through the treacherous generational transition; a Medal of Honor winner who lost part of a leg in Vietnam and later turned against the war, the Senator seemed to successfully combine two potentially disparate elements of his generation -- patriotism and a willingness to question authority. Even as he lags in the polls, many Democratic leaders maintain that Mr. Kerrey's service in Vietnam is an unalloyed plus for him, and in recent days the Senator has tried to prolong discussion of Mr. Clinton's difficulties. But Mr. Kerrey has also said that at times, "being a Vietnam veteran is more of a liability than an asset." A close adviser said the Senator believes his service record can work against him by reminding voters of unresolved issues that they would prefer to forget. "It's still too painful," the adviser said.
For decades, military service has been viewed almost as a prerequisite for the Presidency. The man with his finger on the button, the thinking seemed to go, should at least have demonstrated an ability to get through boot camp. Now that the cold war is over, voters may no longer see military experience as so relevant.
Some analysts say that Mr. Clinton and the other Democratic candidates, former Senator Paul Tsongas and former Gov. Jerry Brown, who never served in the military, and Mr. Harkin, who was a non-combat pilot in the Navy, are fortunate to be running for President at a time when the nation is most concerned about domestic issues. "As long as domestic issues dominate," Professor Delli Carpini said, military service "will not be as important."
But it remains to be seen how the electorate will treat the men who came of age during the Vietnam War. Some analysts worry that the nation's uneasiness with the issues of the 60's will, if unaddressed, end up disqualifying an entire age group from high public office. Todd Gitlin, a professor at Berkeley who has written a book about the decade, notes that drug use and draft resistance were the norm of the day. He argues that applying outdated standards to a new generation of public figures is like an old-style Kremlin purge.
"This purification crusade is generationally dangerous," he said. "What you are really talking about is disenfranchising an entire generation."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Democracy Isn't Always Enough to Repel Attempted Coups

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
For days after President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela took to the airwaves to declare the failure of last week's military putsch against him, his image flickered on television screens across Latin America. Shaken by what he described as a ruthless attempt on his life, Mr. Perez wondered aloud what the plotters could have hoped to gain. "We cannot imagine how these madmen could be full of such anachronism, such ignorance, or such hate or ambition," he said, "for them not to realize that the time of the coup d'etat is over in Latin America."
Given the months of coup rumors that preceded the first attacks late Monday night, Mr. Perez could not have been entirely surprised. But there were reasons for his disbelief. For 34 years, Venezuela has been a democratic exception in South America, passing from one elected government to another. Its economy grew a stunning 9.2 percent last year, winning praise from investors and financiers at home and abroad. Just one day before the revolt, which left as many as 78 dead, Mr. Perez gushed of his success at a meeting of business leaders in Davos, Switzerland. "The spirit of the reforms is no longer a subject of controversy," he said.
 
Grudging Support
 As much as Venezuela's neighbors might share Mr. Perez's shock, they could hardly help but see last week's bloodshed as a reminder of the limits to Latin America's incipient recovery from a decade of economic crisis. However retrograde their methods, the military rebels in Venezuela were not so out of touch with the national mood. For months, as new investment poured into the country, Venezuelans angrily protested rising prices, falling wages, shoddy public services and reported Government corruption; in a poll the week before the coup, 81 percent voiced little or no confidence in the president. And if many countrymen came almost grudgingly to Mr. Perez's defense, their ambivalence seemed only to underscore how in Venezuela, as elsewhere in the region, fiscal austerity, debt restructuring and free-market reforms have helped yield new wealth without necessarily sharing it more equitably. 
 On one level, Mr. Perez was right when he spoke in Switzerland. After years of sharp debate, the same broad lines of economic policy have been adopted by nearly all the big Latin debtor nations. Like the ruling party of Mexico, Mr. Perez has sold off or shut down government enterprises that he took over in an earlier, socialistic incarnation, managing to balance his budget and stockpile reserves in the process. Both the liberal Chileans who struggled to oust the dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet and the Argentine Peronists, who once prided themselves on their social spending, have held to tight monetary policies and fiscal austerity. Inflation has come under greater control across the region, and after three years of virtual stagnation, Latin economies grew an average of more than 2 percent last year, according to United Nations statistics.
 
A Very Slow Trickle
 It is too soon to tell whether such models of development will eventually contribute to political stability in Latin America by spreading the wealth and power once concentrated by the state and its partners. In some cases, an end of big subsidies and special privileges has already undone the influence of some old government allies. But more prominent in the regions' financial reports and glossy magazines have been new images of old-money tycoons buying back businesses that governments took away from them years before, or of new-money entrepreneurs and the speculative killings they have made in real estate and stocks. "According to prevailing theories," the Argentine political scientist Guillermo O'Donnell noted last week, "the only way the poor are going to do better is if the rich get richer first."
So far the new wealth has done relatively little trickling down. In Uruguay and Chile, per capita social spending remains well below the levels of 10 years ago. In Colombia, Uruguay and Paraguay, urban unemployment remains high or continues to rise. Last year, Brazil registered inflation of about 450 percent. In Peru, though inflation fell steeply last year, real minimum wages dropped to 16.8 percent of their level in 1980. Amid the gleaming new businesses, foreign stock issues and pronouncements of investor confidence, other trends established by the debt crisis of the 1980's have continued.
Mexico has been something of an exception, though economists worry that its booming stock market and $11 billion current-account deficit, the broadest measure of trade, have been sustained by speculative and short-term investment. Even as real minimum wages fell for the 10th consecutive year and unemployment and inflation emerged in polls as Mexicans' two primary concerns, the Government regained support with an innovative $2 billion program of public works aimed especially at areas of opposition strength. By contrast, though only 57 percent of Venezuelans are reported able to afford more than one meal a day and minimum wages fell last year to 47 percent of their value in 1980, Mr. Perez has been exceptionally tight with Government money.
Since Tocqueville, political theorists have seen in such moments of rising expectations unevenly fulfilled the raw stuff of revolt. Added to those pressures in many Latin countries, including Venezuela, are once-privileged military officers who find themselves among the public servants hardest hit by government austerity. Considering the somewhat isolated economic success of Chile under Pinochet and Mexico under the control of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has ruled for 62 years, some observers question whether severe austerity and dramatic economic restructuring are even possible in a fully democratic country.
Last week, one might have wondered whether Venezuela, where democracy has at times seemed almost taken for granted, was oddly more at risk than some of its neighbors. Argentina, Peru and Brazil have also grappled with severe economic adjustment, restless military officers and charges of blatant government corruption that seemed at times about to ignite the mix. The difference, perhaps, has been the traumatic and relatively recent experience of military rule in those countries. When soldiers have moved to intervene, people's dissatisfaction with the civilians in power has generally turned out to be not so great after all.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Islamic Militance Along Russia's Rim Is Less Than a Sure Bet

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
Across the centuries of Russia's colonial dealings with Central Asia, there has never been a lack of alarm that somehow an "Islamic crescent" counterforce would coalesce, with all the intimations of Muslim fervor that can so easily seize the xenophobic imagination of outside observers.
The interesting thing in the latest version of that alarm is that it comes from the Bush Administration, not the Yeltsin Government here, and it is focused mainly on Washington's long-running preoccupation with Iran rather than on the plethora of different ethnic, religious and political subtleties that are now becoming apparent among the the Central Asian republics as they try to resurrect themselves from the ashes of Communism. 
 Life on the ground in the region is an ever more complicated mix of hopes and fears lately, but with ties to outside nations clearly being sought for economic deliverance rather than as a religious and cultural denominator -- a denominator that, in the process, might undermine the remnants of the Communist Party machines attempting to survive in the republics by other names, not to mention the region's fledgling democratic insurgencies.
Accordingly, a visitor to the region lately hears South Korea and Turkey invoked as far more promising go-go prospects than Iran, with its fundamentalist call to Allah.
And in counterbalance to the traditional complaints about the foreign domination by Russia, some leaders in the Asian republics have begun pleading with the better educated non-native offspring of colonialism not to flee all the nascent nationalisms, as many have been doing, but to stay as part of a badly needed leadership cadre for the future.
Local politicians consider Iran as putting down a few long-range bets at best -- in Tajikistan and Turkmenistan, perhaps, if the shattered economic life in the region should suffer years of further deterioration.
But even in Tajikistan, the Islamic-edged opposition movement that has arisen to join in the challenge to the entrenched party apparatus made a point in anti-Government demonstrations last fall in Dushanbe to stress an ecumenical spirit that embraces insurgent democrats and secular nationalists. And Turkmenistan, with its more developed petroleum industry, has feelers out for the best deal from either Iran or Turkey, or both.
The initial effect of tentative Iranian overtures in the region seems to be in highlighting the basic division within Islam among the republics, with Saudi Arabia showing interest in having some of its Sunni Muslim proselytizers on the ground to counter Iran's rival Shiite Muslims.
In Uzbekistan, where a hard-line Communist bloc retains power, the issue of Islam is framed not in terms of Iranian fundamentalism but of a rivalry within the clergy over supporting the Government or seeking greater religious and political freedom.
Azerbaijan remains preoccupied with its territorial vendetta with Christian Armenia, a struggle that threatens to isolate Azerbaijan from whatever common promise of economic progress the other Asian republics might manage to encourage in their current talk of free-market changes.
"We are waging a struggle against all kinds of extremism," says President Askar A. Akayev of Kyrgyzstan, one of the favorites of the Bush Administration in openly denouncing Iranian fundamentalism. "We are closest to Turkey and want to stick with Turkey," he says, echoing a preference for Turkey's balancing of Islam with secular Western ties.
This is the preference, too, of reform elements in Kazakhstan, the giant bridge of a republic between Russia and the Asian states whose President, Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, fought to prevent a new variation of colonial isolation by demanding a founders' role for all of the Central Asian republics in the new Commonwealth of Independent States that had been started by the Slavic republics.
 
Interests Are Complex
 His strategy demonstrates the region's complex cross-hatchings of interests, for if Kazakhstan were to be fully isolated in independence its sizable northern Russian minority might begin seeking to break away and destabilize the Nazarbayev Government.
Within the Commonwealth, on the other hand, he bolsters his role in leading the keystone republic in influencing the Central Asian states with survival plans invoking secular, free-market faith and reliance on Korean advisers and entrepreneurs.
With so much flux and promise in a region poorly studied during the cold war, the Bush Administration is now hurriedly opening a new chain of embassies in the Central Asian republics. When Foreign Service professionals reconnoiter the region they are likely to be filing at least as much intelligence on such pervasive economic problems as the desperate water shortage and environmental devastation that were the legacy of Russian and Soviet imperialism as on Iran's hope for ideological inroads.
The central fact the Asian republics are facing is the loss of their considerable Kremlin budget, employment and consumer subsidies under the now defunct Soviet Union. In his ideological war on Czarist Russia, Lenin termed the region "the purest example of colonialism." But the Soviet regime, after subduing the region, only maintained the colonialism.
This is a fact only currently being underlined in the republics as they grope their way from Communism and search, in widely varying ways, for economic hope more than another ideological war.
