HEADLINE: In Unlikely Pairing, Ickes Strengthens Clinton Bid

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
That Harold M. Ickes joined Gov. Bill Clinton's Presidential quest surprised many of Mr. Ickes's political colleagues. Not just because the Arkansan is viewed as a moderate and the iconoclastic Mr. Ickes is a liberal from the West Side of Manhattan who profoundly disagrees with Mr. Clinton's support of the death penalty.
Most people were surprised for another reason. Mr. Clinton is -- or was -- considered the front-runner for the Democratic nomination. And Mr. Ickes, who is as unconventional as he is committed, has been a perennial supporter of losers. Four years ago, he supported the Rev. Jesse Jackson, not to make a President, but to make a point about the Democratic Party's drift from its liberal roots. 
 Mr. Ickes's value to a campaign is as an unrelenting tactician. He can also deliver a devoted following. When City Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, a Democrat who represents the Upper West Side, was recently asked why she was supporting the Governor, an uncharacteristically moderate candidate by her standards, she responded with two words: "Harold Ickes."
Mr. Ickes, 52 years old, a lawyer whose father, Harold L. Ickes, who was Secretary of the Interior and who carried out tough tasks for Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman, has been immersed in politics for 25 years. But about the closest he has come to a cabinet were those that he fashioned as a part-time carpenter. He has managed campaigns for candidates whose headquarters he sometimes built himself, whose philosophy he shared and whom he valiantly fought the good fight for and usually lost.
 
Iconoclastic Tactician
 Mr. Clinton's campaign, which Mr. Ickes directs in New York State, is the first in which he has enlisted with a candidate who is apparently the front-runner. Mr. Clinton represents a candidate with whom Mr. Ickes differs on several issues, but who he believes has the best chance of defeating President Bush.
Disputed allegations about sexual affairs, derogatory comments about Gov. Mario M. Cuomo that Mr. Clinton acknowledges having made and, more recently, questions about his draft status may undermine what is perhaps the greatest source of his support, the view that he is the most electable Democrat in the field.
"I think there's no question a lot of people are undoubtedly raising that as a serious question, and my sense is their judgment is being withheld until New Hampshire results are in," Mr. Ickes said.
He added that "any front-runner is bound to take some lumps," but he acknowledged that whether Mr. Clinton was the front-runner was debatable. "I don't know what tense to use any more," he said.
"I knew about the rumors, but I never knew they had any substance and still don't," said Mr. Ickes, whose father's affair during his first marriage was an open secret that went unreported.
Mr. Ickes has devoted much of his energies lately to damage control. He telephoned political and labor leaders who had signed up to be Clinton delegates or who had pledged their support, trying to gauge the degree to which they might be wavering and to reassure those who were that their candidate may have been wounded, but not fatally, if for no other reason, he reasoned, than there is no obvious alternative.
"I'm pleased that nobody has defected," Mr. Ickes said. He acknowledged, though, that "this is a big bump," as he tried to sound philosophical about a setback that might more deeply embitter politicians who were less accustomed to losing.
"First impressions affect people, and for people first learning about Bill Clinton, they may be concerned," he said. "I wouldn't want anyone to go into my background. None of us is perfect. None of what has come out has shaken me. None of it throws into question his character."
If Mr. Ickes needed more diversion from the campaign or the demands of his law practice, as counsel to Mayor David N. Dinkins's campaign committee he also helped investigations of the committee chairman, Arnold I. Biegen, who was indicted last week on Federal and state charges that he stole $158,000 in campaign money.
 
From Lowenstein's First Race
 Whatever Mr. Clinton's appeal, the breadth of his support in New York is widely credited to Mr. Ickes's persistence and to the loyalty of the following he has developed since he worked in Allard K. Lowenstein's first, and unsuccessful, Congressional campaign, which Ms. Eldridge managed. Mr. Ickes has never run for office and probably never could, because of the prickly personality that he inherited from his father, a self-proclaimed curmudgeon. But the younger Mr. Ickes has toiled tirelessly for others.
Even Mr. Clinton's rivals concede that he has received the bulk of organization support in the state, including the Democratic leaders of the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, the heads of the teachers' and New York City municipal employees' unions and the people whom Mr. Ickes described as "West Side liberals like myself." Many of those liberals and many more labor leaders might have been expected to support Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, Mr. Ickes said.
"But that assumes Bill is conservative or at best a moderate," Mr. Ickes said. "I consider him progressive in the best sense."
 
'A Phenomenal Campaigner'

Mr. Ickes said he also disagreed with Mr. Clinton's support for armed intervention against Iraq last year, but added: "I agree with him on many more things than I disagree with him on. He is a phenomenal campaigner. I just don't think the others measure up. I don't think they're electable."
Mr. Clinton, who met Mr. Ickes 20 years ago in the antiwar movement, telephoned him at his law office in Mineola, L.I., last summer to sound him out about running his campaign for the primary on April 7. Mr. Ickes hesitated, only in case Mr. Jackson decided to run again, but not out of concern that Mr. Cuomo might, because, Mr. Ickes said, Mr. Cuomo was not an announced candidate and had not reached out to him.
 
Removal of Adding Machines
 Everyone who has worked with him has a favorite Harold Ickes story. At one party meeting in a hotel upstate, he joined his political mentor and the man who was going to become his law partner, John F. English, then the Nassau County Democratic chairman, and Carol Opton, another politician, in a precautionary strike to thwart a rival candidate for Democratic national committeeman. They spirited away all the adding machines that would have been needed to compute the weighted vote the next day. The caper proved to be unnecessary, though. Working through the night, they mustered enough support for their own candidate, Basil A. Paterson.
At the 1976 national convention, Sarah Kovner, another liberal from the West Side, recalled, Mr. Ickes was instrumental in bringing the issue of amnesty for Vietnam draft resisters to the delegates' attention. He arranged to have a conscientious objector nominated for vice president and seconded by Ron Kovic, the wounded veteran depicted in the film "Born on the Fourth of July."
When convention officials insisted that they could not accommodate Mr. Kovic's wheelchair at the podium, Mr. Ickes exclaimed: "You did it for George Wallace. You can do it for him." They did.
 
Young Farmer and Cowboy
 Mr. Ickes is known for his political and legal acumen, the zeal and, often, the good humor with which he pursues every goal. Although his bark is usually bigger than his bite, at one argument he sunk his teeth into an adversary's leg. He once nearly hit a county leader. In 1965, a beating by three white men in Louisiana, where he was a civil rights advocate, cost him his left kidney.
Mr. Ickes, who lives in Manhattan with his wife, Laura Handman, also a lawyer, and their 5-year-old daughter, grew up on a farm in Maryland. He worked as a cowboy after graduating from high school; received a pilot's license in New Mexico; majored in economics at Stanford University, where he met Mr. Lowenstein, and graduated from the Columbia University Law School.
He worked in the Presidential efforts of Jimmy Carter, Eugene J. McCarthy, Mr. Jackson and Edward M. Kennedy and for other candidates, including Paul O'Dwyer, William Fitts Ryan and Robert F. Wagner Jr. What distinguished his latest foray was Mr. Clinton's early anointment by opinion polls and politicians as the candidate to beat.
 "I've never chosen a Presidential candidate because they were necessarily going to win," Mr. Ickes said. "But it doesn't hurt."

HEADLINE: Becoming Rare Species: The American Trapper

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCHODACK, N.Y., Feb. 7

 BODY:
Before dawn the other day, Gerald Leggieri Jr. set out to inspect his traps on a farm here in rural southwestern Rensselaer County.
Mr. Leggieri had been invited in by a farmer who feared that coyotes were bothering his dairy cows. A part-time trapper, Mr. Leggieri is a high school teacher of history and economics by profession. 
 Wearing gloves to prevent human scent from contaminating his traps, Mr. Leggieri had scooped out a shallow hole in the ground in a natural path between two dormant hay fields. He set his traps in buckwheat hulls to keep the metal from freezing and then covered them with dirt. As a lure, he placed some glandular material from previously trapped coyotes nearby.
On his return, he found his steel leg-traps had caught two coyotes and a red fox. Using a .22-caliber handgun, he killed each animal with a shot to the head, took them home, skinned them and set the pelts out to dry.
Mr. Leggieri is one of a dwindling number of trappers in New York and the United States at a time when some are arguing that killing animals, especially by trapping, is cruel and unnecessary.
Trappers, wildlife biologists and fur dealers say that the decline in trapping is more a result of the recession than such opposition. They also argue that trappers -- and hunters -- help keep a balance in nature by keeping animal populations down to what the wilderness can support.
Whatever the reasons, the number of trappers, the price of pelts and the sales of fur garments are all down both in New York and the nation.
 
Trapping Licenses Down
 Last year, the state sold 11,513 trapping licenses to local residents, down from 14,713 in 1990 and 17,087 in 1989.
At the peak of the market, raccoon pelts were selling for as much as $50 to $60, with muskrats going for $6.50 to $8. Now, the price of a raccoon pelt is between $8 and $14 and muskrats from $2.50 to $3.50.
In addition, the number of fur-bearers trapped has declined, according to figures from the Department of Environmental Conservation.
In 1989, the last year for which figures are complete, the number of muskrats trapped dropped 46 percent to 193,000. The take of other animals dropped almost as much, raccoons to 65,000, opossums to 25,000, red foxes to 14,000, gray foxes to 6,000 mink to 13,000 and beaver to 17,000.
Even with these declines, the fur business -- from trapping and fur farming to the fashionable sales salons in New York and other big cities -- is a multibillion-dollar industry.
Although trapping dates to the colonization of America, today fur farms are major suppliers. In 1990, for example, 1,400 mink and fox farms in the United States produced 3.4 million mink pelts and 50,000 fox pelts worth $110 million.
William N. Outlaw, a spokesman for the Fur Information Council of America, which has its headquarters in Washington, estimated that retail sales of furs in 1989 were about $1.9 billion. He also said that sales of furs had declined about 25 percent during the current recession.
"Obviously people can put off buying furs when they have more pressing bills to pay," said Janice Henke, a spokeswoman for the National Fur Trappers Association.
 
'No Longer Fashionable'
 Anti-trapping organizations, though, say the drop is largely a result of their campaign against killing animals for what they call "frivolous reasons."
"Fur is no longer fashionable to people who have any kind of a heart," said Heidi Prescott, national outreach coordinator for the Fund for Animals, a nonprofit organization opposed to trapping and hunting. "We foresee the end of the fur industry in 10 years."
But Richard Leggett, president of the New York Trappers Association, thinks furs, and trapping, are making a comeback.
"There seems to be more interest in furs," he said. "Women who were hesitant to wear furs in public are now coming back. They are making a statement that wearing furs is all right."
 
Harvesting the Surplus
 A vice president of the Hudson City Savings Institution, a bank in Hudson, N.Y., Mr. Leggett is a part-time trapper. "I have been trapping ever since I was a boy, and now I am teaching trapping skills to my boy," he said.
Benjamin Tullar, a wildlife biologist for the Department of Environmental Conservation, defended trapping and hunting -- as "ecologically and economically sound."
"A harvestable surplus of fur-bearers is produced every year," he said. "If we don't use it, we lose it because the range can support only so many creatures. Other mortality factors will reduce the harvestable surplus if they are not hunted or trapped."
As in past years, mink, muskrat and raccoon are the most popular furs for coats and other apparel, with furs of darker hues more popular and expensive, according to Ms. Henke.
"The newest thing on the market is a mink-lined raincoat, full reversible, which sells for a few thousand dollars," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Gerald Leggieri Jr. is one of a dwindling number of trappers in New York and the United States. A high school teacher who traps part time, he set a trap on a farm in rural southwestern Rensselaer County and, below, held pelts of a red fox, left, and coyote he trapped there. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Emigres Who Want to Assimilate Pick Co-op City

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
Three years ago Sasha and Mikhael Bzelyansky were working at a hospital in the Russian city of St. Petersburg. Now they are living an unusual experiment in immigrants' assimilation in a sprawling high-rise complex in the northern Bronx.
Scorning the traditional path of generations of immigrants who have clustered together in rough approximations of home like the Chinese in Chinatown, Italians in Little Italy and Russians in Brighton Beach, the Bzelyanskys and 24 other Jewish families from the former Soviet Union have settled in the decidedly polyglot Co-op City. 
 They chose Co-op City rather than Brighton Beach, they say, precisely because they do not want to be surrounded by restaurants that serve familiar foods, where the signs are written in the alphabet of their homeland and the tellers at the bank branches are from Russia.
"It is the reason we want to live in Co-op City, because we want to speak more and more English, because we have to know it," said Mrs. Bzelyansky.
Her husband agreed, saying, "I like very much the relationship between the different peoples here."
 
Slowed by Practical Problems
 With the help of the Metropolitan New York Coordinating Council on Jewish Poverty, which is offering interest-free mortgages, 250 Jewish families from the former Soviet Union will settle in Co-op City in the next two years. That 25 have moved in shows the difficulties in setting up the program, said Richard Lee, general counsel for the Riverbay Corporation, which runs Co-op City.
"Here we had these people coming in as immigrants, and some of them had no income," Mr. Lee said. "We had never even had mortgages before, so of course we had to go through all the procedures of setting up these loans."
There were logistical problems, too. With no one on the Co-op City staff who spoke Russian, it was difficult to show the units to the applicants, much less explain the mounds of paperwork that they had to fill out. The council hired a recent Russian immigrant, Vladimir Karodimov, as a resettlement worker to act as a liaison aide between the families and Co-op City.
Concern arose that the immigrants would receive preference over other groups that were not backed by an organization willing to find them money, Mr. Lee said. "There was a fear that this was a plan that was not racially or ethnically balanced," Mr. Lee said. "We overcame that hurdle by writing the rules and regulations that will allow any similar group to qualify, if they want to present a plan such as this one."
The sales have also been slowed by the care in selecting applicants. "We turn down about three families for every one that we select," the executive director of the council, David Cohen, said. "It's a very complex program, and we have to choose people who are going to repay these loans and who will be able to take care of their rents. Immigrants today are having a tough time."
Sixty to 70 percent of the adults who have moved in with the help of the program have found employment, Mr. Karodimov said. Because of their poor English language skills and the recession, others are having difficulty finding work, he said.
But most of those making new lives at Co-op City are willing to deal with the challenges, Mr. Karodimov said, adding: "It would be easier to live somewhere else. But everybody who is here is saying that they came here because they wanted to adjust to life as soon as possible."
The families in the program cite the affordability of Co-op City, where a three-bedroom apartment costs $17,000, in addition to a monthly maintenance fee, which varies according to incomes and other factors. The families also were lured by the cleanliness and relatively low crime rate of the complex, which has its own security force.
Some families say the high-rise apartment houses remind them of typical housing in Moscow and other Russian cities.
The emigres include people of all ages, though most are young couples with small children. In the former Soviet Union they had been sheet-metal workers, doctors and homemakers.
At Co-op City, 65,000 people live in 15,372 apartments in 35 towers. When the complex opened 22 years ago, it became a haven for Jewish families, many of whom were fleeing the South Bronx, which was changing as new groups moved in. Now about half of the population of the complex is white, with blacks making up 30 percent and Hispanic people 20 percent, according to the 1990 Census.
Jews are 8 percent, said Arnold Eisen, executive vice president of the Bronx Jewish Community Council. That attracts the immigrants, he said, rather than putting them off. "Not everyone wants to live in a ghettoized population of say, a Brighton Beach, or Odessa by the Sea, if you will," Mr. Eisen added.
Leonid Yakobson and his wife, Alla, arrived in the United States more than two years ago, after having tried to emigrate for about 10 years. Their daughter Regina, 14 months old, was born in New York, and one month ago the family moved into a one-bedroom apartment at Co-op City. The Yakobsons had lived in Brighton Beach, which is home to about 100,000 Soviet immigrants, and also in the Pelham Parkway area of the Bronx, a much smaller Russian community. But they say they prefer Co-op City.
 
'Be a Regular Citizen'
 Mr. Yakobson, a doctor and speech therapist in Kiev, Ukraine, is learning English, which he speaks haltingly but determinedly. His wife is also studying English, but she is shyer about speaking it. Both say the best way to adapt is to immerse themselves in the vast community of Co-op City.
A friend, Mikhael Stotland, who dropped by their apartment to tell the couple that a mutual friend in Kiev had received permission to travel to the United States, agreed with them about the need to adjust quickly. "If you want to live in America, you have to speak the language and be a regular citizen," he said. "What's happened in the Russian community is that the people don't speak English. They don't have to."
But they and other Russian Jewish families said their desire to live outside an immigrant community did not mean that they wanted to shed their culture and language. "There is nothing wrong to keep your native language," Mr. Yakobson said.
Another emigre family at Co-op City, Aleksandr and Victoria Shirin, who left Latvia less than a year ago, do not let their son Konstantin, 9, speak to their daughter Maria, 1 1/2, in English. "I make him read in Russian for about a half-hour every day, and I force him to write letters to my mother in Russian," Mrs. Shirin said. "I don't want him to forget, and I want her to learn Russian."

Mr. Shirin played the piano as the family gathered on the sofa; Konstantin Shirin is forced by his parents to read Russian every day, to write letters in Russian and to speak to his sister in Russian, so he does not forget his culture and language. HEADLINE: BOXING;
Holmes Manages to Pull a Triumph Out of His Hat

BYLINE: By PHIL BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 8

 BODY:
In the beginning, Larry Holmes was nervous and his moves tentative. A look of high anxiety flickered across his face. In the Convention Center ring Friday night, he fought like -- well, a 42-year-old grandfather.
In those early minutes of the match, Holmes's opponent, 30-year-old Ray Mercer, reacted to his punches as though they were a mere distraction, with no more impact than what might land on him in a pillow fight. 
 Mercer, a gold medalist at the 1988 Olympics, kept walking forward with the assurance of a hit man, throwing clubbing punches and sending Holmes reeling in the first round with a mere jab.
But before the 12-round nontitle heavyweight bout ended, Mercer would lose that swagger and end up looking like an upright perplexity, a fighter caught up in Holmes's great bamboozle.
For while Holmes struck with punches, it was gamesmanship -- the creaking art of self-defense -- that kept him in the fight and he ended with a shocking unanimous decision.
 
Sparing the Legs
 Holmes, the underdog, showed Mercer a little of this and a little of that. For several rounds, Holmes used a variant of the rope-a-dope, planting his back against the ropes to spare his old legs their labor while muffling Mercer's punches and whacking the occasional combination off Mercer's head.
He bluffed, he conned, he talked to the other man. Once, in Mercer's corner, Holmes even turned to the television camera there and twice addressed it, before wheeling and hitting Mercer.
Holmes did what he had to. His punches never appeared to pain Mercer, but his tactics eventually discouraged him and left Mercer lunging amateurishly to land punches. Mercer simply could not figure a way through Holmes's defense.
Holmes, who held the heavyweight title from 1978 to 1985, was using his longer reach by placing his glove on the top of Mercer's head and simply holding him off. He clinched, he posed, he even wiggled his hips to show that, even if he is 42, he is still Larry Holmes, fierce enough to beat a young pretender.
Holmes won with guile more than with firepower. It wasn't photogenic. It wasn't the balletic art of Muhammad Ali. It was an old fighter with surivival tactics who was able to break down a tough but unsophisticated pug and do it with an amazing economy.
 
Crowd Involvement
 A computer punch count had Mercer throwing 657 punches, compared with 491 for Holmes. But Holmes landed 336 of his 491, or 68.4 percent, while Mercer managed to connect on 247 of 657 for 37.6 percent.
It didn't take long for the Convention Center crowd to realize what Holmes, who has two grandchildren, was doing. They began to chant "Lar-ry, Lar-ry, Lar-ry" in support of the former champion.
As Mercer said afterward, "When you're 42 and it's close, maybe you should get it."
In fact, it wasn't as close as Mercer reckoned. Judges Phil Newman (117-112), Eugene Grant (117-111) and John Poturaj (115-113) all had it for Holmes.
Newman said afterward: "Too smart. Larry did everything he wanted."
Holmes?
"You're only as old as you feel and live," he said at the post-fight news conference.
 
Damage Is Assessed
 While Holmes conceded that Mercer landed punches that hurt, he put the damage in context. "I've been hit harder," he said, "but I was younger."
Holmes, who weighed 233 pounds, has a record of 54-3, with 37 knockouts. Mercer, who weighed 228 3/4 pounds, lost for the first time in 19 fights.
"I fought the best I could," said Mercer. "Larry's defense was one I wasn't accustomed to."
Mercer said that Holmes's elbows caused damage to his right bicep about midway through the fight and diminished his big punch, the right hand.
"But the better man won tonight," he said.
Holmes made just over $1 million, and Mercer got $1.2 million. Holmes said his objective was to get a title fight before the year was out. But it remains to be seen if there is a Holmes in the immediate future of Evander Holyfield, the undisputed heavyweight champion. If not, Holmes could end up in the ring against another 40-something marvel, George Foreman.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Larry Holmes, right, throwing a punch at Ray Mercer during their 12-round heavyweight fight Friday night in Atlantic City. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Magic Plays This Game For History

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla.

 BODY:
PUT simply, there has never been an event in American sports quite like what awaits us here this afternoon.
That son of the electronic age, Magic Johnson, has put this moment in terms of an MTV hit single: "It may be my last game. My V.C.R. will be working, so I can pop it in for my son or daughter, to see me playing with all these All-Stars." 
 Magic's Greatest Hits. The Farewell All-Star Game. He always knew he was a performer, in ways that athletes of the more stolid past could not yet understand.
Lou Gehrig, stricken with a disease that would eventually bear his name in grim tribute, knew he had a debt to the public when he stood in Yankee Stadium and proclaimed himself "the luckiest man on the face of the earth."
But handheld V.C.R.'s did not exist in the black-and-white time of 1939. Gary Cooper eventually played Lou Gehrig in the movies, stoic and stumbling, uncomfortable with the awkward emotions of farewell.
Magic Johnson, from this Technicolor era, believes it is cool to play himself with smiles and hugs. Perhaps the enormity of his forced retirement has not yet really hit him. Or maybe he is as sunny and brave as he seems.
Either way, the cameras will be rolling today when Magic Johnson, poleaxed by H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, starts in the National Basketball Association All-Star Game, to be televised to Kazakhstan, Nicaragua, Singapore, Zimbabwe, more than 90 countries.
It is not exaggerating to say that no athlete has ever felt so much personal support, so much love, when he went into a game, whether it was a championship match or a farewell ceremony or even a glittery all-star game.
Other athletes have felt an entire region behind them. At the Olympic Games, athletes know their own country is rooting for them. In every World Cup, Pele knew that many countries that love joyful soccer were rooting for Brazil. And Muhammad Ali preached the reality that whole swaths of the earth were rooting for him.
But no matter the politics of the moment, there always was an opponent of considerable stature and skill: Max Schmeling, the old Soviet Union, the New York Yankees, the Oakland Raiders, Hulk Hogan or Sgt. Slaughter. Nobody roots for H.I.V.
We all play our games against time. All seasons end. But Earvin Johnson has been given a shortened schedule, by how many years nobody knows, and he has been given an uncharted corridor of beaming good health.
It is hard to be maudlin about this game. Like any good performer, Magic Johnson holds out the possibility of an extended farewell tour. He is still maintaining he will play in the Summer Games in Barcelona, Spain, and he is now thinking out loud about joining the Lakers late in the season, for the playoffs.
But today is the only day he knows he has. Like Tom Sawyer, believed to have drowned, sneaking into the back of the church and attending his own funeral, Magic Johnson gets to play at what will be a tribute to him.
By virtue of the lead time needed for computerized all-star ballots, Johnson's name was engraved on punch cards weeks before his illness was diagnosed last fall. The fans saw his name, and they remembered the big smile and the dramatic passes slashing at diagonals, and they punched his name on their cards.
Some players and members of the press worried about whether they could catch the thing if Magic happened to bleed on them. But David Stern, who spent the 80's trying to teach sports economics to knucklenoses like me, produced four -- count 'em, four -- AIDS experts here for anybody who had not done his homework.
Magic Johnson conducted his own news conference, playing all the positions, as he has done on the court. Beaming, like the sun, he promised a good show today.
Farewell games can be classics. Ted Williams slugged a home run into a gale in his last at-bat Fenway Park, and never cracked a smile. The best farewell I ever saw was for Carlos Alberto, the wily old Brazilian, playing half a game for the Cosmos and half a game for his old club, and then, near midnight, jogging around Giants Stadium while the public-address played Carly Simon's "Nobody Does It Better."
But Carlos Alberto's only weakness was getting old. Magic Johnson has something worse than athletic old age. Other athletes receive golf clubs and cars and electronic gadgets when they retire. Magic Johnson receives love, from his peers and from the world. He deserves no less.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Magic Johnson (Ben Van Hook)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Crown Jewels at Risk

 BODY:
A 72-foot luxury yacht outfitted with a jacuzzi. A 19th-century Italian fruitwood commode. Expensive flowers. Travel to vacation resorts.
Camera shots from an episode of "Life Styles of the Rich and Famous"? Not quite. These items were bought by universities with Federal money provided to support research. A House subcommittee, chaired by John Dingell, has unearthed a seeming billion-dollar cesspool of mischarges and overcharges at Stanford University, M.I.T., Yale and other universities. 
 The committee has fingered stupefying carelessness by university officials and Government auditors but, as yet, no venality. The dogged investigations have already produced hefty dividends: embarrassed universities have remitted millions and are adopting modern accounting systems that will save taxpayers millions more. Had matters stopped here, Mr. Dingell would be a hero.
But he hasn't stopped. Instead, he's unleashed forces that threaten to do unspeakable damage to the nation's leading universities. Government auditors, humiliated during Congressional hearings, now seek to make amends by acting tough. They recommend ripping up valid contracts to make Stanford repay an astonishing $200 million or more and M.I.T. at least $19 million.
Yes, Stanford violated regulations -- presumably inadvertently -- when it billed the Government for upkeep on a yacht. And, yes, Stanford abused its right to pass on legitimate entertainment expenses. But the cost of such improprieties is a pittance -- a fraction of 1 percent of research monies.
By twisting minor indiscretion into a broadside indictment of scores of universities, Mr. Dingell and Government auditors threaten to destroy the crown jewels of the economy. Taxpayers haven't wasted money on university research; it's the best investment taxpayers can ever make in America's future.
Congress agreed more than four decades ago to reimburse universities for not only direct costs of sponsored research -- salaries and test tubes -- but also indirect costs. These are overhead expenses -- the costs of running libraries and computer centers, the heating plant and other facilities that serve the entire university, not just research labs.
To determine indirect costs, universities add up their total overhead expenses and pass along an agreed-upon share to the Government. Overhead costs related to the research labs aren't always separated from those that support classrooms because the attempt to do so would be prohibitively expensive and the outcome arbitrary. Instead, the Government's share is designed, roughly, to equal what it would probably pay if purely research overhead could be isolated.
The Government might agree, for example, to pay 25 percent of all library acquisitions. Critics of the system might wonder why taxpayers are paying 25 percent of the cost of "The Catcher in the Rye" just as they question why taxpayers help furnish the President's house. But they forget that taxpayers avoid picking up 75 percent of the cost of advanced physics journals.
If the system works right, taxpayers pay a fair share. Unfortunately, the system is ripe for abuse because it is hard to draw lines between legitimate overhead and extravagance. If a $1,200 commode is too lavish to include for cost recovery, is $500 also too steep? The regulations don't say.
Yet all the yachts and commodes Stanford ever bought don't amount to very much. Stanford has already agreed to pay back a few million for the questionable items.
What the auditors have in mind is far more insidious. They want to mail Stanford a bill of about $200 million for ordinary overhead reimbursements (not flowers and yachts) it received under contracts the Government signed in the 1980's. The auditors now claim those contracts are inequitable to taxpayers and, therefore, unenforceable.
That claim is outrageous. If the Government doesn't like contracts it signed, it should renegotiate them when they come due -- and fire the officials who originally signed them. Surely it's wrong to break a contract unilaterally, thereby threatening to undermine vital research facilities.
Mr. Dingell exposed incompetence and abuse. But if the Government turns vindictive, it will destroy the foundation of America's technological edge.

HEADLINE: Business Diary

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

ECONOMY
 
Mr. Bush on Health Care 

You don't have to be a genius to figure out that something major is wrong with the health care system. It consumes a massive 13 percent of gross domestic product but leaves 35 million people without insurance. Last week, President Bush offered a plan to fix things up. Lightweight, said critics. The plan calls for cutting the waste out of Medicare and Medicaid, but doesn't specify how. It proposes a cap on malpractice awards, but doesn't say how much. It would provide vouchers worth up to $3,750 to poor families to buy insurance, but makes no assurance that that will be enough. "The plus is we've now got a mainstream consensus that the government must deal with health care," said Joseph Califano, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. Consensus or not, he said, "there is no more chance of passing a major health care reform bill this year than of putting an elephant through a keyhole"
 
And Still, There Are No Jobs
 
The recovery's sails may be up, but no wind is blowing. This slump is now 18 months old with no signs of abating. That's especially true for jobs. According to the Labor Department, unemployment remained stuck at 7.1 percent in January, the same level as December and the highest rate since 1984. The results would have been even worse had 400,000 people who wanted full-time jobs not found part-time work. "Let's not kid ourselves. The economy is declining," said Allen Sinai, of the Boston Company. "The figures indicate negative G.D.P. in the first quarter of about 8 tenths of 1 percent. It's a rough bounce to the bottom."

The Ever-Adaptable Fed
 
Back when Cadillacs still had tail fins, Representative Wright Patman, the Texas populist, thought the Federal Reserve was too darn independent for the nation's good. It didn't give a hoot about economic growth, he said, only inflation. So Mr. Patman tried but failed to shut it down. If only he could see it now. With election fever gripping Washington and the bond market skittish, Fed chairman Alan Greenspan is talking like a politician. He said last week he was not opposed to lowering interest rates further if that was needed to lift the economy off the rocks. "Back in December Mr. Greenspan said no one will blame him for the loss of their office or for the loss of the White House," said Allan Meltzer, a professor of economics at Carnegie Mellon University. "Then in January he said he'd ease rates enough to let the economy recover." That would even make Mr. Patman happy.

Treasury's Short-Term Token
 
Economists call it the preferred-habitat argument. It's a fancy way of saying money moves where investors are best able to get the results they want. That's why depositors switch banks when terms and rates change. But the Treasury has decided to take on the theory. With short-term rates far lower than long-term rates, it said last week it would reduce the amount of 30-year bonds it sells to $10 billion from $12 billion and make up the difference with more 3-year and 10-year bonds. That would save it $55 million in interest payments. But will investors bite? "The original talk was of eliminating the 30-year bond," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago. But the $2 billion shift "is just a token amount."

A Little Zip in Car Sales
 
After running on fumes for more than a year, Detroit finally has its pedal near the metal. Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks are still pretty flat -- but they rose 11.1 percent in late January.

Recession? Talk to Iraq
 
Last week, George Bush's economic advisers submitted the President's Annual Economic Report to Congress. The report said the sluggish economy would probably pick up a little steam in the next few months and finish the year 1.6 percent ahead of last year. But this year's report stepped a little further into the realm of politics than it usually does. If Congress follows the President's plans, growth will climb to 2.2 percent, it said. And the report chose its enemies carefully. Mr. Bush was not responsible for the recession. It was Saddam Hussein of Iraq who caused it. Had the Persian Gulf War not occurred, the economy would be purring. Perhaps that's why Mr. Bush sent Robert M. Gates, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, to the Mideast. Mr. Gates's mission, it is rumored, is to seek support for ousting Mr. Hussein.
 
Priority to the Ozone
 
The greatest obstacles to speeding up the phase-out of ozone-depleting chemicals were a lack of scientific evidence and John H. Sununu, the former White House chief of staff. Mr. Sununu, of course, is gone, and last week new evidence was released that dangerous holes in the ozone layer were opening up over North America. That was enough for the White House. It now supports a Senate proposal to phase out the offending chemicals before the original goal of the year 2000.

 
 
COMPANIES


Federated Is Back
 
Too often, the next step after Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code is the corporate boneyard. But Federated Department Stores Inc., was able to avoid that final resting place. Last week it emerged after two years in court with an offering of 24 million shares of stock that were quickly snatched up by investors. Federated, owner of the Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Strauss and Burdine retail chains, was the $10 billion pipe dream of Canadian developer Robert Campeau. Federated shed 42 stores (it still has 223) and worked out a deal for banks, bondholders and suppliers to forgive about $3 billion in debt in exchange for about $2 billion in Federated stock.

Ringing It Up in Video Rentals
 
One industry has been doing nicely in this recession, thank you very much. Video rentals. According to Alexander & Associates, an industry consultant, movie rentals are at an all-time high -- 106.6 million of them were checked out in the first week of January -- a record. How many of those rentals, do you suppose, were returned rewound?

NBC Nods Off on Thursday
 
More people veg out watching TV on Thursday night than any other night. That means money for the networks -- especially NBC, which dominated the evening with shows like "Cheers," "Cosby" and "L.A. Law." But these shows are getting, well, tired. Last week "Cheers," NBC's highest-rated show, slipped to fourth place from first. "Cosby" and "L.A. Law," fell as well, prompting some critics to wonder what the peacock is up to. "It's sliding," said Jib Fowles, author of "Why Viewers Watch." As he said, "G.E., NBC's parent, doesn't understand TV." NBC should freshen up its lineup, he said.

When the Sony Corporation bought Columbia Pictures and Tri star, and Matsushita Electric Industrial Company bought Universal, critics asked whether these studios would be free to portray Japanese culture as they wished. "No problem," said the acquirers. But then "Hell Camp," a Tristar film about Americans living in Japan was cancelled. Rumors spread through Hollywood that it was killed due to pressure on Sony from Japan's Sumo Association which did not like the way its sport would be portrayed. Tristar denied it. It stopped the project on its own, it said. "Any suggestions that the Sony Corporation has interfered in the creative process or any other aspect of 'Hell Camp' or any other Tristar Pictures project is simply wrong," said Mike Medavoy, chairman of Tristar. Last year, "Mr. Baseball," produced by Universal, about an American living in Japan, had its script rewritten to portray the Japanese in a more favorable light. Criticism flared, but Universal said it had not been pressured by Tokyo.

Unbundling Over Optima
 
The American Express Company once could do no wrong. Then it brought out the Optima Card. Profits at its travel related division dropped 59 percent. It was forced to set aside $265 million against defaults on the credit card. To raise cash, American Express announced last week it was selling off up to 45 percent of its Information Services Corporation, which processess Visa and Mastercard as well as its own cards. Analysts thought the offering might raise up to $800 million for Amex. Is Amex hurting? "This is selling the silverware," said John Keefe, an analyst at Lipper Analytical Services, "They're not really starving for capital at this point, but they're getting a little hungry."
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
What's With the Slurs?
 
Japan is known as a nation that values harmony -- which it calls wa -- in all of its business relations. Politeness is a high form of art. But apparently that does not carry over into its relations with the United States. It seems that Japan's most important politicians are lining up to call Americans, well, lazy. Last month, it was Yoshio Sakurauchi, speaker of the lower house of Parliament, who said Americans were lazy. Then, last week, it was Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, who said Americans "may lack the work ethic," which was, after all, another way of saying Americans are lazy. True, Americans work a few hours less each week than the Japanese do, but the Japanse Labor Ministry itself says Americans are still a tad more productive. Not only that, but the evidence is that the Japanese themselves, if not becoming exactly lazy, are slowly lightening up. Japanese workers are putting in one hour less each week than they did 10 years ago.

Mazda in the U.S.A.
 
For the first time, the Mazda Motor Corporation will be assembling a car in the United State that has enough American content to be classified as a domestic make. The car -- a new 626 model -- has 75 percent of its parts coming from companies operating in the United States. Its glass, paint, tires and electronics are all made here -- some by American companies, some by Japanese transplants operating in the United States. The only parts that are imported from Japan are the engine and transmission. In other words, the most expensive parts.

A Dinosaur Named Cocom
 
America's cold war policy was based on the idea of containment. Keep the Soviet Union huddled within its borders and away from the West's high-tech goodies. To keep Moscow away from such exotica as Macintosh computers and old-fashioned PC's -- the Paris-based Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls was set up. Its members include America's World War II allies (except the Soviet Union, of course) plus Germany and Japan. But is Cocom still needed? Most of corporate America doesn't think so. Neither does much of Europe. Last week, Germany, the Netherlands and Italy introduced a proposal aimed at removing most products from Cocom's list. "The cold war is over," said Eric L. Hirschorn, a lawyer who represents American computer makers. "Why is is over everywhere but in Cocom?"

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Business Diary column on Feb. 9 about the American Express Company misstated the activities of its Information Services Corporation. The corporation processes Visa and Mastercard transactions only, not American Express card transactions.

HEADLINE: Saving Ourselves

BYLINE: By Gina Maranto; Gina Maranto writes about the environment for Discover magazine and other publications.

 BODY:

EARTH IN THE BALANCE
Ecology and the Human Spirit.
By Al Gore.
Illustrated. 407 pp. Boston:
Houghton Mifflin Company.
$22.95. 
 DURING his 15-year tenure in Congress, Senator Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, has made an intensive study of environmental issues. The results, as displayed in "Earth in the Balance," a comprehensive assessment of the forces of planetary destruction -- including overpopulation, deforestation, soil erosion and air and water pollution -- are impressive.
Senator Gore presents even familiar materials in fresh and compelling fashion, drawing from the work of such diverse thinkers as the critic Walter Benjamin, the climate historian Hubert H. Lamb and the physicists Per Bak and Kan Chen.
Now that the cold war is over, he argues, the central strategic threat is that presented by humans to the global environment. In this context, he rethinks the world's industrial and financial arrangements and proposes a "Global Marshall Plan" for the environment.
His recommendations are far-reaching and specific -- for example, to redefine gross national product to account for the ecological costs of growth, or to design tree-planting programs to insure that seedlings are nursed through the first year of growth.
The author exhibits little of the cliched myopia of his profession and is aware of the political obstacles posed by such an integrated approach.
He identifies the root of our current problems as spiritual. If civilization is to persist, he maintains, it must make the rescue of the environment its organizing principle.
His colleagues on Capitol Hill, for starters, should read this perspicacious, heartening book and harken to its message.

HEADLINE: No Silver Lining for Debt Collectors

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
DO hard times mean good times for some industries? For instance, as more businesses and individuals fall behind in paying their bills, do collection agencies benefit?
Those in the debt-collection industry in Westchester say that although their business has increased substantially, their profits have not. 
 "We have seen about an 80 percent increase in the number of accounts over the last year, but at the same time our collectors are working much harder to collect less, about 60 percent of what they were getting from debtors three years ago," said Lynn Starace, president of Trans Credit America, a medical collection agency in Hartsdale, which collects overdue bills from the patients of doctors and dentists.
"People are pretty strapped," Ms. Starace said. "Patients who might have agreed to pay $200 a month on an outstanding bill two years ago are now able to come up with only $50 a month."
Herbert S. Jacobson, president of Berson Associates in White Plains, has been handling commercial accounts -- businesses owing money to businesses -- for 40 years. Almost all of Mr. Jacobson's clients are in the construction industry, and, he said, that industry is experiencing very difficult times.
"Our customers, who are manufacturers and suppliers of building materials, are giving us listings of customers behind in their payments earlier now. One hundred and eighty days used to be the average; now they give us accounts up for collection in 120 to 150 days."
 
25 to 35 Percent Commission
 Mr. Jacobson's agency, typical of all collection agencies, works on a 25 to 35 percent commission.
"If we don't collect our clients' bills, we don't get a penny," he said, "and our collectors are taught that the best way to go about collecting is not by intimidation but by using their good common sense. The most important thing is to deal with people understandingly. If we find an account is impossible to collect, then we will try to work out a reasonable plan of payment. The last thing we want to do is to push anyone beyond their limit, into bankruptcy."
Therefore, Mr. Jacobson said, when a debtor, a subcontractor who owed a supplier several thousand dollars for lumber, "showed a willingness to pay but was pretty stretched, we worked with him on a payment schedule that extended over a reasonable period of time and took it back to our client for his approval.
"Ninety-nine percent of them will agree to such an arrangement because nobody wants to force anyone out of business. When that happens, everyone loses."
Mr. Jacobson, who is 62 years old, acknowledged that the industry has gone through many changes since he entered it 40 years ago.
"Then, debt collectors had a pretty bad image," he said. "Today the industry is more professional and better understood. We have a trade group that sets standards and educates our members. Also, laws have been passed regulating the way collection agencies do business, and those have helped our reputation with the public."
Under the 1977 Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, administered by the Federal Trade Commission, collectors are prohibited from harassing debtors, lying to them or making threatening phone calls. Collectors are also required to keep all correspondence and conversations with debtors private and confidential.
 
'I Was Good at Dealing With People'
 Mr. Jacobson, who said he became a part-time bill collector to support himself while he was in college, added: "I found I was good at dealing with people, which is what collecting bills is all about.
"And after graduation when the agency I was working for offered me a full-time job I gave up the idea of becoming a radio or television performer and went to work for them before I opened my own agency 10 years later."
Mr. Jacobson added that although his agency has had fewer accounts this year, his staff has been making collections faster.
"What is happening is that those people still in business want to stay in business," he said. "Frequently a debtor we deal with turns around and becomes a customer of ours."
Large commercial accounts, those larger than $20,000, are easier to collect, said John Casabianca, president of Trend Credit in New Rochelle. "It's because that type of debtor wants to stay in business," he said.
Mr. Casabianca, who specializes in collections from retail businesses that include large department stores, said: "We just collected $16,000 for a manufacturer client of ours, from the debtor, a large retail store. But smaller accounts are much more difficult to collect right now."
 
New Sources of Business
 The reason, he said, is that collection agencies can still manage to get payment arrangements from retailers that have been in business for more than five years. But agencies trying to collect from retailers that bought small stores within the last three years have an almost impossible task.
"Take the owner of a neighborhood stationery store," Mr. Casabianca said. "He bought the store two years ago, and already it has decreased in value. He has no equity in it to borrow against and, what's more, he is being further squeezed by the payments he owes to the previous owner. In such a case, it is almost impossible to collect debts."
Mr. Casabianca, who has been in the debt-collection business for 15 years, said, however, that the recession has opened up a new source of business for him.
"Like everyone else, my clients are having to let people go. For the first time some of them are putting our collection agency on a retainer, to replace what were formerly in-house collection departments. We not only monitor their accounts, we reconcile outstanding receivables and we photostat invoices and visit debtors and try to get them put on a repayment schedule."
 
New Strategies Developed
 But if the word on the street is that the debtor retailer is in trouble and about to shut down, as Mr. Casabianca said is happening with increasing frequency, then he advises his client to take "whatever he can get, even if it's only 50 percent of what he is owed. Fifty percent is still better than nothing."
Ms. Starace said that in order to deal with the current recession, which has made it harder for collection agencies to collect, the agencies have had to develop some new strategies to keep profitable.
"For us, it has been building volume," she said. "In order to do so we started what I call a pre-collect service. For $9.95, we will send a series of five letters to patients of our clients who have accounts that are 120-270 days overdue."
The first letter, Ms. Starace said, establishes contact and asks the patient to call the doctor's office about the bill. The last letter warns, "If you don't reply to the doctor's office within 10 days, your account will be turned over to a collection agency."
 
'Some People Are Really Deadbeats'
 The pre-collect mailings, Ms. Starace said, have gone out to thousands of patients.
"Sixty-five percent of those who get the letters pay the entire bill," she said. "But the collections from the others, which are handled on a contingency basis by our collection agency, run only about 25 percent. Some people are really deadbeats."
Ira S. Clair, a lawyer in Scarsdale who does collection work, also sends out letters on behalf of clients.
"If clients are owed less than $1,000, I'll send -- for a very nominal charge of $25 to $50 -- a lawyer's letter threatening to sue the debtor. And often it brings the desired results -- payment," Mr. Clair said.

HEADLINE: Is Japan Out to Get Us?

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich's most recent book is "The Work of Nations." He teaches political economy at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.

 BODY:
"WE are definitely at war with Japan," says John Connor, the venerable detective in Michael Crichton's "Rising Sun," as he guides his junior officer through the intricate web of Japan's evil conspiracy to take over America. Here is the latest, and least subtle, of a great tide of recent books demonizing the Japanese. Almost all are classified as nonfiction; a few, like "Rising Sun," as fiction. But in this genre the distinction blurs. Mr. Crichton's characters frequently deliver short lectures on the subject of Japan's insidious design, mixing established fact with fantasy. The result is a thriller that doubles as a crude polemic. Just in case the reader misses his point, Mr. Crichton warns in an afterword of Japan's "adversarial trade, trade like war, trade intended to wipe out the competition," and encourages readers to verify the claims his characters make by consulting several recent works of nonfiction, which he lists.
But the nonfiction books Mr. Crichton cites also tend to mix factual analyses of Japan's economic strength with hyperbolic visions of Japan's plot to run the United States. High on the list is "Agents of Influence" (1990) by Pat Choate, which is partly a thoughtful examination of influence peddling by all large corporations, but also partly a paranoid fantasy about Tokyo's alleged payoffs to influential Americans to achieve "effective political domination over the United States." 
 Another is "Trading Places" (1988) by Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr. -- a useful and detailed chronicle of the frustrations of negotiating trade with Japan, leading to an implausible and unsupported argument that because of our failure to respond adequately to the Japanese challenge, "the power of the United States and the quality of American life is diminishing rapidly in every respect."
A third is "The Enigma of Japanese Power" (1989) by Karel van Wolferen. It combines an insightful analysis of Japan's governing structure with a stereotyped and ahistorical view of Japan as a rudderless, amoral society "in which good behavior is constantly determined by individuals' views of how others expect them to behave . . . and in which conformity to social expectations is not an unfortunate compromise but the only possible way to live."
MR. CRICHTON might have added many other recent works to his list, books that similarly blend fiction and nonfiction as they conjure up a Japan intent on controlling America: William S. Dietrich's "In the Shadow of the Rising Sun" (1991), claiming that Japan "threatens our way of life and ultimately our freedoms as much as past dangers from Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union"; Robert Zielinski and Nigel Holloway's "Unequal Equities" (1991), arguing that Japan's big corporations have rigged their capital markets in ways that undermine American corporations; Daniel Burstein's "Yen! Japan's New Financial Empire and Its Threat to America" (1988), asserting that Japan's growing control over our financial markets puts the United States at risk of falling prey to a "hostile Japanese . . . world order"; and William J. Holstein's "Japanese Power Game" (1990), contending that Japan is motivated by raw power and parochialism, which threaten the United States. I have located over 35 recent books in this genre -- many with bellicose titles like "The Coming War With Japan," "Zaibatsu America: How Japanese Firms are Colonizing Vital U.S. Industries," "The Silent War," "Trade Wars" and so on.
There are several possible explanations for this outpouring, but Japan's recent behavior is not one. Japan still has a long way to go before its economy is truly open, and it can be (and should be) faulted on many grounds, but the big story since the mid-1980's is how far Japan has come in so short a time from its protectionist ways of the 1960's and 1970's. By 1990, Japan was the world's third-largest importer with each Japanese citizen purchasing, on average, about $1,900 worth of imports -- not much less than the average American's purchase of $2,050 of imported products. Japanese imports of manufactured goods have climbed steeply, from less than a quarter of the total in 1980 to over 60 percent last year -- including many high-tech items like space satellites and telecommunications equipment. Since 1985, manufactured exports from the United States to Japan have almost doubled.
Nor do Japanese investments in the United States suggest a conspiracy. For the most part, those investments have been big losers, which is one reason why Japan is cutting back on them. The Treasury bills the Japanese have liked to acquire have declined in value as the dollar has dropped since 1985; the prices of real estate, another Japanese favorite, have fallen since 1989. Only a tiny portion of Japan's total investment has gone to successful American companies; more has been directed at relatively unsuccessful companies in Rust Belt industries like tires and steel. Other investments have taken the form of new factories, where American workers are learning to become more productive and create higher-quality goods than in many American-owned factories.
It is hard to find much of a plot in any of this. Mitsubishi's purchase of a substantial interest in Rockefeller Center, Sony's purchase of Columbia Pictures and Nintendo's recent flirtation with the Seattle Mariners make the headlines, but in almost every controversial case, it has been the American owners who have initiated the deal. The British still own more of the United States than the Japanese do.
Far more significant to Japan's growth than either its trade policies or its American acquisitions has been its willingness to save and to invest in its own productivity. Since the mid-1980's, Japanese companies have invested more money in new factories, capital equipment and products than have American companies -- even though Japan has half our population. And Japan has been investing heavily in education and infrastructure, and will be investing the equivalent of trillions of dollars more over the next decade. That all this investment enables Japan to make products of high quality, which American consumers want to buy, does not constitute a vicious plot.
Before going farther, it is necessary for me to reassure the reader that I am not now, nor have I ever been, an employee of a Japanese company, nor do I receive any research funds from the Japanese, consult for the Japanese or hold an academic chair donated by the Japanese. I feel compelled to issue this disclaimer because so much of the literature under review casts suspicions on any academic who dares suggest that a Japanese plot may not be under way. Pat Choate, in "Agents of Influence," warns darkly of Japan's infestation of American universities in order to distort research in its favor. One of the few characters in Mr. Crichton's "Rising Sun" who is not yet bought off by the Japanese explains that American professors "deliver the Japanese propaganda line. They don't really have a choice, because they need access to Japan to work." Were these professors to sound critical of Japan, they would "lose speaking engagements and consulting jobs. They know that's happened to their colleagues who step out of line." These passages are not only nonsensical, since Japanese funding accounts for a minuscule fraction of professorial incomes, they are uncomfortably reminiscent of suspicions during the 1950's of the loyalty of American university professors and their vulnerability to foreign conspiracy.
But if Japan is not really plotting against us, what accounts for this wave of fearmongering?
Perhaps American sensitivities are running high in light of the 50th anniversary of Pearl Harbor. Memories of the attack can be detected in the metaphors with which the Japanese challenge is described in many of these books: Japan is "targeting" our key industries (Holstein); it is "raiding" our technologies (Dietrich); we are "outgunned . . . in the battle for control of world financial resources" (Burstein); Japan is mounting a "planned attack" on the United States through a "new kind of invasion" (Crichton).
SOMETIMES the Pearl Harbor analogy is explicit. In "Pearl Harbor Ghosts" (1991) Thurston Clarke journeys to Hawaii to discover the legacies of the attack, and draws "lessons . . . too depressing, or simply too terrifying" to be faced by most Americans. "In a Japanese victory more enduring than Pearl Harbor," Japan has won the "trade war," and is turning Hawaii itself into an "economic colony" -- with "paler shadows haunting the mainland." The detective John Connor, in "Rising Sun," counsels his protege to "remember Pearl Harbor."
Yet memory of the disaster 50 years ago is only a small part of the explanation. The fears expressed in these books would not be as intense as they are were it not for America's own economic doldrums. Although several of the books were published before the current recession, low productivity gains and deepening debt have been eating away at the foundations of the American economy for years. The reasons for these long-term ills have been well chronicled: a capital market that resembles a casino and demands immediate profits; an educational system that leaves almost 80 percent of our young people unable to comprehend a news magazine and many others unprepared for work; managers who award themselves princely sums while laying off their workers at the slightest hint of a downturn; a collapsing infrastructure of unsafe bridges and potholed roads; and, more generally, a social norm -- which reached its zenith during the 1980's -- of overconsumption and underinvestment.
None of these failings are readily remedied without considerable sacrifice. It is far easier to blame others. It has been this way through history. When the British economy began to sag at the beginning of this century, British citizens were treated to a series of lurid exposes, such as Frederick MacKenzie's "American Invaders," about the American economic onslaught and its baleful consequences. Seventy years later, Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber issued similar warnings to Europe in "Le Defi Americain" ("The American Challenge"). That these American invasions helped their victims prosper in subsequent years is not now in dispute. Yet at the time they served to distract public attention from domestic problems. Japan plays a similar role for us today.
But I think there is something else going on here as well. Most of these books seek not only to explain our problems in terms of Japan's aggressiveness, but also to incite a response from the reader. These books are calls to arms. Their authors want America to join together against the perceived threat. Join together: American government, American business, American labor. Join together: wealthy Americans, poor Americans, Americans of every creed and ethnicity. In "Trading Places," Clyde Prestowitz asks rhetorically whether the American motto will be " 'every man for himself,' or 'all for one and one for all?' " and answers that "E Pluribus Unum (out of many, one) needs to be reaffirmed." William Dietrich urges us to "develop a national consensus of our own."
JAMES FALLOWS, a Washington-based journalist and among the most thoughtful critics of Japan, develops the unity theme most fully in his book "More Like Us" (1989). After surveying the differences between Japanese and American society, Mr. Fallows urges us to "revive the idea that America is one coherent society, with bonds that are stronger than its internal differences. We understood this instinctively during World War II, but not often enough since then."
The ostensible purpose of joining together is to meet the Japanese challenge. But I think that the real logic -- the deep message of these books, hidden perhaps even from the purveyors of the warnings -- is precisely the reverse. The purpose of having a Japanese challenge is to give us a reason to join together. That is, we seem to need Japan as we once needed the Soviet Union -- as a means of defining ourselves, our interests, our obligations to one another. We should not be surprised that this wave of Japan-as-enemy books coincides exactly with the easing of cold-war tensions.
As the 21st century approaches, we can see, I believe, a profound unease about the coherence of American society reflected in these books. The global economy is tightly linking our citizens to the citizens of other nations -- with ties as strong as, if not stronger than, the economic connections binding us to one another within our borders. Talented and well-educated Americans grow wealthier as the emerging world market rewards them for their problem-solving skills. Unskilled Americans grow poorer as they are forced to compete with millions of unskilled workers from around the world who are eager to work for a small fraction of American wages.
The same technologies of worldwide communication and transportation that have nourished the global economy are creating cultural linkages across borders and threatening the dominance within the United States of a single American culture. An affluent native of Brazil who lives in Miami can now read a Sao Paulo daily newspaper beamed by satellite to a computerized press a few miles away, watch Brazilian television via satellite, send and receive facsimile messages within seconds, telephone Brazil at the touch of a finger and fly home frequently to visit family and friends. Ease of worldwide transportation also means an ever larger number of illegal immigrants. And unlike the great tide of immigrants at the end of the last century, most of the people in this new wave are not European.
The recent movement toward multicultural ism in American schools and colleges, and the sharp reaction to it, can be understood in the same terms: at once a sign of the nation's increasing diversity, and also a warning of the growing power of its centrifuge. At least one Presidential candidate now trudging through New Hampshire, Pat Buchanan, is sounding the nativist alarm, not heard so loud in this country since the 1930's.
This is the real specter haunting these Japan books: not the specter of Japan's dominance, but of an America that no longer coheres. Japan's extreme homogeneity -- racial, cultural, linguistic -- intensifies, by contrast, our feared loss of identity. They do join together; they do seem tightly bound to one another. They know who they are. But who are we?
Yet an economic war with Japan is not necessary to help us find a national self-definition. At best, such a war could function as a pretext for directing America's resources, newly freed up by the end of the cold war, toward health, nutrition and schooling (we must invest in the future generation of Americans, lest the Japanese overtake us!), and toward our infrastructure (Americans must be linked together by fiber-optic cable, so that we can meet the Japanese challenge!). But an economic war with Japan could also be as wasteful and destructive as was the cold war with the Soviet Union -- causing us to restrict Japanese trade and block Japanese investment, engage in a mounting series of economic retaliations and thus substantially diminish our standard of living and theirs. It could also ignite racism and jingoism of the ugliest sort.
The central question for America in the post-Soviet world -- a diverse America, whose economy and culture are rapidly fusing with the economies and cultures of the rest of the globe -- is whether it is possible to rediscover our identity, and our mutual responsibility, without creating a new enemy. The authors under review may think not. I hope they are wrong.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Weeklies See Profits Without A Charge

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Although numerous publications have been battered by the recession, Michael Schenkler remains convinced he can make money by expanding in the free-distribution newspaper business in the New York area.
Mr. Schenkler, president of News Communications Inc., says his small company's four free newspapers -- The Manhattan Spirit, Our Town and The Queens Tribune in New York City and Dan's Papers on eastern Long Island -- are profitable, with a total circulation of about 425,000 copies a week. And he is so certain that he has found the formula for success that he is aggressively seeking to buy other, similar publications. 
 "We're certainly in better shape than the dailies," Mr. Schenkler asserted, noting that three of the city's four daily newspapers -- The Daily News, The New York Post and New York Newsday -- have lost tens of millions of dollars in recent years.
 
Opportunities for Weeklies
 News Communications' plans underscore what some industry executives and analysts say are the opportunities for free-distribution weeklies. Focusing on local issues, these weeklies are different from the free "shoppers" that carry only advertising.
These analysts and executives say the weeklies, which are distributed in stores or to apartment lobbies and doorsteps, are weathering the recession better than many dailies. As a result, they say, the weeklies present a big challenge to dailies in cities and suburbs across the country, from Boston to the wealthy communities outside Los Angeles.
But other analysts are more skeptical. Free weeklies, they maintain, are suffering like nearly everyone else, particularly because they cannot raise revenue by increasing cover prices. They also emphasize that it is difficult to find data on the weeklies.
And these analysts repeat a maxim in the industry: advertisers prefer daily newspapers because they believe that people who pay for publications are more likely to read them.
Free weeklies "lack the stability you get from circulation revenues," said John S. Reidy, a newspaper industry analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. "I really don't view these newspapers as a significant source of competition for a well-run major newspaper."
John Morton, an analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington, said he doubted that free weeklies had escaped the economic slump. He said two weekly chains in the Washington area whose operations he recently examined were definitely feeling it.
But other analysts, as well as some publishers, assert that as the economy has slumped, many businesses have focused on reaching specific neighborhoods with their advertisments in order to cut costs.
 
'Holding Their Own'
 "When businesses scale back, they target more, and weeklies are good recipients for this kind of targeted approach," said Deirdre T. Flynn, executive director of the Association of Free Community Papers, which represents weeklies that claim a combined circulation of 18 million.
Ms. Flynn said the association did not keep statistics on how the industry was faring, but she added that free-distribution newspapers were "holding their own" in the recession.
And Ken Noble, president of Noble Consultants Inc., a market research firm in Bronxville, N.Y., said there was anecdotal evidence that many free weeklies were weathering the downturn well. "Although there is no good data, it is a business that is doing better than average," he said.
Tom Karavakis, president of Add Inc. in Waupaca, Wis., one of the nation's largest chains of free weeklies, said his publications' performance depended to some extent on location: papers in Wisconsin and Ohio had fared well, while others in New York and Connecticut had seen their advertising fall because the recession had hit those states harder.
Mr. Karavakis declined to disclose specific figures, but he asserted that in general his weeklies were doing better than their daily competitors.
 
Mom-and-Pop Customers
 "Large daily newspapers are dependent on department store advertising," he said. "They've lost a lot of linage that we never got in the first place. Our accounts are the mom-and-pop customers who are more easily replaced if they do go out of business."
Mr. Schenkler of News Communications said his newspapers were prospering because they reached neighborhoods attractive to advertisers while keeping costs low by, for example, employing nonunion labor.
As a result, News Communications has posted its first profits since it became a publicly traded company in 1987. It earned $4,000 in the second quarter and $139,000 in the third quarter, the latest period reported. For the first nine months of 1991, it narrowed its losses to $128,000, from $730,000 a year earlier. Revenues rose more than 13 percent in the period, to $5.1 million.
Mr. Schenkler's weeklies focus on local issues like education, crime and community board hearings. A recent issue of The Queens Tribune, for example, included articles on a crime wave at the Queensbridge housing project and political redistricting.
In May, News Communications bought Our Town, which circulates on the East Side of Manhattan, for a little more than $1 million. Since that time, Mr. Schenkler estimated, revenue has grown about 50 percent.
 
Expansion Plans
 "By the time I'm done with what I intend to do," he said, "I'll have a paper in every borough and I'll be in Connecticut and I'll be all the way to the tip of Long Island."
But Mr. Schenkler still faces some important skeptics.
"We on the advertising side have always had a concern about unpaid publications of any kind," said Roberta Garfinkle, senior vice president for print media at the McCann-Erickson advertising agency. "What kind of guarantees do we have that people actually see it?"
