SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1756 words

HEADLINE: SOME HAITIANS SAY CONTINUING ABUSES FORCED A 2D FLIGHT

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Dozens of refugees forcibly returned to Haiti in recent months have told United Nations officials that they suffered beatings, imprisonment, death threats and other abuses that prompted them to flee their country a second time.
The statements, made to interviewers last month at the refugee camp set up by the United States at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, appear to undercut a key argument made by the Bush Administration in defending its policy of forcibly returning Haitian boat people. State Department officials have consistently said there is "no evidence" that any Haitians have suffered political repression upon their return. 
 A State Department official said the refugees' assertions were being investigated.
 
U.N. Aide Urges Review
 A United Nations official familiar with the cases called the accounts "sufficiently disturbing to warrant a review of policy toward the Haitians."
Refugee advocates said the statements would be introduced as evidence when the Supreme Court considers, possibly as early as Monday, a final appeal to slow the return of the thousands of Haitians held at the United States Navy base at Guantanamo.
More than 15,000 boat people have fled Haiti since October, in the aftermath of a violent military coup against the country's first elected Government. Following a long court-ordered delay, the Coast Guard resumed repatriations last week after the Supreme Court cleared the way, even as the process was being appealed.
 
Statements by 42
 The 42 Haitians who made the statements to United Nations refugee officials are officially known as "double-backers," having made desperate second attempts to flee Haiti after returning to their country and encountering violent repression.
Lawyers for the refugees said the Haitians had also been interviewed by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, and 41 of the 42 were recently granted entry to the United States. The Immigration Service apparently determined that the account of one refugee lacked credibility.
One Haitian, who insisted on anonymity, said he had escaped from prison after having been returned to the island in November. While he was in jail other returnees were removed from his cell and beaten, and prison guards said some returnees would be killed for having criticized their Government, he said.
Refugee and immigration rights advocates said today that the State Department, which contends that most Haitians are fleeing for economic reasons, appeared to have played down the risks refugees face in order to secure the Supreme Court's permission to send them back.
"On the one hand you have the I.N.S. receiving credible accounts of death, torture and imprisonment," said Arthur C. Helton, an immigration expert with the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, "and on the other hand you have the State Department spokeswoman claiming there has never been presented any evidence of mistreatment of these people -- a statement that was reflected in the Solicitor General's arguments to the Court."
Mr. Helton, who provided a journalist with transcripts of several of the interviews with the 41 refugees at Guantanamo, called the State Department's handling of the matter a "studied attempt to mislead the Federal judiciary." The interviews were conducted in January by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
 
Reports Given to U.S.
 On Friday, the commissioner, Sadako Ogata, delivered information from interviews with the 41 Haitians to Brunson McKinley, an ambassadorial-level official in the State Department's bureau of refugee programs.
A State Department official said his agency had learned of the accounts by the "double-backers" about a week ago from the interviews conducted at Guantanamo by the Immigration Service. Last week, the official said, the United States Embassy in Port-au-Prince was instructed to investigate several of the cases.
"We haven't confirmed this yet," the official said, denying that there had been any attempt to mislead the public or the judiciary. "We'll see. Maybe it will be confirmed, maybe it won't.
"It is absurd to think that anyone could or would try to hide this," he said, "because about 25 percent of the Haitian boat people have already been screened into this country to pursue asylum claims precisely because they have shown fears of individual persecution."
 
Reliability Questioned
 The spokesman for the Immigration Service, Duke Austin, also raised questions about the reliability of refugees' accounts in general, although he did not dispute the details in these cases. "If you took everything in their interviews that was said as a fact, then every Haitian would be waved in," he said.
On Friday, Richard A. Boucher, a State Department spokesman, said in a Washington briefing: "We have no evidence people were persecuted for having been sent back. We've said before that there are occasional allegations and stories, that our embassy and others try to check these out. But, to date, we haven't had any that do check out."
Asked how reliable the information provided by the refugees about persecution was, the United Nations official said: "The stories they tell are similar and detailed, which adds to their credibility. They also provided the names of other people they were with, and these names have checked out."
Citing the interviews, refugee advocates have called for a temporary halt to sending people back until the United States can insure that it is safe for others to be returned.
 
10,000 Still at Guantanamo
 More than 10,000 Haitians remain at the tent camp at Guantanamo, and most are expected to be returned. More than 2,000 were sent back as of Friday, the Immigration Service said. More than 3,400 have been cleared for entry to the United States to be considered for permanent political asylum, based on the legal criterion of a "well-founded fear of persecution."
The "double-backers" were among 538 Haitians returned in November, before the process was delayed for months by legal appeals. Since immigration interviews are still being conducted at Guantanamo, it is not known how many other double-backers might be there.
The interviews, if accurate, bolster the view that the army-backed government that overthrew the President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, is conducting a campaign of terror against people it believes to be his supporters.
Refugee advocates say it also raises questions about the processing of refugees upon their return to Haiti. At dockside, with heavily armed police standing by, the refugees are interviewed by Haitian immigration officers, fingerprinted and photographed, before being allowed to leave the port area with a small amount of money, provided by the Red Cross, for transportation home.
One 21-year-old refugee, Similus Thomas, said his father, a member of Father Aristide's political movement, Lavalas, had been shot dead on Nov. 1. Twelve days later, Mr. Thomas fled the country by boat, only to be returned by the Coast Guard on Nov. 17.
Two days later, soldiers came looking for him at his mother's home in the Port-au-Prince slum of Cite Soleil, but were told he was not there. According to Mr. Thomas, his cousin, Lifete Similus, who made the voyage with him, was arrested that same day.
Hours later, the body of Lifete Similus was found, dressed in a soldier's uniform and riddled with bullets, in the street near his house.
Mr. Thomas said he was later arrested and jailed along with others among the 229 who were returned with him from Guantanamo. Mr. Thomas said the prisoners were beaten daily and said a guard told him that several had been killed for fleeing Haiti.
Mr. Thomas said he was able to escape dressed in a women's clothing, which had been smuggled into the prison by a friend. He told how he later made his way to the island of La Gonave and hid in the bush, fleeing Haiti on Jan. 9 after begging for passage on a boat.
State Department officials say diplomats looking into this case and that of another resident of Cite Soleil "were unable to turn up any information."
Another refugee, Fritz Jean, a 30-year-old who was forcibly returned with his wife and child on Nov. 13, said he had come forward at the dockside refugee processing center when authorities failed to call out his name.
Mr. Jean said he was told that if his name was not on the list, he could not have been on the Coast Guard cutter, and that he must be one of those who had "denounced the Haitian authorities and his country to the United States."
When Mr. Jean's wife decided to remain in the city, he borrowed from her the $10 she had been given by the Red Cross and began to make his way to his family's hometown of Petit-Goave.
As it left Port-au-Prince, Mr. Jean's bus was stopped at a checkpoint by soldiers who boarded the vehicle and at gunpoint insisted that passengers identify those who had come aboard at the port, he said. The soldiers began to beat these passengers with rifle butts and arrested about 20 men, women and children who had been repatriated with him on the same cutter.
Mr. Jean said somehow he escaped detection. When he arrived in Petit-Goave, he said his mother told him soldiers had already come looking for him. Rather than risk arrest, he left for La Gonave that night. On Jan. 9, he said, he caught his second boat for the United States, but was soon picked up again by the Coast Guard.
Jean-Eddy Theodore, another Petit-Goave resident, described himself as a member of the Association Comite des Jeunes, a pro-Aristide youth group whose vice president had been arrested and beaten after the Sept. 30 coup.
 
Returned in Mid-November
 Sent back to Haiti in mid-November, Mr. Theodore said he was accosted by a soldier as he left the port area, but was left alone after telling him that he had gone there to see a relative.
As he left the dock, Mr. Theodore said he heard shots and immediately fled, sleeping that night by the roadside. The following morning, he said, as he approached the dock area again, he came across the body of a person who had been sent back to Haiti with him.
When Mr. Theodore reached Petit-Goave, he said, his mother alerted him that soldiers were looking for him. Relatives of fellow returnees told him that a warrant had been issued for the arrest of several of them for criticizing the Government.
After soldiers came looking for him at his girlfriend's house, where he had been hiding, Mr. Theodore made his way to La Gonave and caught a boat for the United States on Jan. 9.

HEADLINE: Schools Chief Wants to Lengthen Year for New York City Students

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
New York City Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez is fashioning a plan to lengthen the school day by an hour and the school year by 25 days, both to improve student skills and to make a bid for a hefty share of the $1.1 billion the city hopes to gain through bond refinancing.
Mr. Fernandez, who has gained national attention for initiatives like a condom-distribution program and school-based management, is seizing on an idea that some educators contend can make American students more competitive with those of other industrialized countries. 
 But Mr. Fernandez is also making what he calls a daring "grab" for up to $250 million of the $1.1 billion that Mayor David N. Dinkins hopes will flow to the city through a refinancing of bonds held by the Municipal Assistance Corporation, the agency created during the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's to sell bonds on behalf of the city.
Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, has indicated a willingness to consider allowing the city to use the M.A.C. funds. But he has said the proceeds from a refinancing cannot be used simply to close gaps in the city's budget, but must be combined with investments that yield productivity savings and reductions in the work force to help balance the city's budget within a few years.
Mr. Fernandez said he thought that a longer school day and longer year would increase graduation rates, reduce the number of students who are mistakenly referred to costly programs for the learning disabled and give the city a better educated work force, precisely the kinds of measures he feels Mr. Rohatyn, who has shown a strong personal interest in education, is seeking. Mr. Rohatyn was out of the country and could not be reached for comment.
The move, however, could put the Chancellor in conflict with City Hall. In the past Mr. Fernandez has not shied away from such confrontations on budget matters.
The First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel, reacted coolly to Mr. Fernandez's proposal. In an interview on Friday, Mr. Steisel denied the Chancellor's assertion that he had discussed the proposal with Mayor Dinkins.
Mr. Steisel also said the M.A.C. money was "was not up for grabs" because most of it was earmarked for other purposes.
But he did say that as much as $200 million in M.A.C. money was available for investments in productivity, and he did not rule out the possibility that Mr. Fernandez's proposal might qualify.
"If in fact he can show that by spending money, he's going to produce downsizing, a more productive, less expensive school system, then we would have to look hard at how do you find ways to make that investment," he said.
The United States has one of theshortest school years among industrialized nations. Children in Japan, West Germany, South Korea and Israel are required to attend school between 216 to 243 days a year while those in most American states attend roughly 180 days. Students in foreign countries also spend more time in school each day than the 6 hours and 20 minutes demanded of New York City pupils.
 
Once Tied to 'Farm Economy'
 The disparities are often used to explain the superior performance of foreign students in mathematics and science.
In a lengthy interview last week, Mr. Fernandez said: "Historically, the 180-day school year was tied into the farm economy and the one-room school house, people having to come home before dark, having to be available when the crops were harvested."
But proposals to lengthen the day or year have been hobbled by the American tradition of the long summer vacation, cherished by teachers as well as parents, and by the complex daily rhythms of American family life in an era of working mothers.
Only a handful of schools have experimented with alternatives, so if Mr. Fernandez overcomes the considerable obstacles facing his plan, New York could become the first urban system to stretch the year appreciably beyond 180 days. A commission appointed by Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey recently called for an extension of the school year to 220 days, and at least one town, Englewood, is looking into an extension of the school year to 200 days.
Mr. Fernandez, who prides himself on his reputation as an innovator, suggested that his bid for the corporation money is driven by budgetary practicalities: the city has no money for educational improvements. The only source the Chancellor sees on the horizon is the estimated $1.1 billion that is expected to be realized through a refinancing of corporation bonds over the next four years.
 
A Link to Performance
 Because schools make up a quarter of the city's budget, he said, the refinancing could potentially yield $250 million for the city's schools, with $20 million to $50 million needed for his proposal to extend the school day and year, largely to pay higher salaries for teachers who would be working more hours. Mr. Fernandez has patched together other proposals for the rest of the $250 million, including a large investment in computer-assisted reading programs.
In the interview, he contended that increasing the amount of time students spend in school should produce marked benefits in higher reading and math scores and lower dropout rates that would win Mr. Rohatyn's blessings.
"It should be tied to student outcomes and if it doesn't produce, fold it," Mr. Fernandez said.
He said that under his proposal, 100 of the city's 991 schools, most of them junior high schools, would be asked to fashion individualized plans for lengthening the school day on four days a week and for mandatory five-week summer session programs.
 
Emphasis on Core Classes
 The additional class time would be used for academic subjects like math, English and science and not for recreational or extracurricular activities. Together the summer session and lengthened school days could amount to the equivalent of a 235-day school year, Mr. Fernandez said.
Such proposals could be done over the next few months, he said, and the program could begin in a few schools as early as September. Mr. Fernandez did not spell out how schools would deal with students or teachers who did not want to participate in the program, saying only that each school would have to address such issues in its proposal.
Mr. Fernandez has broached the idea of a longer day, though not of a longer year, to Sandra Feldman, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, during current negotiations over a new contract.
In an interview on Friday, Ms. Feldman said that details of the proposal were sketchy but that "we're open to it if people are appropriately paid and if we're talking about an educational program."
Traditionally, many teachers search for ways to make extra money, and summer-school assignments are regarded as plums.
 
Other Education Plans
 In the interview, Mr. Fernandez also revealed a number of other plans:
*Setting up "family colleges" in which mothers on welfare could attend City University classes while their children attended school in nearby classrooms run by the Board of Education. The first such program will open at Kingsborough Community College on March 6.
*Increasing the science requirement for high school graduation to three years from two, with more rigorous science courses required for graduation.
*Creating 10 small high schools, including one for students interested in environmental sciences that will open in September in the building on East 15th Street that is currently occupied by Stuyvesant High School. Stuyvesant is moving to new quarters just north of Battery Park City.
Mr. Fernandez also lamented the impact of budget cuts on the schools, noting that average class size in the 4th through 12th grades has grown by two students, with high school classes averaging 32.3 students.
 
Focus on Junior High
 Mr. Fernandez explained that junior high schools would be the focus of the the plan to extend the school day and year because they are regarded as the city's most troubled. Many students begin patterns of attendance and work that lead to their dropping out by the time they reach high school.
James S. Vlasto, a spokesman for Mr. Fernandez, said the school day would not be lengthened on Fridays because many schools use that day for special activities and because many Jewish teachers, who need to to get home in time for the Sabbath, could not work longer hours.
Mr. Fernandez noted that his efforts to improve attendance have already resulted in a $22 million increase in state aid, which is based on attendance.
Similarly, he said, a five-week summer session for elementary school students threatened with being held back has cut by half referrals to costly programs for the learning disabled.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Journal;
Steady Drum of '92 Ads Takes Toll on Voters

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GOFFSTOWN, N.H., Feb. 9

 BODY:
Campaign fatigue may be setting in at the D'Angelo Sandwich Shop here.
Each morning, just after Georgette Seguin starts slicing the bread at precisely 9:30, the same commercial attacking President Bush comes on the radio, and Dan Deshaies cannot resist the temptation to come out of the back room, look her in the eye, and begin lip-syncing to the President's voice: "Read my lips: No new taxes." 
"I've probably done it 25 times now, and Georgette still laughs every time," said Mr. Deshaies, the shop's manager, but he allowed that the joke might be wearing thin. "Personally, I think all these campaign ads are kind of stinky, because they won't stop playing the same ones. The Presidency is like a product, and when you sell a product, you should change the ads."
Actually, they do change some of the ads, but for many people here it is hard to tell the difference anymore. The campaign is becoming one long audio-visual blur. The news programs and talk shows are devoted to campaign appearances, to candidates' health-care plans and candidates' bouts of flu, to the character of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, and to the question that mercilessly refuses to die on talk radio: Will Mario Cuomo run?
And just about anyone who turns on a radio or television, whether for Merle Haggard's music or the intrigues of "All My Children," is going to be subjected to a candidate's commercial. The most inescapable message seems to be Mr. Bush's famous no-new-taxes pledge from 1988 -- the sound bite that is biting back.
Commercials for Mr. Bush's conservative challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan, feature the pledge over and over on radio and in television spots accompanied by red and white letters asking, "Can we afford FOUR MORE YEARS of BROKEN promises?" In the latest version, Mr. Buchanan's commercial ends with a group of what seem to be kindly country folks sitting at a general store as they recite "Read our lips" and the announcer says, "Vote Pat Buchanan for President."
So far, the commercials have not won any votes at the sandwich shop -- Mr. Deshaies and Mrs. Seguin are sticking with the President -- and other Republican voters say their anger at the President's policies is beginning to be redirected at Mr. Buchanan's incessant ads.
Another inescapable presence is the smiling face of Mr. Clinton, from the childhood photos appearing on his commercials to the shots of his campaign appearances. Many people in Washington think the continuing questions about the Governor's character -- and the jokes by Johnny Carson and David Letterman -- are bound to cripple his campaign, but here on television Mr. Clinton still manages to look unperturbed, if not smug.
Mr. Clinton's loudest critic, Gennifer Flowers, secured her status as a butt of late-night monologues by appearing twice last week on "A Current Affair" to repeat her accusations that Mr. Clinton had an affair with her. The interviews were conducted so leeringly and credulously that they must have inspired sympathy for Mr. Clinton, and Ms. Flowers's singing of "Stand by Your Man" was possibly a new low even for tabloid television.
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts had his first triumph on television when he appeared Friday evening live on WMUR-TV's newscast to discuss a survey by the Manchester station. The poll showed him replacing Mr. Clinton as the first choice of Democratic voters, and, at least on Friday's newscast, Mr. Tsongas got front-runner treatment.
"I wish to deny that poll," Mr. Tsongas joked in his low-key style, which is becoming more endearing as he gets accustomed to the camera and viewers get accustomed to his droopy presence on the screen. He predictably warned that a single poll could not be trusted, and he reinforced his image of cautious dependability by turning sober and saying, "I think the basic point is that the economic message is taking hold."
 
Kerrey Tries 'a Change'
 Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska is running commercials with a slogan of "Courage for a Change," and the most obvious change is that he is talking to people. In his first commercials he stood alone gesturing robotically as he spoke sternly at the camera.
Last week, Mr. Kerrey looked more personable in a commercial showing him at a kitchen table urging people not to accept his rivals' "counterfeit" health-care plans. His image may also have benefited from another commercial, showing still photographs of him in Vietnam and later receiving the Medal of Honor, that happened to run just before Mr. Clinton appeared live on the news to answer questions about his draft deferment.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa has some of the most striking television advertising. He appears speaking to a circle of people on the empty floor of an abandoned factory, which is initially disconcerting, since it is not clear what all of them are doing in there.
But the camera does a lovely job of catching Mr. Harkin's expressive face as sunlight streams in through the windows, and he has the flair to make the scene convincing as he talks about hearing echoes of advice from the factory's past workers: "Don't forget. Don't give up. Build it again." The commercial seems nearly as well-ingrained in public consciousness as Mr. Bush's read-my-lips sound bite.
But some local viewers are distracted from the message because they recognize the commercial's setting. The building was part of the giant textile mill in Manchester that went out of business in the mid-1930's -- during the New Deal, a period that Mr. Harkin praises as the epitome of American productivity. Over the next half-century, smaller textile businesses used the mill, but they gradually failed, too, and Mr. Harkin's exhortation to "build it again" sounds odd to some people.
 
Locals Are Skeptical
 "The idea that any single candidate could do anything to revive the textile industry here is a fairy tale," said Elizabeth Lessard, a Manchester librarian. "We've been watching these companies fail for decades because they can't compete with the new mills in the South and overseas. You look at him standing in that old factory floor with all the columns in the background, and you think, 'My Lord, who could ever manufacture anything today in that kind of building?' "
Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California is the least conspicuous of the candidates, because he is not running short commercials. Instead, he is relying on a 30-minute commercial, "Take Back America," that appears infrequently and attacks the whole election system as corrupted by money. He also relies on talk radio, and his disgust seems to resonate with certain listeners.
Some voters say that what they like about this year's Democratic campaign is the lack of negativity, or at least the absence of negative advertising. There is still plenty of time before the Feb. 18 primary for things to turn nasty, but so far the Democrats have generally refrained from singling out rivals by name in their commercials.
"They're talking about the issues more this time," said Laurence Gott, a landscaper in Bedford. "People are still mad at the negative advertising from four years ago, and I think it's good that there hasn't been much of the negative stuff. Well, except for that read-my-lips one. Now that's one that stays in your head.
"Yeah, it's getting repetitious. I would also have to say that a lot of people are looking forward to Feb. 19."

HEADLINE: A Community Board in Conflict

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Fear and anguish have upset the workaday business of Community Board 14 in Brooklyn. Angry outbursts and denunciations have disrupted its monthly meetings in school auditoriums. Its storefront office on Avenue H in Flatbush closed for three days last month while its staff underwent counseling, and when the office reopened, a police officer stood guard out front.
For two years now, the community board has been under a sort of political siege as a small but determined group of black community advocates has waged a vigorous campaign to increase the number of blacks on the largely white board. 
 Their protests, which have led to threats, assaults and arrests, accusations of racism and racial and anti-Semitic remarks, have struck a nerve in the district that many fear could disrupt not only the community board but also the racially mixed district, which includes Flatbush and Midwood.
"Their agenda is to obstruct and perpetuate a deep racial mistrust in this community," Terry Rodie, the board's district manager, said. "We cannot let that happen -- whatever it takes."
But the protesters, led by Ernest N. Foster, a local businessman and political aspirant, say the efforts to portray them as dangerous and divisive simply muddle the real issue: blacks, who represent 40 percent of the district, hold just 22 percent of the seats on the board. "The neighborhood has changed drastically, but the power structure hasn't," Mr. Foster said. "Right now I see Flatbush just like South Africa. The majority are here, but we have no power, economically or politically."
The protests, which show no sign of ending, in many ways reflect how the district -- as much of Brooklyn -- has changed and is changing further. In the last decade, as thousands of Caribbean and other immigrants have flowed into the long, narrow district hanging from the southern end of Prospect Park, the black population has increased by 46 percent, according to
the 1990 census. At the same time, the white population has fallen 18 percent.
What has changed much less has been Community Board 14. There are only 11 blacks among the 50 board members, who are appointed to the voluntary position by Borough President Howard Golden from nominations by the City Council members from the district. Two years ago there were only three blacks on the board.
While acknowledging a discrepancy in minority representation, the board's chairman, Alvin M. Berk, who is white, said the color of board members' skin was irrelevant compared with the competence and commitment they bring to the board, which acts as a liaison between the community and the city's various agencies.
"This board is not about race," said Mr. Berk. "This board is about delivering services to the community without regard to race. Service delivery is not racial. There is not a black way to pick up garbage and a white way to pick up garbage."
The protests began early in 1990 -- about the time the board became embroiled in the highly publicized and racially divisive boycott of a Korean greengrocer on Church Avenue. Mr. Foster,
the chairman of the African People's Political Club of Flatbush, said that to him the boycott reflected a blatant instance of how Flatbush's black community struggles without a voice in a system dominated by a white political machine.
The community board, as the first level of city government, became Mr. Foster's target, and since March of 1990, he and a handful of supporters have appeared at almost every one of the board's monthly meetings.
 
Tension and Fear
 While they say their protests have been as benign as chanting or refusing to give up the microphone during the public comment periods, board
members say their presence has disrupted the meetings entirely and created an insidious atmosphere of tension and fear.
Several meetings broke down and had to be abruptly canceled. After repeatedly interrupting the board's meeting last October, Mr. Foster was arrested and charged with disorderly conduct and obstructing governmental administration.
The pitch of the protests reached a critical level at the board's last meeting, in January. After a raucous meeting deteriorated into chaos, one of the protesters shoved a table that crushed Ms. Rodie's left foot, aggravating an injury she said she suffered when kicked at a meeting last year. Janet Bagot, a member of the African People's Political Club, was arrested and charged with assault, disorderly conduct and harassment.
 
Board's Office Closed
 That incident prompted the three-day closing of the board's office, as its employees sought psychological counseling from counselors provided by City Hall.
"This is not a dispute about representation," Mr. Berk, the board chairman, said. "It's about someone trying to disrupt the process of government. It's about someone encouraging an atmosphere of intimidation and lawlessness."
Mr. Golden, the Borough President, declined to discuss Mr. Foster's protests, saying his "15-year record of appointments to the 18 community boards in Brooklyn speaks for itself." Mr. Golden said he agreed to meet with Mr. Foster last April to discuss increasing representation but canceled the meeting after Mr. Foster and six others staged a protest on the steps of Borough Hall.
But City Councilwoman Susan D. Alter, who with Councilman Noach Dear has recommended the board's appointments in the past, said the board has changed to reflect the community's diversity. And, she said, with another round of appointments due in April -- this time on nominations by Ms. Alter, Mr. Dear and two new Council members who represent parts of the district, Una Clark and Anthony Weiner -- that change will continue.
"We've been filling those numbers as people retire, as people leave the board," Ms. Alter said. "In fact, blacks are being put on the board. What Ernie and company keep screaming is, 'Why don't you put in my blacks?' "
 
'Benevolent Dictatorship'
 Colin Moore, the lawyer for Mr. Foster's organizaiton, who has also appeared at the protests, called the board "a benevolent dictatorship" that merely represents the overwhelmingly white political establishment and that feard relinquishing its power to the new majority.
 "The old guard has been there for some time now," Mr. Moore said. "They quite simply are not reading the tea leaves. They want to continue running the board they way they have been."
 Mr. Foster vowed that the protests would continue, including at the board's meeting tonight at Public School 249 on Caton Avenue, until blacks are given what he considers a fair share of seats - perhaps 30 to 35. "We just want to speak our piece," Mr. Foster said. "Every meeting now for two years and if necessary every meeting for 10 years."
 Edward Powell, of the black members and the only one on the board's executive committee, acknowledged an imbalance on the board and, because of it, a historic discrepancy in services in northern Flatbush, but he characterized the protests as counterproductive.
 "I understand the dissatisfaction with the pace at which things are proceeding," said Mr. Powell, the director of a nonprofit volunteer community organization, Umma Group, that serves Flatbush. "But we're not dealing with machinery, where you can tighten a bolt and everything is all right. We're dealing with people."
 Sometimes a neighborhood changes quicker than the political structure that runs it. Sometimes, Mr. Powell said, a neighborhood changes "much quicker than people's hearts."

HEADLINE: On Frigid Northern Plains, One City Finds Way to New Jobs in Hard Times

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GRAND FORKS, N.D.

 BODY:
As hard times whip across the region like a winter wind, this small city in the heartland has dodged the worst of the storm so far.
Luck and geography no doubt play a role. The city is two hours from Winnipeg, a city of 560,000, and every weekend Grand Forks is happily awash in Canadians and their money. They come to Grand Forks to shop because goods at home can cost almost double what they do south of the border because of the higher transportation and other costs and smaller markets in Canada. 
 But more important to the city's future, officials here say, is the Growth Fund: an economic development program that provides flexible and often speedy financial assistance to new or expanding businesses.
In the last four years, about 650 jobs have been created in this city of 50,000 residents.
 
'Going Against the Grain'
 To pay for the program, the voters here even overcame the national aversion to new taxes and in 1987 overwhelmingly approved a 1 percent sales tax on most retail items sold here. About a third of the tax money goes into the Growth Fund, while the rest is used for property-tax reduction and for roads and other basic systems.
Although countless American cities have economic development programs, Grand Forks "is going against the grain," said Donald Haider, a professor of public management at the J. L. Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University.
States and local governments "all across the country are cutting back their economic development programs," Mr. Haider said. "One of the reasons is simply finanical crisis."
There is another difference. The city is small enough, he said, that the program's successes and failures are easily monitored.
 
A Loan, Then Growth
 One of the first businesses to participate in the program was the Stevens Mattress factory in 1988. Since then, Lowell Stevens and his two brothers have watched their company grow like never before.
In large measure because of the program, production at the mattress factory their father founded in 1928 has doubled, and the work force has grown to 30 employees from 10. It is economic development inch by inch.
The Stevens brothers received a low-interest loan of $60,000 to buy a crucial piece of sewing equipment. In return, they promised to hire 10 new employees, but because business improved so quickly they doubled the number.
"The loan and the repayment plan gave us the tool we needed to be competitive," Mr. Stevens said.
Versions of the Grand Forks program have now been adopted by the state government and by several other cities and towns across North Dakota, which continues to struggle against the exodus of its younger citizens, who take their futures and tax dollars with them.
In the 1980's, more than 50,000 residents of this state of fewer than 700,000 people left their towns and farms and scattered across the lonesome plains in search of opportunities not readily found at home: decent paying jobs.
While new jobs are the main goal of the program, city officials also desperately hope to diversify the city's tax base. So far, 19 businesses have received about $3.9 million in low-interest loans, grants and other financial help from the Growth Fund.
Proposals for Growth Fund help are first reviewed by its the staff. Credit and criminal checks are made and other common banking and lending procedures are followed, said John O'Leary, the executive director of the city's Office of Urban Development who is in charge of the Growth Fund's initial reviews.
Then the proposal is turned over to a seven-member committee that either rejects it or recommends its approval by the full City Council. The committee is made up of four members of the Council, the dean of the business college at the University of North Dakota, a businesswoman and a banker.
Rarely does a company's financial package come only from the fund, Mr. O'Leary said. Often the assistance provided by the fund is the final piece in a venture's puzzle.
 
Plans Tailored for Applicants
 Bruce Gjovig, the director of the Center for Innovation and Business Development at the University of North Dakota, said the plans and financial assistance arrangements are tailored to the needs of the applicants to a greater extent than is usually the case in other cities.
"But this is not charity or business welfare," he said. "It has to be a good job that a company is offering to create."
When reviewing a project, the committee also tries to assess "the overall impact on the community," Mr. O'Leary said. He said the city recently rejected a proposal for a potato-flour processing plant that would have strained the city's sewer system.
But when the committee approves a plan, it tries to move quickly. "We've done a deal in as little as seven days," Mr. O'Leary said, adding that the average time from proposal to approval is about six weeks.
At first, city officials estimated each new job would cost about $10,000 to create. But so far, the cost has been about half that.
 
'Localities Aren't Waiting'
 To John Shannon, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute in Washington, Grand Forks is an example of the lengths local officials must go to as the Federal and state governments pull farther and farther back from providing economic assistance to America's cities and towns.
"The big overall significance is that these localities aren't waiting for the boys in the state capital or Washington to bail them out,," Mr. Shannon said. "Six hundred, 700 jobs for a city like Grand Forks is pretty darn significant."
But no one is ready yet to declare the Growth Fund a miracle on the plains. Most jobs it helps create are blue-collar and the hourly wages hover around $5 and $6. Benefits are poor and turnover can be high. On the other hand, the cost of living here is low. A two-bedroom apartment with a garage can be had for $380 a month.
"To be frank, we haven't been very successful in creating high-quality jobs," said Orlin Backes, the chairman of the state's version of the fund. "The first step was to create jobs. Now our goal is to start to become more selective in helping companies that provide high-paying jobs."
 
50 Jobs Lost in Recession
 The Grand Forks effort has suffered some setbacks. The Growth Fund has created 700 jobs, but at least 50 have disappeared in the gale of recession.
And several companies promised more jobs than they could deliever. When that has happened, Mr. O'Leary said, the repayment of the loan has been restructured.
Most companies involved in the program are small businesses, like Stevens Mattress. But the largest grant, $1 million, went to the Energy and Environmental Research Center at the University of North Dakota here for a new building.
"That money, as a grant, was critical to us," said the center's director, Gerald H. Groenewold.
Dr. Groenewold said the center would hire 60 to 90 people because of the building expansion, many of them with doctoral degrees.
"We are creating high-paying jobs for this area," he said.
But the workers earning $6.50 an hour at American Woods are more typical of those who have benefited from the Growth Fund.
"It's not the highest pay in the world but it's steady," said Donna Mireault, who operates a saw at the company, which manufactures yard and patio furniture.
American Woods has used the fund twice for help in building expansion. Bridget Innes, a company vice president, said that partly because of the fund the 7-year-old company had gone from about 100 employees in 1988 to more than 300 today.
"There are a lot of our employees making $20,000 a year," with a lot of overtime, she said. "And some of them are starting to buy houses."
But Steve Dorow, who has worked on the assembly line at the company for 16 months, said he was worried that the new jobs are often too low-paying to offer workers an opportunity to do more than stay in a holding pattern until something better comes along here in Grand Forks or elsewhere.
"People have to leave, whether they want to or not," he said. "We have to change that. But a bunch of low-paying jobs isn't going to do us a lot of good."

HEADLINE: Iraqi Calls Bush a 'Car Salesman'

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MANAMA, Bahrain, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Iraq ridiculed President Bush and condemned the United Nations Security Council today as President Saddam Hussein's Government intensified its criticism of international sanctions.
Alluding to Mr. Bush's efforts in behalf of American automakers on his recent trip to Japan, a spokesman for the Iraqi Culture and Information Ministry said Mr. Bush should "concentrate his efforts on succeeding in his new job as a salesman of cars" and stay out of Iraqi affairs, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. 
 Iraq also accused United Nations nuclear weapons inspectors of violating diplomatic immunity rules by entering the Baghdad headquarters of the Arab Scientific Research Council without permission on Friday.
 
Hostility Mounts
 The developments seem to reflect mounting hostility as sanctions imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990, aggravate hardships in Iraq.
The statements followed reports that Mr. Bush has secretly authorized intensified covert efforts to topple Mr. Hussein and sent Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, to the efforts with allies in the Mideast.
The agency reported that a cultural ministry spokesman, whom it did not identify, had "advised Bush to benefit from the experience and experiments of car salesmen" instead of "falling under the illusion -- he as well as his agents in the region -- that they can interfere in Iraq's internal affairs."
The news agency also quoted Foreign Minister Ahmed Hussein as denouncing the Security Council's decision Wednesday to maintain sanctions against Iraq because it is not complying with conditions of the cease-fire that ended the Persian Gulf war.
The Foreign Minister said that the sanctions have "turned the Security Council into a de facto extension of the foreign policy tools" of forces seeking to topple Saddam Hussein.
The news agency said the visit to the scientific council had been a "deliberate attempt to harm Iraq" by trying to provoke an incident like the one in which Iraqi troops surrounded a United Nations team for several days last summer in an attempt to get back documents on Iraq's nuclear program.
David Livingston, the Bahrain-based representative of the commission overseeing the disposal of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, said the brief face-off had been settled without trouble.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
A Front-Runner in Trouble, Clinton Portrays Himself as a Victim of Attacks

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 9

 BODY:
Meet Bill Clinton, front-runner. In seven days, he has encountered delirious crowds from Maine to South Carolina, raised hundreds of thousands of dollars and attracted nonstop news coverage.
Meet Bill Clinton, doomed candidate. His formidable lead among New Hampshire voters is contracting, according to the most recent polls. Every new day holds the threat of yet another damaging story that could deliver a killing blow. He is damaged goods. All the Washington commentators say so. 
 It is a slippery slope that the Governor of Arkansas is on these days. As his campaign frantically conducts surveys to gauge the state of play, he has devised a stay-above-the-fray strategy that portrays him as the victim of a feeding frenzy and follows these rules: ignore attacks from Democrats; play up the attacks from Republicans.
This strategy was on display in recent days as Mr. Clinton traveled around New Hampshire delivering a sober message of economic revival before returning to the South, where he spent the weekend seeking physical and political replenishment.
"People ask me sometimes during the course of the last three weeks how I've sustained all these obviously very well-planned and coordinated negative hits," Mr. Clinton said in Jonesboro, Ark., to supporters who had paid $100 each to hear him speak on Saturday. "And I said, 'Oh, this is just an ordinary election week in Arkansas.' "
 
Focusing on Republicans
 But in recent days Senators Tom Harkin and Bob Kerrey have seized on reports about how Mr. Clinton escaped the Vietnam War draft to raise new questions about his candidacy. On Monday, Mr. Clinton planned to huddle with his campaign consultants on a plane trip back to New Hampshire from which reporters were barred.
His advisers have been saying there is little to be gained by responding to either of the Democratic Senators because Mr. Clinton remains far ahead of them in the polls. And he has boxed himself out of attacking former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who has most benefited from his latest weaknesses, because until recently Mr. Clinton had been praising him profusely on the campaign trail.
So there is little left to attack but the Republicans, most of them unnamed, who he said are undermining his candidacy. This approach, his advisers hope, has the added advantage of allowing Mr. Clinton to look Presidential by focusing his sights on the general election rather than the primaries.
"New Hampshire voters are very sophisticated," said Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's poll taker. "They already have a front-runner rationalization for any garbage that materializes."
 
Behind on Repairs
 This may be so, but the Clinton campaign has so far done little to patch up the paper cuts that have reinforced the impression of a bleeding campaign. Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee, for instance, endorsed Mr. Clinton in December, and a word of support from him could have aided the campaign's effort on the draft question. But the Governor never contacted him, and Mr. Nunn was left instead to express his doubts about whether Mr. Clinton was telling the truth.
That important supporters like Mr. Nunn are left untended exposes a weakness in a campaign that has had little opportunity to sink its organizational roots after first being swept into front-runner status by early polls and then knocked about by questions of credibility. It has been left instead to Clinton organizers at the state level around the country to do the bulk of the damage control.
But so far, the campaign's problems have had little measurable effect on fund raising. Mr. Clinton's New York organizers hope an event Monday night in Manhattan will raise $500,000.
 
Frustration on Draft Question
 Lately, Mr. Clinton has begun expressing puzzlement and frustration that it has fallen to him to prove that his explanations about issues like the draft deferment he received in the Vietnam War era are true.
A former executive secretary of the Hot Springs, Ark., draft board and the Reserve Officers Training Corps recruiter who dealt with Mr. Clinton have both said recently in published reports that Mr. Clinton attempted to pull strings to avoid being drafted.
Mr. Clinton has responded by saying that although he received the R.O.T.C. deferment for two months in 1969, he had a change of heart and asked to be reclassified as draft-eligible shortly before a draft lottery was passed by Congress. He never served because the number he drew was never called.
If he survives the furor about his draft status, Mr. Clinton and his advisers say, they expect future attacks. They also say they are convinced, for the moment at least, that the public will recoil from anything that begins to resemble what Mr. Clinton describes as "piling on."
"The people are very angry about anybody's attempt to make this election about anything but them," Mr. Clinton said after his appearance in Jonesboro this weekend. "They don't want this election to be another standard negative election where they're asked to vote against somebody who's been drug through the mud."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Iowa;
A Lot to Be Said but No One to Listen

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: POLK CITY, Iowa, Feb. 9

 BODY:
John L. Moeckly, a sixth-generation cattle breeder in the gentle hills here north of Des Moines, has a message for President Bush: "I don't know why he took his junk car people with him to Japan and didn't take beef and pork producers. The Japanese are tired of eating fish heads and rice."
Edith Southwick of Milo, a Burger King employee, wants the Democratic Presidential candidates to know that all is not tranquil in her southeast Iowa town: "We have gangs, drugs, racial problems. We have rapes, shootings, murders -- all in a small town." 
 And Elmer Hoffman, a 66-year-old retired truck driver from Sioux City on the state's western border, offers this advice to all the candidates: "Let's take care of the elderly. A lot of people ain't got no insurance. And the middle class have to be taken care of."
Four years ago, chances are that all three of these Iowans could have spoken their minds directly to the Presidential contenders, who practically moved into this state, often posing for pictures with barnyard animals, to woo supporters in the months leading up to the Iowa caucuses.
 
No Candidates, No Talk
 This year, with the absence of serious contests in either the Democratic or Republican caucuses, there are no longer earnest-faced candidates acting as if the world revolves around the opinions of residents of Altoona, Ottumwa or Council Bluffs.
So the only opportunity for Iowans to be heard even remotely above the din in New Hampshire will be Monday evening, when they express their preferences at 2,166 precinct meetings that will be the first official test of the 1992 campaign. But with Senator Tom Harkin as the favorite son, other Democrats are forfeiting Iowa, and in the Republican caucuses, there is no challenge to President Bush.
With Presidential candidates all but ignoring Iowans this year, the issues addressed in the national political dialogue have decidedly shifted from past primary seasons. For what Iowans have to say about the condition of the country is not always the same as what the citizens say in New Hampshire, where the first primary will be held on Feb. 18.
In interviews around the state, Iowans, who had grown accustomed to receiving a disproportionate share of political attention, say their issues are getting short shrift this time. Their biggest complaint was the lack of discourse on agriculture. While they commended the candidates for emphasizing the need for better health care, voters in this state, which has a large elderly population, said they wanted to hear more. Though economic conditions are not as tough here as in New Hampshire, Iowans also cited the economy as one of their biggest concerns.
 
Quiet, Not Frenzy
 "For the last 12 years, Midwest and agriculture issues were front and center on the national agenda," said Lowell Junkins, the Democratic candidate for Governor here in 1986. "This year, there isn't any debate about agriculture. There's no serious debate about Midwest problems. It's more about the problems of the industrial Northeast."
Unlike the weeks before the caucuses four years ago, this year interest groups are quiet, and there are no signs of the American Association of Retired Persons or the Iowa Farm Unity Coalition, which in the past have set up shop to mobilize voters behind their issues.
"It's like political tumbleweed blowing through the streets of Des Moines," said Phillip J. Roeder, who was spokesman for a Iowa Democratic Party during the 1988 campaign.
"The candidates focus in on what's going to provide them the most good locally in those early tests," Mr. Roeder said. "And there are just not a lot of corn and cattle operations in New Hampshire."
Even so, Mr. Moeckly, 63, and his wife, Marilyn, 62, owners of one of the largest farms in the area, sat around their kitchen table Saturday evening, voicing disappointment that the candidates are not talking about farming.
 
'Let's Get Some Exports'
 In 1988, Mrs. Moeckly said she supported Senator Bob Dole, a Kansas Republican, while Mr. Moeckly did not vote. This time, she said they both supported Mr. Bush because "he knows how politics works, and I don't believe that we'd better change now." But Mrs. Moeckly said she would like Mr. Bush "to work harder on opening foreign markets -- let's get some exports."
But smaller farmers, like Linda Terry of the southwestern Iowa town of Greenfield who works in Mr. Harkin's office in Des Moines, blame Republicans for troubles they have been having in recent years. Ms. Terry also complained that she has heard only two Democrats, Mr. Harkin and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, talk about agriculture.
"Four years ago, everybody had a farm policy or there wasn't any point in coming to Iowa," said Ms. Terry, 42. "We've lost several hundred farmers in the last four years. The farmers that are left, a whole tier of them, have come under financial stress."
Though Ms. Southwick, the Burger King worker, said she was particularly concerned about crime in her rural community, she also called on the candidates to energize the economy. She said she would probably vote for Mr. Harkin because he was from Iowa.
Kathryn Schoen, a 63-year-old court clerk from Des Moines, said she had planned to vote for Mr. Harkin until she thought about his vote to raise Senators' pay.
"I like the idea of making jobs and helping the middle class," she said. "But I tell you what bothered me about Harkin is he voted for that $23,000 raise. That wasn't quite kosher. I liked him till then."
 
Bush Supporter Unaffected
 One voter who seems unaffected by the absence of a contested race here is Tom Bernau, a 31-year-old lawyer from Des Moines. He said he backed Mr. Bush at the caucus here four years ago and intended to do so again.
Mr. Bernau said his only qualm about the President was his handling of the economy. "I think he could have been more attuned to economic issues," he said.
Mark Pogge, a college administrator from Des Moines, also ranks the economy as the top issue. But he said he was torn between two Democrats, Mr. Harkin and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
Mr. Pogge, 35, said he was distressed that he could not confer with the candidates personally to seek their views, as he did in 1988.
Disputing the notion that issues of significance to Iowans are not being addressed this year is Senator Paul Simon, an Illinois Democrat who did his share of posing with hogs here when he ran for President in 1988.
"One thing that really surprised me when I was a Presidential candidate, and I think television plays a major role here," he said, "is that whether you're in New Hampshire or Iowa or New Orleans or Portland, Ore., with rare exception the questions are pretty much the same. We really have become one nation much more than people realize."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Tsongas Surges as Voters Focus on Economics

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 9

 BODY:
The New Hampshire Democratic primary enters its final week with all the ingredients of a political cliffhanger: Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas is pulling even with Gov. Bill Clinton in the public opinion polls and experts say the race is still very much up for grabs.
Even a veteran of the New Hampshire primary wars like Joseph Grandmaison, a former state Democratic chairman and a supporter of Mr. Clinton, confesses, "I've had a terrible time figuring out the dynamics of this race." 
 One of the few certainties here: The voters of New Hampshire are acutely focused on the economy and hungry for detailed plans and programs that are intended to heal it. At one candidate forum after another, New Hampshire residents rose to ask what candidates will do about home foreclosures, lost jobs, shaky health care and competition from abroad.
 
The Challenge for Clinton
 Political experts say this hunger for candidates with "comprehensive plans" and the relentless emphasis on jobs has much to do with Mr. Clinton's success so far, and is one reason Mr. Tsongas has emerged as the principal Clinton alternative.
The latest Boston Globe and WBZ-TV poll suggests that Mr. Tsongas may be moving into a virtual tie with Mr. Clinton, whose campaign has been buffeted for two weeks by tabloid newspaper accusations of extramarital affairs and by questions about his draft status during the Vietnam War.
The challenge for Mr. Clinton is how to force the spotlight back to his message and away from the character questions that have dominated his news coverage in recent weeks.
With a promise to restore the "forgotten middle class," Mr. Clinton advances "strategies" for health care, education and economic development, sweetened with promises of a tax cut for the middle class.
Mr. Tsongas, meanwhile, says he plans to stick to his stern appeal for an economic program to rebuild the nation's manufacturing base. Styling himself as a pro-business liberal, he parts with many in his party by rejecting a middle-class tax cut as poor policy, and championing a cut in the tax on capital gains, targeted to encourage long-term investment.
 
Tsongas Takes Off
 Mr. Tsongas, considered the most improbable of long shots when he announced his campaign a year ago, was happily, almost giddily, proclaiming that his campaign had finally gained critical mass this weekend. "I lived without it for 10 months," he said in an interview, "So I know it when I see it."
The Boston Globe poll made public tonight showed Mr. Clinton at 26 percent, Mr. Tsongas at 26 percent, Mr. Kerrey at 11 percent, Mr. Harkin at 7 percent and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California at 5 percent, with the proportion of undecided voters growing to 18 percent. The poll, based on interviews conducted Saturday and today, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points and included interviews with 560 people considered likely to vote in the Democratic primary.
The Los Angeles Times today published the results of its latest New Hampshire poll, conducted Monday through Friday, showing Mr. Clinton with a slim lead, within the margin of sampling error.
Many political professionals here say that much of the electorate is undecided or only loosely committed to a candidate, and predict a roller coaster of a final week, capped by a final, nationally televised debate on CNN Sunday night.
The Globe reported that the movement toward Mr. Tsongas was particularly strong Saturday and suggested it was fed by doubts about Mr. Clinton's character after reports last week that he had sought to avoid the draft during the Vietnam War. Mr. Clinton denied those reports, as he denied earlier accusations in the tabloid Star that he had a 12-year affair.
The men long expected to be the principal beneficiaries if Mr. Clinton falters -- Mr. Harkin and Mr. Kerrey -- are still trying to ignite their campaigns. Mr. Harkin was, by necessity, in Iowa this weekend, where that state's caucuses will officially begin the nominating season on Monday.
The self-declared "Real Democrat" in the race was on television here, however, with a tough commercial blasting policies that force "American workers to compete against slave labor."
Mr. Kerrey, meanwhile, continues to emphasize his plan for national health insurance, but is sharpening his focus on the economy; television commercials now present him as a proven job-creator as Governor of Nebraska and as an entrepreneur. "I believe Americans understand we're in the economic fight of our lives," he said on ABC's "This Week" with David Brinkley. "And we're ready to do battle."
The draft issue has also highlighted, once again, Mr. Kerrey's record as a Medal of Honor winner who lost part of his leg in Vietnam. The contrast was heightened when his campaign this weekend brought in Max Cleland, former head of the Veterans Administration and now Secretary of State for Georgia. Mr. Cleland lost both legs and an arm in Vietnam, and when he and Mr. Kerrey embraced they produced one of the most powerful visuals of the campaign.
 
Next Stop, the South
 While this drama plays out, Democrats around the country are straining to read the murky mind of New Hampshire. The Iowa caucuses on Monday have been treated almost as an afterthought by the party and the various campaigns, which have ceded the state to Mr. Harkin, the state's junior Senator. New Hampshire is the big game, and the stakes are huge.
If Mr. Clinton wins on Feb. 18, then rolls into the primaries March 3 and 10 in the friendly South, many Democrats believe that he will wrap up the nomination fast. The concern among some in the party is that New Hampshire will produce a false positive for Mr. Clinton, that his showing here is as much a reflection of the weakness of the opposition as his own political strength.
Has he truly prevailed over the accusations of infidelity, or would he carry that baggage into a fall campaign where the Republicans would know how to use it? Mr. Clinton gained considerable support because many Democrats considered him the strongest contender for the fall election; Mr. Kerrey's allies are now trying to turn the "electability" argument against the Arkansas Governor.
Conversely, a victory here by Mr. Tsongas raises its own questions; when the race moves South, the former Massachusetts Senator will not have the leisure of ten months of painstaking, voter-by-voter campaigning that he had here in New Hampshire, nor will he have the advantage of coming from a neighboring state. Super Tuesday is a tarmac, satellite-dish and 30-second-commercial campaign that demands money and media savvy -- not Mr. Tsongas's strong points so far.
These questions keep stirring the anxious talk in Washington and elsewhere in the country about another candidate entering the race.
Mr. Tsongas, keenly aware that many in his party still cannot accept him as the "Clinton alternative," says he will raise "the 50 percent courage gap" with any late entering candidate: Where were they when Mr. Bush, whose approval rating is now in the 40's, was close to 90 percent in the polls? Still, the buzz continues, and the write-in effort mounted last week for Governor Mario M. Cuomo (although not endorsed by the Governor) only feeds it.
Mr. Cuomo himself lurks on the border, quite literally. He will speak at Harvard Wednesday night on the state of the economy, and will doubtless draw considerable press attention and will doubtlesss protest that the press misreads his intentions.

International
OPEC's president said he would press for a significant cut in oil production to prop up prices, which have dropped 20 percent since November. The official, who is also Algeria's oil minister, said he would ask OPEC's 12 members, which are scheduled to meet on Wednesday, to reduce production by about 6 percent. The average price of OPEC crude oil is now about $16 a barrel, compared with the group's goal of $21. Output has increased to an 11-year high of 24.2 million barrels a day. [Page D1.]

HEADLINE: Aristide Condemns U.S. Policy

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Angered by reports that Haitians are being mistreated as they return home, Haiti's exiled President asserts that the United States is using a double standard to deny political asylum to refugees from his homeland.
In an interview on Saturday night, the ousted leader, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, condemned a policy that he said shelters refugees from Communist Cuba but returns Haitians to a country governed by a repressive military. 
 "It's a policy of discrimination," he said in Caracas, where he has been living since he was ousted in a military coup last Sept. 30.
"Even President Bush has recognized that Haiti is a case of a totalitarian regime," Father Aristide said.
Father Aristide said that some of the Haitians sent back last week from the American naval base in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, have been detained and beaten.
Father Aristide, whose chances of returning to power depend heavily on foreign pressure, also criticized a Bush Administration move to soften the embargo against Haiti to press the military to allow his return to power.
United States officials argue that after four months, the embargo has only increased malnutrition and unemployment.
More than 2,000 Haitians were sent home last week from the naval base at Guantanamo Bay, where they had been housed and fed since they fled their country on rickety boats in the aftermath of the coup.
More than 11,000 Haitians who have fled since last October remain at the naval base awaiting immigration interviews and rulings on their asylum claims.
Immigration officials say that 1,402 have been released to the United States to be considered for permanent political asylum, based on the legal standard of a well-founded fear of persecution.

NEW YORK CITY
 
AN ABUSED LIFE, A CRIPPLED SYSTEM
The story of Yaakov Riegler, who died in 1990 after repeated beatings by his mother, is about an affectionate retarded boy and a mother who was overwhelmed by the unending tasks of homemaking. It is about a child welfare system that was unable, despite repeated warnings, to help the child. And it is about a pediatrician who, though he knew of the mother's abusive history and was called on several times to treat Yaakov's wounds, said he recognized in the Riegler household only a harried mother, not a battered child. A1.
 
FEAR BECOMES REALITY IN CONEY ISLAND 
 Ruth Mitchell anguished over the safety of her young boys in their crumbling, crime-infested Coney Island neighborhood, but on Saturday afternoon, it was Ms. Mitchell whose life was claimed suddenly, ended by a bullet that seemed to come out of nowhere. Last night, the police announced the arrests of two teen-agers in the killing. A1.

New York City Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez is fashioning a plan to lengthen the school day by an hour and the school year by 25 days in an effort both to pump up student skills and to make a bid for a hefty share of the $1.1 billion that New York City hopes to gain through bond refinancing. HEADLINE: Venezuela, Wary After Coup Attempt, Censors Press

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Wary that plotters of an unsuccessful coup may be depicted as heroes, the Government has stationed censors in newsrooms and confiscated stacks of magazines in some of the strictest press controls imposed since the advent of civilian rule in 1958.
President Carlos Andres Perez contends that the restrictions, adopted after the failed military putsch last Tuesday, are a temporary step to calm the public. 
 "We have said, don't exalt the man who attempted the military coup," Mr. Perez told journalists on Saturday night. "Let's not make a starring figure out of a felon who betrayed the armed forces and caused death and damage."
Using telephone calls, scissors and, when necesssary, police raids, Interior Ministry censors have worked the hardest to eliminate photographs and articles centering on Hugo Chavez Frias, the army lieutenant colonel who led the uprising. Loyalist Government forces put down the rebellion, but only after clashes in which about 80 people were killed. More than 1,000 soldiers have been arrested.
 
Approved by Lawmakers
 Mr. Perez, who was almost killed in the coup attempt, has emphasized in interviews that Venezuelan lawmakers approved the suspension of press freedom and the limits on other civil liberties last week.
Journalists say the censorship violates one of Latin America's oldest traditions of press freedom and exposes the deep insecurity of the Government, which lacks popular support.
"The media are not responsible for the coup attempt," said Francisco Solorzano, secretary of Venezuela's National Journalists Association. "Furthermore, the censorship measures are a kind of attack against one of the bastions of democracy."
Television, newspapers and magazines are under orders not to broadcast or to print Colonel Chavez's picture. To enforce the order, the police seized copies of two news magazines, Zeta and Elite, that displayed cover photos of the 37-year-old rebel commander wearing his red paratrooper's beret.
Late last week, El Diario de Caracas newspaper told its readers in an advertisement that its Saturday issue would carry a full-color supplement with exclusive photos of the military uprising. When readers went to newsstands on Saturday morning, they found that police officers had confiscated most copies of the supplement.
The Inter-American Press Association's committee on press freedom plans to issue a statement on Monday condemning Venezuela's censorship measures.
"The way to fight for freedom and democracy is not by applying the same measures that dictators apply to the press," Eduardo Ulibarri, president of the committee, said today in a telephone interview from Costa Rica, where he is editor in chief of La Nacion newspaper.
Censors have also sought to prevent publication of articles or advertisements that suggest that the coup attempt enjoyed popular support or was widely backed within the military.
In one of several confrontations with major dailies here, an Interior Ministry censor allowed publication of El Nacional today only after editors removed an article about a news conference by a retired military general.
 
Retired Officers Cite Corruption
 In full-page advertisements that ran on Friday, an association of retired military officers cited corruption and poor administration by the last four civilian governments as causes of coup attempts.
Mr. Perez served a five-year term as President in the 1970's and was elected again to the post in 1988. Support for his Government has plummeted in the last three years because of corruption scandals and economic austerity measures.
"The Government is absolutely scared," said Roberto Fabricio, a vice president of the Inter-American Press Association's freedom committee, who witnessed the argument on Saturday night between El Nacional's editors and the censor.
"This is the ultimate symbol of weakness: when a democratically elected President cannot let a newspaper publish a retired general's press conference."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Venezuelan Government has stationed censors in newsrooms in an attempt to prevent plotters of the unsuccessful coup last week from being depicted as heroes. At El Nacional, a Caracas newspaper, secret police agents interrogated journalists on Saturday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Bush Budget: Officials See Local Damage

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
At a time when New York City is seeking an additional $200 million in Federal money to close its own fiscal gap, city officials looking in detail at President Bush's proposed budget have concluded that it would reduce Federal aid to various city agencies by as much as $428 million.
That estimate came yesterday from City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, who released a report tallying the potential economic impact of the President's proposal on a variety of city programs, including those that provide health care, support public housing and assist the homeless. 
 Despite the cutbacks, however, Ms. Holtzman said she calculated, "using generous estimates," that the President's budget would increase Federal aid to a handful of other city programs by as much as $116 million and would contribute an additional $70 million to its capital budget for sewage treatment alone. But she cautioned that such money, earmarked for specific programs, would not help the city narrow its budget gap.
"People in New York are really going to be hurt very badly," said Ms. Holtzman, who last week announced her candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate seat currently held by Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Long Island Republican. "This is more than a body blow, this could cause very serious harm."
 
Big Boos, Small Cheers
 Though City Hall officials said that they had not done the mathematical analysis needed to support or refute Ms. Holtzman's report, they noted that the reductions put forth by the President, however alarming, were far from set in stone.
"Many of these cuts have been proposed by President Bush and President Reagan before him," said Judy L. Chesser, Mayor David N. Dinkins's chief Washington lobbyist. "Most of them have been rejected by Congress in the past and are not likely to pass this time around."
Philip R. Michael, the Mayor's budget director, said that the city was pressing Congress to resist the cuts, and that he remained optimistic that the city would ultimately wrest from the Federal Government more money to fend off the effects of the recession and balance its next fiscal year budget of $29.4 billion.
And while the tone of Ms. Holtzman's report was ominous, both she and Ms. Chesser, who critiqued the proposed Federal budget in a memorandum to the Mayor last month, found some faint reasons for praise.
 
Cuts in Housing
 Both pointed to potential increases in Head Start, a pre-school program for low-income families, as well in programs meant to prevent infant mortality and lead poisoning and to assist New Yorkers afflicted with AIDS and tuberculosis. Both also cited the availibility of special coastal cities grants that could be used to build sewage-treatment plants.
But she said those proposed increases pale when compared to the laundry list of reductions that the President has put forward.
Many of the cuts, Ms. Holtzman and Ms. Chesser contended, would hurt those New Yorkers most in need, including those living in or seeking to live in low-income housing.
Public housing grants and other housing programs would be cut by $128 million and the New York City Housing Authority would lose $28 million in Federal funds, Ms. Holtzman said. Financing for the development of any additional public housing units would also be eliminated, Ms. Chesser said.
The city's Home Heating program, which provides subsidies to working class families, would be reduced by $22 million under the proposed budget, and the Emergency Assistance program, which helps homeless families, would lose $40 million, Ms. Holtzman said.
The increase in additional heath-care costs borne by the city under the President's budget would also be large, both Ms. Holtzman and Ms. Chesser predicted. The budget's ceiling on the amount that the Federal Government reimburses the city for Medicaid would cost the city about $63 million, Ms. Holtzman said. And though Ms. Chesser did not provide specific estimates, she said she foresaw the city being stung by proposed cuts in money earmarked for minority health care programs, primary-care training and financial aid for nurses working in inner-city hospitals.
Ms. Holtzman, echoing the comments of some transit officials, said she feared that the President's budget might jeopardize the new $1.25 subway and bus fare by eliminating $90 million in operating subsidies to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
 
Hopes of Reversal
 And she said immigrants would suffer as well. Federal financing of State Legalization Impact Assistance Grants, which provide reimbursement for services extended to immigrants, would be cut by about $20 million on the city level, Ms. Holtzman said. Federal cash subsidies and medical assistance providing for the settlement of refugees in the city would be cut by $21 million, Ms. Holtzman said.
But for all the grim predictions, both Ms. Holtzman and Ms. Chesser said they believed many of the cuts could be reversed if the city's voters growled loud enough for their elected officials to hear.
"There doesn't appear to be any sentiment in Congress for drastically cutting state and local budgets," Ms. Chesser said. "I think we're more likely to get an increase."
