HEADLINE: Private L.I. Water Rates Spur Drive for Takeover

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLORAL PARK, L.I.

 BODY:
When 100 homeowners settled into their cold metal folding chairs at the American Legion hall here the other night, a subject that falls near the bottom of the financial agenda for most Americans -- water service and what it costs -- provoked an outburst of passion.
All were residents of this Nassau County village made up mostly of retirees and middle-income families struggling through the worst recession in decades. To make matters worse, they are customers of a private water utility that charges double, or even triple, what nearby municipal utilities charge -- as much as $899 a year for an average family. 
 These homeowners, the Waterbill Watchdogs, have joined a legion of municipal, county and state officials who favor public takeover of private water utilities in Nassau County.
 
'Obscene' Bills
 "The more you look into this, the more obscene it becomes," said Charlie Desmond, the business manager for a coffee service and one of the founders of the Floral Park group, whose members buy their water from the Jamaica Water Supply Company, a private investor-owned utility.
"The disparity in what consumers pay is huge, and it's just not fair," said Richard M. Kessel, director of the State Consumer Protection Board, who is among those advocating public takeover of the private water companies in Nassau.
Even the state's Public Service Commission, which regulates the rates charged by the state's more than 400 private utilities, acknowledges problems.
 
'Concerned About the Rates'
 "We are concerned about the rates charged by Jamaica Water," said Peter A. Bradford, the commission's chairman. Although his agency approved a series of rate increases in recent years that have widened the disparity in prices with municipal water companies, he said his staff recommended reductions in Jamaica Water's prices last year, and might order a rollback when an investigation of the company's prices and service is completed later this year.
The dispute is far from new, having roots in the evolution of water-supply systems that extend back more than a century, when private companies dug the wells and built viaducts or pipelines in much of the nation. Gradually, most private utilities were bought by cities, counties or states as the communities they served grew larger.
In Nassau County, where four large private companies maintain a checkerboard of service areas, the call for lower bills, revamped regulations and outright takeover has intensified during the recession.
The disparity in prices was reflected in a 1990 study by Mr. Kessel's office and the Town of North Hempstead, which showed that average bills during June, July and August from the three largest private water utilities in Nassau were two to four times higher than those by the county's municipal companies.
In a separate study of bills for all of 1991, Mr. Desmond's group said the private companies had charged their customers who used 200,000 gallons -- a typical amount for families with children -- three times as much as their municipal counterparts. Jamaica Water, which charged $899, was the most expensive.
The company has been pumping water from Long Island's acquifer since 1877, and with 130,000 customers is New York State's second largest water company, behind New York City's municipal water supply system. The company insists that it, like its customers, has been victimized by the region's fiscal problems and archaic regulations.
"The driving force behind our prices is taxes," said Kevin Conroy, a company vice president. He maintained that the best way to cut water bills was to cut the company's taxes.
"What would benefit our customers most is tax abatements," he said.
Jamaica Water, like most other private utilities, pays property taxes on its land and buildings and other taxes on its income that are not paid by municipal utilities. Its costs are passed on to its customers. But studies by New York State and citizen watchdog groups like the one here show that Jamaica Water's tax bills do not fully account for its higher rates.
"The very fact Jamaica Water is investor-owned means that it is much more profit oriented and needs to charge more than a municipal utility," Mr. Kessel said.
 
A Diversified Corporation
 Based in Lake Success, Jamaica Water is a subsidiary of JWP Inc., a diversified coporation that has grown rapidly since the mid-1980's through the acquisition of the BusinessLand chain of retail computer stores and several engineering and high technology businesses.
For more than a decade, Jamaica Water has been battling to retain its operations in Queens, where the administrations of former Mayor Edward I. Koch, and now of David N. Dinkins, have tried to take it over, first through a negotiated purchase and later through condemnation. The condemnation division of State Surpreme Court in Queens is determining a fair market value if the city is to acquire the Queens operations through condemnation. The city's lawyers have set the value at $62 million; the company has told the court the value should be $900 million.
In the meantime, the company is receiving subsidies from the city, through tax abatements and low-priced water that allow it to keep the its bills to customers in Queens at the same level as those of other city residents, and far below the rates it charges in Nassau County.
With consumers here and in much of Nassau paying the high rates, the Nassau County Board of Supervisors last year appointed a Water Board to study a public takeover of Jamaica Water and other other private water utilities.
County officials said their decision would hinge partially on the ruling by the court in Queens on the value of Jamiaca Water's operations there, because similar criteria might be applied in condemnation hearings before a Nassau County court judge.
 
Sale of Bonds
 If either Queens or Nassau proceeds with condemnation, officials said they would raise money for the transaction through the sale of tax-exempt bonds and set up a new tax-exempt water system.
But the economic consequences could be harsh, because removing a major water utility from the tax roles would create new fiscal strains.
"I have been hearing about condemnation for years, but the fact is they just can't afford it," said Edward J. Tirello, a utilities industry analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
His skepticism was not shared by the members of Waterbill Watchdogs, who have met repeatedly since the group was formed in September to organize their campaign for lower priced water.
"This simply cannot continue," said Ralph Ratto, the owner of a Floral Park interior design store and president of the group. The group favors the creation of a small municipal utility to serve its own village if Jamaica Water is not taken over by the county.
"Water bills here are a very major expense," he added. "Our senior citizens are paying more for water than for heat."
At the Consumer Protection Board, Mr. Kessel said condemnation was not likely soon.
"Because of what would be lost in the tax base, I don't think we can expect it to happen soon," he said. But he added that public ownership of the water utilities was "the ultimate solution, even if we have to plan for it years ahead."

HEADLINE: Executives Skeptical on Bush Health Plan

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Some business executives say President Bush's health-care proposals could make their problems worse because they do not go far enough to slow the rapid increase in the nation's medical spending.
"It is a plus that the President has come forward and taken a position that we need overall reform," said Walter Maher, director of Federal relations on human resources issues for the Chrysler Corporation. "But we have to bring our health costs more in line with those of our major competitors, Japan and Germany. That requires some very tough cost-containment strategy, which I did not see in the proposal." 
 The executives warned that further cutbacks in Federal programs for the elderly and poor, which were included in the President's budget message, would probably lead to even higher charges to businesses by hospitals and doctors seeking to make up for lost income.
Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers in Washington, praised the President's proposals to assure health coverage for workers changing jobs and to encourage health maintenance organizations and networks of doctors and hospitals that provide lower fees and accept supervision of quality of care.
"However, we are concerned with some of the options offered to finance this $100 billion program," Mr. Jasinowski said. "One approach would cap Medicaid and Medicare payments. That would likely result in additional cost-shifting to employers."
Most business spokesmen praised the President for entering the debate on health care, after more than a year of Administration hesitation to address the issue. They predicted that some of his proposals had a good chance of being enacted because they are similar to those of the Democratic chairmen of the Congressional tax-writing committees, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois.
But the President's proposal to provide tax credits and tax deductions to help more people buy health insurance also came in for criticism. The United States already spends $2 billion a day, about 13 percent of the gross national product, on health care, and some people said the credits and deductions might stimulate spending.
"It makes no sense to simply throw money at the problem," Mr. Maher said. "You have to address the cost side of the question as well."
Don Summers, president of Austin Welder and Generator Services in Austin, Tex., with nine employees, said his company was "priced out of the health-care market in May 1990" after monthly insurance premiums tripled in three years. He praised Mr. Bush's plan but added, "we need to go back to community rating," that is, uniform insurance rates for everyone in a community.
That approach, he said, spreads "the risk, the way insurance is supposed to work."
 
Medical Practices Attacked
 Mr. Summers said the Government should also "oversee the outrageous greed of medical practitioners."
"It should outlaw practices that allow hospitals to bill both individuals and insurance companies" for the same treatment, he said, referring to a process called unbundling.
Hospital executives applauded the President's proposals to expand coverage for people without insurance, but they also had questions about the financing.
"The plan appears to provide coverage for most of the uninsured," said Don Oder, senior vice president and chief operating officer of Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago. "The big question in our minds is the financing. We don't know enough about that yet.
 
Planned Cuts Called Unwise
 He noted that the Administration's budget proposals include restrictions on spending for the Medicaid program for the poor and Medicare for the elderly and disabled, "which are already underfunded." Mr. Oder said that more than 60 percent of hospitals in a 1990 Government survey lost money on Medicare patients.
Jerome H. Grossman, chairman of the New England Medical Center, a teaching hospital in Boston, agreed that it would be "unwise strategy" to pay the costs by taking money from other Government health programs.
Making a similar point, Dr. Morris B. Mellion, an Omaha doctor who is president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, a professional group that has 73,000 members, said the Administration was "talking about taking from the poor and elderly and giving to other poor people."
Spokesmen for small businesses said they were already being overcharged by hospitals and doctors to make up for Government cutbacks in Medicare and Medicaid programs.
"Small business already receives a significant brunt of the cost shift," said Gary B. Kushner, president of Kushner & Company, a consulting firm based in Kalamazoo, Mich. "We're at the bottom of the waterfall."
Martha Thornton, a senior vice president in Chicago with the Ameritech Corporation, which has 77,000 employees in Bell telephone companies in five Midwestern states, said, "The most positive thing about the President's proposal is that it offers another alternative in the debate over what should be done."
She also opposed putting new restrictions on Medicare and Medicaid. But she said the President's plan would indeed help control the growth of health-care costs by making it easier for small groups to get insurance, limiting payments in medical malpractice lawsuits, and encouraging health maintenance organizations and hospital and physician networks.
"There's enough money in the system today to finance needed health care, if we control the system," she said.
 
Insurers 'Are Pleased'
 Health insurers generally welcomed Mr. Bush's plan, which could benefit their business on several fronts -- subsidizing new customers and encouraging them to use the insurers' medical networks and health maintenance organizations.
"We are pleased to see the President offering a set of ideas that builds on the private, employer-based health-care system," said Bernard S. Tresnowski, president of the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association.
Jon Glaudemans, a spokesman for the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, said the plan "guarantees choice to all Americans and avoids a Government takeover of the health-care system." He added: "We're glad to see the President entering the debate. His leadership is essential to meaningful reform, which we support."

HEADLINE: Companies Press U.S. on Vietnam

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
At a time when American competitiveness, or lack of it, in Asia is much debated, corporations and business organizations in the United States are pressing for an end to the trade and investment boycott of Vietnam, a country where American companies say they believe they could do very well.
The quiet lobbying -- led by the petroleum, construction, telecommunications and consulting industries -- is prompted by the perception that the Japanese have been positioning themselves in Vietnam for decades and will grab many of the contracts when Vietnam becomes integrated in world trade. 
 Japan and South Korea, apparently uncomfortable with an American-led embargo, have begun moving in recent weeks toward greater participation in the Vietnamese economy.
American products, introduced in South Vietnam in the 1960's and 1970's, are highly prized by Hanoi -- and still functioning. An official of Caterpillar Far East Commercial Ltd., the Asian subsidiary of Caterpillar Inc., based in Peoria, Ill., told a Congressional committee recently that on a visit to Vietnam last spring he saw working Caterpillar vehicles that had been delivered 20 years ago.
"The interest in Vietnam is substantial," said Virginia Foote, director of the three-year-old United States Vietnam Trade Council, a private group that helps American companies and individuals position themselves for the competition expected in the Vietnmese economy when the embargo is finally lifted. The council's chairman is William H. Sullivan, a former United States Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Vietnam, whom Hanoi approached for help in 1988.
Ms. Foote said at least 10 large corporations and about 300 smaller companies, plus dozens of individual entrepreneurs, had joined the council, which gives briefings every couple of months in Washington to keep Americans abreast of trade laws as well as developments in Vietnam. The council is asking the Treasury Department for a license to bring Vietnamese to the United States under fellowships, or to allow Americans to teach courses in Vietnamese schools or companies.
Nearly 17 years after the end of the Vietnam War, the United States not only maintains a nearly total embargo against country-to-country dealings with Vietnam but also opposes any assistance to Hanoi by international lending and development organizations, in particular the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank and the International Monetary Fund, where Vietnam is in arrears from past borrowing.
Washington does not, however, object to the World Bank's conducting surveys or giving advice in Vietnam in preparation for later development. On Dec. 17, the State Department relaxed travel restrictions, allowing group tours to Vietnam to be sold in the United States. Moreover, about $1 million in humanitarian assistance goes to Vietnam annually through private organizations, and an unknown amount of financial help is provided Vietnamese families by relatives in the West.
But all applications for commercial trading licenses are routinely rejected, Government officials say. Americans, unlike their competitors in Japan and Europe, are not permitted to open offices in Vietnam. In Asia, American Chambers of Commerce in Hong Kong, Bangkok and other cities have begun campaigns to lobby Congress and the Administration for a change in this restrictive policy.
 
Hanoi Seeking Oil Bids
 Hanoi, short of hard currency and suffering from the loss of Soviet aid, is urgently seeking bids to explore and develop its oilfields in the South China Sea and to begin constructing or reconstructing roads, power plants, airports, ports and industrial buildings. Vietnam needs aircraft and wants to sell textiles and agriculture products, including tropical fruit and processed seafood.
Jerry Smith, a spokesman for Phillips Petroleum in Bartlesville, Okla., acknowledged that Phillips was among the oil companies interested in exploring Vietnamese offshore fields "as soon as the embargo comes off."
David Dollar, the World Bank's Vietnam specialist, said the rebuilding of Vietnam, extremely impoverished by half a century of wars, is likely to cost roughly $500 million a year for five years. Mr. Dollar, speaking at the Asia Society last month, said it was far from clear where Vietnam would secure the money for these contracts.
 
Low Incomes, High Debt
 The country has nearly 70 million people and one of the lowest per-capita incomes in the world -- barely $200 a year -- and is $140 million in arrears to the International Monetary Fund. Hanoi is also thought to have large foreign debts in rubles to the former Soviet Union and in hard currencies to commercial lenders in Japan. Hanoi and Tokyo are now negotiating a debt-repayment plan.
At the Commerce Department, several officials said that Americans's interest in trading or investing in Vietnam is significant, despite the uncertainties. Among those asking for help and information are war veterans who would like to go back and help the country rebuild.
 
Change Not Expected Soon
 State Department officials who deal with Vietnam say they are aware of the concerns of American business, and they acknowledge that Vietnam, with a well-educated labor force eager for jobs, holds a lot of potential. But the general feeling in the Bush Administration, in Congress and in private research organizations is that lifting the embargo and granting diplomatic recognition to Vietnam are not likely to occur before this year's Presidential election.
Under the terms of a "road map" the American Government presented to the Vietnamese last spring, Hanoi must help smooth the transition to democracy in neighboring Cambodia and demonstrate that it is doing all it can to resolve at least 82 possibly solvable cases involving the 2,267 Americans who are missing in Indochina or whose remains have not been found.
In the State Department, even officials most predisposed to hastening the recognition of Vietnam say that Hanoi is not extending as much cooperation as it could, perhaps because Communist hard-liners continue to deal from a position of mistrust and suspicion in issues involving Americans.

HEADLINE: OPEC Set To Discuss Output Cut

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 9

 BODY:
The president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that he would press for a significant cut in oil production to prop up sagging prices, which have dropped by 20 percent since November.
Jibril Aminu, who is also the oil minister of Nigeria, said he would ask OPEC's 12 members to reduce production by about 6 percent when they meet on Wednesday in Geneva. 
 At the moment, the average price of OPEC crude oil is about $16 a barrel, and OPEC output has increased to an 11-year high of 24.2 million barrels a day.
 
Benefits for Consumers
 Americans and other consumers have been enjoying the benefits of OPEC's high production. Retail gasoline prices are at their lowest in months, and heating oil prices are also quite low.
"I think we need to cut by 1.5 million barrels per day in order to firm up prices, arrest the slide and begin moving toward the $21-a-barrel" price that OPEC has set as a goal, Mr. Aminu said in a statement issued in Lagos, Nigeria, before he left for Geneva.
Venezuela's oil minister, Celestino Armas, said last week that there was "a growing inclination among OPEC producers to agree to reduce output in order to raise prices."
 
Who Gets What
 But agreeing on how to regulate production is never an easy matter for OPEC, whose members usually have a difficult time deciding on who will get what share of the production agreed to. Numerous meetings in recent years have ended in stalemates, or with production ceilings agreed to that were subsequently ignored.
And this week's meeting is likely to be little different.
Iran, Libya and Algeria are seeking the largest cuts in production, as much as 10 percent. But any agreement to limit output requires the consent of Saudi Arabia, OPEC's largest and most influential member.
The Saudis currently pump about 8.5 million barrels of oil a day, about 35 percent of OPEC's total. And Saudi Arabia has been adamant about retaining such a share, whatever cuts are made.
The pressure to cut output and increase oil revenues also reflects economic hardships and social tensions in Algeria and Venezuela, situations that have been heightened by declining oil revenue since November.
The Saudis have tried to strike a conciliatory note in recent weeks, saying they are willing to reduce output in conjunction with others. In late January, Saudia Arabia reduced production by 100,000 barrels a day.
But the Saudis have been deliberately vague about how far they will go in order to leave more leeway for the negotiations in Geneva.
The Saudis already dispute the generally bearish views about soft demand for OPEC oil in the second quarter, suggesting they may opt for the smallest proposed cut, of 5 percent. While OPEC economists and the International Energy Agency in Paris estimate the world will only need 22.7 million barrels a day of OPEC's crude starting in March, the Saudis say demand will be higher than that.
For the last 18 months, OPEC has been spared the difficulties of reducing output because of the disappearance of Kuwait and Iraq as key oil producers. The other OPEC members made up for the shortage by pumping as much oil as they could produce.
By far the greatest beneficiary of this policy of high production has been Saudi Arabia. Its share of OPEC's overall output went from 24 percent before the Persian Gulf crisis began in the summer of 1990 to 35 percent now. Venezuela and the United Arab Emirates also profited handsomely.
The three countries have opposed any reversal of the policy of unfettered production until a few weeks ago, when prices started to slide .
"The whole psychology has changed," said Gary Ross, president of the New York-based Petroleum Industry Research Associates.
With sentiment rising for a cut in production, Platt's Oilgram, a newsletter, commented, "The most touted scenarios involve an across-the-board cut that would exclude Iraq and Kuwait."
 
Uncertainty in Iraq
 Iraq, which has been banned by the United Nations from exporting oil since it invaded Kuwait in August 1990, has rejected a United Nations proposal to resume limited exports of about one million barrels a day, largely because of a dispute on how much of the revenues from such exports Iraq would be allowed to collect.
Kuwait, which had a pre-invasion output capacity of two million barrels of oil a day, is still recovering from the ravages of war. Although the fires set by retreating Iraqis in Kuwaiti oilfields have largely been extinguished, much rebuilding is required.
The Kuwaitis are now producing around 600,000 barrels a day and have made it clear that they cannot be expected to slow down the recovery of their oil industry. Kuwaiti exports of oil are still at a modest level of 500,000 barrels a day.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Gasoline Prices Steady

 
By The Associated Press
The retail price of gasoline in the United States dropped only slightly in the last two weeks, according to the weekly survey of 13,000 stations by Trilby Lundberg. She predicted that a three-month price slide was over. Miss Lundberg's survey found the average price of all grades of gasoline, including taxes, was 116.99 cents a gallon, a drop of two-thirds of a penny from Jan. 24. "This may be the end of the price slide," Miss Lundberg said. "Wholesale prices to retailers have been rising, and this drop of 0.64 may be the last one for a while."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Pressures Are Building For Rate Cut

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Less than two months ago, the Federal Reserve Board shocked and delighted financial markets with an unusually aggressive cut in short-term interest rates.
But thus far, many credit market analysts say, the visible benefits to the economy from that bold move on Dec. 20 have been exceedingly modest, and the pressure is building for the central bank to do more. 
 "Despite its dramatic easing efforts in the final months of 1991, the Federal Reserve is not yet off the hook," Robert DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers, wrote in the firm's weekly "Comments on Credit." Chances of another cut in the overnight Federal funds rate, to 3.75 percent or perhaps lower, have increased greatly, Mr. DiClemente said, adding that the move could come within days.
 
Some Help to Housing Sales
 Lower interest rates appear to have strengthened the housing market somewhat and afforded homeowners the opportunity to make up some of the income lost on short-term money market investments by refinancing their mortgages. Another leading indicator, growth in the nation's money supply, has accelerated over the last few weeks.
And there have been faint signs that consumers spent more money last month than they did in January 1991, when fighting broke out in the Persian Gulf.
Despite those signs, most analysts said chances of a quick recovery, which some economists had been predicting, were all but eliminated by the January report on employment.
The employment data prompted James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, to predict that despite the recent small increases in output in the third and fourth quarters, the National Bureau of Economic Research, the organization that dates business cycles, is likely to find that the recession that began in mid-1990 continued into the first quarter of 1992, making it the longest downturn since the Great Depression.
 
Drop in Factory Output Expected
 Aside from the unexpectedly large decline of 91,000 in non-farm payroll employment, analysts said the drop in the manufacturing workweek virtually guaranteed that factory output fell further last month. Moreover, the report showed that those who had jobs were paid less. Though positive for the inflation outlook, the decline in hourly earnings and employment levels will probably not do much to bolster consumer attitudes.
"There is no question the recession continued in January," said Joseph Carson, chief economist at Dean Witter Financial Services. "The first quarter is going to be horrible, probably worse than most people think. I think another easing of monetary policy is very likely in the short run."
At issue, some analysts said, is whether the Fed, which saw the economy losing momentum as 1991 came to a close, calibrated the size of its Dec. 20 cuts in interest rates on the assumption that the first quarter would be weak. If so, short-term rates may stay at current levels for a bit longer.
 
Factor of Rise in Yields
 The rise in bond yields over the last three weeks also argued against a quick change in policy, some analysts said.
"The rise of nearly 50 basis points in long rates means that credit is more costly to borrowers, no matter what they do with the Federal funds rate," said Jerry L. Jordan, a senior vice president at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. "That increase is a real constraint on the Fed. So, too, are the few bits and pieces of positive news that lead you to say something is going on. Those are like telling the Fed, 'Hey, let's give this a little more time.' "
The employment report, coupled with increased anticipation of further easing by the Fed, has probably brightened the outlook for the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions this week.
"Looking at how weak the economy is and how low inflation is, bond yields at 7.75 percent are very, very attractive," said Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities.
 
Outlook for Japanese Buying
 But after a visit to Japan last week, Mr. Brusca added that the attraction was not likely to prove terribly strong to those across the Pacific.
"The Japanese will buy some securities at the auctions," he said. "They always do. But when I was talking to investors there last week there were concerns about the dollar. We are looking at another refunding that will be domestically financed."
Late Friday, the three-year notes to be sold on Tuesday at the start of the refunding were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 5.41 percent. The 10-year notes to be auctioned Wednesday were offered at a price to yield 7.19 percent. And the 30-year bonds to be sold Thursday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.77 percent.
 
Awaiting This Week's Figures
 The Fed has chosen to ease monetary policy before refunding auctions in the past, but analysts said that this time it was more likely that policy makers would delay a decision at least until the January retail sales and producer price figures are announced on Wednesday and Thursday.
Most economists expect the wholesale price numbers to be extremely favorable for credit market participants, but they say the sales figures could be strong and temporarily upset the market.
A vigorous rise in retail sales should not be interpreted as the start of a consumer-led rebound, economists said, in part because excluding automobile sales, retail sales have fallen for the last five months. Moreover, the year-over-year comparisons are against sales that were unnaturally depressed by the war last year, among other things.

HEADLINE: Profits vs. Programs for British TV

BYLINE: By SUZANNE CASSIDY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
The forced resignation of the executive chairman of Granada Television Ltd., whose hits included "Brideshead Revisited" and "The Jewel in the Crown," has stirred fears here that quality programming will be sacrificed in the quest for short-term profits in Britain's increasingly competitive television industry.
Granada is one of Britain's most respected commercial television companies, and its critically acclaimed programs have proved quite popular in the United States as well as in Britain. 
 But recent changes in the economics of British television may push broadcasting companies to cut programming costs, a move that could depress sales of British programs overseas, especially in the United States, the largest market.
 
Franchise Auction
 The debate over profits versus programming is neither new nor confined to Granada; indeed, it lay at the heart of the controversy surrounding the British Government's auction of the 16 commercial television franchises that comprise ITV, as the Independent Television network is known.
One leading broadcaster, Thames Television, lost its franchise in the October auction. And some other commercial television companies were forced to make such high bids that they are expected to seek cuts in ITV's overall budget.
At Granada, which kept its franchise for a relatively low bid, its chief executive, David Plowright, still faced demands for increased profits that he thought would compromise the quality of his company's programming. Mr. Plowright, who was the head of programming when "Brideshead Revisited" and "The Jewel in the Crown" were produced, balked at these demands, so last week he was forced to resign.
Mr. Plowright's ouster has already provoked protests. On Friday, some 70 writers, including Alan Bennett, John Cleese, Harold Pinter and Fay Weldon, said in a letter to the British daily The Guardian that Mr. Plowright's ouster posed "a serious threat" to Granada's "continued production of programs of quality and distinction."
Another letter, signed by nearly 50 directors and producers, including Derek Granger, the producer of "Brideshead Revisited," said the dismissal of Mr. Plowright marked "a sad, black day not just for Granada but for British television as a whole."
Mr. Granger said in an interview that there was "an increasing chance" that American viewers would now see fewer good British programs.
 
'Fundamental Disagreement'
 In a statement earlier in the week, Gerry Robinson, chief executive of Granada's parent, Granada Group P.L.C., said only that he and Mr. Plowright had been "unable to reach a working agreement for the future."
Mr. Plowright, in the same statement, said more bluntly that there was a "fundamental disagreement" between him and Granada Group about "how to manage the change into the new broadcasting environment of the next decade."
Granada Television executives said Mr. Robinson was seeking profit increases that Mr. Plowright considered unreasonable. They said he feared that Granada's ability to provide quality programming would be endangered if budgets had to be slashed too quickly and too sharply.
Jonathan Clare, a spokesman for Granada Group, said that while Mr. Plowright was responsible only for the television company, Mr. Robinson had to "balance the conflicting interests" of the customers, employees and shareholders of the entire Granada Group. The parent company's profits dropped 53 percent last year from 1990.
 
International Sales
 But too much of a focus on short-term profits could ultimately hurt the British television industry. The commercial television companies currently have international sales of about $150 million a year, while the British Broadcasting Corporation sells at least another $70 million in programs abroad.
David Murrell, the head of the British media practice at KPMG Peat Marwick McLintock, the accounting and consulting firm, noted that overseas broadcasters preferred ambitious and well-made programs with stories that can appeal to non-British audiences. But such programs are often expensive to make.
In addition, low-budget British dramatic programs would face extremely tough competition for American audiences, because Hollywood routinely spends $500,000 or more to produce each 30-minute episode of many popular prime-time shows. The difference in production quality could be all too obvious.
Among the British companies that face an uncertain future is Thames Television. Thames's productions include the popular "Rumpole of the Bailey," which is also broadcast in the United States on public television.
A Thames spokesman, Roy Addison, said that since the company had lost its broadcasting license, it was "examining all the possibilities for independent productions and other broadcasting opportunities."
Thames plans to maintain its international sales arm, but Mr. Addison said Americans may not see more of its high-budget programs like "Rumpole" unless they are commissioned by the British Broadcasting Corporation or other television companies.
British television companies, however, have now become very reluctant to commission such programs for next year because of the industry's uncertainty, said Mr. Murrell of KPMG Peat Marwick McLintock.
 
'Tremendous Tensions'
 Even among the ITV franchise winners, there are "tremendous tensions," said Mr. Murrell, because a new central commissioning and scheduling system is not yet in place.
In addition, Mr. Murrell said, all of the 16 companies must agree on a total ITV budget. Since several franchises were so costly, he said, some companies may not have much money left for programming.
As such, "all of them are likely to go for the lowest common denominator," he said. "If you're going on vacation with friends, one of whom has very little money, you don't go to the most exciting place."
Given the uncertainty within the ITV network, "this ought to be a bonanza time for the BBC," Mr. Murrell said.
 
Trouble at the BBC
 But, he added, "the problem is, the BBC has its own difficulties."
Government-appointed consultants have demanded that the BBC come up with 200 million, or about $365 million, in cost savings or new revenues. It also is looking nervously toward the 1996 expiration of its royal charter, which gives the BBC its status as Britain's publicly financed broadcast service.
Such concerns about the BBC, along with commercial television, appeared to be on the mind of Mr. Granger, the former Granada producer. In an interview last week, he warned that the climate for quality broadcasting in Britain was becoming "ferociously cold."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
3 Car-Part Makers Worth Watching

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

 BODY:
THE companies that supply parts to auto makers would appear to have brighter prospects, given the eventual cyclical rebound that is expected in auto sales and a recent pledge from Japanese auto makers to buy more car parts from the United States.
But analysts warn investors to proceed with caution, noting that the auto parts industry is changing in ways that will benefit some suppliers and hurt others. Both foreign and domestic auto makers, for example, rely increasingly on their suppliers for design and engineering expertise, skills that not all component makers possess. Auto makers are also trying to build longer-term relationships with fewer suppliers and insisting that they meet stringent quality guidelines. 
 "There are suppliers that are not going to cut the mustard," said Philip K. Fricke, a Prudential Securities automotive analyst.
Some economists also warn that the agreement by Japanese auto makers to double their purchase of American parts to $19 billion by 1994 may backfire on American companies, because Japanese auto makers may rush to establish their own parts plants in the United States.
With so many caveats, the list of widely recommended stocks is not long. Those that are praised have in-house design and engineering know-how, a track record of delivering quality products, and parts that can be marketed worldwide. Proprietary techniques or technologies are a bonus.
One analyst also believes that smaller suppliers will garner more investment interest in coming years than will larger, more mature companies with higher labor and pension costs. "There seems to be more confidence in smaller parts companies to grow through thick and thin than traditional companies," said Jack V. Kirnan, a Kidder, Peabody automotive analyst.
One such company is the Gentex Corporation of Zeeland, Mich., whose main product is an automobile rear-view mirror that dims automatically to eliminate glare from the headlights of trailing cars. Its Night Vision Safety mirror, which uses a patented electrochemical technology, was first installed on a Lincoln Continental in 1988. The mirrors are now available on 39 car and truck models, including some made by General Motors, Ford, Chrysler, Mercedes, BMW, Nissan and Fiat. Contracts for this year should increase shipments to 790,000 units.
Given the current appetite of consumers for safety-related features, the product is likely to be offered on a growing range of less luxurious models in coming years. Gentex is also developing applications of the technology for architectural glass. Mr. Fricke predicted that Gentex would grow at a compounded annual rate of 33 percent over the next five years. The stock, which closed Friday at $18.875, up 12.5 cents, in over-the-counter trading, is trading near its high for the year. Mr. Fricke said the stock could appreciate to the $30 range within 18 months.
Other recommended stocks include Magna International of Toronto, which makes a wide range of auto parts, including transmission parts, seats, mirror assemblies and trunk-latch releases. The components manufacturer was noted for its missteps in the mid- and late-1980's, when it expanded rapidly and increased production capacity just in time for the automobile industry to hit a downturn. But after a hiatus from the company, its chairman, Frank Stronach, returned to marshal a turnaround. In fiscal 1990, Magna recorded an operating loss of $50 million; the following year it reported an operating profit of $50 million.
The stock's price has reflected its turnaround; trading at $2 a year ago, it closed Friday at $21.25 in over-the-counter trading. Mr. Fricke said the stock was previously surging on the story of its turnaround but is now doing well on the basis of its earnings potential. Analysts also believe that Magna will be among the beneficiaries of increased business from the Japanese transplant manufacturers. "The stock is very cheap on future earnings," Mr. Fricke said.
Analysts are also recommending the stock of the Dana Corporation of Toledo, Ohio., whose engineering expertise is considered first rate. The company stands to receive a significant portion of the business from Toyota if and when the auto maker follows through with its widely publicized plan to build a large pickup truck in this country.
"There's a good chance that Dana is going to get orders for axles, driveshafts and frames," said Mr. Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody, who rates Dana as an attractive long-term investment.
The company currently supplies components for Japanese transplants that make trucks, including Isuzu and Nissan. Others rate the stock as a hold, because the stock's price already reflects future earning power in a healthier sales climate.
Dana's stock closed Friday at $31.125, down 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: ALBERTVILLE;
Sniffles and Shaky Skates Make for a Rough Debut

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBERTVILLE, France, Feb. 9

 BODY:
They had become virtual American folk heroes, the waitress and the truck driver: two middle-class kids raising money through public appearances and the sale of booster pins so they could live out their dreams as Olympic athletes. With a stretch, you could almost imagine them climbing that victory podium and bowing their heads to be draped with the gold medals.
In a dream, anyway. 
 For all their endearing qualities, this was not the night Calla Urbanski and Rocky Marval had envisioned for their Olympic debut. As the figure-skating competition of the 1992 Winter Games opened here tonight with the original program for pairs, they skated to music from the musical "Can-Can," selected just to please the French crowd, but suffered a major error early and ranked seventh after the round.
As the United States champions, they not only trailed the favorites, two pairs from the United Team of former Soviet athletes -- Natalya Mishkutienok and Artur Dmitriev, the current world champions, and Yelena Bechke and Denis Petrov -- they were behind another American couple, Natasha Kuchiki and Todd Sand, who managed sixth.
Not to worry. Urbanski, the 31-year-old waitress and former bartender from Wilmington, Del., and Marval, the 27-year-old owner of a trucking company in New Egypt, N.J., and occasional driver, are having the times of their lives just experiencing the Olympics.
 
'This Is It'
 "When we skated out, I turned to Calla and said: 'This is it. This is the Olympics,' " Marval said, still buzzing.
Urbanski, the oldest skater in the Games, said: "That made me feel good. We both had a rough day and a rough night, so we wanted to go out there and enjoy it and not let the moment pass us by."
Their difficulties arose from untimely colds. More than a few of the United States skaters were suffering at the team's quarters in Brides-les-Bains, a village 45 minutes away from here by bus. Urbanski and Marval had requested a certain antihistamine from the American medical personnel on Saturday night, only to learn the supply was depleted. By today, the medication had arrived, but a little too late to help.
Despite their enthusiasm, they were somewhat flat in their presentation, Marval more than Urbanski, and it was he that brought them most of the trouble. In executing side-by-side double-axel jumps, one of the eight required elements in the original program, he took off awkwardly, considered doing only a single axel, went ahead with the double anyway, then slid into the restraining boards upon landing.
"She did it at the nationals, so I guess it was my turn here," Marval said, recalling Urbanski's fall last month at the national championships in Orlando, Fla. They stood third after the original but overtook Kuchiki and Sand as well as Jenni Meno and Scott Wendland to win their first national title. Meno and Wendland, runners-up in Orlando, skated well tonight but failed to convince the judges, who ranked them 12th.
 
Room For Improvement
 "It's hard to get 5.6's and 5.7's, then drop to 4.9's and 5.0's," said Urbanski, reflecting the difference between here and Orlando. "But I know we can do better."
Marval said: "I'm sure we can pull up one or two spots. Our goal was top five, and I think that's realistic."
By holding the leading positions, the United Team pairs provided that much more evidence that not all phases of former Soviet society are eroding under the weight of economic deprivations. Soviet pairs won the previous seven Olympic titles, and it would be virtually impossible to imagine one of the United Team leaders not making it eight titles Tuesday night after the free-skate phase of competition, which counts for two-thirds of the overall score.
Mishkutienok and Dmitriev was were especially appealing, prancing about to music from "Don Quixote" and erring only when they lost synchronization of side-by-side spins. Their double axels were splendid, which Mishkutienok appreciated more than anyone but maybe their coach, Tamara Moskvina.
"This was the first I have done this season," she said. She had botched them at the Lalique Trophy competition here last November and at the European championships last month in Lausanne, Switzerland, events they won, anyway, which is the best indication their streak is likely to continue.
Even if it appears the waitress and the truck driver are having more fun.

HEADLINE: The New Heroin Bargain

 BODY:
As the U.S. begins to lose its appetite for cocaine, South American drug dealers are trying to develop a new market for heroin. Disturbing as it is, the prospect of more heroin abuse has one positive implication. It adds weight to the already powerful arguments for spending more on drug treatment to rescue addicts.
During the 1980's, heroin seemed to lose its appeal as the drug world discovered crack. The population of heroin addicts appeared to have stabilized at about 750,000 nationwide, compared with 4.5 million using cocaine. The heroin users were an aging group and public health officials were less concerned about their addiction than that they had begun to spread AIDS by sharing needles. 
 But now there's evidence that as the American crack epidemic has peaked, some South American producers who spent the 80's growing cocaine have begun planting heroin poppies in hopes of a revived market for the drug in the U.S.
The prospect dismays many law enforcement and drug policy officials. But some see a silver lining. It's by no means certain that heroin could be marketed as effectively as crack to new addicts. Indeed, the increased use appears to involve addicts who tire of crack, a stimulant, and switch to heroin, an opiate.
Furthermore, American drug treatment programs are on much firmer ground dealing with heroin than with crack. Their experience with heroin dates back to the 1960's, and they have developed a whole menu of treatment modes to meet the varying needs of individual addicts. In addition, the legitimate drug industry now markets two products -- methadone and naltrexone -- that effectively block heroin craving and permit addicts to lead normal lives.
Whatever hopes history may justify, public spending for drug treatment of all sorts remains miserably inadequate. Washington currently provides about $550 million in direct and block grants for drug treatment. States and localities provide another half-billion.
That money, along with private funds, now supports about 600,000 treatment slots capable of serving 1.7 million addicts each year. Students of drug policy say that accommodating all the addicts willing to accept treatment would require at least 300,000 more slots. With no private help, that would cost governments an additional $1.6 billion.
So serious a commitment could not be made without heavy Federal participation. The urban states with the biggest drug problems are so strapped that they are lucky simply to hold the line on treatment spending. The President's drug policy office has become acutely mindful of the need, but Congress in recent years has denied any real increases in treatment funding.
Rising heroin use means more treatment dollars might be spent more effectively than ever, with powerful implications for crime control, prevention of birth defects, AIDS and other diseases -- and attendant improvement in the quality of life for city residents in general. When legislators ignore such a bargain, voters have every reason to ask why.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Worriers Vs. Wallowers

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Environmentalists are saying that the Bush Administration will do nothing about gases dangerously warming the planet. And Administration officials are saying that it is the environmentalists who are full of impractical hot air.
While the warming worriers are demanding urgent action, the officials are wrestling with -- and alas, wallowing in -- the practical problems of doing something. 
 Too bad for us all that President Bush is not knocking their talented heads together. Yoked to common purpose, they could make extraordinary contributions to the critical working session of the U.N. "Earth Summit" in New York next week.
With ominous news of the ozone layer depleting faster than expected, Mr. Bush managed to reverse himself last week and accept Senate plans to phase out the offending gases. But on greenhouse gases, he stands by as the warring parties continue to spend more time proselytizing baffled journalists than talking to each other about viable solutions.
The first point warming worriers make is that science sits on their side. Experts generally do agree that greenhouse gases, mainly carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels, are trapping heat and warming the earth's temperature. How warm and how fast are arguable matters, but scientists are alarmed now.
The worriers, led by the governments of Western Europe and Japan, have a two-point plan. They call for setting targets and timetables (T.& T.) for reducing CO2 , principally by conserving energy. And they propose giving money to poorer countries to make environmental measures affordable along with economic development.
The U.S., they say, is isolated among industrialized nations in resisting these moves. They see the New York meeting as the last chance to set the world on track toward solutions in time for the U.N. summit meeting this June in Brazil. They are dismayed that Mr. Bush still has not promised to attend in June.
With few exceptions, Administration officials question the scientific consensus. They also insist that European leaders know the practical difficulties of reducing CO2 and are playing games to court their own environmentalists (using the U.S. as an excuse for their own inaction) and gain economic advantages (given their lead in energy efficiency).
The officials argue that realistic strategies for controlling warming gases have to be tailored to individual countries and must be comprehensive and flexible. But they would not venture to say whether this approach would limit CO2 increases. They say they are working on new meaty proposals. But these will not include legally mandated targets and timetables for CO2 reductions. Too artificial and difficult to define on a national basis, they believe -- and not without good reasons.
Yet, some officials say they are entertaining the idea of targets and timetables as general goals. To this end, officials told of an ingenious bureaucratic game tied to the fact that CO2 growth is pegged to general economic growth: given Administration projections of average annual growth for the rest of the decade of about 2.9 percent, there is little hope of reducing CO2 levels. So the pro-T.& T. crowd proposes lowering the projections to what most non-governmental economists realistically predict, about 1.9 percent. This would bring the U.S. within shouting distance of European T.& T. levels. But it would also be an admission of slower economic growth and thus a failure of White House economic policies. So, stalemate.
In any event, this scheme would only change abstract numbers without actually holding down CO2 output. Which is why officials say they are looking at other ideas, like longer- lasting light bulbs -- a good idea, but it would not put a big dent in CO2 growth.
Even if industrialized countries found ways to limit CO2 output, these efforts would be offset by increases in developing countries. Officials are well aware of this and know poor countries will need aid to square the circle. But they say the present budget contained no money for a World Bank environmental/development fund. They say they are still looking.
George Bush was not nearly so cautious when he spoke of global warming in the 1988 Presidential campaign. "Those who think we're powerless to do anything about the greenhouse effect are forgetting the White House effect," he said. Those welcome words are not forgotten by many worriers and wallowers who wait for him to bring them together -- for planet's sake.

HEADLINE: Send the Candidates a Message

BYLINE: By James Reston; James Reston is former chief Washington correspondent and executive editor of The New York Times.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the preliminaries to the Presidential election, all the candidates have been asking the voters to send a message to Washington, but nobody has been sending a message to them. Herewith a few suggestions.
To the Democrats: why do you go into the playoffs with your second team? You have tried that and lost five of the last six Presidential elections. It's true that the country is in a recession, but it's no depression, and George Bush, whatever else he is, is no Herbert Hoover. At least he looks and sounds like a President, and, as Ronald Reagan proved, the appearance of things catches more votes than the substance. 
 Forget about 1932. You have no Franklin D. Roosevelt. And forget about 1948. You don't even have a Harry S. Truman in the race. The President has told you he will do anything to be re-elected, and he probably will, even if he has to keep or forget his promises.
Meanwhile, keep your second team off television. Why advertise your weakness? They don't even make it clear to people that Democrats got us out of the Depression and gave old folks Social Security and the unemployed some insurance. They don't concentrate on the gross national stupidity of the 1980's but fuss with one another about the mysteries of economics -- a sure way to turn off voters.
To the Republicans: is it wise to keep talking about cutting the capital gains tax? Even if the revenues trickled down to help the poor, nobody understands such cuts but the rich. It all sounds like a scheme to comfort the comfortable and afflict the afflicted. Meanwhile, say a few nice things about Gov. Mario Cuomo and other Democratic dropouts; that may keep them satisfied and on the sidelines. And don't be beastly to the Democratic candidates; these guys are your allies, not your enemies.
Also, in the name of Republican decency, forget about Willie Horton. Chuck the sly racial appeals and tricky code words that divide people. One other thing: can't you do something about Dan Quayle? It's bad politics and bad manners for the President to insist on keeping him on the ticket. This is a decision to be made by the party in convention, not by a President who insults voters by claiming that Mr. Quayle is the most qualified substitute President.
To George Bush: please, Mr. President, stop starting your sentences with "Hey!" and waving to people who aren't there. Why have an Education President who cusses like a preacher? Why the tough guy mucker pose? The people don't like it, and you're not good at it. We liked the old Bush, who used to speak as his father spoke against Joe McCarthy, who denounced "voodoo" economics and hated debt, who talked about getting the people together and stayed home once in a while.
Why demand a new order in the world and give us the same old political disorder and muddle at home?. It's no answer to say you're doing the best you can. That's what worries us.
To the voters and nonvoters: don't give up. If you don't like the candidates, you can write in somebody else's name. Or the parties, if they did what they're supposed to do, could insist on nominating their best people at conventions.
None of the above is likely to decide the election. But it might make the candidates come a little closer to the truth. Political lying used to be no worse than a bad personal habit, but now it's a science and even an industry. This calls for the revival of mocking laughter or even some justified heckling, and maybe a few more bumper stickers: No More Lies. Why Not the Best? Or even, Whither Art Thou, Mario? Otherwise, everybody "out there" and even "in here," in the Beltway, is likely to feel even worse next November than they do now.

HEADLINE: Buying American Won't Be Enough

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the rush to buy American (front page, Jan. 27), let us not forget that most United States businesses that can benefit from such a move in the short term will have to function efficiently over the long haul in not just a national, but a global economy.
That is, the coming decade's real growth markets -- for automobiles, tractors, household goods and appliances, and a host of other goods and services -- will be in second- and third-world countries, especially in Eastern Europe, the Pacific rim and to a lesser extent the Americas. 
 American companies must compete for their share in these wider markets if we hope to remain a "first-world" economy. Japanese companies will, of course, be among our strongest competitors.
Buying American now may create an illusion of success for some United States businesses; but its main impact will be to forestall the changes -- particularly in management and in public policy -- that must be made to assure a wider competitiveness.
Being good is not good enough. American industry has to be world class.
 
LAURENCE B. CHASE
Summit, N.J., Jan. 27, 1992

HEADLINE: To Curb Congressional Mailing Abuse

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I believe my position was misconstrued in "Frankly, It's an Abuse" (Topics of The Times, Jan. 19), on abuse of franking, the Congressional free mailing privilege.
A little more than a year ago, I was teaching high school civics students about our Government and the careful balance of accountability that must be maintained among the judicial, legislative and executive branches of the Federal system. 
 Today, as a member of the House of Representatives, I encounter a situation that requires an equally important balance -- that of building and maintaining accountability to our constituents by communicating effectively while limiting expense. Congress has given itself the privilege of sending mailing after mailing without any public record. Last year was the first when members had to keep track of how much they sent. Estimates show that Congressional mail has decreased significantly.
As a supporter of reform in all areas of politics, I believe this measure of accountability is essential.
Before I was elected to Congress, I spoke out against the widespread abuse of the franking privilege. I have worked to limit use of the frank, sending out only one mass mailing over the entire year. It contained an opinion survey and information on the environment, education, the economy and energy.
A study of franked mail for the first six months of 1991 by the National Taxpayers' Union showed that I used less of my allocated mail budget than 80 percent of my colleagues. While the final reports for the year have not been issued yet by the Postal Service, I believe you would find I used only about 30 percent of what was allowed.
I appreciate your criticism of the frank because there are many blatant abuses, but I have violated no rule.
 
WAYNE T. GILCHREST
Member of Congress, 1st Dist., Md.
Washington, Jan. 21, 1992

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans;
Buchanan Says Party Needs His 'Little Rebellion'

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 9

 BODY:
Countering assertions that his candidacy is splitting Republicans and providing ammunition for Democrats, Patrick J. Buchanan has stepped up his attack on President Bush, accusing him of abandoning conservative principles.
In a blistering speech Saturday night at a dinner for conservatives, Mr. Buchanan said conservatives in Washington, as epitomized by the President, had lost touch with their ideals and their constituency. 
 "You know," Mr. Buchanan said, "a great American, Thomas Jefferson, once said, 'I hold it that a little rebellion now and again is a good thing, as necessary in the political world as storms in the physical.'
"Well, my friends, a little rebellion is what the Buchanan brigades are all about."
Addressing more than 1,000 people at the $430-a-plate dinner sponsored by the New Hampshire Conservative Political Victory Fund, Mr. Buchanan criticized the President for supporting a tax increase as part of the budget agreement negotiated with Congressional leaders in October 1990. Mr. Bush's agreement to those increases, which contradicted his 1988 campaign pledge of "no new taxes," has been the mantra of the Buchanan campaign.
"We have got to begin standing up again for what we've always stood for as Republicans and conservatives," Mr. Buchanan said. "When Federal spending is consuming a record 26 percent of the gross national product, that is not conservatism and that is not Republicanism."
Mr. Buchanan also called into question Mr. Bush's political courage. "One reason I admired Ronald Reagan is that when he came to Washington, he buckled on his sword and he went out and fought from Day One for what he wanted," he said.
Mr. Buchanan was referring to Mr. Bush's deadline for Congress to enact his economic proposals, a deadline that few expect Congress to meet.
After Mr. Buchanan had finished his speech and left the hall, the audience watched a videotaped endorsement of Mr. Bush by Mr. Reagan.
On the tape the former President took note of the fact that Mr. Bush was not at the dinner. "He's in Washington wrestling with the liberals in Congress that are trying to block his agenda for your future," Mr. Reagan said. "And, although now we face some hard times, I believe that the experienced leadership of George Bush is our best hope to build a stronger America."
When word spread before the dinner that Mr. Reagan would endorse Mr. Bush, it caused a stir among some members of the group sponsoring the event. Officials of the organization, a political action committee, said that it would take no position in the New Hampshire Republican primary.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 11, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about a speech by Patrick J. Buchanan attacking President Bush referred incorrectly to the event at which he spoke. It was a $30-a-plate dinner in Manchester, N.H., not a $430-a-plate dinner.

HEADLINE: A Plea for Truth-in-Bashing

BYLINE: By James Fallows; James Fallows, Washington editor of The Atlantic, is working on a book about East Asia.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Reasonable people can disagree abut whether a "buy American" campaign makes sense. But we could do without several fatuous arguments:
1. You can't tell where this stuff comes from anyway. Even the hard-headed Mike Royko has fallen for this. In a recent column, he said that he'd bought an American car and a friend had bought Japanese -- but that the Japanese car was made in America and was probably more American than the real thing. Hah! The joke was on the buy-American crowd. 
 In principle, corporations might eventually lose all ties to their parent nations. This is nearly the case with American computer makers. None of the major components of Apple, Compaq, Dell or other "American" computers are produced in the U.S., except for the microprocessing chip itself.
But "American" cars are overwhelmingly made in America. Because Chrysler buys many engines from Mitsubishi, the North American content of its cars is less than Ford's or G.M.'s. Because Honda builds engines in Ohio, its North American content is higher than Toyota's or Nissan's. But the Big Three are all much more "American" than any Japanese brand. The average North American content for Chrysler vehicles is more than 85 percent. According to Canadian officials inspecting "made in Ohio" Hondas, it remains an open question whether the cars are even 50 percent North American.
This doesn't prove that Americans should reject cars from Japanese "transplants," or even that they should care where their cars come from. But we should stop pretending that the origin is an unsolvable enigma.
2. The whiff of racism is in the air. It's foolish ever to rule out racism as a factor, but the term is being applied reflexively to controversies that have simpler explanations. I don't care who owns the Seattle Mariners -- and if I did, I'd choose Nintendo over George Steinbrenner any day. But there is no evidence that baseball is resisting the Nintendo owners because of their race rather than their nationality. Suppose Senator Daniel Inouye were buying the team. Would anyone complain?
To many people in Japan, the distinction between nationality and "race" may seem elusive. To Americans, the distinction should be clear and fundamental. If we think that clashes of national interests with Japan inevitably have the "whiff of racism" because the countries' racial make-up differs, then we're logically forced to consider Japan's many nationalistic policies racist as well -- including its ban on foreign ownership of its baseball teams.
Japan's ban on rice imports penalizes racially non-Japanese farmers from Thailand to Arkansas. It's enough to call this policy "pig-headed" or "protectionist," without insisting that it's racist as well. If you disagree with the protests over Nintendo in Seattle, just call them "xenophobic." There's no reason to haul in the most loaded term in our political language.
3. If our schools are bad, then we've got no problems with Japan. Most oratory suggests only two possible explanations for trade problems. Either the Japanese economy is unfair, closed and tricky, or else Americans are lazy, spendthrift and dumb. To the extent one explanation is true, we can ignore the other -- as the standard editorial does when saying: We mustn't lecture the Japanese until we [fix our schools, cut the budget deficit, stop crime, etc.].
Our brains should be big enough to contain two ideas -- that we have both internal and external problems. Does anyone think Koreans are dumb and lazy? Yet Korea has a big economic imbalance with Japan, much like ours. So do Taiwan, Singapore and other get-the-job-done societies. America's budget deficit and low savings increase the size of our trade deficit, but they're not the only factors involved.
America has serious social problems, which would be serious even if there were no other countries in the world. The auto-parts trade deficit is not the reason we should care about families or schools; the texture of our life is. But we also have long-term economic problems with Japan, which most other countries share.
Agree or disagree with Dick Gephardt and Lee Iacocca, as you choose -- but if you disagree, don't assume that they're bigots, or that they're trying to distract attention from America's shortcomings.

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Suspect Is Arrested In Woman's Killing In Crown Heights

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
A 23-year-old unemployed handyman, who the police said may have offered to do odd jobs so he could case houses to burglarize, was charged yesterday in the brutal stabbing death of a Hasidic woman in the Crown Heights neighborhood in Brooklyn.
The slaying on Thursday was followed by a rock-and bottle-throwing incident between Hasidim and black and Hispanic residents -- a brief echo of the violence that erupted there last summer after a black child was killed by a car driven by a Hasidic man and an Australian rabbinical student was slain. 
 The victim last week, Phyllis Lapine, was stabbed more than 30 times after returning home from a shopping trip.
The police identified the suspect as Romane LaFond, a black man who lives with his parents in a ground-floor apartment at 1625 President Street, a few blocks from Mrs. Lapine's house. They said he had long arrest record, had been arrested for a burglary in Crown Heights last August and was being questioned on a sex-abuse warrant when detectives made a connection to the Lapine case.
Police officials said the warrant was issued in connection with a first-degree assault on a Hasidic woman in the neighborhood on Dec. 26. Detectives refused to provide the details of the incident, but said it did not involve rape or sodomy.
Demands by the community for an arrest in the stabbing put intense pressure on the police, City Hall and other public officials. The Hasidic community had planned to demonstrate every night until an arrest was made, and the announcement that a suspect had been taken into custody drew immediate praise from community leaders. The streets of Crown Heights were quiet last night, but more police officers than usual were on duty. Riot gear was stacked within arm's reach at the precinct station house, but was not needed.
Chief of Detectives Joseph R. Borrelli said at a news conference last night that detectives "got help from the entire Crown Heights community" -- including blacks and Hasidim -- that pointed to Mr. LaFond, who was charged with murder, burglary and weapons possession.
"Everybody will be able to sleep at night," the victim's husband, Dennis Lapine, said after the arrest was announced. Sitting in the home where his wife had been killed, surrounded by friends and family, including his two sons, he added, "There's a God in the world who controls things."
Police officials gave different answers when asked what the motive for the slaying was -- Deputy Inspector Lawrence Loesch said it appeared to have been robbery, but other police officials said they were uncertain -- but there was a consensus that bias was not a factor. The police said they were not classifying Mrs. Lapine's killing as a bias crime, and Rabbi Joseph B. Spielman, the head of the Crown Heights Jewish Community Council, called it "a plain act of wanton violence, rather than bias."
The police said that Mr. Lafond's record included two arrests on burglary charges, two on assault charges, one on robbery charges and one on weapons possession charges. Law-enforcement officials said he had been sentenced to 2 to 6 years in prison on one of the robbery charges in 1985, had served some time in jail and had completed his parole last year. They said they did not know how the other cases had been resolved.
At Mr. LaFond's five-story apartment building last night, neighbors described him as a disturbed young man who hung around the neighborhood because he did not have a steady job. One person said he had helped out with a van service. Neighbors and the police said Mr. LaFond had a stormy relationship with his parents.
After Mrs. Lapine's body was found on Thursday, the police said she had been killed by an intruder who apparently surprised her when she returned home from the supermarket. She was carrying bags of groceries that were still on the front stoop hours after she died.
Chief Borrelli said Mr. LaFond had apparently tried to talk his way into houses in the neighborhood by posing as a handyman. "He has come to people's attention, trying some kind of a story that he's a handyman and he does odd jobs," Chief Borrelli said.
The chief said that people in the neighborhood said they had seen Mr. LaFond around the time Mrs. Lapine died. "There was some rumors going around that an individual was seen in the vicinity," Chief Borrelli said. "The people from the community were able to give us a lead as to who that individual might be."
 
Found by Neighbor
 Mrs. Lapine's body was found on the living-room couch in the brick house after her 5-year-old son, Avrohom, arrived home from his school, the Lubavitch Yeshiva. Unable to get in, Avrohom went to a neighbor, who opened the door and found the body.
The police said they found Mrs. Lapine's 2-year-old daughter, Sarah Chanah, hiding under a bed.
In the confusion that followed the discovery of the body and compounded the horror of a case in which the police initially said they had no witnesses and no suspects, detectives said that Mrs. Lapine's dress had been "pushed up." But they did not say whether she had been sexually assaulted. Last night Chief Borrelli said the authorities were waiting for the results of an autopsy.
In the first hours after Mrs. Lapine's handbag was found on a couch, detectives were not sure whether any money had been taken. The side door of the house appeared to have been jimmied open, but the police were not certain whether the marks on the door were new or whether the house had been broken into before.
 
Chants by Hasidim
 As details of the slaying spread through the tightly knit Hasidic community in Crown Heights, where Hasidic Jews and blacks have lived in an uneasy coexistence for years, Jewish demonstrators expressed heated anger at the crime. Some Hasidim marched through the streets, chanting "No more welfare!" and "Go back to Africa!"
The next day, black residents watched as about 4,000 Hasidim marched in a long funeral procession to the Lapines' home on Lefferts Avenue. Aware of the potential for trouble, hundreds of police officers were assigned to extra patrols in Crown Heights.
Last night, there was relief that someone had been charged, and kind words for the detective work that led to Mr. LaFond's arrest. Rabbi Jacob Goldstein, the chairman of Community Board 9, said: "Quick efficient police action is to be highly commended. All of the residents of the community can sleep better tonight. One member of the community said we have to have a Desert Storm parade for the cops."
Eli Blachman, a next door neighbor of the Lapines who is taking care of their four children, said: "The murderer has been caught, but we still have to help the children. These children have no mother."
Echoing the comments of other Jews in Crown Heights last night, Rabbi Spielman, of the Crown Heights Jewish Community Council, said, "The response of the police was proper and on time. We hope this will continue when it comes to preventing these crimes."
