HEADLINE: DINKINS PLAN GIVES MINORITY CONCERNS MORE IN CONTRACTS

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Asserting the time had come to correct decades of rampant discrimination in the city's procurement process, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced a sweeping policy initiative yesterday to award more than 20 percent of city contracts to businesses owned by minorities or women.
Mr. Dinkins said that he had instructed city agencies to develop a program to increase the amount of business the city gives to companies owned by minorities and women. 
 The details of the plan have yet to be worked out, but Mr. Dinkins said the program would not include quotas for the awarding of contracts.
The plan represents the first time that the city has sponsored a government contract program to aid minorities and women.
 
Change in Policy
 In the past, New York City adopted preferences for small businesses and companies based in the city, but such programs were conducted without reference to race, ethnic background or sex. To qualify for Federal transportation money, the city requires that minorities make up a certain percentage of the subcontractors who work on transit projects.
The proposal by the Mayor could put the city at the forefront of efforts by a government entity to set preference goals in the aftermath of a 1989 Supreme Court decision. The court ruled that a similar set-aside program for public works contracts in Richmond was unconstitutional, finding that such programs could be justified only if they served the "compelling state interest" of redressing "identified discrimination," either by the Government or by private parties.
The challenge to the Richmond ordinance was brought in 1983 by the J. A. Croson Company, a white-owned mechanical plumbing and heating contractor. Croson lost a bid to supply toilets for the city jail when it was unable to certify that it would use a minority-owned subcontractor for 30 percent of the $126,000 contract. The city denied the company's request for a waiver of the 30 percent requirement.
While other major cities like Atlanta, Chicago, Denver, Seattle, and San Francisco have adopted programs that set aside contracts for companies whose owners are women or members of minority groups, the Supreme Court ruling in the Richmond case has forced many cities dismantle such programs or to show specific evidence of past discrimination.
To prove that such an affirmative action program is justified in New York City, the Mayor released a study yesterday that showed companies owned by minorities and women make up 25 percent of the businesses that compete for municipal contracts but that these companies received only 7 percent of the $2.3 billion in contracts reviewed in the study.
Aides to Mr. Dinkins predicted yesterday that the Mayor's plan would withstand any court challenge because the study establishes "a pattern of individual discriminatory acts" that "lend support to a local government's determination that race-conscious remedial relief is justified," as defined in the Supreme Court ruling.
 
Examining Contracts
 The study, which was conducted by National Economic Research Associates, a private consulting firm, examined contracts and purchase orders issued by city agencies for construction, professional services, and supplies for the 1989 and 1990 fiscal years. On major construction contracts, the study found that black-owned businesses received 17 cents of every dollar the city had expected them to receive. Asian businesses received 14 cents and businesses owned by women received 20 cents.
For Mayor Dinkins, the affirmative action program allows him to make good on his long-standing promise to address the concerns of the city's minority community at a time when he is seeking re-election and needs to solidify his core constituency. By using an executive order, the Mayor did not need the approval of the City Council or any other body to set up the program.
"I hope the day comes soon when we are treated fairly and equally for our good work, not denigrated because of our gender or whence our ancestors came," said Mr. Dinkins, announcing the new program at a City Hall meeting attended by women and minority business executives and community leaders.
Minority-owed business development groups praised the Mayor's initiative yesterday, saying that it would encourage minorities and women to form new businesses and joint-ventures with established contractors to compete for city contracts.
"Given the racial and ethnic composition of New York, a program like this is long overdue, but I commend the Mayor for finally biting the bullet and going ahead with it," said Harriet R. Michel, president of the National Minority Supplier Development Council, which matches major corporations with minority suppliers.
But former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who declined to adopt set-aside programs for women and minorities during his administration, said yesterday that he opposed such programs because they discriminated against white males who own comparable businesses. "Dave Dinkins cloaks this as goals, but it is a set-aside program based on race and it will be struck down like the Richmond case," Mr. Koch said.
Instead of an affirmative action program, the former Mayor said that Mr. Dinkins should use an executive order to bar contractors who discriminate from doing business with the city.
Frank McArdle, who heads the General Contractors Association, which represents heavy construction industry, said: "We look forward to working with the Mayor in implementing his new initiative to insure the city gets the maximum amount of competition and equal opportunity for its contracting industry."
Kenneth J. Knuckles, the Commissioner of General Services, which is the city's landlord and purchasing agent, said that while plans to begin the Mayor's initiative were still being developed, the city was likely to split some large contracts into smaller parts and speed up payments to give minority- and women-owned businesses more opportunity to compete.
Dinkins administration officials said that the city had no plans to change the current standards and rules for competing for city business and that city would insure that minority and women contractors were not fronts for other businesses.

HEADLINE: Problems at White House Persist 2 Months Into New Chief's Tenure

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Two months after John H. Sununu's removal, Administration officials and Republican advisers say the organizational and political problems that the former chief of staff left behind still plague the White House.
The new chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner, has tried to make his mark by smoothing relations between the White House and the campaign and by undertaking a much-advertised reorganization of the White House staff. 
 The reorganization, like the chief of staff himself, is too fresh to be judged fully. But Mr. Skinner's influence has been evident in Mr. Bush's sudden willingness to recognize the reality of the current recession and to compromise with Congress where Mr. Sununu had been unbending, as on a 13-week extension of unemployment benefits and on restrictions on chemicals that damage the atmospheric ozone layer.
 
'Pretty Substantial Team'
 Mr. Skinner said he had appointed a "pretty substantial team." Since he has been in the job he has helped President Bush produce an economic growth plan and a proposal for health care changes that Republicans were demanding of the White House for months.
But the economic plan has received as much criticism as praise, with critics saying it reflects the continued influence of Richard G. Darman, the budget director, rather than any new direction.
A number of Administration officials and Republicans say President Bush is still hobbled by disjointed communications, poorly planned campaign trips, squabbling over domestic policy and rivalries among policy makers.
Mr. Skinner is known to be frustrated by what he regards as the marginal competence of some holdovers from the Sununu period, but feels that he cannot clean house too abruptly for reasons of public relations and morale.
The overall picture that emerges is that of a rocky first month of an election year, with Republican strategists and some Administration officials giving Mr. Skinner's performance mediocre grades but hoping that the President, Mr. Skinner and the campaign team can restore the political edge and efficiency of Mr. Bush's 1988 operation.
The centerpiece of the White House reorganization is the appointment of Clayton K. Yeutter, the former Agriculture Secretary, to a new post charged with centralizing what had been a diffuse policy-making apparatus. But even before Mr. Yeutter takes office, Mr. Skinner has made clear that his job will be as a "broker" of ideas, not as the architect of policy.
And many Republicans questioned whether the appointment of Mr. Yeutter gave Mr. Bush much political benefit externally or extra policy muscle internally. Similarly, many of Mr. Bush's aides and advisers questioned the appointment of Andrew H. Card Jr., a White House aide, as Transportation Secretary in an election year when Mr. Bush might have benefited from choosing a woman, a member of a minority or someone who also came from outside the department but who represented some useful political constituency.
On the political side, Mr. Skinner has formed a potentially powerful partnership with Mr. Bush's campaign chairman, Robert M. Teeter, which both men are counting on to give them influence over policy in the campaign. The two men have put together a more aggressive schedule for Mr. Bush in the week remaining before the New Hampshire primary. The President plans to announce his candidacy formally on Wednesday at two events, one in Washington and the other in New Hampshire. He will spend the entire weekend in New Hampshire instead of just Saturday, as originally planned.
Disappointed officials and party strategists called the White House reorganization a series of compromises and half-measures that reflected Mr. Bush's basic conviction that there was nothing wrong with his staff or his policies, that the economy would soon right itself and that he would be re-elected in November.
"The President is not panicked enough to think things really have to change," one official said.
Officials and party strategists said Mr. Skinner had also not challenged the dominance of Mr. Darman and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
Nor have Mr. Skinner's changes filled what a senior Republican called a "vacuum" in the White House: No one has emerged to fill James A. Baker 3d's role of previous campaigns -- giving Mr. Bush unvarnished counsel and carrying the weight, as one strategist put it, "to make him stick to the script when he has to."
 
On the Campaign Trail
 This absence of direction seems evident in Mr. Bush's performance on the campaign trail, where he has stumbled through several erratic speeches with little in the way of a coherent political message. The President, never a master ad-libber, has ad-libbed his way through small-bore appearances -- looking out of touch as he marveled at electronic scanners at a mock supermarket or, as he did in New Hampshire last month, repeating his stage directions ("Message: I care").
In Washington, Cabinet members continue to question major policy decisions, sometimes in public. Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp Jr. calledsome of the President's budget proposals "gimmicks" and was then forced to apologize.
Last week, Mr. Darman openly challenged Mr. Yeutter. "I work for the President," Mr. Darman snapped when asked if Mr. Yeutter would have authority over him.
John P. Sears, a former campaign manager for President Ronald Reagan, said: "They don't have any politicians in the place. Politicians used to be those guys who didn't run for office and helped those who did. There was another category of people that used to be called candidates, who ran for office. That's what they've got, candidates and no politicians."
Mr. Skinner, who is concerned enough about his image to call a reporter back the day after an interview to offer names of lawmakers who would say he is doing a good job, tersely dismissed criticism of his performance as "carping."
He said his new team would mend President Bush's ailing domestic policy apparatus. "The President gave me the latitude to backfill in some key positions," he said, "and we believe with the talent that's here we've put together a team that will do a great job for him. The President would not have made a change like this if he didn't think there was a problem."
Administration officials credit Mr. Skinner with ending a reign of fear under Mr. Sununu, permitting more voices to be heard in Mr. Bush's councils and stopping short of a clean sweep through the White House staff.
But officials said that the openness often produced a cacophony, not new ideas, and that Mr. Skinner was still groping for control under intense pressure from the unfolding campaign.
Officials also said it was not compassion that prevented wholesale dismissals at the White House but the pressures of the budget and the campaign, coupled with a reluctance by Mr. Skinner to take on Mr. Darman and Mr. Brady.
In addition to Mr. Yeutter, who was named a counselor to the President for domestic affairs, Mr. Skinner, acting with Mr. Bush's approval, named Henson Moore, the Deputy Secretary of Energy, as the deputy chief of staff, and Sherrie Rollins as director of public liaison. He added the job of coordinating all White House communications to the portfolio of Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman.
 
'Fresh New Advice'
 "When you have two former Cabinet officers with records of their own in top staff jobs," Mr. Skinner said, "plus one of the strongest deputies in the Cabinet, who is a former Congressman, you're going to bring into the process some fresh new advice and counsel."
But Bush advisers and aides said moving Mr. Yeutter to the White House from chairman of the Republican National Committee was primarily intended to make a space at the top of the party for Richard N. Bond, a longtime Bush aide considered a more able political tactician and spokesman.
Many Administration officials and Bush advisers doubt Mr. Yeutter will be able to exert his will over Mr. Darman.
Last week, at a breakfast with reporters, Mr. Darman offered this characteristically complex locution when asked if Mr. Skinner's reorganization would diminish his authority:
"I can't think of an answer to that question that would not cause me a problem," he said. "If I were to say that I thought my influence would increase, you would write that Darman is characteristically arrogant and who knows what else. If I were to say that I thought my influence would decrease, you would say, Darman's, well, diminished. If I were to say about the same, it would make a whole lot of people unhappy."

HEADLINE: As Food Airlift Starts, Baker Hints U.S. Might Agree to Role in a Ruble Fund

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Feb. 10

 BODY:
An international airlift with food and medical aid for the former Soviet Union got under way today, with the aim of providing critical short-term help as well as hope for the newly independent countries struggling through the winter, the organizers said.
Shortly before the airlift, which is being called Operation Provide Hope, began in a hailstorm at Rhein-Main Air Base outside Frankfurt, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who attended the opening, hinted for the first time that Washington might be prepared to take part in a longer-term, multibillion-dollar stabilization fund for the Russian economy. 
 This would be on the condition that it was tied to an economic reform program worked out with the International Monetary Fund.
Mr. Baker made his remarks, on his flight from Washington to Germany, perhaps partly in response to complaints by Boris N. Yeltsin after the Russian President's visit to Washington 10 days ago. Mr. Yeltsin said some Western nations were not doing enough to support his economic reforms.
 
Diverting Attention
 Today's airlift, initially organized by the United States at a 47-nation aid conference in Washington last month, seemed both a gesture to provide some substantial relief in an emergency, as well as a publicity maneuver intended to overshadow how slow and relatively limited the overall American aid contribution has been.
For the next 10 to 14 days, American C-141 and C-5A cargo planes, which began lumbering off today from Rhein-Main in Germany and from two air bases in Turkey, will ferry roughly $60 million worth of food, medicine and medical equipment left over from the Persian Gulf war to 23 sites in the new Commonwealth of Independent States. These range from St. Petersburg in the north, to Armenia in the south, to Kazakhstan in the east.
The food includes tons of canned lasagna, apple pie filling, dehydrated pork chops and other military rations.
Planes from Germany, France, Italy and Japan also flew in aid today, The Associated Press reported.
American teams, flown in earlier, will meet the shipments on arrival and try to make sure that they get to the orphanages, hospitals and other relief centers for which they are intended.
 
Flights Are Ultimately Costly
 Officials emphasized that the airlift was largely symbolic, acknowledging that it would only begin to address the problem of shortages in the independent republics.
As Richard L. Armitage, the American coordinator for the operation explained, one huge C-5A packed with food carries only enough to support an active Moscow soup kitchen through two dinners. The entire American food contribution amounts to 16 million meals, enough to feed all of Moscow for two nights or so.
Some of the flights are carrying Agriculture Department butter and powdered milk that was supposed to have gone by ship weeks ago, but because of logistical trouble was piled up at American docks. Ultimately, Mr. Armitage said, the use of planes is neither efficient nor economical in providing bulk assistance, and a better use of ships and railroads must be found.
Last fall, Congress gave the Administration $100 million to transport such aid, and this is the first use being made of it.
"Our objective," said Mr. Baker, who stopped in Frankfurt to be photographed beginning the airlift that he had initiated, "was not only to help stem a rising tide of human misery, but to send a message of hope and support in hard times.
"We know that 54 American flights will not stock all the emergency pharmacies of Ukraine, Uzbekistan or Azerbaijan," he continued. "But these flights will provide emergency food and medical supplies. And above all, they will carry a dramatic message of hope to the peoples of the new independent states."
While the American contribution consists of roughly 2,000 tons of bulk food and medicine, the European Community has been giving 400 tons of food a day, and in this airlift Belgium is providing an amount that is almost half the American total.
The airlift and a briefing for reporters traveling with Mr. Baker reflected the double message that the Bush Administration is sending about assistance to the countries of the former Soviet Union.
 
Leadership vs. Politics
 On one level, Washington believes that if it is to maintain leadership of the Western alliance, it must be seen as taking the lead in the Russian aid effort. In a line that will probably not be well received in Europe, Mr. Baker, in his speech at Rhein-Main, thanked "the other members of the international community who have decided to join the United States in this effort."
But on another level, in this election year, President Bush and Secretary Baker do not want to be in the position of asking the American people for any significant amount of new revenue to help the former Soviet Union. This airlift of leftover gulf war supplies seems intended to answer that problem.
The Administration does appear to be taking the first tentative steps toward considering establishment of a long-term currency-stabilization fund, something the Russians have been seeking for some time.
This is a pool of cash that would stabilize the ruble by assuring both Russians and foreigners that the currency could be exchanged at a fixed rate, because it would be backed by a multibillion-dollar fund. Mr. Yeltsin has requested a support fund for the ruble of $5 to $6 billion, and a parallel fund for critical imports.
After months of declaring that it was premature even to discuss the conditions under which the United States might take part in a ruble fund, Mr. Baker has very cautiously started to lay the groundwork, in public, for an American contribution.
In the most tentative words possible, he told reporters today that "it may well be that there might be some participation by nations either as a group or bilaterally in support" of a Russian stabilization program that was approved by the International Monetary Fund. This would first require full Russian membership in the I.M.F., which is expected late in April, and a "credible economic reform program."
He acknowledged that countries might have to contribute to a Russian fund "over and above" their regular payments to the International Monetary Fund. Such an American special payment might come to at least $2 billion.
Mr. Baker insisted that the Administration had taken no concrete steps to establish a fund, but that it was now being discussed more seriously.
Reporters traveling with the Secretary of State were told that if the stabilization program is effective, as has been the case in Poland, the money in the fund is "never used," because the fund's existence provides the assurances required to successfully stabilize the currency.
The underlying message was that it would not cost the American taxpayer anything. Reporters were also told the United States would not support a parallel fund that provided cash to enable the Russians to import consumer goods. That would be difficult to explain in an election year.
 
Bottom Lines
 In total, the United States has pledged about $5.75 billion in aid to the former Soviet states, including about $3.75 billion in credits for food, of which $3.1 billion have already been used. Operation Provide Hope includes $44 million for food, $34 million in medical-related aid, and transportation costs just under $10 million.
Since 1990, the European Community has offered roughly $80 billion in assistance, mostly from Germany. The Japanese have pledged $3 billion and Saudi Arabia, $1.5 billion; many other nations are contributing, too.
Mr. Baker leaves Frankfurt tonight, and his itinerary will take him to seven former Soviet republics: Moldova, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan and Russia.

First Shipment Arrives
MOSCOW, Feb. 10 (AP) -- American soldiers handed over surplus food and medicine to Russian troops today as the first wave of planes arrived at Sheremetyevo Airport, near Moscow.
"It's a little shameful that my country has come to this," said Pvt. Andrei Chernyi, a 19-year-old recruit. "But what can you do? That's life."
 To prevent the aid from ending up on the black market, Salvation Army workers rode the food trucks from the airport to a military warehouse, which will be guarded 24 hours a day.

HEADLINE: Thornburgh Is Seen as Likely to Take a U.N. Job

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 10

 BODY:
President Bush wants former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to take a new top post at United Nations overseeing the organization's budget and administration, United Nations and American officials say.
The United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Ghali, asked Mr. Bush to find an American to fill this job when he attended the summit meeting of the Security Council here last month and the President then offered the job to Mr. Thornburgh, the officials said. 
 Although Mr. Thornburgh could not be reached for comment today, aides close to him said that he was likely to accept the position but that he wanted first to meet Mr. Ghali to discuss plans for the United Nations and establish a good working relationship.
 
One of 8 New Positions
 The new post, Under Secretary General for Administration and Management, involves overall responsibility for budget and personnel matters and is one of eight deputy positions created by Mr. Ghali in the restructuring of the Secretariat announced on Friday.
The Bush Administration has strongly supported the reorganization, which consolidated a number of smaller departments into eight major divisions, each headed by an Under Secretary General reporting directly to the Secretary General.
The United States had also made clear that it wanted an American to take the top financial and management post since Washington is the single largest contributor to the United Nations, paying 25 percent of its $1.2 billion annual budget, and is now committed to holding spending steady in real terms after allowance for inflation.
If Mr. Thornburgh accepts the job, he will become one of only two outsiders in the second rung of the United Nations hierarchy. The other is Vladimir F. Petrovsky, a former First Deputy Foreign Minister of the defunct Soviet Union, who will become one of two new Under Secretaries General for Political Affairs responsible for mediating in conflicts around the world.
 
In Private Law Practice
 After a somewhat fractious three-year stewardship of the Justice Department, Mr. Thornburgh, who is 60 years old, resigned as Attorney General in August to contest the Senate seat vacated by the death of Senator John Heinz 3d.
Although initially favored to recapture the seat for the Republicans, Mr. Thornburgh was unexpectedly defeated by Harris Wofford, a former Labor Secretary for the state of Pennsylvania, where Mr. Thornburgh served twice as Governor. Since then Mr. Thornburgh has resumed private law practice in Pittsburgh and Washington. But in December Mr. Thornburgh was reported meeting with Mr. Bush and the White House chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner, to discuss his hopes of returning to public life.

HEADLINE: Fiery Nationalism Drove Venezuelan Plotters

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 10

 BODY:
A violently nationalist ideology inspired army officers who mounted an unsuccessful coup last week and came close to killing the President of Venezuela, the second-largest net supplier of oil to the United States after Saudi Arabia.
According to documents made available here, the officers drew on writings by 19th-century Venezuelan military leaders to advocate redeeming the "lost" 20th century by wiping away "the so-called democratic experiment." 
 A "national salvation government" also would have jettisoned orthodox free-market economic policies that currently prevail in Venezuela, which is endowed with the largest oil reserves in South America.
The price of these "deep changes" would be fire and blood, the plotters warned. A 12-page manifesto opened with a quote attributed to Thomas Jefferson that "the tree of liberty should be irrigated from time to time with the blood of patriots and tyrants."
Pamphlets by the officers' group, "Los Bolivarianos," -- named after Simon Bolivar, the liberator of Venezuela from Spanish rule -- proposed hanging civilian politicians in public squares or executing them by firing squads in sports stadiums, according to a recently retired Commander in Chief of the Army, Carlos Julio Penaloza Zambrano.
"The level of hate especially caught my attention," General Penaloza said last week in a television interview before censorship ended public discussion here of the movement. "They were convinced that the only way to wash the honor of the humiliated fatherland was through a ritual bath using the blood of corrupt men who had put our nation on its knees. Chavez Frias was our Saddam Hussein."
Army Lieut. Col. Hugo Chavez Frias, the coup's mastermind, told army interrogators last week that his movement's intention was to select "an honor tribunal" that would try President Carlos Andres Perez and have him executed by a firing squad.
The 69-year-old President, who reportedly asked for a machine gun to defend himself during last Tuesday's predawn palace attack, has maintained that the plotters intended to kill him in the palace. His wife, Blanca Rodriguez de Perez, says the attackers wanted to wipe out the family.
She said the rebels continued to fire machine guns and mortars at the presidential residence for hours after the President had appeared live on national television from a studio across town.
Twelve army battalions in four major cities -- roughly 10 percent of the army -- participated in the revolt.
Interrogations of the 176 army officers detained have revealed an ultranationalist streak as the primary cause for the uprising. Leading the list were border issues: statements by President Perez that Colombia has "small rights" over the Gulf of Venezuela, the invasion of Venezuela's Amazon by Brazilian gold miners and the donation by Mr. Perez of police equipment to Guyana, a neighboring country with a large territorial dispute with Venezuela.
The mutinous officers, most in their 20's and 30's, also complained of unpunished cases of corruption involving military and political leaders, of privatization of state companies and of the withdrawal of subsidies for food and medicines.
In addition to denouncing economic "shock policies" implemented by "savage hands," the young officers' manifesto proposed that Venezuela adopt an obscure new ideology -- the "EBR System."
Apparently drawn up by Colonel Chavez and by colleagues who served with him as history instructors at Venezuela's military academy, the system's initials stand for three prominent 19th-century Venezuelans -- Ezequiel Zamora, a populist general; Bolivar, a general who liberated most of the Andes from Spanish colonial rule, and Simon Rodriguez, a teacher of Bolivar in late 18th-century Caracas.
The manifesto called for the creation of a vaguely defined "different political model" that would break with imported models and that would provide for "individual and collective human necessities."

NEW YORK CITY
 
DINKINS PUSHES MINORITY CONTRACTS
Asserting that the time had come to correct decades of rampant discrimination in the city's procurement process, Mayor Dinkins announced a sweeping policy initiative to award more than 20 percent of the city's contracts to businesses owned by minorities and women. A1.
 
ARREST IN CROWN HEIGHTS KILLING
A 23-year-old unemployed handyman who the police said might have offered to do odd jobs so he could case houses he wanted to burglarize was charged yesterday in the stabbing death of a Hasidic woman in Crown Heights. The killing had pushed the troubled Brooklyn neighborhood to the brink of another racial confrontation. A1.
 
LIFE AND ART
The National Gallery of Art has liberated Herbert and Dorothy Vogel's one-bedroom Manhattan apartment from their collection of 2,500 sculptures, drawings and paintings. But the retired postal clerk and the retired librarian are still doing what they have done for 30 years -- devoting their lives to contemporary art. A1.
 
50 HOMELESS AFTER GAS BLAST
A natural gas explosion rocked and heavily damaged a problem-plagued Harlem apartment building, touching off a raging fire that drove hundreds of tenants into the cold, injured 23 people, one critically, and left more than 50 people homeless. B3.
 
A SEA OF ILLEGAL GUNS
The only thing unusual about the gun that the police say killed Ruth Mitchell in Coney Island on Saturday is that it was a rifle in a sea of illegal handguns. The rest of its story is told with increasing frequency these days as drugs and guns continue to ravage poor and working-class neighborhoods. B3.

TWO VIEWS OF TEANECK CASE
The jury in the manslaughter trial of a white Teaneck police officer accused of killing a black teen-ager heard sharply contradictory closing arguments about the events surrounding the shooting and the officer's motives for firing. The defense lawyer contended that the officer, Gary Spath, was threatened by the 16-year-old youth, Phillip Pannell, who had reached into a pocket containing a handgun. But the prosecutor argued that Mr. Pannell was attempting to surrender when he was shot and that Officer Spath and his partner had concocted a story to justify the shooting. B6.
 
MONEY AND MELODRAMA
This time, the volunteer firefighters and laid-off probation officers starred in the Nassau County budget melodrama. The firefighters, 1,000 strong, paraded past the County Executive Building in more than 100 polished red and lemon fire trucks, blaring horns and sirens, to protest county cuts in training programs, inspectors, and investigators. Inside, the probation officers sat in glum silence, as an officer due to be laid off after eight years on the job tried to turn in his gold shield in protest. B6.

HEADLINE: Fort Lauderdale Rides New Wave

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.

 BODY:
Next month, hundreds of thousands of college students will besiege sandy shores and snowy slopes around the country to celebrate the rites of spring. But just a handful will head for this beach resort, which for 35 years was the spring-break capital of the world.
That is just fine with local officials and most business owners, who say they could not be happier, even though it means the loss of $140 million generated by spring break. 
 "You can get so addicted to that kind of money that you never ask at what cost," said Nicki E. Grossman, a commissioner of Broward County, which includes Fort Lauderdale.
 
Community's Frayed Nerves
 But the city was finally forced to ask that question when a record 350,000 young people streamed in in 1985. They disrupted traffic and overburdened the legal system, with mostly petty crimes, to such a degree that newspapers and television stations around the country took unfavorable notice. Needless to say, the situation also frayed this community's collective nerves.
"Fort Lauderdale had gridlock, beachlock and kidlock," said Richard D. Weaver, president of the Greater Fort Lauderdale Convention and Visitors Bureau.
When the six-week blitz ended in April, the police chief gave his officers T-shirts declaring, "We Survived Spring Break." Only one-third of the crowd was college students, he said, the rest being "everything from high school students to bikers."
"That's when we decided we couldn't afford it anymore," said Ms. Grossman, who is also chairman of the Broward County Tourism Development Council. "We pulled back the welcome mat on spring break, and since then we have gone after families and European visitors."
That decision proved costly to many hotels and shops that catered to the college crowd, but the gamble appears to be paying off.
Each week, 195 flights from Stockholm, Copenhagen, Amsterdam and Frankfurt land at the Fort Lauderdale/Hollywood International Airport, loaded with tourists who find it cheaper to vacation here than in Europe. Foreigners now account for nearly 20 percent of Greater Fort Lauderdale's visitors, up from about 10 percent in 1985. Moreover, many of the visitors from overseas, as opposed to those who come from Canada and Mexico, vacation here in the summer, when most Americans seek a more temperate clime.
Last year, some 4.9 million visitors to the area spent $3.2 billion, compared with 3.3 million visitors in 1985 who spent $2.2 billion. That $1 billion difference narrows when the 1985 amount is adjusted to equal 1991 dollars, but even so, Fort Lauderdale is clearly ahead of where it was then. During that same period, spring-break visitors dwindled to 15,000, from 350,000.
 
New Convention Center
 Visitor and tourist revenues could rise significantly if the city's new $50 million convention center comes anywhere near to meeting expectations. The three-story, glass-fronted building is within Port Everglades, through which 2.2 million cruise ship passengers passed last year.
The convention and meeting business earned Fort Lauderdale about $212 million in 1990. But feasibility and economic impact studies conducted for Broward County in 1988 projected that the center, with 150,000 square feet of exhibition space, will eventually bring in an additional $104.3 million in annual revenues.
"When we opened last September, we had about 350 conventions booked through the year 2000," Mr. Weaver said. "Through September 1992 we will have had 12 citywide conventions and 43 short-term events. Down the road, we're looking to have about 30 citywide conventions a year."
The city is working to convince even more conventioneers and tourists that Fort Lauderdale is no longer synonymous with spring break. The city recently opened sales offices in Washington, London, Toronto and Stockholm, and it plans one in Frankfurt. In the last year, Fort Lauderdale has paid the way for 2,500 British travel agents and tour operators to come see for themselves that Fort Lauderdale no longer resembles the setting of the Glendon Swarthout novel "Where the Boys Are."
The book was made into a 1960 motion picture with Connie Francis, George Hamilton and Yvette Mimieux, giving Fort Lauderdale even wider exposure.
Mr. Swarthout and his wife, Kate, visited Fort Lauderdale last December, for a 50th wedding anniversary cruise to San Francisco via the Panama Canal. "I hadn't been there since the mid-1960's," said Mr. Swarthout, who lives in Arizona. "It seemed a lot more sedate. The bubbles have gone out of it."
That judgment seems unlikely to disturb the city's leaders, who made a strong effort to distance Fort Lauderdale from spring break. They ended their ads in college newspapers inviting students. They erected a five-foot high wall along Highway A1A, the coastal thoroughfare, partly to control traffic but also, some say, to serve as both a physical and psychological barrier. And they directed the police to enforce an ordinance that prohibited beer drinking on streets and beaches.
In 1986, 750 visitors during student break were charged with offenses largely related to drinking, and the next year about 2,000 were arrested. That tough new attitude gave rise to the slogan, "Come on vacation, leave on probation."
In 1991 and 1992, the city is spending $20 million to revitalize the beachfront's roads and sidewalks.
Not everyone is overjoyed at the change. "I did 50 percent of my annual gross income in that six-week period," said Roger Handevidt, the owner of the Orton Terrace, a 15-unit hotel three blocks from the beach. "Today you probably have more foreclosures than at anytime in the 12 years I've been here."
While Mr. Handevidt found the students who stayed at his hotel "rowdy, but not necessarily destructive," he acknowledged that some hotels suffered from student vandalism. He also said the number of women students began declining sharply in the mid-1980's as the number of drunken male teen-agers increased.
 
Rolling With the Changes
 At the Elbo Room, a popular beachfront bar that was featured in the movie "Where the Boys Are," business has also slipped since the old days. "There's been a gradual dwindling since 1985," said John Foose, its manager. "But we've kind of rolled with the changes -- from a wild and crazy bar to one that's kind of tame, with a lot of European customers."
The students who still come here for spring break, city officials say, tend to be couples eager to avoid their less-inhibited peers.
At the Surf Shop, a T-shirt shop facing the beach, Benjamin McNiff, an employee, said the transformation had been relatively painless. In the past, he said, "the students would rather spend 7 to 10 bucks on beer than on T-shirts." He continued: "Or else 12 would come in and 10 would rip you off. Now, families spend $50 to $100."
Peter and Dagmar Neufeldt, who own the Banyan Marina Apartments, about a mile from the beach, also like the city's about-face.
"We wouldn't have allowed kids here," Mr. Neufeldt said. "They'd have ruined it." While there is a widespread perception that students spent money only on beer and hamburgers, a survey by the Broward County Tourist Development Council found that in 1985, the average visitor stayed an average of 7.4 days and spent an average of $54.05 a day. Today, the average visitor stays 9.2 days and spends $71.41 a day.
 
Gain for Daytona Beach
 Many students now spend spring break in places like the Gulf Coast of Texas; the Caribbean; Cancun, Mexico, and Baja California, as well as skiing meccas like Aspen and Vail, Colo. But the new capital of spring break is Daytona Beach, Fla., more than 200 miles north of Fort Lauderdale.
"When Fort Lauderdale lowered the boom on spring break, we realized what a tremendous asset it could be to have the future leaders of America at our door," said Suzanne Smith, a vice president with the Daytona Beach Chamber of Commerce.
Last year, some 400,000 students went to Daytona Beach for spring break.

HEADLINE: United Air Cuts Back Spending

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
In the face of persistent recession, United Airlines took a big step back from an ambitious expansion strategy yesterday, announcing that it was cutting its capital spending by $6.7 billion over the next three years and postponing the delivery of new aircraft.
The airline, one of the nation's strongest, had sought to keep its expansion drive going in spite of hard times, but continuing poor traffic and heavy fare discounting forced it to pull back. 
 Both business and leisure travel have been low, showing only a small recovery from the disastrous levels of last year, when fear of terrorists during the Persian Gulf war caused many companies to eliminate international travel altogether and other travelers to stay close to home.
 
 
Delaying Boeing Orders
 The airline said it was putting off the delivery of 44 Boeing 737's and 60 Boeing 757's. The news pushed the stock of the Boeing Company down $1.375, to $48, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The UAL Corporation, United's parent company, slipped 87.5 cents, to $144.25.
The move by United could force Boeing to make further cutbacks in its production schedules. The Seattle-based airplane maker's huge backlog of orders has enabled it to ride out the recession largely unscathed so far, but it recently announced that it was cutting back on its 737 plane production to 14 a month, from 21.
Both Stephen M. Wolf, UAL's chairman, and Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of American Airlines, had been strong believers in firm expansion plans during downturns on the theory that they put a company in a good position to gain market share in a recovery.
 
Some Didn't Make It
 But the last year has been a brutal one for the industry. American has already announced a big capital spending cutback. Two carriers, Pan Am and Midway, have been forced to liquidate while two others, T.W.A. and America West, have filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors.
T.W.A.'s creditors agreed to reduce the carrier's debt and the airline has a strong cash position, giving it a good chance to emerge from bankruptcy.
"Finally, airlines have gotten religion about living within their means," said Rose Ann Tortora, an airline analyst for County NatWest. "They are going to pay a little more of their own way." During the 1980's, the airline industry borrowed billions to pay for huge new airplane orders.
Tassos Phillippakos, an aerospace analyst for Moody's Investors Service, said that United's move would force Boeing to make further production cutbacks and could lead to layoffs.
He added, however, that the level of new orders was still high and that compared with the 1980's the delivery rate was still higher, even with the stretch-out of new deliveries.
T. Craig Martin, a spokesman for the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, said that no United order or options "have been canceled." He said that both United and Boeing had agreed to have orders and options put off to later years.
 
Held on for a While
 Mr. Wolf, chairman of UAL, had sought to keep United on its aggressive expansion for a time even after American pulled back last year by cutting capital expansion by $8 billion and stretching out the delivery of many of its new aircraft.
He held firm for a while. At the end of January, however, United reported a loss of $252.6 million for the fourth quarter, compared with a loss of $123.5 million in the fourth quarter last year.
The cut yesterday, which will bring a drop in capital spending by about 35 percent, to $12.2 billion, brought United's pullback close to the size of American's.
United said it would take delivery of 156 airplanes during 1993 to 1995, 122 less than originally planned. It added that it would take delivery of the 66 aircraft it was committed to in 1992.
It will also continue to take delivery of wide-bodied aircraft, since it has acquired major new routes to Europe and Latin America.
Ms. Tortora said that the strategy in putting off delivery of planes would allow the airline to lease new planes for low payments. Leasing companies are taking delivery of about 250 new airplanes a year, she said, and only about 30 percent of these have been leased.

HEADLINE: Secession Fever Strikes Queens

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
They just want an even break, they say in Queens -- cleaner streets, a little respect, the old fire brigade back, that idyllic time when "the city" with all its pleasures and problems meant Manhattan, across the river, and Queens was a semisuburban refuge a short subway ride away.
So when three Queens lawmakers introduced legislation in Albany last week proposing that Queens follow the path of Staten Island and consider secession from New York City, they touched a chord among residents suspicious that their borough gets second-class treatment. 
 "We're not getting much here from the city so we might as well be our own city," said Phil Melito of Richmond Hill, who grumps that he and his wife, Joan, have lived in Queens "40 years, so we've seen a lot of changes -- for the worse."
With a sovereign Queens, he says, "We could have a cleaner city. It looks pretty bad the way it is now."
Never mind that the secession bill has virtually no chance of passage.
Never mind that Queens actually has more political power these days than any time in recent memory -- in the persons of the new Assembly Speaker, Saul Weprin, and the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is a son of Queens, too.
And never mind that no one -- neither the bill's sponsors nor city planners -- can say if Queens is really getting its fair share of city services, or even if it has the wherewithal to go it alone.
In proposing secession, the three lawmakers -- Assemblyman Anthony S. Seminerio, a Democrat, and Republican Senators Serphin R. Maltese and Frank Padavan -- are drawing on a sense of being put upon that has become a virtual mode of politics and language of resentment in the boroughs outside Manhattan.
Queens, a borough of nearly two million people, has been nursing a special grudge against City Hall and Manhattan politicians at least since the blizzard of 1969, when Mayor John V. Lindsay left the suburban-style neighborhoods of northeastern Queens sitting for days under a blanket of snow.
Now, the recession, the city's budget crisis and a fear of new assaults on the quality of life have only deepened a feeling of powerlessness among the hard-pressed, middle- and working-class communities that are already struggling to maintain their neighborhood identities during a period of new immigration and racial transition.
The secession drive comes at a time when a proposal to eliminate a fire battalion in Brooklyn, or to transfer a favorite assistant principal from Queens to Manhattan, can feel like the death blow to a neighborhood, a time when the Mayor's proposal to scatter 24 homeless shelters around the city -- including up to 11 in Queens -- can fuel rebellion.
 
Empathy in Brooklyn
 "I think it's come up again because of the mayor's homeless plan," Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens said. "It kind of exacerbated again the talk of secession."
Feeling pushed to the wall, some Queens activists think their borough might just be better off on its own.
"We can't say to the South Bronx we want to take half your medical services and half your poverty programs," said Arlene R. Pedone, president of the Richmond Hill Block Association. "They need it. But because the pie was cut, it's the have-nots fighting the have-nots. If you have your own city -- if you start from the beginning to build your services and see what your population needs -- there is less fighting for the small piece of the pie."
Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn says: "I'm not one of those who says Manhattan shouldn't be part of the union. But to call us 'outer boroughs' is a disgrace."
Assemblyman Seminerio speaks the same language. "They treat us just like we're an outer borough. We're nonexistent," he said several days after introducing the secession measure, which would allow Queens residents to vote on whether to create a charter commission to draw up plans for a separate city.
"My people in Queens, and I believe all the people in Queens, are intelligent enough to vote on whether they want it or not," he said. So, for that matter, could Brooklyn, as far as he's concerned. Or even Manhattan. "So we'll have five cities. What's the big deal?" he asked.
Other Queens leaders are more cautious about whether the borough has the tax base to offer the current level of services without raising taxes.
"Could we go it alone? I don't know the answer," said Borough President Shulman, who said she was ambivalent about the bill. "We'd have to investigate very carefully. The last thing in the world you'd want to do is raise taxes to where it becomes a burden to the individual citizen."
According to figures compiled by the city Department of Finance, Queens in the 1991-92 fiscal year accounted for 16 percent of the city's property taxes.
But she added, "As a government person who has to deliver services on a local level, it's an attractive concept."
Speaker Weprin, who is from Hollis, is leaning against the bill. His spokesman, Steven A. Greenberg, said the Assemblyman is concerned about the borough's ability to go it alone. "He's not sure of any benefits to the borough of Queens from these actions."
The Queens secession bill has been introduced at a time when the political clout of the borough has never been stronger.
 
The Unisphere as Mecca
 "What's precipitated it is not a lack of power but a lack of finances," said City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, Democrat of Astoria, who said he opposed the move. "It would be terrible. You might as well forget the city of New York."
Governor Cuomo, a native son of Holliswood, has predicted that the measure will never get to his desk.
But for a few moments this week, the idea of secession, of becoming a city that would dwarf a place like Detroit, caught people's whimsy.
"Maybe it would bring more business to Queens if we were separate," said Diane F. Engberg, a 43-year-old Richmond Hills housewife, bundled in coat and scarf as she dashed across Jamaica Avenue. "We have Flushing Meadows and the Unisphere," she said, warming to the idea that Queens could even be a tourists' mecca.
Alma Young of Laurelton saw secession as a way to stop immigration from Manhattan. If Queens were to separate, she said, "I hope it would stay the way it is: semi-city, semi-country."
If Queens were no longer part of the Big Apple, then what would it be? "The little apple?" ventured the Queens Borough President.
Ann Ferrara, a guest service agent at the Sheraton La Guardia East, and perhaps not entirely objective since she has moved from Queens to Brooklyn, called the whole idea absurd.
"Why bother?" she said. "There are too many other things to be concerned with. There's just no need for it at all. It's like saying we're going to paint all the buildings blue."

HEADLINE: Con Ed Nears Rate Increase In 3-Year Plan

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
After nine years of electricity price freezes and even a cut, Consolidated Edison and the staff of the New York Public Service Commission have reached an agreement that would, if approved by the commission, give the utility a 19.8 percent rate increase over the next three years.
But the Consumer Protection Board, which by law represents consumer interests before the Public Service Commission, argues that three-year deals are inherently unfair to customers, and that for several reasons, the increase should be smaller. 
 After an administrative law judge holds public hearings on the agreement, he will submit a recommendation to the seven-member commission.
Under the agreement, according to Con Ed, the first-year increase would raise the monthly bill of a typical residential customer to $41.02 from $38.82. A Con Ed spokesman pointed out that the figure would still be lower than in 1983, when, with fuel adjustment clauses, it was $42.28. At the end of the three-year period, the price would be $48.10. Residential customers consume about one-third of the power; most of the rest of the use is commercial.
 
Previous Backing From Board
 The Consumer Protection Board had enthusiastically backed the three multiyear agreements that have governed rates since 1983, but Richard M. Kessel, executive director of the board, said yesterday that "when they were freezing rates, there was nothing to object to."
Mr. Kessel also said yesterday that rates may be rising so steeply because Con Edison has spent so much money trying to save energy, and that its conservation and efficiency program should be re-evaluated to insure that it is cost-effective. For years, consumer advocates have been urging the company to do more.
Dan Walden, a spokesman for Con Edison, said the company needed an increase "because the underlying economics of the industry have changed." Con Ed began the 1980's with a huge amount of surplus-generating capacity because in the 70's it overestimated the growth of demand, and built too many generating stations.
As growing demand erodes the surplus, he said, the utility could spread its rising costs across more and more kilowatt hours sold. But now, he said, the company cannot continue to sell more kilowatt hours without buying them from somewhere. To keep customers supplied, it is buying more power from independent producers. These costs are the biggest part of the increase request, Mr. Walden said.
In an agreement dated Jan. 24, the company and the commission's staff called for an increase of $225 million to take effect on April 1, followed by $400 million the next April 1 and $300 million the April 1 after that. The increases would be 4.8 percent, 8 percent at 5.5 percent, for a compound total of 19.8 percent.
New York, like other states, has moved toward setting rates every three years instead of annually. The Public Service Commission recently granted a three-year package to the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, and is considering a three-year package for the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation.
 
Settlement Clauses
 At the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, a Washington-based organization made up of public service commission members from around the country, Michael Foley, an electric utility expert, said multiyear agreements were generally viewed as "a good bargain for all concerned" because regulators could scrutinize each request more closely, customers could predict their rates, and utilities could predict their revenue.
The traditional system in New York is for a company to submit a rate request every year, and lawyers for the company and the state then spend 11 months in hearings and negotiations.
Peter A. Bradford, the chairman of the commission, said that he could not talk about the Con Ed case, but that the commission would not be able to handle all cases well if each of the seven major electric companies, the gas companies and the telephone companies asked for a rate increase every year. He added that the multiyear agreements had clauses to reopen the cases "if anything has gotten significantly out of line with the assumptions made at the time of the settlement."
But Mr. Kessel is arguing that in a recession, it makes no sense to announce a billion-dollar electricity price increase because it "sends the wrong signal" to businesses and consumers. "If the Mayor proposed a billion-dollar tax increase, people would freak," he said in an interview.
But reaching such an agreement during a recession involves a bet that could go sour for either side, he acknowledged, with the utility agreeing on a rate of return on equity that could seem paltry by the standards that might apply during an economic boom, if such a boom is realized during the term of the agreement.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Has Gain in Quarter But Profit Drop for the Year

 BODY:
The New York Times Company reported a sharp rise in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday but said that for all of 1991 its profits were down, as the recession continued to cut into advertising revenue.
The results included various one-time adjustments, including costs linked to a staff reduction and interest expenses on a new printing plant, without which earnings would have risen for the year. 
 Analysts said the numbers masked some improving trends. "The earnings were pretty much in line with expectations," said Kevin R. Gruneich, an investment analyst with the First Boston Corporation. "The guts of the numbers actually look quite good. The fact that operating earnings increased while revenues remained the same shows the impact of cost controls."
 
Results for the Quarter
 The company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $34.6 million, or 45 cents a share, on revenues of $452.5 million, more than doubling from the $12.2 million, or 16 cents a share, on revenues of $456 million in the period a year earlier.
For the year, the company said it earned $47 million, or 61 cents a share, on revenues of $1.7 billion, down 27.5 percent from the $64.8 million, or 85 cents a share, on revenues of $1.78 billion in 1990.
"We are particularly pleased to see some improving trends," said Michael A. Kupinski, an analyst with A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. Mr. Kupinski noted an improvement in the performance of the magazine group and said the declines in classified advertising were less than he had first estimated.
The company's results were affected by several one-time adjustments: a 13-cents-a-share gain from a reversal of an accounting provision relating to Federal taxes, a 15-cents-a-share charge to cover severance costs under a voluntary staff reduction, a 20-cents-a-share charge related to magazine acquisitions and a 14-cents-a-share charge for a change relating to interest expenses at The New York Times's Edison, N.J., printing plant.
Without these adjustments, 1991 earnings would have been 97 cents a share and quarterly earnings 41 cents, the company said.
 
Ad Linage Drops
 For the year, advertising linage at The New York Times was 78.6 million lines, a 15.5 percent decline from the year earlier. For the fourth quarter, advertising linage dropped by 8.8 percent, to 22.1 million lines. The company said that help wanted and real estate advertising were hurt the most.
Operating earnings for the year for the newspaper group, which comprises The New York Times, 32 regional newspapers and a half interest in The International Herald Tribune, were $113.6 million, excluding the $20 million pretax charge for severance costs, on revenues of $1.27 billion. This compared with 1990 operating earnings of $140.3 million on revenues of $1.36 billion.
In the fourth quarter, the newspaper group had operating profits of $49.2 million on revenues of $345.7 million, compared with operating profits of $32.1 million on revenues of $350.1 million in the 1990 quarter. The quarter's improvement resulted from higher circulation revenues, lower newsprint costs and lower expenses, the company said.
The company said it was unclear whether there would be additional charges against earnings in 1992 connected with the planned opening of the Edison plant. An agreement in principle has been reached with the union representing The Times's drivers, and arbitration with the mailers' union continues, the company said.
If the contracts are settled by binding arbitration rather than negotiation, the company said, using the remainder of a 1989 reserve of about $25 million "will not be required."
Magazine group operating profit was $1.4 million for the quarter. For the year, the group had an operating loss of $492,000. The fourth-quarter operating profit for the broadcasting/ information services group was $4.8 million, compared with $4.7 million a year earlier.
On the American Stock Exchange, the company's shares rose 25 cents, to $28.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond and Note Prices Are Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were mixed in slow trading yesterday, as dealers continued preparations for three days of quarterly refunding auctions, beginning with the sale today of $15 billion of new three-year Treasury notes.
Traders said there was light selling by dealers of 10-year and 30-year securities to make way for the $21 billion worth of new long-term notes and bonds to be sold later in the week. 
 Expectations remained high that the Federal Reserve Board will soon ease monetary policy again and were reflected at yesterday's auction of new three- and six-month Treasury bills, which were sold at the lowest rates in nearly 20 years.
 
'Concerned About Confidence'
 Nevertheless, in its Open Market operations yesterday, the Fed sent another clear signal to market participants that it had not decided to lower its target on the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market below its current level of 4 percent.
"The Fed made it very clear," one government securities trader said. "Based on our reading of the minutes from the last Open Market Committee meeting, our sense is that they are extremely concerned about confidence and will be watching the consumer confidence number closely when it comes out on Thursday."
The minutes from the committee's December meeting showed that most of the Fed governors favored a move away from the gradualist approach the central bank had been employing in favor of something more drastic. The minutes show that policy makers were hoping the big rate cuts they announced on Dec. 20 would have a positive impact on consumer confidence.
To date, the lift the Fed was hoping for has not arrived.
The chances of another reduction in short-term rates were seen as greater after the Labor Department issued a grim report on Friday on employment conditions in January.
The report showed declines in overall payroll employment, the length of the average workweek and the amount of average hourly earnings. Analysts said it was only the third time since 1947 that all three measures fell in a single month.
"These numbers are not going to do much to help consumer confidence," said Paul W. Boltz, chief financial economist at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore.
Mr. Boltz said the report caused him to lower his estimates for overall economic growth in the first half of the year to an anemic seven-tenths of 1 percent from 1.5 percent. The odds that output will actually decline in the first quarter are "about 50-50," he said.
 
Short-Term Rates Drop
 At yesterday's bill auctions, the three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 3.72 percent, down from an average rate of 3.86 percent at last week's sale. It was the lowest rate since the auction on May 15, 1972, when the rate was 3.699 percent.
Bids on the six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 3.80 percent, compared with 3.93 percent at the auction a week ago. The rate was the lowest on a six-month bill since they averaged 3.796 percent at the auction on March 6, 1972.
Analysts and traders said demand for the bills was good, but they added that the auction was no preview for how the refunding issues would be received. An easing of monetary policy by the Fed would have limited impact on securities with maturities of more than two years, they said.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the three-year notes to be sold today were offered at a price to yield 5.43 percent. The 10-year notes to be sold tomorrow were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.20 percent. And the 30-year bonds that will be auctioned on Thursday were trading at a price to yield 7.79 percent.
"The overall bullish fundamental outlook, underscored by the weak employment report, makes the bond look cheap at yields higher than 7.75 percent," analysts at MMS International, an economic information and service company, said in their daily market commentary.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 102 1/2 late yesterday, down 10/32 , to yield 7.78 percent, compared with 7.75 percent late on Friday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes were offered at 9729/32 , up 2/32 , to yield 6.75 percent. And the 4 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 9930/32 , unchanged on the day, to yield 4.90 percent.
 
Corporate Issues
 New issuers in the investment-grade corporate bond market included KFW International Finance Inc., which offered $200 million worth of securities through an underwriting group led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
The 7 5/8 percent notes, which mature on Feb. 10, 2004, were priced at $99.34 to yield 7.71 percent, 50 basis points, or half a percentage point, above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The issue was rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Shearson Lehman Holdings offered $200 million of seven-year securities through an underwriting group led by Lehman Brothers.
The 8 3/8 percent notes mature on Feb. 15, 1999 and were priced at $99.091 to yield 8.55 percent, 1.75 percentage points more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The issue was rated A-3 by Moody's and A by S.& P.
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was slow, traders said, and prices of most issues were unchanged.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds told much the same story. In advance of a large volume of new issues expected to be priced this week, traders said, investors were reluctant to establish new positions.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Problems for Yen and Mark Help the Dollar to Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday, strengthened by political uncertainty in Japan, economic problems in Germany and the failure of the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates in the United States.
Gold prices fell marginally in Asia and Europe before rebounding slightly in the United States. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, bullion for current delivery fetched $355.90, up 90 cents. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted gold at $355.40 as of 4 P.M. Eastern time, up 90 cents from Friday. 
 Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar drew some early vitality from Japan, where the governing Liberal Democratic Party lost a local election over the weekend that raised more clouds over Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa's administration. As a result, there were few buyers for yen-denominated investments.
Later in European trading, currency dealers said the dollar drew further strength from a growing belief that Germany's economic problems were intensifying and would require lower interest rates there for a revival, which would depress the value of the mark.
"People are focusing on the German reality," said Andrew Hodge, vice president of corporate treasury services at the New York branch of Bank Brussels Lambert.
The dollar gained further when the Federal Reserve, the United States' central bank, did not reduce short-term interest rates despite widespread predictions of such a move to stimulate the anemic American economy. Fed action was expected in view of unexpectedly weak employment data for January, reported Friday. Lower rates would make dollar-denominated investments worth less.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.17 yen, to 125.35 yen, although that was higher than its New York finish on Friday of 125.30 yen. Later, in London the dollar was quoted at 125.65 yen. In New York the dollar ended higher, at 126.70 yen.
In London the British pound fell to $1.8280, from $1.8370 late Friday. In New York, the pound fetched $1.8190, cheaper than its $1.8370 value late on Friday.
Other late-dollar rates in New York, compared with levels late on Friday, included: 1.5770 marks, up from 1.5595; 1.4085 Swiss francs, up from 1.3910; 1.1776 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1781; 5.3775 French francs, up from 5.3150, and 1,187.50 Italian lire, up from 1,174.25.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Some Decide To Pass Up Olympics

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
THE Winter Olympics are in full swing, but many of America's largest advertisers and their agencies are sitting this one out.
While some mega-marketers are spending tens of millions of dollars to link themselves in consumers' minds to the 1992 Games in Albertville, France, companies like General Motors, Mastercard and Coors, which in the past were eager sponsors, are shunning the quadrennial spectacle. 
 "Let's take the Super Bowl and the N.B.A. All-Star Game and compare them for the next two weeks to the Olympics," Marty Blackman, the president of Blackman & Raber, a New York sports and entertainment marketing and consulting company, said yesterday.
"What competition there will equal the attention these two other events have grabbed in the United States?" he asked. "Nothing."
The primary sign that the Olympics have lost some luster was the agonizingly slow sales pace for commercial time compared with previous Olympics; CBS did not sell out its 116 hours of coverage until Friday.
But the main reason is that viewers have so many other options now. That is in stark contrast to the 1960's and 1970's, when the alternatives to watching the Olympics were reruns on two other networks and a grainy print of "Mighty Joe Young" on an independent station.
Now, viewers have a plethora of alternatives as they flip from channel to channel: cable networks like CNN, ESPN and TBS; beefed-up independent stations, and broadcast networks that rather than taking a dive offer substantial fare against the Olympics in what the television industry calls counter-programming.
For most clients, said Fred Wray, the senior vice president and media director at Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago, "it's smarter to concentrate our efforts on other prime-time programming."
And viewers can play network programmers at home, using their VCR's and laser disk players in lieu of watching the Olympics.
All that is not to say the Olympics have lost their status as a powerful transmitter of sponsored messages. Overnight ratings in 25 leading markets on Sunday from 8 to 11 P.M., Eastern time, showed that CBS's coverage of figure skating, downhill skiing and other events drew a strong 25.0 rating and a 34 share. Each rating point represents 431,151 households, and the share is the percentage of homes with televisions in use.
That was welcome news to CBS, which spent $243 million for rights to telecast the Games and had promised advertisers an average 17 rating though Feb. 23.
The CBS showing compared with a 19.4 rating- 27 share for NBC, 12.0 rating-17 share for ABC and 9.5 rating-13 share for Fox.
CBS also released special early national ratings, which showed a 23.4 rating and a 33 share on Sunday, 19 percent above the first Sunday rating registered when ABC broadcast the 1988 Winter Olympics from Calgary, Alberta. But comparable figures for the other networks were not available. For those data, each rating point represented 921,000 homes.
And a lengthy list of more than 60 advertisers have signed to sponsor the Games, from Anheuser-Busch, Coca-Cola and Ford Motor to McDonald's, Merrill Lynch and Toyota.
Coca-Cola has agreed to become the first global sponsor of the 1994 Winter Olympics in Norway and the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta.
Even so, there are other reasons for the Olympic torch not to burn as brightly as in previous years. The most significant dampener has been the recession.
"A matter of resources" was the reason that General Motors decided to bypass the Winter Olympics, a spokesman in Detroit said, although its domestic competitors, Ford and Chrysler, are participating. Instead, he added, the auto maker will take part in the Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain.
Two other marketing giants, Burger Kingand Pepsi-Cola, are saving money by forgoing the elaborate national Olympics ad schedules of their rivals, McDonald's and Coca-Cola. Rather, both are buying commercial time on local stations' telecasts of the Games. And Mr. Wray of Foote, Cone cited what he called "the severe premium you pay" to be associated with the Olympics.
To George Schweitzer, the senior vice president of CBS marketing and communications, "the value of the Olympics as an event has not diminished." "But," he added, "the economy around it had."
So in selling commercial time, he continued, "what we ran into was an economy that forced choices between the Olympics and other things. This year, it's the Olympics instead of something else, whereas it used to be additive."
Also looming as a killjoy to American Olympics fever is the end of Communism. The collapse of the Soviet Union and its bloc of Eastern satellites has eliminated the Us-Versus-Them appeal of the games to millions of Americans.
Mr. Schweitzer said that CBS was hoping the absence of an "Evil Empire" would mean more medals for American athletes, citing the 1984 Summer Olympics in which Americans romped during a Soviet boycott.
"Research shows that the more chance Americans have to win medals," he added, "the higher the ratings."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Massachusetts Program to Aid Middle-Class Home Buyers

 BODY:
In a home-mortgage program that a state official said would benefit "the forgotten middle class" and serve as a national model, Massachusetts began to offer fixed-rate mortgages last week that low-to-middle-income residents can more easily qualify to receive.
The Middle Class American Dream program, introduced by the Massachusetts official, State Treasurer Joseph D. Malone, is the first of its kind in the nation, although Connecticut and Pennsylvania have narrower programs. 
 In Massachusetts, mortgages are being made available through the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae. A group of 29 approved banks and mortgage companies is offering the mortgages to the public, and a state teachers and employees pension fund is providing $125 million to purchase securities from Fannie Mae that are backed by the mortgages. The state pension fund will earn income from its investment through Fannie Mae.
Mortgage applicants are being processed on a first-come, first-served basis, and Mr. Malone said he expected about 1,000 loans to be granted in the first phase.
 
 
Lower Down Payments
 The program provides relaxed home-mortgage qualification rules to state residents with a gross income of 135 percent, or less, of the median household income in the proposed purchase location; the income ceiling is $68,000. Under the guidelines, the down-payment requirement drops to 5 percent of the purchase price, from as much as 20 percent. State teachers and employees may be eligible to make a down payment of as little as 3 percent.
In addition, the normal requirement that payments on mortgage principal and interest not exceed 28 percent of gross household income is eased to 33 percent. Applicants are not required to provide two months of principal and interest in an escrow account, as is usually mandated. Borrowers will pay 1 1/4 points instead of the traditional 2 points when closing on the mortgage. (Each point equals a fee of 1 percent of the loan amount.)
Closing costs, like legal fees, are reduced. The interest rate is based on current market rates at the time of commitment.
Under the program's guidelines, borrowers must receive home buyer counseling from the bank or mortgage company and the home must be in Massachusetts. Borrowers need not be first-time home buyers and there is no maximum purchase-price limitation.
 Mr. Malone said the Connecticut and Pennsylvania programs were not aimed at the middle class as much as this one. In Massachusetts, first-time home buyers with incomes below $35,700 may be eligible for a tax credit, called a mortgage credit certificate, being offered by the state's Housing Finance Agency.
The response to the program has been overwhelming, Mr. Malone said. An "800" number at Fannie Mae offices given out last Tuesday brought in 17,000 phone calls, knocking out Fannie Mae's phone system and requiring that new lines be added.
"When you couple President Bush's proposal for a $5,000 tax credit with this program, it presents a great opportunity for the prospective home buyer," Mr. Malone said.
He added that the state intended to sell the mortgages in the lucrative secondary market for Fannie Mae loans, replenish the money in the program and offer another opportunity to those who could not obtain loans during the initial round.

SECTION: Section D; Page 8; Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 187 words

HEADLINE: Business Loan Demand Is Off

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Demand for business loans weakened in the last three months, a Government survey said today, though residential mortgage demand grew sharply as interest rates fell to their lowest levels in nearly 20 years.
At the same time, the survey by the Federal Reserve of 60 big domestic and 18 foreign banks showed that virtually none had changed their credit standards for approving business loans since the last poll in October. 
 Many economists and businesses say tougher Government regulations have caused banks to tighten loan standards, leading to a credit shortage that has aggravated the economy's problems.
Not only did business loan applications decline, but demand for consumer installment loans also continued to weaken, though banks were showing more willingness to provide consumer credit, the survey said.
Government and private economists cite the huge buildup of debt in the 1980's as a big contributor to the continuing economic slump.
The banks that noted weaker business loan demand often cited decreases in monetary needs for inventory rebuilding and for investment in new plants and equipment.
